29 Ind. Ant. VI. 9. ↑

30 Ind. Ant. VII. 90. ↑

31 This change of title was probably connected with the increase of Gurjara power, which resulted in the founding of the Gurjara kingdom of Broach about a.d. 580. See Chapter X. below. ↑

32 Ind. Ant. XI. 306. ↑

33 Ind. Ant. VI. 13. ↑

34 K√°vyamidam rachitam may√° Valabhy√°m, Śrí Dharasena-narendra p√°lit√°y√°m. ↑

35 Ind. Ant. VII. 76. ↑

36 Journ. Beng. A. S. IV. and an unpublished grant in the museum of the B. B. R. A. Soc. ↑

37 Ind. Ant. XI. 305. ↑

38 Since his authorities mention the destroyers of Valabhi under the vague term mlechchhas or barbarians and since the era in which they date the overthrow may be either the Vikrama b.c. 57, the Śaka a.d. 78, or the Valabhi a.d. 319, Tod is forced to offer many suggestions. His proposed dates are a.d. 244 Vik. Saṃ. 300 (Western India, 269), a.d. 424 Val. Saṃ. 105 (Ditto, 51 and 214), a.d. 524 Val. Saṃ. 205 (Annals of R√°jasth√°n, I. 83 and 217–220), and a.d. 619 Val. Saṃ. 300 (Western India, 352). Tod identifies the barbarian destroyers of Valabhi either with the descendants of the second century Parthians, or with the White Huns Getes or K√°this, or with a mixture of these who in the beginning of the sixth century supplanted the Parthians (An. of R√°j. I. 83 and 217–220; Western India, 214, 352). Elliot (History, I. 408) accepting Tod’s date a.d. 524 refers the overthrow to Skythian barbarians from Sindh. Elphinstone, also accepting a.d. 524 as an approximate date, suggested (History, 3rd Edition, 212) as the destroyer the Sassanian Naushirv√°n or Chosroes the Great (a.d. 531–579) citing in support of a Sassanian inroad Malcolm’s Persia, I. 141 and Pottinger’s Travels, 386. Forbes (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 22) notes that the Jain accounts give the date of the overthrow Vik. Saṃ. 375 that is a.d. 319 apparently in confusion with the epoch of the Gupta era which the Valabhi kings adopted.39 Forbes says (Ditto, 24): If the destroyers had not been called mlechchhas I might have supposed them to be the Dakhan Ch√°lukyas. Genl. Cunningham (Anc. Geog. 318) holds that the date of the destruction was a.d. 658 and the destroyer the R√°shṭrakúṭa R√°ja Govind who restored the ancient family of Saur√°shṭra. Thomas (Prinsep’s Useful Tables, 158) fixes the destruction of Valabhi at a.d. 745 (S. 802). In the K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer Col. Watson in one passage (page 671) says the destroyers may have been the early Muhammadans who retired as quickly as they came. In another passage (page 274), accepting Mr. Burgess’ (Arch. Sur. Rep. IV. 75) Gupta era of a.d. 195 and an overthrow date of a.d. 642, and citing a Wadhw√°n couplet telling how Ebhal Valabhi withstood the Iranians, Col. Watson suggests the destroyers may have been Iranians. If the P√°rsis came in a.d. 642 they must have come not as raiders but as refugees. If they could they would not have destroyed Valabhi. If the P√°rsis destroyed Valabhi where next did they flee to. ↑

39 Similarly S. 205 the date given by some of Col. Tod’s authorities (An. of R√°j. I. 82 and 217–220) represents a.d. 524 the practical establishment of the Valabhi dynasty. The mistake of ascribing an era to the overthrow not to the founding of a state occurs (compare Sachau’s Alberuni, II. 6) in the case both of the Vikrama era b.c. 57 and of the Ś√°liv√°hana era a.d. 78. In both these cases the error was intentional. It was devised with the aim of hiding the supremacy of foreigners in early Hindu history. So also, according to Alberuni’s information (Sachau, II. 7) the Guptak√°la a.d. 319 marks the ceasing not the beginning of the wicked and powerful Guptas. This device is not confined to India. His Mede informant told Herodotus (b.c. 450 Rawlinson’s Herodotus, I. 407) that b.c. 708 was the founding of the Median monarchy. The date really marked the overthrow of the Medes by the Assyrian Sargon. ↑

40 Tod (An. of R√°j. I. 231) notices what is perhaps a reminiscence of this date (a.d. 766). It is the story that Bappa, who according to Mew√°ḍ tradition is the founder of Gehlot power at Chitor, abandoned his country for Ir√°n in a.d. 764 (S. 820). It seems probable that this Bappa or Saila is not the founder of Gehlot power at Chitor, but, according to the Valabhi use of Bappa, is the founder’s father and that this retreat to Ir√°n refers to his being carried captive to Mansúra on the fall either of Valabhi or of Gandh√°r. ↑

41 Reinaud’s Fragments, 143 note 1; Mémoire Sur l’Inde, 105; Sachau’s Alberuni, I. 193. The treachery of the magician Ranka is the same cause as that assigned by Forbes (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 12–18) from Jain sources. The local legend (Ditto, 18) points the inevitable Tower of Siloam moral, a moral which (compare R√°s M√°l√°, I. 18) is probably at the root of the antique tale of Lot and the Cities of the Plain, that men whose city was so completely destroyed must have been sinners beyond others. Dr. Nicholson (J. R. A. S. Ser. I. Vol. XIII. page 153) in 1851 thought the site of Valabhi bore many traces of destruction by water. ↑

42 Lassen (Ind. Alt. III. 533) puts aside Alberuni’s Arab expedition from Mansúra as without historical support and inadmissible. Lassen held that Valabhi flourished long after its alleged destruction from Mansúra. Lassen’s statement (see Ind. Alt. III. 533) is based on the mistaken idea that as the Valabhis were the Balharas the Balharas’ capital M√°nkir must be Valabhi. So far as is known, except Alberuni himself (see below) none of the Arab geographers of the ninth, tenth or eleventh centuries mentions Valabhi. It is true that according to Lassen (Ind. Alt. 536) Masudi a.d. 915, Istakhri a.d. 951, and Ibn H√°ukal a.d. 976 all attest the existence of Valabhi up to their own time. This remark is due either to the mistake regarding Malkhet or to the identification of B√°lwi or Balzi in Sindh (Elliot’s History, I. 27–34) with Valabhi. The only known Musalm√°n reference to Valabhi later than a.d. 750 is Alberuni’s statement (Sachau, II. 7) that the Valabhi of the era is 30 yojanas or 200 miles south of Aṇahilav√°ḍa. That after its overthrow Valabhi remained, as it still continues, a local town has been shown in the text. Such an after-life is in no way inconsistent with its destruction as a leading capital in a.d. 767. ↑

43 According to Alberuni (Sachau, I. 21) Al Mansúra, which was close to Br√°hman√°b√°d about 47 miles north-east of Haidar√°b√°d (Elliot’s Musalm√°n Historians, I. 372–374) was built by the great Muhammad K√°sim about a.d. 713. Apparently Alberuni wrote Muhammad K√°sim by mistake for his grandson Amru Muhammad (Elliot, I. 372 note 1 and 442–3), who built the city a little before a.d. 750. Reinaud (Fragments, 210) makes Amru the son of Muhammad K√°sim. Masudi (a.d. 915) gives the same date (a.d. 750), but (Elliot, I. 24) makes the builder the Ummayide governor Mansúr bin Jamhur. Idrísi (a.d. 1137 Elliot, I. 78) says Mansúra was built and named in honour of the Khalif Abu J√°far-al-Mansur. If so its building would be later than a.d. 754. On such a point Idrísi’s authority carries little weight. ↑

44 Elliot, I. 244. ↑

45 That the word read Barada by Elliot is in the lax pointless shikasta writing is shown by the different proposed readings (Elliot, I. 444 note 1) N√°rand, Barand, and Barid. So far as the original goes Balaba is probably as likely a rendering as Barada. Reinaud (Fragments, 212) says he cannot restore the name. ↑

46 Though, except as applied to the Porbandar range of hills, the name Barada is almost unknown, and though Ghumli not Barada was the early (eighth-twelfth century) capital of Porbandar some place named Barada seems to have existed on the Porbandar coast. As early as the second century a.d., Ptolemy (McCrindle, 37) has a town Barda-xema on the coast west of the village Kome (probably the road or kom) of Saur√°shṭra; and St. Martin (Geographie Grecque et Latine de l’Inde, 203) identifies Pliny’s (a.d. 77) Varetatæ next the Odomberæ or people of Kachh with the Varadas according to Hemachandra (a.d. 1150) a class of foreigners or mlechchhas. A somewhat tempting identification of Barada is with Beruni’s B√°rwi (Sachau, I. 208) or Baraoua (Reinaud’s Fragments, 121) 84 miles (14 parasangs) west of Soman√°tha. But an examination of Beruni’s text shows that B√°rwi is not the name of a place but of a product of Kachh the b√°ra or bezoar stone. ↑

47 Elliot, I. 445. ↑

48 Compare Tod (Annals, I. 83 and 217). Gajni or Gayni another capital whence the last prince Śíl√°ditya was expelled by Parthian invaders in the sixth century. ↑

49 Compare Reinaud (Fragments, 212 note 4) who identifies it with the Áin-i-Akbari Kandah√°r that is Gandh√°r in Broach. The identification is doubtful. Tod (Annals, I. 217) names the fort Gajni or Gayni and there was a fort Gajni close to Cambay. Elliot (I. 445) would identify the Arab Kandah√°r with Khandad√°r in north-west K√°thi√°v√°ḍa.

Even after a.d. 770 Valabhi seems to have been attacked by the Arabs. Dr. Bhagv√°nl√°l notices that two Jain dates for the destruction of the city 826 and 886 are in the Vira era and that this means not the Mah√°vira era of b.c. 526 but the Vikram era of b.c. 57. The corresponding dates are therefore a.d. 769 and 829. Evidence in support of the a.d. 769 and 770 defeat is given in the text. On behalf of Dr. Bhagv√°nl√°l’s second date a.d. 829 it is remarkable that in or about a.d. 830 (Elliot, I. 447) Músa the Arab governor of Sindh captured B√°la the ruler of As Sharqi. As there seems no reason to identify this As Sharqi with the Sindh lake of As Sharqi mentioned in a raid in a.d. 750 (Elliot, I. 441: J. R. A. S. (1893) page 76) the phrase would mean B√°la king of the east. The Arab record of the defeat of B√°la would thus be in close agreement with the Jain date for the latest foreign attack on Valabhi. ↑

50 The identification of the Balharas of the Arab writers with the Ch√°lukyas (a.d. 500–753) and R√°shṭrakúṭas (a.d. 753–972) of M√°lkhet in the East Dakhan has been accepted. The vagueness of the early (a.d. 850–900) Arab geographers still more the inaccuracy of Idrísi (a.d. 1137) in placing the Balharas capital in Gujar√°t (Elliot, I. 87) suggested a connection between Balhara and Valabhi. The suitableness of this identification was increased by the use among R√°jput writers of the title Balakarai for the Valabhi chief (Tod An. of R√°j. I. 83) and the absence among either the Ch√°lukyas (a.d. 500–753) or the R√°shṭrakúṭas (a.d. 753–972) of M√°lkhet of any title resembling Balhara. Prof. Bhand√°rkar’s (Deccan History, 56–57) discovery that several of the early Ch√°lukyas and R√°shṭrakúṭas had the personal name Vallabha Beloved settled the question and established the accuracy of all Masudi’s (a.d. 915) statements (Elliot, I. 19–21) regarding the Balhara who ruled the Kamkar, that is Kamrakara or Karn√°ṭak (Sachau’s Beruni, I. 202; II. 318) and had their K√°narese (Kiriya) capital at Mankir (M√°lkhet) 640 miles from the coast. ↑

51 After their withdrawal from Valabhi to Mew√°ḍ the V√°las took the name of Gehlot (see below page 98), then of Aharya from a temporary capital near Udepur (Tod’s An. of R√°j. I. 215), next of Sesodia in the west of Mew√°ḍ (Tod’s An. of Raj. I. 216; Western India, 57). Since 1568 the R√°na’s head-quarters have been at Udepur. R√°j. Gaz. III. 18. After the establishment of their power in Chitor (a.d. 780), a branch of the Gehlot or Gohil family withdrew to Kheir in south-west M√°rw√°r. These driven south by the R√°thoḍs in the end of the twelfth century are the Gohils of Piram, Bh√°vnagar, and R√°jpipla in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and Gujar√°t. Tod’s Annals of R√°j. I. 114, 228. ↑

52 The somewhat doubtful J√°ikadeva plates (above page 87 and K√°thi√°v√°ḍa Gazetteer, 275) seem to show the continuance of Maitraka power in North K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. This is supported by the expedition of the Arab chief of Sandh√°n in Kachch (a.d. 840) against the Medhs of Hind which ended in the capture of M√°lia in North K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. Elliot, I. 450. Hiuen Tsiang (a.d. 630) (Beal’s Buddhist Records, II. 69) describes Saur√°shṭra as a separate state but at the same time notes its dependence on Valabhi. Its rulers seem to have been Mehrs. In a.d. 713 (Elliot, I. 123) Muhammad Kasim made peace with the men of Surasht, Medhs, seafarers, and pirates. ↑

53 The only contemporary rulers in whose grants a reference to Valabhi has been traced are the Gurjjaras of Broach (a.d. 580–808) one of whom, Dadda II. (a.d. 633), is said (Ind. Ant. XIII. 79) to have gained renown by protecting the lord of Valabhi who had been defeated by the illustrious Śrí Harshadeva (a.d. 608–649), and another Jayabhaṭa in a.d. 706 (Ind. Ant. V. 115) claims to have quieted with the sword the impetuosity of the lord of Valabhi. ↑

54 Tod An. of Raj. I. 217: Western India, 269. ↑

55 Tod An. of Raj. I. 112 and Western India, 148: R√°s M√°l√°, I. 21. It is not clear whether these passages prove that the Sesodias or only the V√°las claim an early settlement at Dh√°nk. In any case (see below page 101) both clans trace their origin to Kanaksen. ↑

56 Tod’s Western India, 51. ↑

57 Tod’s An. of Raj. I. 230. ↑

58 The cherished title of the later Valabhis, Śíl√°ditya Sun of Virtue, confirms the special sun worship at Valabhi, which the mention of Dharapaṭṭa (a.d. 550) as a devotee of the supreme sun supports, and which the legends of Valabhi’s sun-horse and sun-fountain keep fresh (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 14–18). So the great one-stone liṅgas, the most notable trace of Valabhi city (J. R. A. S. Ser. I. Vol. XIII. 149 and XVII. 271), bear out the Valabhi copperplate claim that its rulers were great worshippers of Śiva. Similarly the R√°na of Udepur, while enjoying the title of Sun of the Hindus, prospering under the sun banner, and specially worshipping the sun (Tod’s Annals, I. 565) is at the same time the Minister of Śiva the One Liṅg Eklingakadiw√°n (Ditto 222, R√°j. Gaz. III. 53). The blend is natural. The fierce noon-tide sun is Mah√°k√°la the Destroyer. Like Śiva the Sun is lord of the Moon. And marshalled by Soman√°tha the great Soul Home the souls of the dead pass heavenwards along the rays of the setting sun. [Compare Sachau’s Alberuni, II. 168.] It is the common sun element in Śaivism and in Vaishnavism that gives their holiness to the sunset shrines of Soman√°tha and Dw√°rka. For (Ditto, 169) the setting sun is the door whence men march forth into the world of existence Westwards, heavenwards. ↑

59 This explanation is hardly satisfactory. The name Gehlot seems to be Guhila-putra from Gobhila-putra an ancient Br√°hman gotra, one of the not uncommon cases of R√°jputs with a Br√°hman gotra. The R√°jput use of a Br√°hman gotra is generally considered a technical affiliation, a mark of respect for some Br√°hman teacher. It seems doubtful whether the practice is not a reminiscence of an ancestral Br√°hman strain. This view finds confirmation in the Aitpur inscription (Tod’s Annals, I. 802) which states that Guhadit the founder of the Gohil tribe was of Br√°hman race Vipra kula. Compare the legend (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 13) that makes the first Śíl√°ditya of Valabhi (a.d. 590–609) the son of a Br√°hman woman. Compare (Elliot, I. 411) the Br√°hman Ch√°ch (a.d. 630–670) marrying the widow of the Sh√°hi king of Alor in Sindh who is written of as a R√°jput though like the later (a.d. 850–1060) Shahiyas of K√°bul (Alberuni, Sachau II. 13) the dynasty may possibly have been Br√°hmans.60 The following passage from Hodgson’s Essays (J. A. Soc. Bl. II. 218) throws light on the subject: Among the Kh√°s or R√°jputs of Nep√°l the sons of Br√°hmans by Kh√°s women take their fathers’ gotras. Compare Ibbetson’s Panj√°b Census 1881 page 236. ↑

60 In support of a Br√°hman origin is Prinsep’s conjecture (J. A. S. Bl. LXXIV. [Feb. 1838] page 93) that Divaij the name of the first recorded king may be Dvija or Twice-born. But Divaij for Dev√°ditya, like Silaij for Śíl√°ditya, seems simpler and the care with which the writer speaks of Chach as the Br√°hman almost implies that his predecessors were not Br√°hmans. According to Elliot (II. 426) the P√°ls of K√°bul were R√°jputs, perhaps Bhattias. ↑

61 Tod’s Annals, I. 229–231. ↑

62 Annals, I. 229. ↑

63 Gladwin’s Áin-i-Akbari, II. 81; Tod’s Annals, I. 235 and note *. Tod’s dates are confused. The Aitpur inscription (Ditto, page 230) gives Śakti Kum√°ra’s date a.d. 968 (S. 1024) while the authorities which Tod accepts (Ditto, 231) give a.d. 1068 (S. 1125). That the Moris were not driven out of Chitor as early as a.d. 728 is proved by the Navs√°rí inscription which mentions the Arabs defeating the Mauryas as late as a.d. 738–9 (Saṃ. 490). See above page 56. ↑

64 Tod Western India 268 says Siddha R√°ja (a.d. 1094–1143): Múla R√°ja (a.d. 942–997) seems correct. See R√°s M√°l√°, I. 65. ↑

65 K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 672. ↑

66 The chronicles of Bhadrod, fifty-one miles south-west of Bh√°vnagar, have (K√°th. Gaz. 380) a Selait V√°la as late as a.d. 1554. ↑

67 K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 672. Another account places the movement south after the arrival of the Gohils a.d. 1250. According to local traditions the V√°las did not pass to Bhadrod near Mahuva till a.d. 1554 (K√°th. Gaz. 380) and from Bhadrod (K√°th. Gaz. 660) retired to Dholarva. ↑

68 K√°th. Gaz. 111 and 132. According to the Áin-i-Akbari (Gladwin, II. 60) the inhabitants of the ports of Mahua and Tul√°ja were of the V√°la tribe. ↑

69 K√°th. Gaz. 680. ↑

70 K√°th. Gaz. 414. ↑

71 The V√°la connection with the K√°this complicates their history. Col. Watson (K√°th. Gaz. 130) seems to favour the view that the V√°las were the earliest wave of K√°this who came into K√°thi√°v√°ḍa from M√°lwa apparently with the Guptas (a.d. 450) (Ditto, 671). Col. Watson seems to have been led to this conclusion in consequence of the existence of the petty state of K√°tti in west Kh√°ndesh. But the people of the K√°tti state in west Kh√°ndesh are Bhils or Kolis. Neither the people nor the position of the country seems to show connection with the K√°this of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. Col. Watson (K√°th. Gaz. 130) inclines to hold that the V√°las are an example of the rising of a lower class to be R√°jputs. That both V√°las and K√°this are northerners admitted into Hinduism may be accepted. Still it seems probable that on arrival in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa the V√°las were the leaders of the K√°this and that it is mainly since the fall of Valabhi that a large branch of the V√°las have sunk to be K√°this. The K√°thi traditions admit the superiority of the V√°las. According to Tod (Western India, 270: Annals, I. 112–113) the K√°this claim to be a branch or descendants of the V√°las. In K√°thi√°v√°ḍa the V√°las, the highest division of K√°this (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 296; K√°th. Gaz. 122, 123, 131, 139), admit that their founder was a V√°la R√°jput who lost caste by marrying a K√°thi woman. Another tradition (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 296; K√°th. Gaz. 122 note 1) records that the K√°this flying from Sindh took refuge with the V√°las and became their followers. Col. Watson (K√°th. Gaz. 130) considers the practice in Porbandar and Nav√°nagar of styling any lady of the Dh√°nk V√°la family who marries into their house K√°thi√°níb√°i the K√°thi lady proves that the V√°las are K√°this. But as this name must be used with respect it may be a trace that the V√°las claim to be lords of the K√°this as the Jetwas claim to be lords of the Mers. That the position of the V√°las and K√°this as R√°jputs is doubtful in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and is assured (Tod’s Annals, I. 111) in R√°jput√°na is strange. The explanation may perhaps be that aloofness from Muhammadans is the practical test of honour among R√°jput√°na Hindus, and that in the troubled times between the thirteenth and the seventeenth centuries, like the Jh√°l√°s, the V√°las and K√°this may have refused Moghal alliances, and so won the approval of the R√°n√°s of Mew√°ḍ. ↑

72 K√°th. Gaz. 110–129. ↑

73 Western India, 207; Annals, I. 112–113. ↑

74 It is worthy of note that B√°las and K√°thi√°s are returned from neighbouring Panj√°b districts. B√°las from Dehra Ismail Kh√°n (Panj√°b Census Report 1891 Part III. 310), K√°thi√° R√°jputs from Montgomery (Ditto, 318), and K√°thi√° J√°ts from Jhang and Dera Ismail Kh√°n (Ditto, 143). Compare Ibbetson’s (1881) Panj√°b Census, I. 259, where the K√°thias are identified with the Kathaioi who fought Alexander the Great (b.c. 325) and also with the K√°this of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. According to this report (page 240) the V√°las are said to have come from M√°lwa and are returned in East Panj√°b. ↑

75 Tod’s Annals, I. 83 and 215; Elliot, II. 410; Jour. B. Br. A. S. XXIII. ↑

76 Annals, I. 215. ↑

77 Kath. Gaz. 589. ↑

78 Bṛihat-Saṃhit√°, XIV. 21. The usual explanation (compare Fleet Ind. Ant. XXII. 180) Gold-Śakas seems meaningless. ↑

79 Sachau, II. 11. Among the legends are the much-applied tales of the foot-stamped cloth and the self-sacrificing minister. ↑

80 Western India, 213. ↑

81 Tod’s Annals, I. 83, 215; Western India, 270–352. ↑

82 Sachau, I. 208, II. 341. For the alleged descent of the Sesodi√°s and V√°las from R√°ma of the Sun race the explanation may be offered that the greatness of Kanishka, whose power was spread from the Ganges to the Oxus, in accordance with the Hindu doctrine (compare Beal’s Buddhist Records, I. 99 & 152; R√°s M√°l√°, I. 320; Fryer’s New Account, 190) that a conqueror’s success is the fruit of transcendent merit in a former birth, led to Kanishka being considered an incarnation of R√°ma. A connection between Kanishka and the race of the Sun would be made easy by the intentional confusing of the names Kshatrapa and Kshatriya and by the fact that during part at least of his life fire and the sun were Kanishka’s favourite deities. ↑

83 Gladwin’s Áin-i-Akbari, II. 81: Tod’s Annals, I. 235. ↑

84 The invasion of Sindh formerly (Reinaud’s Fragments, 29) supposed to be by Naushirv√°n in person according to fuller accounts seems to have been a raid by the ruler of Seist√°n (Elliot, I. 407). Still Reinaud (Mémoire Sur l’Inde, 127) holds that in sign of vassalage the Sindh king added a Persian type to his coins. ↑

85 Compare Tod’s Annals, I. 235–239 and Rawlinson’s Seventh Monarchy, 576. ↑

86 Rawlinson Seventh Monarchy, 452 note 3. ↑

87 Compare Tod’s Annals, I. 63; Thomas’ Prinsep, I. 413; Cunningham’s Arch. Survey, VI. 201. According to their own accounts (R√°s M√°l√°, I. 296) the K√°this learned sun-worship from the V√°la of Dh√°nk by whom the famous temple of the sun at Th√°n in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa was built. ↑

88 V√°las Musalm√°n J√°ts in Lahor and Gurdaspur: V√°ls in Gujar√°t and Gujranw√°l√°: V√°ls in Mozafarnagar and Dhera Ismael Khan. Also V√°lahs Hindus in K√°ngra. Panj√°b Census of 1891, III. 162. ↑

89 Bṛihaṭ Saṃhit√°, V. 80. ↑

90 Corp. Ins. Ind. III. 140–141. ↑

91 The references are; Langlois’ Harivaṃśa, I. 388–420, II. 178. That in a.d. 247 Balkh or B√°ktria was free from Indian overlordship (McCrindle’s Periplus, 121), and that no more distant tribe than the Gandh√°ras finds a place in the Harivaṃśa lists combine to make it almost certain that, at the time the Harivaṃśa was written, whatever their origin may have been, the B√°hlikas were settled not in B√°ktria but in India. ↑

92 The passage from the Karṇa Parva or Eighth Book of the Mah√°bh√°rata is quoted in Muir’s Sanskrit Texts, II. 482, and in greater fullness in St. Martin’s Geog. Greque et Latine de l’Inde, 402–410. The B√°hikas or B√°lhikas are classed with the Madras, Gandh√°ras, Araṭṭas, and other Panj√°b tribes. In their Br√°hman families it is said the eldest son alone is a Br√°hman. The younger brothers are without restraint Kshatriyas, Vaiśyas, Śudras, even Barbers. A Br√°hman may sink to be a Barber and a barber may rise to be a Br√°hman. The B√°hikas eat flesh even the flesh of the cow and drink liquor. Their women know no restraint. They dance in public places unclad save with garlands. In the Harivaṃśa (Langlois, I. 493 and II. 178, 388, 420) the Bahlikas occur in lists of kings and peoples. ↑

93 Kern in Muir’s Sanskrit Texts, II. 446. St. Martin (Geog. Greque et Latine de l’Inde, 149) takes B√°hika to be a contraction of B√°hlika. Reasons are given below for considering the Mah√°bh√°rata form B√°hika a confusion with the earlier tribes of that name rather than a contraction of B√°hlika or B√°lhika. The form B√°hika was also favoured by the writer in the Mah√°bh√°rata because it fitted with his punning derivation from their two fiend ancestors Vahi and Hika. St. Martin, 408. ↑

94 St. Martin Geog. Greque et Latine de l’Inde, 403, puts the probable date at b.c. 380 or about fifty years before Alexander. St. Martin held that the passage belonged to the final revision of the poem. Since St. Martin’s time the tendency has been to lower the date of the final revision by at least 500 years. The fact noted by St. Martin (Ditto, page 404) that Jartika which the Mah√°bh√°rata writer gives as another name for B√°hika is a Sanskritised form of Jat further supports the later date. It is now generally accepted that the Jats are one of the leading tribes who about the beginning of the Christian era passed from Central Asia into India. ↑

95 The name Valabhi, as we learn from the Jain historians, is a Sanskritised form of Valahi, which can be easily traced back to one of the many forms (B√°lhíka, B√°lhika, Balhika, Bahlíka, B√°hlika, V√°hlíka, Vahlíka, V√°lhíka, V√°lhika, Valhika) of a tribal name which is of common occurrence in the Epics. This name is, no doubt rightly, traced back to the city of Balkh, and originally denoted merely the people of Baktria. There is, however, evidence that the name also denoted a tribe doubtless of Baktrian origin, but settled in India: the Emperor Chandra speaks of defeating the V√°hlikas after crossing the seven mouths of the Indus: Var√°ha-Mihira speaks of the V√°lhikas along with the people who dwell on Sindhu’s banks (Bṛ. Saṃ. V. 80): and, most decisive of all, the K√°śik√° Vṛitti on P√°ṇ. VIII. iv. 9 (a.d. 650) gives Bahlíka as the name of the people of the Sauvíra country, which, as Alberuni tells us, corresponded to the modern Mult√°n, the very country to which the traditions of the modern V√°las point.

If the usual derivation of the name B√°lhika be accepted,96 it is possible to go a step further and fix a probable limit before which the tribe did not enter India. The name of Balkh in the sixth century b.c. was, as we learn from Darius’ inscriptions, B√°khtri, and the Greeks also knew it as Baktra: the Avesta form is Bakhdhi, which according to the laws of sound-change established by Prof. Darmsteter for the Arachosian language as represented by the modern Pushtu, would become Bahli (see Chants Populaires des Afghans, Introd. page xxvii). This reduction of the hard aspirates to spirants seems to have taken place about the first century a.d.: parallel cases are the change from Parthava to Palhava, and Mithra to Mihira. It would seem therefore that the Bahlikas did not enter India before the first century a.d.: and if we may identify their subduer Chandra with Chandragupta I., we should have the fourth century a.d. as a lower limit for dating their invasion.

Unfortunately, however, these limits cannot at present be regarded as more than plausible: for the name Balhika or Valhika appears to occur in works that can hardly be as modern as the first century a.d. The Atharvaveda-pariśishtas might be put aside, as they show strong traces of Greek influence and are therefore of late date: and the supposed occurrences in P√°ṇini belong to the commentators and to the Gaṇap√°ṭha only and are of more or less uncertain age. But the name occurs, in the form Balhika, in one hymn of the Atharvaveda itself (Book V. 22) which there is no reason to suppose is of late date.

The lower limit is also uncertain as the identification of Chandra of the inscription with the Gupta king is purely conjectural.—(A. M. T. J.) ↑

96 There is a very close parallel in the modern Panj√°b, where (see Census Report of 1881) the national name Baluch has become a tribal name in the same way as B√°lhika. ↑

97 Hodgson’s Essays on Indian Subjects, I. 405 Note. ↑

98 McCrindle’s Periplus, 121. Compare Rawlinson’s Seventh Monarchy, 79. The absence of Indian reference to the Yuechi supports the view that in India the Yuechi were known by some other name. ↑

99 According to Reinaud (Mémoire Sur l’Inde, 82 note 3) probably the modern Kochanya or Kashania sixty or seventy miles west of Samarkand. This is Hiuen Tsiang’s (a.d. 620) Ki’uh-shwangi-ni-kia or Kush√°nika. See Beal’s Buddhist Records, I. 34. ↑

100 Etude sur la Geographie Grecque et Latine de l’Inde, 147. ↑

101 McCrindle’s Alexander in India, 350. ↑

102 The suggestion is made by Mr. A. M. T. Jackson. ↑

103 McCrindle’s Alexander, 136. ↑

104 McCrindle’s Alexander, 252. ↑

105 Compare Strabo, XV. I. 8. The Oxydrakai are the descendants of Dionysus. Again, XV. I. 24: The Malloi and the Oxydrakai who as we have already said are fabled to be related to Dionysus. ↑

106 See McCrindle’s Alexander, 157, 369, 378, 398. Compare St. Martin Geog. Grecque et Latine de l’Inde, 102. ↑

107 Strabo, XV. I. 8 and 24, Hamilton’s Translation, III. 76, 95. ↑

108 References to the vines of Nysa and Meros occur in Strabo, Pliny, Quintus Curtius, Philostratus, and Justin: McCrindle’s Alexander in India, 193 note 1, 321, and 339. Strabo (Hamilton’s Translation, III. 86) refers to a vine in the country of Musikanus or Upper Sindh. At the same time (Ditto, 108) Strabo accepts Megasthenês’ statement that in India the wild vine grows only in the hills. ↑

109 The Kathaioi Malloi and Oxydrakai are (Arrian in McCrindle’s Alexander, 115, 137, 140, 149) called independent in the sense of kingless: they (Ditto, 154) sent leading men not ambassadors: (compare also Diodorus Siculus and Plutarch, Ditto 287, 311): the Malloi had to chose a leader (Q. Curtius, Ditto 236). ↑

110 K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 138. ↑

111 K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 137. ↑

112 Cutch Gazetteer, 80. ↑

113 Cutch Gazetteer, 81. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER IX.

THE CHÁLUKYAS

(a.d. 634–740.)


Chapter IX.
The Ch√°lukyas, a.d. 634–740. The Ch√°lukyas conquered their Gujar√°t provinces from the south after subduing the Konkan Mauryas of Purí either R√°j√°purí that is Janjira or Elephanta in Bombay harbour. The fifth century V√°da inscription of king Suketuvarmman proves that this Maurya dynasty1 ruled in the Konkan for at least a century before they came into collision with the Ch√°lukyas under Kírtivarmman.2 They were finally defeated and their capital Purí taken by Chaṇḍadaṇḍa an officer of Pulakeśi II. (a.d. 610–640).3 The Ch√°lukyas then pressed northwards, and an inscription at Aihole in South Bij√°pur records that as early as a.d. 634 the kings of L√°ṭa, M√°lava, and Gurjjara submitted to the prowess of Pulakeśi II. (a.d. 610–640).

Jayasiṃhavarmman, a.d. 666–693.The regular establishment of Ch√°lukya power in South Gujar√°t seems to have been the work of Dh√°r√°śraya Jayasiṃhavarmman son of Pulakeśi II. and younger brother of Vikram√°ditya Saty√°śraya (a.d. 670–680). A grant of Jayasiṃhavarmman’s son Śíl√°ditya found in Navs√°rí describes Jayasiṃhavarmman as receiving the kingdom from his brother Vikram√°ditya. As Jayasiṃhavarmman is called Paramabhaṭṭ√°raka Great Lord, he probably was practically independent. He had five sons and enjoyed a long life, ruling apparently from Navs√°rí. Of the five Gujar√°t Ch√°lukya copperplates noted below, three are in an era marked Saṃ. which is clearly different from the Śaka era (a.d. 78) used in the grants of the main Ch√°lukyas. From the nature of the case the new era of the Gujar√°t Ch√°lukyas may be accepted as of Gujar√°t origin. Grants remain of Jayasiṃhavarmman’s sons dated Ś. 421, 443, and 490.4 This checked by Vikram√°ditya’s known date (a.d. 670–680) gives an initial between a.d. 249 and 259. Of the two Gujar√°t eras, the Gupta-Valabhi (a.d. 319) and the Traikúṭaka (a.d. 248–9), the Gupta-Valabhi is clearly unsuitable. On the other hand the result is so closely in accord with a.d. 248–9, the Traikúṭaka epoch, as to place the correctness of the identification almost beyond question.

Jayasiṃhavarmman must have established his power in South Gujar√°t before a.d. 669–70 (T. 421), as in that year his son Śry√°śraya made a grant as heir apparent. Another plate of Śry√°śraya found in Surat shows that in a.d. 691–2 (T. 443) Jayasiṃhavarmman was still ruling with Śry√°śraya as heir apparent. In view of these facts the establishment of Jayasiṃhavarmman’s power in Gujar√°t must be taken at about a.d. 666. The copperplates of his sons and grandson do not say whom Jayasiṃhavarmman overthrew. Probably the defeated rulers were Gurjjaras, as about this time a Gurjjara dynasty held the Broach district with its capital at N√°ndípurí the modern N√°ndod in the R√°jpipla State about thirty-five miles east of Broach. So far [108]
Chapter IX.
The Ch√°lukyas, a.d. 634–740.
Jayasiṃhavarmman a.d. 666–693. as is known the earliest of the N√°ndod Gurjjaras was Dadda who is estimated to have flourished about a.d. 580 (T. 331).5 The latest is Jayabhaṭa whose Navs√°rí copperplate bears date a.d. 734–5 (T. 486)6 so that the Gurjjara and Ch√°lukya kingdoms flourished almost at the same time. It is possible that the power of the earlier Gurjjara kings spread as far south as Bals√°r and even up to Konkan limits. It was apparently from them that, during the reign of his brother Vikram√°ditya, Jayasiṃhavarmman took South Gujar√°t, driving the Gurjjaras north of the T√°pti and eventually confining them to the Broach district, the Gurjjaras either acknowledging Ch√°lukya sovereignty or withstanding the Ch√°lukyas and retaining their small territory in the Broach district by the help of the Valabhis with whom they were in alliance.7 In either case the Ch√°lukya power seems to have hemmed in the Broach Gurjjaras, as Jayasiṃhavarmman had a son Buddhavarmman ruling in Kaira. A copperplate of Buddhavarmman’s son Vijayar√°ja found in Kaira is granted from Vijayapura identified with Bij√°pur near Par√°ntij, but probably some place further south, as the grant is made to Br√°hmans of Jambusar. Five copperplates remain of this branch of the Ch√°lukyas, the Navs√°rí grant of Śry√°śraya Śíl√°ditya Yuvar√°ja dated a.d. 669–70 (T. 421); the Surat grant of the same Śíl√°ditya dated a.d. 691–2 (T. 443); the Bals√°r grant of Vinay√°ditya Mangalar√°ja dated a.d. 731 (Śaka 653); the Navs√°rí grant of Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya dated a.d. 738–9 (T. 490); the Kaira grant of Vijayar√°ja dated Śaṃvatsara 394; and the undated Nirpan grant of N√°gavarddhana Tribhuvan√°śraya.

Śry√°śraya Śíl√°ditya (Heir Apparent), a.d. 669–691.The first four grants mention Jayasiṃhavarmman as the younger brother of Vikram√°ditya Saty√°śraya the son of Pulakeśi Saty√°śraya the conqueror of Harshavarddhana the lord of the North. Jayasiṃhavarmman’s eldest son was Śry√°śraya Śíl√°ditya who made his Navs√°rí grant in a.d. 669–70 (T. 421); the village granted being said to be in the Navas√°rik√° Vishaya. Śry√°śraya’s other plate dated a.d. 691–2 (T. 443) grants a field in the village of Osumbhal√° in the K√°rmaneya Áh√°ra that is the district of K√°mlej on the T√°pti fifteen miles north-east of Surat. In both grants Śíl√°ditya is called Yuvar√°ja, which shows that his father ruled with him from a.d. 669 to a.d. 691. Both copperplates show that these kings treated as their overlords the main dynasty of the southern Ch√°lukyas as respectful mention is made in the first plate of Vikram√°ditya Saty√°śraya and in the second of his son Vinay√°ditya Saty√°śraya. Apparently Śry√°śraya died before his father as the two late grants of Bals√°r and Kheḍ√° give him no place in the list of rulers.

Mangalar√°ja, a.d. 698–731.Jayasiṃhavarmman was succeeded by his second son Mangalar√°ja. A plate of his found at Bals√°r dated a.d. 731 (Śaka 653) records a grant made from Mangalapurí, probably the same as Purí the doubtful Konkan capital of the Śil√°h√°ras.8 As his elder brother was heir-apparent in a.d. 691–2 (T. 443), Mangalar√°ja must have succeeded some years later, say about a.d. 698–9 (T. 450). From this it may be inferred that the copperplate of a.d. 731 was issued towards the end of his reign. [109]


Chapter IX.
The Ch√°lukyas, a.d. 634–740.
Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya, a.d. 738. Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya, a.d. 738.Mangalar√°ja was succeeded by his younger brother Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya. This is the time of Khalif Hash√°m (H. 105–125, a.d. 724–743) whose Sindh governor Junaid is recorded to have sent expeditions against Marm√°d, Mandal, Dalmaj (K√°mlej?), B√°rus, Uzain, M√°liba, Baharimad (Mevad?), Al Bail√°im√°n (Bhinm√°l?), and Juzr. Though several of these names seem to have been misread and perhaps misspelt on account of the confusion in the original Arabic, still Marm√°d, Mandal, Barus, Uzain, M√°liba, and Juzr can easily be identified with M√°rv√°d, Mandal near Viramg√°m, Bharuch, Ujjain, M√°lwa, and Gurjjara. The defeat of one of these raids is described at length in Pulakeśi’s grant of a.d. 738–9 (T. 490) which states that the Arab army had afflicted the kingdoms of Sindhu, Kacchella, Saur√°shṭra, Ch√°voṭaka, Maurya, and Gurjjara that is Sindh, Kacch, the Ch√°vaḍ√°s, the Mauryas of Chitor,9 and the Gurjjaras of Bhínm√°l.10 [110]
Chapter IX.
The Ch√°lukyas, a.d. 634–740.
Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya, a.d. 738. Pulakeśi was at this time ruling at Navs√°rí. It is uncertain how much longer this Ch√°lukya kingdom of Navs√°rí continued. It was probably overthrown about a.d. 750 by the Gujar√°t branch of the R√°shṭrakúṭas who were in possession in a.d. 757–8.11

Buddhavarmman, a.d. 713 (?).The Kaira grant dated 394 gives in hereditary succession the names Jayasiṃha, Buddhavarmman, and Vijayar√°ja.12 The grant is made from Vijayapura, which, as the late Colonel West suggested, may be Bij√°pur near Par√°ntij though this is far to the north of the otherwise known Ch√°lukya limits. The village granted is Pariyaya in the K√°ś√°kula division. If taken as Traikúṭaka the date 394 corresponds to a.d. 642–3. This is out of the question, since Vijayar√°ja’s grand-uncle Vikram√°ditya flourished between a.d. 670 and 680. Professor Bhandarkar considers the plate a forgery, but there seems no sufficient reason for doubting its genuineness. No fault can be found with the character. It is written in the usual style of Western Ch√°lukya grants, and contains the names of a number of Br√°hman grantees with minute details of the fields granted a feature most unusual in a forged grant. In the Gupta era, which equally with the Traikúṭaka era may be denoted by the word Saṃ. and which is more likely to be in use in North Gujar√°t the 394 would represent the fairly probable a.d. 713. Jayasiṃha may have conquered part of North Gujar√°t and sent his son Buddhavarmman to rule over it.

N√°gavarddhana.Jayasiṃha appears to have had a third son N√°gavarddhana ruling in West N√°sik which was connected with South Gujar√°t through Bals√°r, P√°rdi, and Penth. The Nirpan grant of N√°gavarddhana is undated,13 and, though it gives a wrong genealogy, its seal, the form of composition, the biruda or title of the king, and the alphabet all so closely agree with the style of the Gujar√°t Ch√°lukya plates that it cannot be considered a forgery.

Not long after a.d. 740 the Ch√°lukyas seem to have been supplanted in South Gujar√°t by the R√°shṭrakúṭas.

Ch√°lukya Tree.CHÁLUKYA FAMILY TREE.

Pulakeśivallabha Saty√°śraya,
Conqueror of Harshavarddhana, Lord of the North.
a.d. 610–640.
(Main Ch√°lukyas). (Gujar√°t Branch).
Vikram√°ditya Saty√°śraya,
a.d. 669–680.		 Jayasiṃhavarmman Dh√°r√°śraya,
a.d. 669–691.
Vinay√°ditya.
(Navs√°rí.) (Navs√°rí.) (Kaira.) (N√°sik.) (Navs√°rí.)
Śíl√°ditya Śry√°śraya Yuvar√°ja,
T. 421 (a.d. 669–70) and T. 443 (a.d. 691–2).		 Mangalar√°ja or Mangalarasar√°ya,
Śaka 653
(a.d. 731–2).		 Buddhavarmman.
Vijayar√°ja
G. 394
(a.d. 713).		 N√°gavarddhana. Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya,
T. 490
(a.d. 738–9).

[111]


Chapter IX.
The Ch√°lukyas, a.d. 634–740. Vijayar√°ja’s grant of the year 394 (a.d. 642–3) is the earliest trace of Ch√°lukya rule in Gujar√°t. Dr. Bhagv√°nl√°l, who believed in its genuineness, supposes it to be dated in the Gupta era (G. 394 = a.d. 714) and infers from it the existence of Ch√°lukya rule far to the north of Broach. But the most cursory comparison of it with the Kheḍ√° grants of Dadda II. (see Ind. Ant. XIII. 81ff) which are dated (admittedly in the [so-called] Traikúṭaka era) 380 and 385 respectively, shows that a large number of Dadda’s grantees reappear in the Ch√°lukya grant. The date of the Ch√°lukya plate must therefore be interpreted as a Traikúṭaka or Chedi date.

a.d. 610–640.This being so, it is clearly impossible to suppose that Vijayar√°ja’s grandfather Jayasiṃha is that younger son of Pulakeśi II. (a.d. 610–640) who founded the Gujar√°t branch family. It has been usually supposed that the Jayasiṃha of our grant was a younger brother of Pulakeśi II.: but this also is chronologically impossible: for Jayasiṃha can hardly have been more than ten years of age in a.d. 597–98, when his elder brother was set aside as too young to rule. His son Buddhavarmman could hardly have been born before a.d. 610, so that Buddhavarmman’s son Vijayar√°ja must have made his grant at the age of twelve at latest. The true solution of the question seems to be that given by Dr. Bhand√°rkar in his Early History of the Deccan (page 42 note 7), namely that the grant is a forgery. To the reasons advanced by him may be added the fact pointed out by Mr. Fleet (Ind. Ant. VII. 251) that the grant is a palimpsest, the engraver having originally commenced it “Svasti Vijayavikshep√°n Na.” It can hardly be doubted that Na is the first syllable of N√°ndípurí the palace of the Gurjjara kings. Many of the grantees were Br√°hmans of Jambusar and subjects of Dadda II. of Broach, whose grants to them are extant. It seems obvious that Vijayar√°ja’s grant was forged in the interest of these persons by some one who had Gurjjara grants before him as models, but knew very little of the forms used in the chancery of the Ch√°lukyas.

Setting aside this grant, the first genuine trace of Ch√°lukya rule in Gujar√°t is to be found in the grant of the Sendraka chief Nikumbhallaśakti, which bears date Saṃ. 406 (a.d. 654–5) and relates to the gift to a Br√°hman of the village of Balisa (Wanesa) in the Treyaṇṇa (Ten) district. Dr. Bühler has shown (Ind. Ant. XVIII. page 265ff) that the Sendrakas were a K√°narese family, and that Nikumbhallaśakti must have come to Gujar√°t as a Ch√°lukya feudatory, though he names no overlord. He was doubtless subordinate to the Ch√°lukya governor of N√°sik.

The next grant that requires notice is that of N√°gavarddhana, who describes himself distinctly as the son of Pulakeśi’s brother Jayasiṃha, though Dr. Bhagv√°nl√°l believed this Jayasiṃha to be Pulakeśi’s son. Mr. Fleet points out other difficulties connected with this grant, but on the whole decides in favour of its genuineness (see Ind. Ant. IX. 123). The description of Pulakeśi II. in this grant refers to his victory over Harshavarddhana, but also describes him as having conquered the three kingdoms of Chera, Chola, and P√°ṇḍya by means of his horse of the Chitrakaṇṭha breed, and as meditating on the feet of Śri N√°gavarddhana. Now all of these epithets, except the reference to Harshavarddhana, belong properly, not to Pulakeśi II. but to his son Vikram√°ditya I. The conquest of the confederacy of Cholas, Cheras (or Keraḷas), and P√°ṇḍyas is ascribed to Vikram√°ditya in the inscriptions of his son Vinay√°ditya (Fleet in Ind. Ant. X. 134): the Chitrakaṇṭha horse is named in Vikram√°ditya’s own grants (Ind. Ant. VI. 75 &c.) while his meditation upon the feet of N√°gavarddhana recurs in the T. 421 grant of Śry√°śraya Śíl√°ditya (B. B. R. A. S. XVI. 1ff). This confusion of epithets between Pulakeśi II. and Vikram√°ditya makes it difficult to doubt that N√°gavarddhana’s grant was composed either during or after Vikram√°ditya’s reign, and under the influence of that king’s grants. It may be argued that even in that case the grant may be genuine, its inconsistencies being due merely to carelessness. This supposition the following considerations seem too negative. Pulakeśi II. was alive at the time of Hiuen Tsiang’s visit (a.d. 640), but is not likely to have reigned very much longer. And, as Vikram√°ditya’s reign is supposed to have begun about a.d. 669–70, a gap remains of nearly thirty years. That part of this period was occupied by the war with the three kings [112]
Chapter IX.
The Ch√°lukyas, a.d. 634–740. of the south we know from Vikram√°ditya’s own grants: but the grant of Śry√°śraya Śíl√°ditya referred to above seems to show that Vikram√°ditya was the successor, not of his father, but of N√°gavarddhana upon whose feet he is described as meditating. It follows that N√°gavarddhana succeeded Pulakeśi and preceded Vikram√°ditya on the imperial throne of the Ch√°lukyas whereas his grant could not have been composed until the reign of Vikram√°ditya.

Although the grant is not genuine, we have no reason to doubt that it gives a correct genealogy, and that N√°gavarddhana was the son of Pulakeśi’s brother Jayasiṃha and therefore the first cousin of Vikram√°ditya. The grant is in the regular Ch√°lukya style, and the writer, living near the Northern Ch√°lukya capital, N√°sik, had better models than the composer of Vijayar√°ja’s grant. Both grants may have been composed about the time when the Ch√°lukya power succumbed to the attacks of the R√°shṭrakúṭas (a.d. 743).—(A. M. T. J.)

[113]

4 J. B. B. R. A. S. XVI. 1ff.: Proceedings VIIth Oriental Congress, 210ff. ↑

5 See Chap. X. below. ↑

6 Ind. Ant. XIII. 73. ↑

7 Ind. Ant. XIII. 70. ↑

8 B. B. R. A. S. XVI. 5. ↑

9 For the Moris or Mauryas, described as a branch of Pram√°ras, who held Chitor during the eighth century compare Tod. Jr. R. A. S. 211; Wilson’s Works, XII. 132. ↑

10 The text of the copperplate runs:

शरझसीरमुद्ररोद्धारिणि तरलतरतारतरवारिदा

[24] रितोदितसैन्धवकच्छेल्लर्सोराष्ट्र चावोटक मौर्यगुर्जरादिरा [ज्ये] निःशोषदाक्षिणात्यक्षितिपतिजि

[25] गीषया दक्षिणापथप्रवेश ……… प्रथममेवनवसारिकाविषयप्रसाधनायागते त्वरित

Plate II.

[1] तुरगखरमुखरखुरोत्खातधरिणिधूलिधूसरितदिगन्तरे कुन्तप्रान्तनितान्तविमर्द्यमानरभसाभिधावितो

[2] द्भटस्थूलोदरविवरविनिर्ग्गतांत्रप्रथुतररुधिरधारांजितकवचभीषणवपुषि स्वामिमहा

[3] सन्मानदानग्रहणᳲक्रयीकृतस्वशिरोभिरभिमुखमापतितैप्रदंयदशनाग्रदष्टोष्टपुटकैरने

[4] कसमराजिरविवरवरिकटितटहयविधटनविशालितधनरुधिरपटलपाटलितपटुक्रपाणपठ्ठैरपि महा

[5] योवैरलब्वपरभागैः विपक्षक्षपणाक्षेपक्षिप्रक्षिप्रतीक्ष्णक्षुरप्रप्रहारविलूनवैरिशिरᳲकमलगलनालैरा

[6] हवरसरभसरोमांचकंचुकाच्छादिततनूभिरनेकैरपि नरेन्द्रव्रंदव्रदारकैरजितपुर्वैः व्यपगतमस्माक

[7] म्रणमनेन स्वामिनः स्वशिरः प्रदानेनाद्यतावदेकजन्मीयमित्येवमिषोपजातपरितोषानन्तरप्रहतपटुप

[8] टहरवप्रवृत्तकबन्वबद्धरासमण्डलीके समरशिरासे विजितेताजिकानिके शोय्यानुरागिणा श्रीवदत्रमनरें

[9] द्रेण प्रसादीकृतापरनामचतुष्टयस्तद्ध्यथा दक्षिणापथसाधारणचलुक्विकुलालंकारपृथ्वीवदत्रमानिवर्त्तकनिव

[10] र्त्तयित्रवनिजनाश्रयश्रीपुलकेशिराजस्सर्वानेवात्मीयान्‌

 ↑

11 Journal B. B. R. A. S. XVI. 105. ↑

12 Ind. Ant. VII. 241. ↑

13 Ind. Ant. IX. 123. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER X.

THE GURJJARAS

(a.d. 580–808.)


Chapter X.
The Gurjjaras, a.d. 580–808. During Valabhi and Ch√°lukya ascendancy a small Gurjjara kingdom flourished in and about Broach. As has been noticed in the Valabhi chapter the Gurjjaras were a foreign tribe who came to Gujar√°t from Northern India. All the available information regarding the Broach Gurjjaras comes from nine copperplates,1 three of them forged, all obtained from South Gujar√°t. These plates limit the regular Gurjjara territory to the Broach district between the Mahí and the Narbad√°, though at times their power extended north to Kheḍ√° and south to the T√°pti. Like the grants of the contemporary Gujar√°t Ch√°lukyas all the genuine copperplates are dated in the Traikúṭaka era which begins in a.d. 249–50.2 The Gurjjara capital seems to have been N√°ndípurí or N√°ndor,3 the modern N√°ndod the capital of R√°jpipla in Rewa K√°ntha about thirty-four miles east of Broach. Two of their grants issue N√°ndípurítaḥ4 that is ‘from N√°ndípurí’ like the Valabhítaḥ or ‘from Valabhi’ of the Valabhi copperplates, a phrase which in both cases seems to show the place named was the capital since in other Gurjjara grants the word v√°saka or camp occurs.5

Copperplates.Though the Gurjjaras held a considerable territory in South Gujar√°t their plates seem to show they were not independent rulers. The general titles are either Samadhigata-panchamah√°śabada ‘He who has attained the five great titles,’ or S√°manta Feudatory. In one instance Jayabhaṭa III. who was probably a powerful ruler is called S√°mant√°dhipati6 Lord of Feudatories. It is hard to say to what suzerain these Broach Gurjjaras acknowledged fealty. Latterly they seem to have accepted the Ch√°lukyas on the south as their overlords. But during the greater part of their existence they may have been feudatories of the Valabhi dynasty, who, as [114]
Chapter X.
The Gurjjaras, a.d. 580–808.
Copperplates. mentioned above were probably Gurjjaras who passed from M√°lwa to South Gujar√°t and thence by sea to Valabhi leaving a branch in South Gujar√°t.

The facts that in a.d. 649 (Valabhi 330) a Valabhi king had a ‘camp of victory’ at Broach where Raṇagraha’s plate7 shows the Gurjjaras were then ruling and that the Gurjjara king Dadda II. gave shelter to a Valabhi king establish a close connection between Valabhi and the N√°ndod Gurjjaras.

Their copperplates and seals closely resemble the plates and seals of the Gujar√°t Ch√°lukyas. The characters of all but the forged grants are like those of Gujar√°t Ch√°lukya grants and belong to the Gujar√°t variety of the Southern India style. At the same time it is to be noted that the royal signature at the end of the plates is of the northern type, proving that the Gurjjaras were originally northerners. The language of most of the grants is Sanskrit prose as in Valabhi plates in a style curiously like the style of the contemporary author B√°ṇa in his great works the K√°dambarí and Harshacharita. From this it may be inferred that B√°ṇa’s style was not peculiar to himself but was the style in general use in India at that time.

Gurjjara Tree.The following is the Gurjjara family tree:

Dadda I. a.d. 580.
Jayabhaṭa I. a.d. 605.
Dadda II. a.d. 633.
Jayabhaṭa II. a.d. 655.
Dadda III. a.d. 680.
Jayabhaṭa III. a.d. 706–734.

A recently published grant8 made by Nirihullaka, the chieftain of a jungle tribe in the lower valley of the Narbad√°, shows that towards the end of the sixth century a.d. that region was occupied by wild tribes who acknowledged the supremacy of the Chedi or Kalachuri kings: a fact which accounts for the use of the Chedi or Traikúṭaka era in South Gujar√°t. Nirihullaka names with respect a king Śaṅkaraṇa, whom Dr. Bühler would identify with Śaṅkaragaṇa the father of the Kalachuri Buddhavarmman who was defeated by Mangalíśa the Ch√°lukya about a.d. 600.9 Śaṅkaragaṇa himself must have flourished about a.d. 580, and the Gurjjara conquest must be subsequent to this date. Another new grant,10 which is only a fragment and contains no king’s name, but which on the ground of date (Saṃ. 346 = a.d. 594–5) and style may be safely attributed to the Gurjjara dynasty, shows that the Gurjjaras were established in the country within a few years of Śaṅkaragaṇa’s probable date.

A still nearer approximation to the date of the Gurjjara conquest is suggested by the change in the titles of Dharasena I. of Valabhi, who [115]
Chapter X.
The Gurjjaras, a.d. 580–808. in his grants of Saṃvat 25211 (a.d. 571) calls himself Mah√°r√°ja, while in his grants of 269 and 27012 (a.d. 588 and 589), he adds the title of Mah√°s√°manta, which points to subjection by some foreign power between a.d. 571 and a.d. 588. It seems highly probable that this power was that of the Gurjjaras of Bhínm√°l; and that their successes therefore took place between a.d. 580 and 588 or about a.d. 585.

Dadda I. C. 585–605 a.d.The above mentioned anonymous grant of the year 346 (a.d. 594–95) is ascribed with great probability to Dadda I. who is known from the two Kheḍ√° grants of his grandson Dadda II. (C. 620–650 a.d.)13 to have “uprooted the N√°ga” who must be the same as the jungle tribes ruled by Nirihullaka and are now represented by the N√°ikd√°s of the Panch Mah√°ls and the Talabdas or Locals of Broach. The northern limit of Dadda’s kingdom seems to have been the Vindhya, as the grant of 380 (a.d. 628–29) says that the lands lying around the feet of the Vindhya were for his pleasure. At the same time it appears that part at least of Northern Gujar√°t was ruled by the Mah√°s√°manta Dharasena of Valabhi, who in Val. 270 (a.d. 589–90) granted a village in the √°h√°ra of Kheṭaka (Kheḍ√°).14 Dadda is always spoken of as the S√°manta, which shows that while he lived his territory remained a part of the Gurjjara kingdom of Bhínm√°l. Subsequently North Gujar√°t fell into the hands of the M√°lava kings, to whom it belonged in Hiuen Tsiang’s time (C. 640 a.d.).15 Dadda I. is mentioned in the two Kheḍ√° grants of his grandson as a worshipper of the sun: the fragmentary grant of 346 (a.d. 594–95) which is attributed to him gives no historical details.

Jayabhaṭa I. Vítar√°ga, C. 605–620 a.d.Dadda I. was succeeded by his son Jayabhaṭa I. who is mentioned in the Kheḍ√° grants as a victorious and virtuous ruler, and appears from his title of Vítar√°ga the Passionless to have been a religious prince.

Dadda II. Praś√°ntar√°ga, C. 620–650 a.d.Jayabhaṭa I. was succeeded by his son Dadda II. who bore the title of Praś√°ntar√°ga the Passion-calmed. Dadda was the donor of the two Kheḍ√° grants of 380 (a.d. 628–29) and 385 (a.d. 633–34), and a part of a grant made by his brother Raṇagraha in the year 391 (a.d. 639–40) has lately been published.16 Three forged grants purporting to have been issued by him are dated respectively Śaka 400 (a.d. 478), Śaka 415 (a.d. 493), and Śaka 417 (a.d. 495).17 Both of the Kheḍ√° grants relate to the gift of the village of Siríshapadraka (Sisodra) in the Akrúreśvara (Ankleśvar) vishaya to certain Br√°hmans of Jambusar and Broach. In Raṇagraha’s grant the name of the village is lost.

Dadda II.’s own grants describe him as having attained the five great titles, and praise him in general terms: and both he and his brother Raṇagraha sign their grants as devout worshippers of the sun. Dadda II. heads the genealogy in the later grant of 456 (a.d. 704–5),18 which states that he protected “the lord of Valabhi who had been defeated by the great lord the illustrious Harshadeva.” The event referred to must have been some expedition of the great Harshavardhana of Kanauj [116]
Chapter X.
The Gurjjaras, a.d. 580–808.
Dadda II. Praś√°ntar√°ga, C. 620–650 a.d. (a.d. 607–648), perhaps the campaign in which Harsha was defeated on the Narbad√° by Pulakeśi II. (which took place before a.d. 634). The protection given to the Valabhi king is perhaps referred to in the Kheḍ√° grants in the mention of “strangers and suppliants and people in distress.” If this is the case the defeat of Valabhi took place before a.d. 628–29, the date of the earlier of the Kheḍ√° grants. On the other hand, the phrase quoted is by no means decisive, and the fact that in Hiuen Tsiang’s time Dhruvasena of Valabhi was son-in-law of Harsha’s son, makes it unlikely that Harsha should have been at war with him. It follows that the expedition referred to may have taken place in the reign of Dharasena IV. who may have been the son of Dhruvasena by another wife than Harsha’s granddaughter.

To Dadda II.’s reign belongs Hiuen Tsiang’s notice of the kingdom of Broach (C. 640 a.d.).19 He says “all their profit is from the sea” and describes the country as salt and barren, which is still true of large tracts in the west and twelve hundred years ago was probably the condition of a much larger area than at present. Hiuen Tsiang does not say that Broach was subject to any other kingdom, but it is clear from the fact that Dadda bore the five great titles that he was a mere feudatory. At this period the valuable port of Broach, from which all their profit was made, was a prize fought for by all the neighbouring powers. With the surrounding country of L√°ṭa, Broach submitted to Pulakeśi II. (a.d. 610–640):20 it may afterwards have fallen to the M√°lava kings, to whom in Hiuen Tsiang’s time (a.d. 640) both Kheḍ√° (K’ie-ch’a) and Ánandapura (Vadnagar) belonged; later it was subject to Valabhi, as Dharasena IV. made a grant at Broach in V.S. 330 (a.d. 649–50).21

Knowledge of the later Gurjjaras is derived exclusively from two grants of Jayabhaṭa III. dated respectively 456 (a.d. 704–5) and 486 (a.d. 734–5).22 The later of these two grants is imperfect, only the last plate having been preserved. The earlier grant of 456 (a.d. 704–5) shows that during the half century following the reign of Dadda II. the dynasty had ceased to call themselves Gurjjaras, and had adopted a Pur√°ṇic pedigree traced from king Karṇa, a hero of the Bh√°rata war. It also shows that from Dadda III. onward the family were Śaivas instead of sun-worshippers.

Jayabhaṭa II. C. 650–675 a.d.The successor of Dadda II. was his son Jayabhaṭa II. who is described as a warlike prince, but of whom no historical details are recorded.

Dadda III. B√°husah√°ya, C. 675–700.Jayabhaṭa’s son, Dadda III. B√°husah√°ya, is described as waging wars with the great kings of the east and of the west (probably M√°lava and Valabhi). He was the first Śaiva of the family, studied Manu’s works, and strictly enforced “the duties of the varṇas or castes and of the √°śramas or Br√°hman stages.” It was probably to him that the Gurjjaras owed their Pur√°ṇic pedigree and their recognition as true Kshatriyas. Like his predecessors, Dadda III. [117]
Chapter X.
The Gurjjaras, a.d. 580–808.
Dadda III. B√°husah√°ya, C. 675–700. was not an independent ruler. He could claim only the five great titles, though no hint is given who was his suzerain. His immediate superior may have been Jayasiṃha the Ch√°lukya, who received the province of L√°ṭa from his brother Vikram√°ditya (c. 669–680 a.d.)23

Jayabhaṭa III. c. 704–734 a.d.The son and successor of Dadda III. was Jayabhaṭa III. whose two grants of 456 (a.d. 704–5) and 486 (a.d. 734–5)24 must belong respectively to the beginning and the end of his reign. He attained the five great titles, and was therefore a feudatory, probably of the Ch√°lukyas: but his title of Mah√°s√°mant√°dhipati implies that he was a chief of importance. He is praised in vague terms, but the only historical event mentioned in his grants is a defeat of a lord of Valabhi, noted in the grant of 486 (a.d. 734–5). The Valabhi king referred to must be either Śíl√°ditya IV. (a.d. 691) or Śíl√°ditya V. (a.d. 722). During the reign of Jayabhaṭa III. took place the great Arab invasion which was repulsed by Pulakeśi Jan√°śraya at Navs√°rí.25 Like the kingdoms named in the grant of Pulakeśi, Broach must have suffered from this raid. It is not specially mentioned probably because it formed part of Pulakeśi’s territory.

After a.d. 734–5 no further mention occurs of the Gurjjaras of Broach. Whether the dynasty was destroyed by the Arabs or by the Gujar√°t R√°shṭrakúṭas (a.d. 750) is not known. Later references to Gurjjaras in R√°shṭrakúṭa times refer to the Gurjjaras of Bhínm√°l not to the Gurjjaras of Broach, who, about the time of Dadda III. (C. 675–700 a.d.), ceased to call themselves Gurjjaras.

A few words must be said regarding the three grants from Il√°o, Umet√°, and Bagumr√° (Ind. Ant. XIII. 116, VII. 61, and XVII. 183) as their genuineness has been assumed by Dr. Bühler in his recent paper on the Mah√°bh√°rata, in spite of Mr. Fleet’s proof (Ind. Ant. XVIII. 19) that their dates do not work out correctly.

Dr. Bhagv√°nl√°l’s (Ind. Ant. XIII. 70) chief grounds for holding that the Umet√° and Il√°o grants (the Bagumr√° grant was unknown to him) were forgeries were:

  • (1) Their close resemblance in palæography to one another and to the forged grant of Dharasena II. of Valabhi dated Śaka 400;
  • (2) That though they purport to belong to the fifth century they bear the same writer’s name as the Kheḍ√° grants of the seventh century.

Further Mr. Fleet (Ind. Ant. XIII. 116) pointed out:

  • (3) That the description of Dadda I. in the Il√°o and Umet√° grants agrees almost literally with that of Dadda II. in the Kheḍ√° grants, and that where it differs the Kheḍ√° grants have the better readings.

To these arguments Dr. Bühler has replied (Ind. Ant. XVII. 183):

  • (1) That though there is a resemblance between these grants and that of Dharasena II., still it does not prove more than that the forger of Dharasena’s grant had one of the other grants before him;
  • (2) That, as the father’s name of the writer is not given in the Kheḍ√° grants, it cannot be assumed that he was the same person as the writer of the Il√°o and Umet√° grants; and [118]
    Chapter X.
    The Gurjjaras, a.d. 580–808.
  • (3) That genuine grants sometimes show that a description written for one king is afterwards applied to another, and that good or bad readings are no test of the age of a grant.

It may be admitted that Dr. Bühler has made it probable that the suspected grants and the grant of Dharasena were not all written by the same hand, and also that the coincidence in the writer’s name is not of much importance in itself. But the palæographical resemblance between Dharasena’s grant on the one hand and the doubtful Gurjjara grants on the other is so close that they must have been written at about the same time. As to the third point, the verbal agreement between the doubtful grants on the one hand and the Kheḍ√° grants on the other implies the existence of a continuous tradition in the record office of the dynasty from the end of the fifth till near the middle of the seventh century. But the Saṅkheḍ√° grant of Nirihullaka (Ep. Ind. II. 21) shows that towards the end of the sixth century the lower Narbad√° valley was occupied by jungle tribes who acknowledged the supremacy of the Kalachuris. Is it reasonable to suppose that after the first Gurjjara line was thus displaced, the restorers of the dynasty should have had any memory of the forms in which the first line drew up their grants? At any rate, if they had, they would also have retained their original seal, which, as the analogy of the Valabhi plates teaches us, would bear the founder’s name. But we find that the seal of the Kheḍ√° plates bears the name “S√°manta Dadda,” who can be no other than the “S√°manta Dadda” who ruled from C. 585–605 a.d. It follows that the Gurjjaras of the seventh century themselves traced back their history in Broach no further than a.d. 585. Again, it has been pointed out in the text that a passage in the description of Dadda II. (a.d. 620–650) in the Kheḍ√° grants seems to refer to his protection of the Valabhi king, so that the description must have been written for him and not for the fifth century Dadda as Dr. Bühler’s theory requires.

These points coupled with Mr. Fleet’s proof (Ind. Ant. XVIII. 91) that the Śaka dates do not work out correctly, may perhaps be enough to show that none of these three grants can be relied upon as genuine.—(A. M. T. J.)

[119]

2 See above page 107. ↑

3 That N√°ndor or N√°ndod was an old and important city is proved by the fact that Br√°hmans and V√°ni√°s called N√°ndor√°s that is of N√°ndor are found throughout Gujar√°t, M√°ngrol and Chorv√°d on the South K√°thi√°v√°ḍa coast have settlements of Vel√°ri betelvine cultivators who call themselves Nandora V√°ni√°s and apparently brought the betelvine from N√°ndod. Dr. Bühler, however, identifies the N√°ndípurí of the grants with an old fort of the same name about two miles north of the east gate of Broach. See Ind. Ant. VII. 62. ↑

4 Ind. Ant. XIII. 81, 88. ↑

5 Ind. Ant. XIII. 70. ↑

6 The fact that the Umet√° and Il√°o plates give their grantor Dadda II. the title of Mah√°r√°j√°dhir√°ja Supreme Lord of Great Kings, is one of the grounds for believing them forgeries. ↑

7 Ep. Ind. II. 20. ↑

8 Ep. Ind. II. 21. ↑

12 Ind. Ant. VI. 9, VII. 70. ↑

13 Ind. Ant. XIII. 81–88. ↑

14 Ind. Ant. VII. 70. ↑

16 Ind. Ant. XIII. 81–88, Ep. Ind. II. 19. ↑

24 Ind. Ant. V. 109, XIII. 70. The earlier grant was made from K√°y√°vat√°ra (K√°rw√°n): the later one is mutilated. ↑

25 Before a.d. 738–9. See Chap. IX. above. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER XI.

THE RÁSHṬRAKÚṬAS

(a.d. 743–974.)


Chapter XI.
The R√°shṭrakúṭas, a.d. 743–974. The R√°shṭrakúṭa connection with Gujar√°t lasted from Śaka 665 to 894 (a.d. 743–974) that is for 231 years. The connection includes three periods: A first of sixty-five years from Śaka 665 to 730 (a.d. 743–808) when the Gujar√°t ruler was dependent on the main Dakhan R√°shṭrakúṭa: a second of eighty years between Śaka 730 and 810 (a.d. 808–888) when the Gujar√°t family was on the whole independent: and a third of eighty-six years Śaka 810 to 896 (a.d. 888–974) when the Dakhan R√°shṭrakúṭas again exercised direct sway over Gujar√°t.

Their Origin.Information regarding the origin of the R√°shṭrakúṭas is imperfect. That the Gujar√°t R√°shṭrakúṭas came from the Dakhan in Śaka 665 (a.d. 743) is known. It is not known who the Dakhan R√°shṭrakúṭas originally were or where or when they rose to prominence. R√°thoḍ the dynastic name of certain Kanauj and M√°rw√°r R√°jputs represents a later form of the word R√°shṭrakúṭa. Again certain of the later inscriptions call the R√°shṭrakúṭas Raṭṭas a word which, so far as form goes, is hardly a correct Prakrit contraction of R√°shṭrakúṭa. The Sanskritisation of tribal names is not exact. If the name Raṭṭa was strange it might be pronounced Ratta, Ratha, or Raddi. This last form almost coincides with the modern K√°narese caste name Reddi, which, so far as information goes, would place the R√°shṭrakúṭas among the tribes of pre-Sanskrit southern origin.

Their Name.If Raṭṭa is the name of the dynasty kúṭa or kúḍa may be an attribute meaning prominent. The combination R√°shṭrakúṭa would then mean the chiefs or leaders as opposed to the rank and file of the Raṭṭas. The bardic accounts of the origin of the R√°thoḍs of Kanauj and M√°rw√°r vary greatly. According to a Jain account the R√°thoḍs, whose name is fancifully derived from the raht or spine of Indra, are connected with the Yavans through an ancestor Yavanaśva prince of P√°rlipur. The R√°thoḍ genealogies trace their origin to Kuśa son of R√°ma of the Solar Race. The bards of the [120]
Chapter XI.
The R√°shṭrakúṭas, a.d. 743–974.
Their Name. Solar Race hold them to be descendants of Hiraṇya Kaśipu by a demon or daitya mother. Like the other great R√°jput families the R√°thoḍs’ accounts contain no date earlier than the fifth century a.d. when (a.d. 470, S. 526) N√°in P√°l is said to have conquered Kanauj slaying its monarch Ajip√°l.1 The Dakhan R√°shṭrakúṭas (whose earliest known date is also about a.d. 450) call themselves of the Lunar Race and of the Yadu dynasty. Such contradictions leave only one of two origins to the tribe. They were either foreigners or southerners Br√°hmanised and included under the all-embracing term R√°jput.

Early Dynasty, a.d. 450–500.Of the rise of the R√°shṭrakúṭas no trace remains. The earliest known R√°shṭrakúṭa copperplate is of a king Abhimanyu. This plate is not dated. Still its letters, its style of writing, and its lion seal, older than the Garuḍa mark which the R√°shṭrakúṭas assumed along with the claim of Y√°dava descent, leave no doubt that this is the earliest of known R√°shṭrakúṭa plates. Its probable date is about a.d. 450. The plate traces the descent of Abhimanyu through two generations from M√°n√°ṅka. The details are:

M√°n√°ṅka.
Devar√°ja.
Bhavishya.
Abhimanyu.

The grant is dated from M√°napura, perhaps M√°n√°ṅka’s city, probably an older form of M√°nyakheṭa the modern M√°lkhed the capital of the later R√°shṭrakúṭas about sixty miles south-east of Shol√°pur. These details give fair ground for holding the M√°n√°ṅkas to be a family of R√°shṭrakúṭa rulers earlier than that which appears in the usual genealogy of the later R√°shṭrakúṭa dynasty (a.d. 500–972).

The Main Dynasty, a.d. 630–972.The earliest information regarding the later R√°shṭrakúṭas is from a comparatively modern, and therefore not quite trustworthy, Ch√°lukya copperplate of the eleventh century found by Mr. Wathen. This plate states that Jayasiṃha I. the earliest Ch√°lukya defeated the R√°shṭrakúṭa Indra son of Kṛishṇa the lord of 800 elephants. The date of this battle would be about a.d. 500. If historic the reference implies that the R√°shṭrakúṭas were then a well established dynasty. In most of their own plates the genealogy of the R√°shṭrakúṭas begins with Govinda about a.d. 680. But that Govinda was not the founder of the family is shown by Dantidurga’s Elura Daś√°vat√°ra inscription (about a.d. 750) which gives two earlier names Dantivarmman and Indra. The founding of R√°shṭrakúṭa power is therefore of doubtful date. Of the date of its overthrow there is no question. The overthrow came from the hand of the Western Ch√°lukya Tailappa in Śaka 894 (a.d. 972) during the reign of the last R√°shṭrakúṭa Kakka III. or Kakkala. [121]

R√°shṭrakúṭa Family Tree, a.d. 630–972.The following is the R√°shṭrakúṭa family tree:

1 Dantivarmman
(about a.d. 630).
2 Indra I.
(about a.d. 655).
3 Govinda I.
(about a.d. 680).
4 Kakka I.
or Karka I.
(about a.d. 705).
5 Indra II.
(about a.d. 730).		 Dhruva. 7 Kṛishṇa
(about a.d. 765).
Govinda.
6 Dantidurga, Dantivarmman
(Śaka 675, a.d. 753).
Kakka II.
Śaka 669 (a.d. 747).
8 Govinda II.
(about a.d. 780).		 9 Dhruva, Dh√°r√°varsha,
Nirupama, Dhora,
(about a.d. 795).
10 Govinda III. Prabhútavarsha Vallabhanarendra, Jagattuṅga Pṛithivívallabha,
(Śaka 725, 728, 729,
a.d. 803, 806, 807).		 I. Indra (founder of Gujar√°t Branch).
II. Karka
(Śaka 734, 738, 743,
a.d. 812, 816, 821).		 III. Govinda Prabhútavarsha,
(Śaka 749,
a.d. 827).
11 Amoghavarsha Śarvva, Durlabha Śrívallabha; Lakshmívallabha, Vallabha Skaṇḍa,
(Śaka 773, 799, a.d. 851, 877).
Dantivarmman (?) IV. Dhruva I. Dh√°r√°varsha, Nirupama,
(Śaka 757, a.d. 835).
12 Ak√°lavarsha Kṛishṇa II. Kannara
(about a.d. 880–911).
VII. Ak√°lavarsha-Kṛishṇa
(Śaka 810, a.d. 888).
V. Ak√°lavarsha Śubhatunga,
(a.d. 867).
Jagattunga
(did not reign.)		 VI. Dhruva II.
(Śaka 789, 793,
a.d. 867, 871).
13 Indra III. Pṛithivívallabha Raṭṭakandarpa, Kirttin√°r√°yana Nityaṃvarsha (Śaka 836, a.d. 914). 16 Baddiga
17 Kṛishṇa
(Ś. 867, 878
a.d. 945, 956).		 19 Kottiga. Nirupama.
14 Amoghavarsha 15 Govindar√°ja S√°has√°nka Suvarnavarsha. Kakkala or Karkar√°ja
(Śaka 894, a.d. 972).

Copperplates.The earliest Gujar√°t R√°shṭrakúṭa grant, Kakka’s of Śaka 669 (a.d. 747), comes from Ántroli-Ch√°roli in Surat. It is written on two plates in the Valabhi style of composition and form of letters, and, as in Valabhi grants, the date is at the end. Unlike Valabhi grants the era is the Śaka era. The grant gives the following genealogy somewhat different from that of other known R√°shṭrakúṭa grants:

Kakka.
Dhruva.
Govinda.
Kakka II.
(Śaka 669, a.d. 747).

[122]


Chapter XI.
The R√°shṭrakúṭas, a.d. 743–974.
Kakka II. a.d. 747. Kakka II. a.d. 747.The plate notices that Kakka the grantor was the son of Govinda by his wife the daughter of the illustrious N√°gavarmman. Kakka is further described by the feudatory title ‘Samadhigatapanchmah√°śabdaḥ’ Holder of the five great names. At the same time he is also called Paramabhaṭṭ√°raka-Mah√°r√°ja Great Lord Great King, attributes which seem to imply a claim to independent power. The grant is dated the bright seventh of Áśvayuja, Śaka 669 (a.d. 747). The date is almost contemporary with the year of Dantidurga in the S√°mangad plate (a.d. 753). As Dantidurga was a very powerful monarch we may identify the first Kakka of this plate with Kakka I. the grandfather of Dantidurga and thus trace from Dhruva Kakka’s son a branch of feudatory R√°shṭrakúṭas ruling in M√°lwa or Gujar√°t, whose leaders were Dhruva, his son Govinda, and Govinda’s son Kakka II. Further Dantidurga’s grant shows that he conquered Central Gujar√°t between the Mahí and the Narbad√°2 while his Elura Daś√°vat√°ra inscription (a.d. 750) shows that he held L√°ṭa and M√°lava.3 Dantidurga’s conquest of Central Gujar√°t seems to have been signalised by grants of land made by his mother in every village of the M√°tri division which is apparently the M√°tar t√°luka of the Kaira district.4 It is possible that Dantidurga gave conquered Gujar√°t to his paternal cousin’s son and contemporary Kakka, the grantor of the Ántroli plate (a.d. 747), as the representative of a family ruling somewhere under the overlordship of the main Dakhan R√°shṭrakúṭas. Karka’s Baroda grant5 (a.d. 812) supports this theory. Dantidurga died childless and was succeeded by his uncle Kṛishṇa. Of this Kṛishṇa the Baroda grant says that he assumed the government for the good of the family after having rooted out a member of the family who had taken to mischief-making. It seems probable that Kakka II. the grantor of the Ántroli plate is the mischief-maker and that his mischief was, on the death of Dantidurga, the attempt to secure the succession to himself. Kṛishṇa frustrated Kakka’s attempt and rooted him out so effectively that no trace of Kakka’s family again appears.

Kṛishṇa and Govinda II. a.d. 765–795.From this it follows that, so far as is known, the R√°shṭrakúṭa conquest of Gujar√°t begins with Dantidurga’s conquest of L√°ṭa, that is South Gujar√°t between the Mahí and the Narbad√°, from the Gurjjara king Jayabhaṭa whose latest known date is a.d. 736 or seventeen years before the known date of Dantidurga. The Gurjjaras probably retired to the R√°jpipla hills and further east on the confines of M√°lwa where they may have held a lingering sway.6 No Gujar√°t event of importance is recorded during the reign of Kṛishṇa (a.d. 765) or of his son Govinda II. (a.d. 780) who about [123]
Chapter XI.
The R√°shṭrakúṭas, a.d. 743–974.
Kṛishṇa and Govinda II. a.d. 765–795. a.d. 795 was superseded by his powerful younger brother Dhruva.7

Dhruva I. a.d. 795.Dhruva was a mighty monarch whose conquests spread from South India as far north as Allah√°b√°d. During Dhruva’s lifetime his son Govinda probably ruled at Mayúrakhandi or Morkhanda in the N√°sik district and held the Gh√°t country and the Gujar√°t coast from Bals√°r northwards. Though according to a Kapadvanj grant Govinda had several brothers the R√°dhanpur (a.d. 808) and Van-Dindori (a.d. 808) grants of his son Govinda III. state that his father, seeing Govinda’s supernatural Kṛishṇa-like powers, offered him the sovereignty of the whole world. Govinda declined, saying, The Kaṇṭhik√° or coast tract already given to me is enough. Seeing that Mayúrakhandi or Morkhanda in N√°sik was Govinda’s capital, this Kaṇṭhik√° appears to be the coast from Bals√°r northwards.

Govinda III. a.d. 800–808.According to Gujar√°t Govinda’s (a.d. 827–833) K√°ví grant (a.d. 827), finding his power threatened by Stambha and other kings, Dhruva made the great Govinda independent during his own lifetime. This suggests that while Dhruva continued to hold the main R√°shṭrakúṭa sovereignty in the Dakhan, he probably invested Govinda with the sovereignty of Gujar√°t. This fact the K√°ví grant (a.d. 827) being a Gujar√°t grant would rightly mention while it would not find a place in the R√°dhanpur (a.d. 808) and Van-Dindori (a.d. 808) grants of the main R√°shṭrakúṭas. Of the kings who opposed Govinda the chief was Stambha who may have some connection with Cambay, as, during the time of the Aṇahilav√°ḍa kings, Cambay came to be called Stambha-tírtha instead of by its old name of Gambhút√°. According to the grants the allied chiefs were no match for Govinda. The Gurjjara fled through fear, not returning even in dreams, and the M√°lava king submitted. Who the Gurjjara was it is hard to say. He may have belonged to some Gurjjara dynasty that rose to importance after Dantidurga’s conquest or the name may mean a ruler of the Gurjjara country. In either case some North Gujar√°t ruler is meant whose conquest opened the route from Broach to M√°lwa. From M√°lwa Govinda marched to the Vindhyas where the king apparently of East M√°lwa named M√°r√° Śarva submitted to Govinda paying tribute. From the Vindhyas Govinda returned to Gujar√°t passing the rains at Śríbhavana,8 apparently Sarbhon in the Ámod t√°luka of Broach, a favourite locality which he had ruled during his father’s lifetime. After the rains Govinda went south as far as the Tungabhadra. On starting for the south Govinda handed Gujar√°t to his brother Indra with whom begins the Gujar√°t branch of the R√°shṭrakúṭas. Several plates distinctly mention that Indra was given the kingdom of the lord of L√°ṭa by (his brother) Govinda. Other Gujar√°t grants, apparently with intent to show that Indra won Gujar√°t and did not receive it in gift, after mentioning Śarvva Amoghavarsha as the successor of Govinda (a.d. 818), state that the king (apparently of Gujar√°t) was Śarvva’s uncle Indra. [124]


Chapter XI.
The R√°shṭrakúṭas, a.d. 743–974.
Indra, a.d. 808–812. Indra, a.d. 808–812.As Govinda III. handed Gujar√°t to his brother Indra about Śaka 730 (a.d. 808) and as the grant of Indra’s son Karka is dated Śaka 734 (a.d. 812) Indra’s reign must have been short. Indra is styled the ruler of the entire kingdom of L√°ṭeśvara,9 the protector of the mandala of L√°ṭa given to him by his lord. An important verse in an unpublished Baroda grant states that Indra chased the lord of Gurjjara who had prepared to fight, and that he honourably protected the multitude of Dakhan (Dakshiṇ√°patha) feudatories (mah√°s√°mantas) whose glory was shattered by Śrívallabha (that is Śarvva or Amoghavarsha)10 then heir-apparent of Govinda. That is, in attempting to establish himself in independent power, Indra aided certain of the R√°shṭrakúṭa feudatories in an effort to shake off the overlordship of Amoghavarsha.

Karka I. a.d. 812–821.Indra was succeeded by his son Karka I. who is also called Suvarṇavarsha and P√°t√°lamalla. Karka reversed his father’s policy and loyally accepted the overlordship of the main R√°shṭrakúṭas. Three grants of Karka’s remain, the Baroda grant dated Śaka 734 (a.d. 812), and two unpublished grants from Navs√°rí and Surat dated respectively Śaka 738 (a.d. 816) and Śaka 743 (a.d. 821). Among Doctor Bhagv√°nl√°l’s collection of inscriptions bequeathed to the British Museum the Baroda grant says that Karka’s sv√°mi or lord, apparently Govinda III., made use of Karka’s arm to protect the king of M√°lava against invasion by the king of Gurjjara who had become puffed up by conquering the lords of Gauḍa and Vanga that is modern Bengal. This powerful Gurjjara king who conquered countries so distant as Bengal has not been identified. He must have been ruling north of the Mahí and threatened an invasion of M√°lwa by way of Dohad. He may have been either a Valabhi king or one of the Bhinm√°l Gurjjaras, who, during the decline of the Valabhis, and with the help of their allies the Ch√°vaḍ√°s of Aṇahilav√°ḍa whose leader at this time was Yog R√°ja (a.d. 806–841), may have extended their dominion as far south as the Mahí. As the Baroda plate (a.d. 812) makes no mention of Amoghavarsha-Śarvva while the Navs√°rí plate (a.d. 816) mentions him as the next king after Govinda III. it follows that Govinda III. died and Amoghavarsha succeeded between a.d. 812 and 816 (Ś. 734 and 738). This supports Mr. Fleet’s conclusion, on the authority of Amoghavarsha’s Sirur inscription, that he came to the throne in Śaka 736 (a.d. 814).
