R√°nakadeví was the daughter of a potter of Majev√°di village about nine miles north of Jun√°gaḍh, so famous for her beauty that Siddhar√°ja determined to marry her. Meanwhile she had accepted an offer from Kheng√°r whose subject she was and had married him. Siddhar√°ja enraged at her marriage advanced against Kheng√°r, took him prisoner, and annexed Sorath. That Kheng√°r’s kingdom was annexed and Sajjana, mentioned by Jinaprabhasúri, was appointed Viceroy is proved by a Girn√°r inscription dated a.d. 1120 (S. 1176).

An era called the Siṃha Saṃvatsara connected with the name of Jayasiṃha and beginning with a.d. 1113–1114 (S. 1169–70), occurs in several inscriptions found about Prabh√°sa and South K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. This era was probably started in that year in honour of this conquest of Kheng√°r and Sorath.66 The earliest known mention of the Siṃha Saṃvatsara era occurs in a step-well at M√°ngrol called the Sodhali V√°v. The inscription is of the time of Kum√°rap√°la and mentions Sahajiga the father of Múlaka the grantor as a member of the bodyguard of the Ch√°lukyas. The inscription states that Sahajiga had several sons able to protect Saur√°shṭra, one of whom was Somar√°ja who built the temple of Sahajigeśvara, in the enclosure of the Soman√°tha temple at Prabh√°sa; another was Múlaka the n√°yaka of Sur√°shṭra, who is recorded to have made grants for the worship of the god by establishing cesses in Mangalapura or M√°ngrol and other places. The inscription is dated a.d. 1146 (Monday the 13th of the dark half of Aśvín Vikrama S. 1202 and Siṃha S. 32). This inscription supports the view that the Siṃha era was established by Jayasiṃha, since if the era belonged to some other local chief, no Ch√°lukya viceroy would adopt it. The Siṃha era appears to have been kept up in Gujar√°t so long as Aṇahilapura rule lasted. The well known Ver√°val inscription of the time of Arjuṇadeva is dated Hijri 662, Vikrama S. 1320, Valabhi S. 945, Siṃha S. 151, Sunday the 13th of Ásh√°ḍha Vadi. This inscription shows that the Siṃha era was in use for a century and a half during the sovereignty of Aṇahilav√°ḍa in Sur√°shṭra.

Regarding Sajjana Siddhar√°ja’s first viceroy in Sur√°shṭra, the Prabandhachint√°maṇi says that finding him worthy the king appointed Sajjana the daṇḍ√°dhipati of Sur√°shṭradeśa. Without consulting his master Sajjana spent three years’ revenue in building a stone temple of [177]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Siddhar√°ja Jayasingha, a.d. 1094–1143. Nemin√°tha on Girn√°r instead of a wooden temple which he removed. In the fourth year the king sent four officers to bring Sajjana to Aṇahilav√°ḍa. The king called on Sajjana to pay the revenues of the past three years. In reply Sajjana asked whether the king would prefer the revenue in cash or the merit which had accrued from spending the revenue in building the temple. Preferring the merit the king sanctioned the spending of the revenues on the Tírtha and Sajjana was reappointed governor of Sorath.67 This stone temple of Sajjana would seem to be the present temple of Nemin√°tha, though many alterations have been made in consequence of Muhammadan sacrilege and a modern enclosure has been added. The inscription of Sajjana which is dated a.d. 1120 (S. 1176) is on the inside to the right in passing to the small south gate. It contains little but the mention of the S√°dhu who was Sajjana’s constant adviser. On his return from a second pilgrimage to Soman√°tha Siddhar√°ja who was encamped near Raivataka that is Girn√°r expressed a wish to see Sajjana’s temple. But the Br√°hmans envious of the Jains persuaded the king that as Girn√°r was shaped like a liṅg it would be sacrilege to climb it. Siddhar√°ja respected this objection and worshipped at the foot of the mountain. From Girn√°r he went to Śatruñjaya. Here too Br√°hmans with drawn swords tried to prevent the king ascending the hill. Siddhar√°ja went in disguise at night, worshipped the Jain god Ádíśvara with Ganges water, and granted the god twelve neighbouring villages. On the hill he saw so luxuriant a growth of the s√°llaki a plant dear to elephants, that he proposed to make the hill a breeding place for elephants a second Vindhya. He was reminded what damage wild elephants would cause to the holy place and for this reason abandoned his plan.

Siddhar√°ja’s second and greater war was with M√°lwa. The cotemporary kings of M√°lwa were the Param√°ra ruler Naravarman who flourished from a.d. 1104 to 1133 (S. 1160–1189) and his son and successor Yaśovarman who ruled up to a.d. 1143 (S. 1199) the year of Siddhar√°ja’s death As the names of both these kings occur in different accounts of this war, and, as the war is said to have lasted twelve years, it seems that fighting began in the time of Naravarman and that Siddhar√°ja’s final victory was gained in the time of Yaśovarman in Siddhar√°ja’s old age about a.d. 1134 (S. 1190). This view is supported by the local story that his expedition against Yaśovarman was undertaken while Siddhar√°ja was building the Sahasraliṅga lake and other religious works. It is not known how the war arose but the statement of the Prabandhachint√°maṇi that Siddhar√°ja vowed to make a scabbard of Yaśovarman’s skin seems to show that Siddhar√°ja received grave provocation. Siddhar√°ja is said to have left the building of the Sahasraliṅga lake to the masons and architects and himself to have [178]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Siddhar√°ja Jayasingha, a.d. 1094–1143. started for M√°lwa. The war dragged on and there seemed little hope of victory when news reached Siddhar√°ja that the three south gates of Dh√°r√° could be forced. With the help of an elephant an entrance was effected. Yaśovarman was captured and bound with six ropes, and, with his captured enemy as his banner of victory, Siddhar√°ja returned to Aṇahilapura. He remembered his vow, but being prevented from carrying it out, he took a little of Yaśovarman’s skin and adding other skin to it made a scabbard. The captured king was thenceforward kept in a cage. It was this complete conquest and annexation of M√°lwa that made Siddhar√°ja assume the style of Avantín√°tha ‘Lord of Avantí,’ which is mentioned as his biruḍa or title in most of the Chaulukya copperplates.68 M√°lwa henceforward remained subject to Aṇahilav√°ḍa. On the return from M√°lwa an army of Bhíls who tried to block the way were attacked by the minister S√°ntu and put to flight.

Siddhar√°ja’s next recorded war is with king Madanavarman the Chandela king of Mahobaka the modern Mahob√° in Bundelkhand. Madanavarman, of whom General Cunningham has found numerous inscriptions dating from a.d. 1130 to 1164 (S. 1186–1220),69 was one of the most famous kings of the Chandela dynasty. An inscription of one of his successors in K√°lanjar fort records that Madanavarman ‘in an instant defeated the king of Gurjjara, as Kṛishṇa in former times defeated Kaṃsa,70 a statement which agrees with the Gujar√°t accounts of the war between him and Jayasiṃha. In this conflict the Gujar√°t accounts do not seem to show that Siddhar√°ja gained any great victory; he seems to have been contented with a money present. The Kírtikaumudí states that the king of Mahobaka honoured Siddhar√°ja as his guest and paid a fine and tribute by way of hospitality. The account in the Kum√°rap√°lacharita suggests that Siddhar√°ja was compelled to come to terms and make peace. According to the Kírtikaumudí, and this seems likely, Siddhar√°ja went from Dh√°r√° to K√°lanjara. The account in the Prabandhachint√°maṇi is very confused. According to the Kum√°rap√°lacharita, on Siddhar√°ja’s way back from Dh√°r√° at his camp near Patan a bard came to the court and said to the king that his court was as wonderful as the court of Madanavarman. The bard said that Madanavarman was the king of the city of Mahobaka and most clever, wise, liberal, and pleasure-loving. The king sent a courtier to test the truth of the bard’s statement. The courtier returned after six months declaring that the bard’s account was in no way exaggerated. Hearing this Siddhar√°ja at once started against Mahobaka and encamping within sixteen miles of the city sent his minister to summon Madanavarman to surrender. Madanavarman who was enjoying himself took little notice of the minister. This king, he said, is the same who had to fight twelve years with Dh√°r√°; if, as is probable, since he is a kab√°di or wild king, he wants money, pay him what he wants. The money [179]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Siddhar√°ja Jayasingha, a.d. 1094–1143. was paid. But Siddhar√°ja was so struck with Madanavarman’s indifference that he would not leave until he had seen him. Madanavarman agreed to receive him. Siddhar√°ja went with a large bodyguard to the royal garden which contained a palace and enclosed pleasure-house and was guarded by troops. Only four of Siddhar√°ja’s guards were allowed to enter. With these four men Siddhar√°ja went in, was shown the palace garden and pleasure-houses by Madanavarman, was treated with great hospitality, and on his return to Patan was given a guard of 120 men.

The Dvy√°śraya says that after his conquest of Ujjain Siddhar√°ja seized and imprisoned the king of a neighbouring country named Sim. We have no other information on this point.

The Dohad inscription dated a.d. 1140 mentions the destruction of Sindhur√°ja that is the king of Sindh and other kings. The Kírtikaumudí also mentions the binding of the lord of Sindhu. Nothing is known regarding the Sindh war. The Kírtikaumudí mentions that after a war with Arṇor√°ja king of S√°mbhar Siddhar√°ja gave his daughter to Arṇor√°ja. This seems to be a mistake as the war and alliance with Arṇor√°ja belong to Kum√°rap√°la’s reign.

Siddhar√°ja, who like his ancestors was a Śaiva, showed his zeal for the faith by constructing the two grandest works in Gujar√°t the Rudramah√°laya at Sidhpur and the Sahasraliṅga lake at Patan. The Jain chroniclers always try to show that Siddhar√°ja was favourably inclined to Jainism. But several of his acts go against this claim and some even show a dislike of the Jains. It is true that the Jain sage Hem√°ch√°rya lived with the king, but the king honoured him as a scholar rather than as a Jain. On the occasion of the pilgrimage to Soman√°tha the king offered Hem√°ch√°rya a palanquin, and, as he would not accept the offer but kept on walking, the king blamed him calling him a learned fool with no worldly wisdom. Again on one occasion while returning from M√°lwa Siddhar√°ja encamped at a place called Śrínagara, where the people had decorated their temples with banners in honour of the king. Finding a banner floating over a Jain temple the king asked in anger who had placed it there, as he had forbidden the use of banners on Jain shrines and temples in Gujar√°t. On being told that it was a very old shrine dating from the time of Bharata, the king ordered that at the end of a year the banner might be replaced. This shows the reverse of a leaning to Jainism. Similarly, according to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi, Hem√°ch√°rya never dared to speak to the king in favour of Jainism but used to say that all religions were good. This statement is supported by the fact that the opening verses of all works written by Hem√°ch√°rya in the time of Siddhar√°ja contain no special praise of Jain deities.

So great is Siddhar√°ja’s fame as a builder that almost every old work in Gujar√°t is ascribed to him. Tradition gives him the credit of the Dabhoi fort which is of the time of the V√°ghel√° king Víradhavala, a.d. 1220–1260. The Prabandhachint√°maṇi gives this old verse regarding Siddhar√°ja’s public works: ‘No one makes a great temple (Rudramah√°laya), a great pilgrimage (to Soman√°tha), a great Ásth√°na (darb√°r hall), or a great lake (Sahasraliṅga) [180]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Siddhar√°ja Jayasingha, a.d. 1094–1143. such as Siddhar√°ja made.’71 Of these the Rudramah√°laya, though very little is left, from its size and the beauty of its carving, must have been a magnificent work the grandest specimen of the architecture of the Solaṅki period. The remains of the Sahasraliṅga lake at Aṇahilapura show that it must have been a work of surprising size and richness well deserving its title of mah√°saraḥ or great lake. Numerous other public works are ascribed to Siddhar√°ja.72

At this period it seems that the kings of Gujar√°t S√°mbhar and other districts, seeing the great reputation which his literary tastes had gained for Bhoja of Dh√°r√° used all to keep Pandits. Certain carvings on the pillars of a mosque at the south-west of the modern town of Dh√°r√° show that the building almost as it stands was the Sanskrit school founded by Bhoja. The carvings in question are beautifully cut Sanskrit grammar tables. Other inscriptions in praise of Naravarman show that Bhoja’s successors continued to maintain the institution. In the floor of the mosque are many large shining slabs of black marble, the largest as much as seven feet long, all of them covered with inscriptions so badly mutilated that nothing can be made out of them except that they were Sanskrit and Prakrit verses in honour of some prince. On a rough estimate the slabs contain as many as 4000 verses.73 According to the old saying any one who drank of the Sarasvatí well in Dh√°r√° became a scholar. Sarasvatí’s well still exists near the mosque. Its water is good and it is still known as Akkal-kui or the Well of Talent. As in Dh√°r√° so in Ajmir the Aṛh√°í-dink√° Jhopḍ√° mosque is an old Sanskrit school, recent excavations having brought to light slabs with entire dramas carved on them. So also the Gujar√°t kings had their Pandits and their halls of learning. Śríp√°la, Siddhar√°ja’s poet-laureate, wrote a poetical eulogium or praśasti on the Sahasraliṅga lake. According to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi Siddhar√°ja gathered numerous Pandits to examine the eulogium. As has already been noticed Siddhar√°ja’s constant companion was the great scholar and Jain √°ch√°rya Hemachandra also called Hem√°ch√°rya, who, under the king’s patronage, wrote a treatise on grammar called Siddhahema, and also the well-known Dvy√°śrayakosha which was intended to teach both grammar and the history of the Solaṅkis. Hemachandra came into even greater [181]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Siddhar√°ja Jayasingha, a.d. 1094–1143. prominence in the time of Kum√°rap√°la, when he wrote several further works and became closely connected with the state religion. Several stories remain of Siddhar√°ja assembling poets, and holding literary and poetic discussions.

Record is preserved of a sabh√° or assembly called by the king to hear discussions between a Śvet√°mbara Jaina √°ch√°rya named Bhaṭṭ√°raka Devasúri and a Digambara Jaina √°ch√°rya named Kumudachandra who had come from the Karṇ√°ṭak. Devasúri who was living and preaching in the Jain temple of Arishṭanemi at Karṇ√°vatí,74 that is the modern Ahmad√°b√°d, was there visited by Kumudachandra. Devasúri treated his visitor with little respect telling him to go to Patan and he would follow and hold a religious discussion or v√°da. Kumudachandra being a Digambara or skyclad Jaina went naked to Patan and Siddhar√°ja honoured him because he came from his mother’s country. Siddhar√°ja asked Hemachandra to hold a discussion with Kumudachandra and Hemachandra recommended that Devasúri should be invited as a worthy disputant. At a discussion held before a meeting called by the king Kumudachandra was vanquished, probably because the first principle of his Digambara faith that no woman can attain nirv√°ṇa, was insulting to the queen-mother, and the second that no clothes-wearing Jain can gain mukti or absorption, was an insult to the Jain ministers. The assembly, like Br√°hmanical sabh√°s at the present day, appears to have declined into noise and Siddhar√°ja had to interfere and keep order. Devasúri was complimented by the king and taken by one Áhada with great honour to his newly built Jaina temple.75

Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174.In spite of prayers to Soman√°tha, of incantations, and of gifts to Br√°hmans, Siddhar√°ja Jayasiṃha had no son. The throne passed into the line of Tribhuvanap√°la the great-grandson of Bhímadeva I. (a.d. 1074–62) who was ruling as a feudatory of Siddhar√°ja at his ancestral appanage of Dahithalí. Tribhuvanap√°la’s pedigree is Bhímadeva I.; his son Kshemar√°ja by Bakul√°deví a concubine; his son Harip√°la; his son Tribhuvanap√°la. By his queen K√°smíradeví Tribhuvanap√°la had three sons Mahíp√°la, Kírttip√°la, and Kum√°rap√°la, and two daughters Premaladeví and Devaladeví. Premaladeví was married to one of Siddhar√°ja’s nobles a cavalry general named K√°nhada or Kṛishṇadeva: Devaladeví was married to Arṇor√°ja76 or Anar√°ja [182]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. king of Ś√°kambhari or S√°mbhar, the Ánalladeva of the Hammíramah√°k√°vya. Kum√°rap√°la himself was married by his father to one Bhup√°ladeví. According to the Dvy√°śraya, Tribhuvanap√°la was on good terms with Siddhar√°ja serving him and going with him to war. The Kum√°rap√°lacharita also states that Kum√°rap√°la used to attend the court of Siddhar√°ja. But from the time he came to feel that he would have no son and that the bastard Kum√°rap√°la would succeed him Siddhar√°ja became embittered against Kum√°rap√°la. According to the Jain chronicles Siddhar√°ja was told by the god Soman√°tha, by the sage Hemachandra, by the goddess Ambik√° of Kodin√°r,77 and by astrologers that he would have no son and that Kum√°rap√°la would be his successor. According to the Kum√°rap√°lacharita so bitter did his hate grow that Siddhar√°ja planned the death of Tribhuvanap√°la and his family including Kum√°rap√°la. Tribhuvanap√°la was murdered but Kum√°rap√°la escaped. Grieved at this proof of the king’s hatred Kum√°rap√°la consulted his brother-in-law Kṛishṇadeva who advised him to leave his family at Dahithalí and go into exile promising to keep him informed of what went on at Aṇahilapura. Kum√°rap√°la left in the disguise of a jaṭ√°dh√°ri or recluse and escaped the assassins whom the king had ordered to slay him. After some time Kum√°rap√°la returned and in spite of his disguise was recognized by the guards. They informed the king who invited all the ascetics in the city to a dinner. Kum√°rap√°la came but noticing that the king recognized him in spite of his disguise, he fled. The king sent a trusted officer with a small force in pursuit. Kum√°rap√°la persuaded some husbandmen, the chief of whom was Bhímasiṃha, to hide him in a heap of thorns. The pursuers failing to find him returned. At night Kum√°rap√°la was let out bleeding from the thorns, and promised the husbandmen that the day would come when their help would be rewarded. He then shaved his topknot or jaṭ√° and while travelling met with a lady named Devaśrí of Udambara village who pitying him took him into her chariot and gave him food. Kum√°rap√°la promised to regard her as a sister. He then came to Dahithalí where the royal troops had already arrived. Siddhar√°ja sent an army which invested the village leaving Kum√°rap√°la without means of escape. He went to a potter named Sajjana or Aliṅga who hid him in the flues of his brick-kiln throwing hay over him. The troops searched the village, failed to find Kum√°rap√°la, and retired. The potter then helped Kum√°rap√°la from his hiding place and fed him. A former friend named Bosari joined Kum√°rap√°la and they went away together Kum√°rap√°la commending his family to the care of Sajjana. On the first day they had no food. Next day Bosari went to beg and they together ate the food given to Bosari in a monastery or maṭh where they slept. In time they came to Cambay where they called upon Hem√°ch√°rya and asked him their future. Hem√°ch√°rya knew and recognized Kum√°rap√°la. Kum√°rap√°la asked when fate would bless him. Before Hem√°ch√°rya [183]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. could reply Udayana, one of the king’s ministers, came. Hem√°ch√°rya said to Udayana, ‘This is Kum√°rap√°la who shall shortly be your king.’ Hem√°ch√°rya also gave Kum√°rap√°la a writing stating that he would succeed to the throne. Kum√°rap√°la acknowledged his obligations to Hem√°ch√°rya and promised to follow his advice. Udayana took him to his house and gave him food and clothes. Siddhar√°ja came to know of this and sent his soldiers who began to search. Kum√°rap√°la returned to Hem√°ch√°rya who hid him in a cellar covering its door with manuscripts and palm leaves. The soldiers came but failed to search under the manuscripts and returned. Kum√°rap√°la acknowledged his obligations to Hem√°ch√°rya and said he owed him two great debts one for telling him the day on which he would come to the throne; the other for saving his life. Kum√°rap√°la left Cambay at midnight, the minister Udayana supplying him with provisions. From Cambay he went to Vaṭapadrapura probably Baroda, where feeling hungry he entered the shop of a V√°nia named Katuka and asked for parched gram. The V√°nia gave the gram and seeing that Kum√°rap√°la had no money accepted his promise of future payment. From Baroda he came to Bhrigukachh or Broach where he saw a soothsayer and asked him his future. The soothsayer, seeing the bird kali-deví perched on the temple flagstaff, said ‘You will shortly be king.’ Kum√°rap√°la shaved his matted hair and went from Broach to Ujjain where he met his family. But as here too the royal troops followed him he fled to Kolh√°pura where he came across a Yogí who foretold his succession to a throne and gave him two spells or manṭras. From Kolh√°pura Kum√°rap√°la went to K√°ñchí or Conjeveram and from there to the city of K√°lambapattana.78 The king of K√°lambapattana Prat√°pasiṃha received him like an elder brother and brought him into his city, built a temple of Śivananda Kum√°rap√°leśvara in his honour, and even issued a coin called a Kum√°rap√°la. From K√°lambapattana Kum√°rap√°la went to Chitrakúṭa or Chitor and from there to Ujjain whence he took his family to Siddhapura going on alone to Aṇahilapura to see his brother-in-law Kṛishṇadeva. According to the Vich√°raśreṇi Siddhar√°ja died soon after in a.d. 1143 on the 3rd of K√°rttika Śuddha Saṃvat 1199.

In the dissensions that followed the king’s death Kum√°rap√°la’s interests were well served by his brother-in-law Kṛishṇadeva. Eventually the names of three candidates, Kum√°rap√°la and two others, were laid before the state nobles sitting in council to determine who should be king. Of the three candidates the two others were found wanting, and Kum√°rap√°la was chosen and installed according to the Vich√°raśreṇi on the 4th of M√°rgaśírsha Suddha and according to the Kum√°rap√°laprabandha on the 4th of M√°rgaśírsha Vadhya. At the time of his succession, according to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi and the Kum√°rap√°laprabandha, Kum√°rap√°la was about fifty years of age. [184]


Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. On his accession Kum√°rap√°la installed his wife Bhup√°ladeví his anointed queen or pattar√°ni; appointed Udayana who had befriended him at Cambay minister; B√°haḍa or V√°gbhaṭa son of Udayana79 chief councillor or mah√°m√°tya; and Aliṅga second councillor or mah√°pradh√°na. Áhada or Árabhaṭṭa, apparently another son of Udayana, did not acknowledge Kum√°rap√°la and went over to Arṇor√°ja Án√°ka or Ano king of Sap√°dalaksha or the S√°mbhar territory who is probably the same as the Ánalladeva of the Hammíramah√°k√°vya.80

The potter Sajjana was rewarded with a grant of seven hundred villages near Chitrakúṭa or Chitoḍa fort in R√°jput√°na, and the author of the Prabandhachint√°maṇi notices that in his time the descendants of the potter ashamed of their origin called themselves descendants of Sagara. Bhímasiṃha who hid Kum√°rap√°la in the thorns was appointed head of the bodyguard; Devaśrí made the sister’s mark on the royal forehead at the time of Kum√°rap√°la’s installation and was granted the village of Devayo;81 and Katuka the V√°ni√° of Baroda, who had given Kum√°rap√°la parched gram was granted the village of Vaṭapadra or Baroda. Bosari Kum√°rap√°la’s chief companion was given L√°ṭamaṇdala, which seems to mean that he was appointed viceroy of L√°ṭa or South Gujar√°t.

Kanhada or Kṛishṇadeva Kum√°rap√°la’s brother-in-law and adviser overvaluing his great services became arrogant and disobedient insulting the king in open court. As remonstrance was of no avail the king had Kṛishṇadeva waylaid and beaten by a band of athletes and taken almost dying to his wife the king’s sister. From this time all the state officers were careful to show ready obedience.

The old ministry saw that under so capable and well served a ruler their power was gone. They accordingly planned to slay the king and place their own nominee on the throne. The king heard of the plot: secured the assassins: and employed them in murdering the conspirators. According to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi, Áhada or Árabhaṭṭa who had gone over to the S√°mbhar king and was in charge of the S√°mbhar infantry, bribed the local nobles as a preliminary to a war which he had planned against Kum√°rap√°la. He so far succeeded as to bring Ána or Án√°ka the S√°mbhar king with the whole of his army to the borders of Gujar√°t to fight Kum√°rap√°la. Kum√°rap√°la went to meet Án√°ka. But, in consequence of intrigues, in the battle that followed the Gujar√°t army did not obey orders. Kum√°rap√°la advanced in front on an elephant, and B√°haḍa trying to climb on Kum√°rap√°la’s elephant was thrown to the ground and slain. Án√°ka was also pierced with arrows and the S√°mbhar army was defeated and plundered of its horses.82 [185]


Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. The Dvy√°śraya, probably by the aid of the author’s imagination, gives a fuller account of this war. One fact of importance recorded in the Dvy√°śraya is that Án√°ka though defeated was not slain, and, to bring hostilities to an end, gave his daughter Jalhaṇ√° to Kum√°rap√°la in marriage.83 The Kum√°rap√°lacharita calls the S√°mbhar king Arṇor√°ja and says that it was Kum√°rap√°la who invaded the S√°mbhar territory. According to this account Kum√°rap√°la went to Chandr√°vatí near Ábu and taking its Param√°ra king Vikramasiṃha with him marched to Ś√°kambhari or S√°mbhar and fought Arṇor√°ja who was defeated but not killed. Kum√°rap√°la threatened to cut out Arṇor√°ja’s tongue but let him go on condition that his people wore a headdress with a tongue on each side. Arṇor√°ja is said to have been confined in a cage for three days and then reinstalled as Kum√°rap√°la’s feudatory. Vikramasiṃha of Chandr√°vatí, who in the battle had sided with Arṇor√°ja, was punished by being disgraced before the assembled seventy-two feudatories at Aṇahilav√°ḍa and was sent to prison, his throne being given to his nephew Yaśodhavala. After his victory over Arṇor√°ja Kum√°rap√°la fought, defeated, and, according to the Kírtikaumudí, beheaded Ball√°la king of M√°lwa who had invaded Gujar√°t. The result of this contest seems to have been to reduce M√°lwa to its former position of dependence on the Aṇahilav√°ḍa kings. More than one inscription of Kum√°rap√°la’s found in the temple of Uday√°ditya as far north as Udayapura near Bhilsa shows that he conquered the whole of M√°lwa, as the inscriptions are recorded by one who calls himself Kum√°rap√°la’s general or daṇḍan√°yaka.84

Another of Kum√°rap√°la’s recorded victories is over Mallik√°rjuna said to be king of the Konkan who we know from published lists of the North Konkan Śil√°h√°ras flourished about a.d. 1160. The author of the Prabandhachint√°maṇi says this war arose from a bard of king Mallik√°rjuna speaking of him before king Kum√°rap√°la as R√°japit√°maha or grandfather of kings.85 Kum√°rap√°la annoyed at so arrogant a title looked around. Ámbaḍ√°,86 one of the sons of Udayana, divining the king’s meaning, raised his folded hands to his forehead and expressed his readiness to fight Mallik√°rjuna. The king sent him with an army which marched to the Konkan without halting. At the crossing of the Kal√°viní it was met and defeated by Mallik√°rjuna. Ámbaḍ√° returned in disgrace and shrouding himself, his umbrella and his tents in crape retreated to Aṇahilav√°ḍa. The king finding Ámbada though humiliated ready to make a second venture gave him a larger and better appointed force. With this army Ámbaḍ√° again started for the Konkan, crossed the Kal√°viní, attacked Mallik√°rjuna, and in a hand-to-hand fight [186]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. climbed his elephant and cut off his head. This head cased in gold with other trophies of the war he presented to the king on his triumphant return to Aṇahilapura. The king was greatly pleased and gave Ámbaḍ√° the title of R√°japit√°maha. Of this Mallik√°rjuna two stone inscriptions have been found one at Chiplún dated a.d. 1156 (Śaka 1078) the other at Bassein dated a.d. 1160 (Śaka 1082). If the story that Mallik√°rjuna was slain is true the war must have taken place during the two years between a.d. 1160 and 1162 (Śaka 1082, 1084) which latter is the earliest known date of Mallik√°rjuna’s successor Apar√°ditya.

The Kum√°rap√°lacharita also records a war between Kum√°rap√°la and Samara king of Sur√°shṭra or south K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, the Gujar√°t army being commanded by Kum√°rap√°la’s minister Udayana. The Prabandhachint√°maṇi gives Sausara as the name of the Sur√°shṭra king87: possibly he was some Gohilv√°d Mehr chief. Udayana came with the army to Vadhw√°n, and letting it advance went to P√°lit√°na. While he was worshipping at P√°lit√°na, a mouse carried away the burning wick of the lamp. Reflecting on the risk of fire in a wooden temple Udayana determined to rebuild the temple of stone. In the fight with Sausara the Gujar√°t army was defeated and Udayana was mortally wounded.88 Before Udayana died he told his sons that he had meant to repair the temple of Ádíśvara on Śatruñjaya and the Śakunik√° Vih√°ra at Broach and also to build steps up the west face of Girn√°r. His sons B√°haḍa and Ámbaḍ√° promised to repair the two shrines. Subsequently both shrines were restored, Kum√°rap√°la and Hem√°ch√°rya and the council of Aṇahilapura attending at the installation of Suvṛittin√°tha in the Śakunik√° Vih√°ra. The Girn√°r steps were also cut, according to more than one inscription in a.d. 1166 (S. 1222).89 This war and Udayana’s death must have occurred about a.d. 1149 (S. 1205) as the temple of Ádn√°tha was finished in a.d. 1156–57 (S. 1211). B√°haḍa also established near Śatruñjaya a town called B√°haḍapura and adorned it with a temple called Tribhuvanap√°lavasati.90 After the fight with Sausara Kum√°rap√°la was threatened with another war by Karṇa91 king of D√°hala or Chedi. Spies informed the king of the [187]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. impending invasion as he was starting on a pilgrimage to Soman√°tha. Next day he was relieved from anxiety by the news that while sleeping on an elephant at night king Karṇa’s necklace became entangled in the branch of a banyan tree, and the elephant suddenly running away, the king was strangled.

The Prabandhachint√°maṇi records an expedition against S√°mbhar which was entrusted to Ch√°haḍa a younger brother of B√°haḍa. Though Ch√°haḍa was known to be extravagant, the king liked him, and after giving him advice placed him in command. On reaching S√°mbhar Ch√°haḍa invested the fort of B√°br√°nagar but did not molest the people as on that day 700 brides had to be married.92 Next day the fort was entered, the city was plundered, and the supremacy of Kum√°rap√°la was proclaimed. This B√°br√°nagar has not been identified. There appears to be some confusion and the place may not be in S√°mbhar but in B√°bari√°v√°ḍa in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. Ch√°haḍa returned triumphant to Patan. The king expressed himself pleased but blamed Ch√°haḍa for his lavish expenditure and conferred on him the title of R√°ja-gharatta the King-grinder.

Though the Gujar√°t chronicles give no further details an inscription in the name of Kum√°rap√°la in a temple at Udepur near Bhilsa dated a.d. 1166 records that on Monday, Akshaya tritiy√° the 3rd of Vaiś√°kh Sud (S. 1222), Thakkara Ch√°haḍa granted half the village of Sangav√°ḍa in the Rang√°rik√° district or bhukti. Just below this inscription is a second also bearing the name of Kum√°rap√°la. The year is lost. But the occasion is said to be an eclipse on Thursday the 15th of Paush Sudi when a gift was made to the god of Udayapura by Yaśodhavala the viceroy of Kum√°rap√°la.93 [188]


Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. Similar inscriptions of Kum√°rap√°la’s time and giving his name occur near the ruined town of Ker√°du or Kir√°ṭa-Kúpa near B√°lmer in Western R√°jput√°na. The inscriptions show that Kum√°rap√°la had another Am√°tya or minister there, and that the kings of the country round Ker√°du had been subject to Gujar√°t since the time of Siddhar√°ja Jayasiṃha. Finally the inscription of Kum√°rap√°la found by Colonel Tod in a temple of Brahma on the pinnacle of Chitoḍa fort94 shows that his conquests extended as far as Mew√°ḍa.

According to the Kum√°rap√°lachint√°maṇi Kum√°rap√°la married one Padm√°vatí of Padmapura. The chronicler describes the city as to the west of the Indus. Perhaps the lady belonged to Padmapura, a large town in Kashmír. Considering his greatness as a king and conqueror the historical record of Kum√°rap√°la is meagre and incomplete. Materials may still come to light which will show his power to have been surprisingly widespread.

Mr. Forbes95 records the following Br√°hmanical tradition of a Mew√°ḍa queen of Kum√°rap√°la, which has probably been intentionally omitted by the Jain chroniclers.

Kum√°rap√°la, says the Br√°hman tradition, had wedded a Sisodaní R√°ni, a daughter of the house of Mew√°ḍa. At the time that the sword went for her the Sisodaní heard that the R√°ja had made a vow that his wives should receive initiation into the Jain religion at Hem√°ch√°rya’s convent before entering the palace. The R√°ni refused to start for Patan until she was satisfied she would not be called on to visit the Ách√°rya’s convent. Jayadeva Kum√°rap√°la’s household bard became surety and the queen consented to go to Aṇahilapura. Several days after her arrival Hem√°ch√°rya said to the R√°ja ‘The Sisodaní R√°ni has never come to visit me.’ Kum√°rap√°la told her she must go. The R√°ni refused and fell ill, and the bard’s wives went to see her. Hearing her story they disguised her as one of themselves and brought her privately home to their house. At night the bard dug a hole in the wall of the city, and taking the R√°ni through the hole started with her for Mew√°ḍa. When Kum√°rap√°la became aware of the R√°ni’s flight he set off in pursuit with two thousand horse. He came up with the fugitives about fifteen miles from the fort of Idar. The bard said to the R√°ni, ‘If you can enter Idar you are safe. I have two hundred horse with me. As long as a man of us remains no one shall lay hands on you.’ So saying he turned upon his pursuers. But the R√°ni’s courage failed and she slew herself in the carriage. As the fight went on and the pursuers forced their way to the carriage, the maids cried ‘Why struggle more, the R√°ni is dead.’ Kum√°rap√°la and his men returned home.96

The Param√°ra chiefs of Chandr√°vatí near Ábu were also feudatories of Kum√°rap√°la. It has been noted that to punish him for siding with Arṇor√°ja of S√°mbhar Kum√°rap√°la placed Vikrama Siṃha the Chandr√°vatí chief in confinement and set Vikrama’s [189]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. nephew Yaśodhavala on his throne. That Kum√°rap√°la conquered the chiefs of S√°mbhar and M√°lwa is beyond question. Among his names is the proud title Avantí-n√°tha Lord of M√°lwa.

The Kum√°rap√°laprabandha gives the following limits of Kum√°rap√°la’s sway. The Turushkas or Turks on the north; the heavenly Ganges on the east; the Vindhya mountains on the south; the Sindhu river on the west.97 Though in tradition Kum√°rap√°la’s name does not stand so high as a builder as the name of Siddhar√°ja Jayasiṃha he carried out several important works. The chief of these was the restoring and rebuilding of the great shrine of Someśvara or Soman√°tha Patan. According to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi when Kum√°rap√°la asked Devasúri the teacher of Hem√°ch√°rya how best to keep his name remembered Devasúri replied: Build a new temple of Soman√°tha fit to last an age or yuga, instead of the wooden one which is ruined by the ocean billows. Kum√°rap√°la approved and appointed a building committee or pañchakula headed by a Br√°hman named Gaṇḍa Bh√°va Bṛihaspati the state officer at Soman√°tha. At the instance of Hem√°ch√°rya the king on hearing the foundations were laid vowed until the temple was finished he would keep apart from women and would take neither flesh nor wine. In proof of his vow he poured a handful of water over Nílakaṇṭha Mah√°deva, probably his own royal god. After two years the temple was completed and the flag hoisted. Hem√°ch√°rya advised the king not to break his vow until he had visited the new temple and paid his obeisance to the god. The king agreed and went to Soman√°tha, Hem√°ch√°rya preceding him on foot and promising to come to Soman√°tha after visiting Śatruñjaya and Girn√°r. On reaching Soman√°tha the king was received by Gaṇḍa-Bṛihaspati his head local officer and by the building committee, and was taken in state through the town. At the steps of the temple the king bowed his head to the ground. Under the directions of Gaṇḍa-Bṛihaspati he worshipped the god, made gifts of elephants and other costly articles including his own weight in coin, and returned to Aṇahilapura.

It is interesting to know that the present battered sea-shore temple of Soman√°tha, whose garbh√°g√°ra or shrine has been turned into a mosque and whose spire has been shattered, is the temple of whose building and consecration the above details are preserved. This is shown by the style of the architecture and sculpture which is in complete agreement with the other buildings of the time of Kum√°rap√°la.98 [190]


Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. Kum√°rap√°la’s temple seems to have suffered in every subsequent Muhammadan invasion, in Alaf Khan’s in a.d. 1300, in Mozaffar’s in a.d. 1390, in Mahmúd Begada’s about a.d. 1490, and in Muzaffar II.’s about a.d. 1530. Time after time no sooner had the invader passed than the work of repair began afresh. One of the most notable restorations was by Kheng√°r IV. (a.d. 1279–1333) a Chúḍ√°sam√° king of Jun√°gaḍh who is mentioned in two Girn√°r inscriptions as the repairer of Soman√°tha after its desecration by Al√°-ud-dín Khilji. The latest sacrilege, including the turning of the temple into a mosque, was in the time of the Ahmad√°b√°d king Muzaffar Sh√°h II. (a.d. 1511–1535). Since then no attempt has been made to win back the god into his old home.

In the side wall near the door of the little shrine of Bhadrak√°li in Patan a broken stone inscription gives interesting details of the temple of Soman√°tha. Except that the right hand corners of some of the lines are broken, the inscription is clear and well preserved. It is dated a.d. 1169 (Valabhi 850). It records that the temple of the god Someśa was first of gold built by Soma; next it was of silver built by R√°vana; afterwards of wood built by Kṛishṇa; and last of stone built by Bhímadeva. The next restoration was through Gaṇḍa-Bṛihaspati under Kum√°rap√°la. Of Gaṇḍa-Bṛihaspati it gives these details. He was a Kany√°kubja or Kanoj Br√°hman of the P√°śupata school, a teacher of the M√°lwa kings, and a friend of Siddhar√°ja Jayasiṃha. He repaired several other temples and founded several other religious buildings in Soman√°tha. He also repaired the temple of Ked√°reśvara in Kumaon on learning that the Khaśa king of that country had allowed it to fall into disrepair. After the time of Kum√°rap√°la the descendants of Gaṇḍa-Bṛihaspati remained in religious authority in Soman√°tha.

Kum√°rap√°la made many Jain benefactions.99 He repaired the temple of S√°gala-Vasahik√° at Stambha-tírtha or Cambay where Hem√°ch√°rya received his initiation or díksh√°. In honour of the lady who gave him barley flour and curds he built a temple called the Karambaka-Vih√°ra in Patan. He also built in Patan a temple called the Mouse or Mushaka-Vih√°ra to free himself from the impurity caused by killing a mouse while digging for treasure. At Dhandhuka Hem√°ch√°rya’s birthplace a temple called the Jholik√°-Vih√°ra or cradle temple was built. Besides these Kum√°rap√°la is credited with building 1444 temples.

Though Kum√°rap√°la was not a learned man, his ministers were men of learning, and he continued the practice of keeping at his court scholars especially Sanskrit poets. Two of his leading Pandits were R√°machandra and Udayachandra both of them Jains. R√°machandra is often mentioned in Gujar√°ti literature and appears to have been a great scholar. He was the author of a book called the Hundred Accounts or Prabandhaśata. After Udayana’s death Kum√°rap√°la’s chief minister was Kapardi a man of learning skilled in Sanskrit poetry. And all through his reign his principal adviser [191]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. was Hemachandra or Hem√°ch√°rya probably the most learned man of his time. Though Hem√°ch√°rya lived during the reigns both of Siddhar√°ja and of Kum√°rap√°la, only under Kum√°rap√°la did he enjoy political power as the king’s companion and religious adviser. What record remains of the early Solaṅkis is chiefly due to Hemachandra.

The Jain life of Hem√°ch√°rya abounds in wonders. Apart from the magic and mystic elements the chief details are: Ch√°chiga a Modh V√°nia of Dhandhuka100 in the district of Ardh√°shṭama had by his wife P√°hiní101 of the Ch√°muṇḍa gotra, a boy named Ch√°ngodeva who was born a.d. 1089 (Kartik fullmoon Saṃvat 1145). A Jain priest named Devachandra Ách√°rya (a.d. 1078–1170; S. 1134–1226) came from Patan to Dhandhuka and when in Dhandhuka went to pay his obeisance at the Modh Vasahik√°. While Devachandra was seated Ch√°ngodeva came playing with other boys and went and sat beside the √°ch√°rya. Struck with the boy’s audacity and good looks the √°ch√°rya went with the council of the village to Ch√°chiga’s house. Ch√°chiga was absent but his wife being a Jain received the √°ch√°rya with respect. When she heard that her son was wanted by the council, without waiting to consult her husband, she handed the boy to the √°ch√°rya who carried him off to Karṇ√°vatí and kept him there with the sons of the minister Udayana. Ch√°chiga, disconsolate at the loss of his son, went in quest of him vowing to eat nothing till the boy was found. He came to Karṇ√°vatí and in an angry mood called on the √°ch√°rya to restore him his son. Udayana was asked to interfere and at last persuaded Ch√°chiga to let the boy stay with Devachandra.

In a.d. 1097, when Ch√°ngodeva was eight years old Ch√°chiga celebrated his son’s consecration or díksh√° and gave him the name of Somachandra. As the boy became extremely learned Devachandra changed his name to Hemachandra the Moon of gold. In a.d. 1110 (S. 1166) at the age of 21, his mastery of all the Ś√°stras and Siddh√°ntas was rewarded by the dignity of Súri or sage. Siddhar√°ja was struck with his conversation and honoured him as a man of learning. Hemachandra’s knowledge, wisdom and tact enabled him to adhere openly to his Jain rules and beliefs though Siddhar√°ja’s dislike of Jain practices was so great as at times to amount to insult. After one of their quarrels Hem√°ch√°rya kept away from the king for two or three days. Then the king seeing his humility and his devotion to his faith repented and apologised. The two went together to Soman√°tha Patan and there Hem√°ch√°rya paid his obeisance to the liṅga in a way that did not offend his own faith. During Siddhar√°ja’s reign Hem√°ch√°rya wrote his well known grammar with aphorisms or sútras and commentary or vṛitti called Siddha-Hemachandra, a title compounded of the king’s name and his own. As the Br√°hmans found fault with the absence of any detailed references to the king in the work Hemachandra [192]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. added one verse at the end of each chapter in praise of the king. During Siddhar√°ja’s reign he also wrote two other works, the Haimín√°mam√°l√°, “String of Names composed by Hema(chandra)” or Abhidh√°nachint√°maṇi and the Anek√°rthan√°mam√°l√°, a Collection of words of more than one meaning. He also began the Dvy√°śrayakosha102 or Double Dictionary being both a grammar and a history. In spite of his value to Kum√°rap√°la, in the beginning of Kum√°rap√°la’s reign Hem√°ch√°rya was not honoured as a spiritual guide and had to remain subordinate to Br√°hmans. When Kum√°rap√°la asked him what was the most important religious work he could perform Hem√°ch√°rya advised the restoring of the temple of Soman√°tha. Still Hem√°ch√°rya so far won the king to his own faith that till the completion of the temple he succeeded in persuading the king to take the vow of ahiṁs√° or non-killing which though common to both faiths is a specially Jain observance. Seeing this mark of his ascendancy over the king, the king’s family priest and other Br√°hmans began to envy and thwart Hem√°ch√°rya. On the completion of the temple, when the king was starting for Soman√°tha for the installation ceremony, the Br√°hmans told him that Hem√°ch√°rya did not mean to go with him. Hem√°ch√°rya who had heard of the plot had already accepted the invitation. He said being a recluse he must go on foot, and that he also wanted to visit Girn√°r, and from Girn√°r would join the king at Soman√°tha. His object was to avoid travelling in a palanquin with the king or suffering a repetition of Siddhar√°ja’s insult for not accepting a p√°lkí. Soon after reaching Soman√°tha Kum√°rap√°la asked after Hem√°ch√°rya. The Br√°hmans spread a story that he had been drowned, but Hem√°ch√°rya was careful to appear in the temple as the king reached it. The king saw him, called him, and took him with him to the temple. Some Br√°hmans told the king that the Jain priest would not pay any obeisance to Śiva, but Hem√°ch√°rya saluted the god in the following verse in which was nothing contrary to strict Jainism: ‘Salutation to him, whether he be Brahma, Vishṇu, Hara, or Jina, from whom have fled desires which produce the sprouts of the seed of worldliness.’103 After this joint visit to Soman√°tha Hemachandra gained still more ascendancy over the king, who appreciated his calmness of mind and his forbearance. The Br√°hmans tried to prevent the growth of his influence, but in the end Hemachandra overcame them. He induced the king to place in the sight of his Br√°hmanical family priests an image of Ś√°ntin√°tha Tírthaṅkara among his family gods. He afterwards persuaded Kum√°rap√°la publicly to adopt the Jain faith by going to the hermitage of Hemachandra and giving [193]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. numerous presents to Jain ascetics. Finally under his influence Kum√°rap√°la put away all Br√°hmanical images from his family place of worship. Having gone such lengths Kum√°rap√°la began to punish the Br√°hmans who insulted Hemachandra. A Br√°hman named V√°mar√°śi, a Pandit at the royal court, who composed a verse insulting Hemachandra, lost his annuity and was reduced to beggary, but on apologising to Hemachandra the annuity was restored. Another Br√°hmanical officer named Bh√°va Bṛihaspati, who was stationed at Soman√°tha, was re-called for insulting Hemachandra. But he too on apologising to Hemachandra was restored to Soman√°tha. Under Hemachandra’s influence Kum√°rap√°la gave up the use of flesh and wine, ceased to take pleasure in the chase, and by beat of drum forbade throughout his kingdom the taking of animal life. He withdrew their licenses from hunters, fowlers and fishermen, and forced them to adopt other callings. To what lengths this dread of life-taking was carried appears from an order that only filtered water was to be given to all animals employed in the royal army. Among the stories told of the king’s zeal for life-saving is one of a Bania of S√°mbhar who having been caught killing a louse was brought in chains to Aṇahilav√°ḍa, and had his property confiscated and devoted to the building at Aṇahilav√°ḍa of a Louse Temple or Yúk√°-Vih√°ra. According to another story a man of Nador in M√°rw√°r was put to death by Kelhana the chief of Nador to appease Kum√°rap√°la’s wrath at hearing that the man’s wife had offered flesh to a field-god or kshetrap√°la. Hemachandra also induced the king to forego the claim of the state to the property of those who died without a son.

During Kum√°rap√°la’s reign Hemachandra wrote many well known Sanskrit and Prakrit works on literature and religion. Among these are the Adhy√°tmopanishad or Yogaś√°stra a work of 12,000 verses in twelve chapters called Prak√°śas, the Tris√°shṭhis√°l√°k√°purushacharitra or lives of sixty-three Jain saints of the Utsarpiní and Avasarpiní ages; the Pariśishṭaparvan, a work of 3500 verses being the life of Jain Sthaviras who flourished after Mah√°víra; the Pr√°kṛita Śabd√°nuś√°sana or Pr√°krit grammar; the Dvy√°śraya104 a Prakrit poem written with the double object of teaching grammar and of giving the history of Kum√°rap√°la; the Chhandonuś√°sana a work of about 6000 verses on prosody; the Liṅg√°nuś√°sana a work on genders; the Deśín√°mam√°l√° in Prakrit with a commentary a work on local and provincial words; and the Alaṅk√°rachúḍ√°maṇi a work on rhetoric. Hemachandra died in a.d. 1172 (S. 1229) at the age of 84. The king greatly mourned his loss and marked his brow with Hemachandra’s ashes. Such crowds came to share in the ashes of the pyre that the ground was hollowed into a pit known as the Haima-Khadda or Hema’s Pit.

Kum√°rap√°la lived to a great age. According to the author of the Prabandhachint√°maṇi he was fifty when he succeeded to the [194]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Kum√°rap√°la, a.d. 1143–1174. throne, and after ruling about thirty-one years died in a.d. 1174 (S. 1230). He is said to have died of lúta a form of leprosy. Another story given by the Kum√°rap√°laprabandha is that Kum√°rap√°la was imprisoned by his nephew and successor Ajayap√°la. The Kum√°rap√°laprabandha gives the exact length of Kum√°rap√°la’s reign at 30 years 8 months and 27 days. If the beginning of Kum√°rap√°la’s reign is placed at the 4th Magsar Sud Saṃvat 1299, the date of the close, taking the year to begin in K√°rtika, would be Bh√°drapada Śuddha Saṃvat 1229. If with Gujar√°t almanacs the year is taken to begin in Ásh√°ḍha, the date of the close of the reign would be Bh√°drapada of Saṃvat 1230. It is doubtful whether either Saṃvat 1229 or 1230 is the correct year, as an inscription dated Saṃvat 1229 Vaish√°kha Śuddha 3rd at Udayapura near Bhils√° describes Ajayap√°la Kum√°rap√°la’s successor as reigning at Aṇahilapura. This would place Kum√°rap√°la’s death before the month of Vaish√°kha 1229 that is in a.d. 1173.105

Ajayap√°la, a.d. 1174–1177.As Kum√°rap√°la had no son he was succeeded by Ajayap√°la the son of his brother Mahíp√°la.106 According to the Kum√°rap√°laprabandha Kum√°rap√°la desired to give the throne to his daughter’s son Prat√°pamalla, but Ajayap√°la raised a revolt and got rid of Kum√°rap√°la by poison. The Jain chroniclers say nothing of the reign of Ajayap√°la because he was not a follower of their religion. The author of the Sukṛitasankírtana notices a small silver canopy or pavilion shown in Ajayap√°la’s court as a feudatory’s gift from the king of Sap√°dalaksha107 or Sew√°lik. The author of the Kírtikaumudí dismisses Ajayap√°la with the mere mention of his name, and does not even state his relationship with Kum√°rap√°la. According to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi Ajayap√°la destroyed the Jain temples built by his uncle. He showed no favour to Ámbaḍ√° and Kum√°rap√°la’s other Jain ministers. Ajayap√°la seems to have been of a cruel and overbearing temper. He appointed as his minister Kapardi because he was of the Br√°hmanical faith.108 But considering his manners arrogant he ordered him to be thrown into a caldron of boiling oil. On another occasion he ordered the Jain scholar R√°machandra to sit on a red-hot sheet of copper. One of his nobles Ámra-bhaṭa or Ámbaḍ√° refused to submit to [195]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Ajayap√°la, a.d. 1174–1177. the king, saying that he would pay obeisance only to Vítar√°ja or Tírthaṅkara as god, to Hemachandra as guide, and to Kum√°rap√°la as king. Ajayap√°la ordered the matter to be settled by a fight. Ámbaḍ√° brought some of his followers to the drum-house near the gate, and in the fight that followed Ámbaḍ√° was killed. In a.d. 1177 (S. 1233), after a short reign of three years, Ajayap√°la was slain by a doorkeeper named Vijjaladeva who plunged a dagger into the king’s heart.109

Múlar√°ja II., a.d. 1177–1179.Ajayap√°la was succeeded by his son Múlar√°ja II. also called B√°la Múlar√°ja as he was only a boy when installed. His mother was N√°ikídeví the daughter of Paramardi, apparently the K√°damba king Perm√°di or Śiva Chitta who reigned from a.d. 1147 to 1175 (S. 1203–1231).110 The authors of the Kírtikaumudí111 and the Sukṛitasankírtana say that even in childhood Múlar√°ja II. dispersed the Turushka or Muhammadan army.112 The Prabandhachint√°maṇi states that the king’s mother fought at the G√°dar√°raghatta and that her victory was due to a sudden fall of rain. Múlar√°ja II. is said to have died in a.d. 1179 (S. 1235) after a reign of two years.

Bhíma II. a.d. 1179–1242.Múlar√°ja II. was succeeded by Bhíma II. The relationship of the two is not clearly established. Mr. Forbes makes Bhíma the younger brother of Ajayap√°la. But it appears from the Kírtikaumudí and the Sukṛitasankírtana that Bhíma was the younger brother of Múlar√°ja. The Sukṛitasankírtana after concluding the account of Múlar√°ja,113 calls Bhíma ‘asya bandhu’ ‘his brother,’ and the Kírtikaumudí, after mentioning the death of Múlar√°ja, says that Bhíma his younger brother ‘anujanm√°sya’ became king.114 [196]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Bhíma II. a.d. 1179–1242. Múlar√°ja we know came to the throne as a child. Of Bhíma also the Kírtikaumudí says that he came to the throne while still in his childhood, and this agrees with the statements that he was the younger brother of Múlar√°ja. Bhíma probably came to the throne a.d. 1178 (S. 1234). There is no doubt he was reigning in a.d. 1179 (S. 1235), as an inscription in the deserted village of Ker√°lu near B√°lmer of Aṇahilav√°ḍa dated a.d. 1179 (S. 1235) states that it was written ‘in the triumphant reign of the illustrious Bhímadeva.’115 A further proof of his reigning in a.d. 1179 (S. 1235) and of his being a minor at that time is given in the following passage from the Tabak√°t-i-N√°sirí: In a.d. 1178 (Hijri 574) the R√°í of Nahrw√°l√° Bhímdeo, was a minor, but he had a large army and many elephants. In the day of battle the Muhammadans were defeated and the Sult√°n was compelled to retreat.116 Merutuṇga says that Bhíma reigned from a.d. 1179 (S. 1235) for sixty-three years that is up to a.d. 1242 (S. 1298), and this is borne out by a copperplate of Bhíma which bears date a.d. 1240 (S. 1296117 M√°rgha Vadi 14th Sunday118).

Bhíma was nicknamed Bholo the Simpleton. The chroniclers of this period mention only the V√°ghel√°s and almost pass over Bhíma. The author of the Kírtikaumudí says ‘the kingdom of the young ruler was gradually divided among powerful ministers and provincial chiefs’; and according to the Sukṛitasankírtana ‘Bhíma felt great anxiety on account of the chiefs who had forcibly eaten away portions of the kingdom.’ It appears that during the minority, when the central authority was weak, the kingdom was divided among nobles and feudatories, and that Bhíma proved too weak a ruler to restore the kingly power. Manuscripts and copperplates show that Bhímadeva was ruling at Aṇahilav√°ḍa in S. 1247, 1251, 1261, 1263, and 1264,119 and copperplates dated S. 1283, 1288, 1295, and 1296 have also been found. Though Bhíma in name enjoyed a long unbroken reign the verses quoted above show that power rested not with the king but with the nobles. It appears from an inscription that in a.d. 1224 (S. 1280) a Ch√°lukya noble named Jayantasiṃha was supreme at Aṇahilav√°ḍa though he mentions Bhíma and his predecessors with honour and respect.120

It was probably by aiding Bhíma against Jayantasiṃha that the V√°ghel√°s rose to power. According to the chroniclers the V√°ghel√°s succeeded in the natural course of things. According to the Sukṛitasankírtana Kum√°rap√°la appeared to his grandson Bhíma and directed him to appoint as his heir-apparent Víradhavala son of Lavaṇapras√°da and grandson of Arṇor√°ja the son of Dhavala king of Bhimapalli. Next day in court, in the presence of his nobles, when Lavaṇapras√°da and Víradhavala entered the king said to [197]
Chapter II.
The Chaulukyas, a.d. 961–1242.
Bhíma II. a.d. 1179–1242. Lavaṇapras√°da: Your father Arṇor√°ja seated me on the throne: you should therefore uphold my power: in return I will name your son Víradhavala my heir-apparent.121 The author of the Kírtikaumudí notes that Arṇor√°ja son of Dhavala, opposing the revolution against Bhíma, cleared the kingdom of enemies, but at the cost of his own life. The author then describes Lavaṇapras√°da and Víradhavala as kings. But as he gives no account of their rise to supremacy, it seems probable that they usurped the actual power from Bhíma though till a.d. 1242 (S. 1295) Bhíma continued to be nominal sovereign.

Bhíma’s queen was Líl√°deví the daughter of a Choh√°n chief named Samarasiṃha.122 [198]

1 Ind. Ant. IV. 71–72 and VI. 180. ↑

2 Ind. Ant. VI. 180ff. The suggestion may be offered that the Kany√°kubja which is mentioned as the seat of Múlar√°ja’s ancestors, is Karṇakubja, an old name of Jun√°gaḍh. Compare Burgess’ K√°thi√°w√°r and Kutch, 156. ↑

3 Ind. Ant. VI. 191ff. ↑

4 Kirtane’s Hammíramah√°k√°vya, I. ↑

5 The Choh√°ns of Ajmir were also known as the rulers of Ś√°kambharí, the S√°mbhar lake in R√°jput√°na on the borders of Jaipur and Jodhpur. The corrected edition of the Harsha inscription published by Prof. Kielhorn in Epigraphia Indica II. 116ff. shows that their first historical king was Gúvaka, who reigned some time in the first half of the ninth century (c. 820 a.d.) The Choh√°ns are still very numerous in the neighbourhood of the Sew√°lik hills, especially in the districts of Amb√°l√° and Karn√°l. Compare Ibbetson’s Panj√°b Census for 1881. ↑

6 It appears from the grant of Śaka 972 published by Mr. Dhruva in Ind. Ant. XII. 196 and from the Surat grant of Kírttir√°ja dated Śaka 940, that this B√°rappa was the founder of a dynasty who ruled L√°ṭa or South Gujar√°t as under-kings of the Dakhan Ch√°lukyas until at least a.d. 1050. B√°rappa was, as his name shows, a Southerner from the K√°narese country, but his descendants spell the family name Chaulukya in the same way as the dynasty of Aṇahilav√°ḍa. ↑

7 Dr. Bühler (Ind. Ant. XII. 123) sees a reference to this retirement in Múlar√°ja’s grant of Saṃvat 1043. ↑

8 Apparently a Sanskrit form of B√°rappa. ↑

9 Broach according to the commentator. ↑

10 The Sukṛitasankírtana mentions this defeat of B√°rappa who is said to be a general of the Kany√°kubja or Kanoj king. The Prabandhachint√°maṇi (Múlar√°japrabandha) also mentions the invasion and slaughter of B√°rappa; but there is no reference to it in the grant of B√°rappa’s descendant Trilochanap√°la (Ind. Ant. XII. 196ff.) ↑

11 Canto II. Verse 3. ↑

12 As Mr. Forbes rightly observed Graharipu the Planet-seizer is a made-up title based on the resemblance of the planet-seizer’s name R√°hu to R√° the title of the Chúḍ√°sam√°s of Jun√°gaḍh. The personal name of the chief is not given and the list of the Jun√°gaḍh Chúḍ√°sam√°s is too incomplete to allow of identification. ↑

13 The mention of her name and of the language in which she wrote suggest something remarkable in the race and position of queen Nílí. ↑

14 Perhaps Sith√° in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍ. ↑

15 The same account appears in the Kum√°rap√°lacharita. ↑

16 Compare the Lakshmí-Vih√°ra Jain temple in Jesalmir built by the Jain Saṅgha and called after the reigning king Lakshmaṇa. ↑

17 Dr. Bühler’s copperplate of Múlar√°ja records a grant to this temple, said to be of Múlan√°thadeva in Maṇḍali in the Vardhi zilla, apparently the modern M√°ndal near Pañch√°sar in the Vadhi√°r province near Jhinjhuv√°ḍa. The grant is in Saṃvat 1043 and is dated from Aṇahilapura though the actual gift was made at Śrísthala or Sidhpur after bathing in the Sarasvatí and worshipping the god of the Rudramah√°laya. The grant is of the village of Kamboika, the modern Kaṃboi near Modhera. Ind. Ant. VI. 192–193. The grant is said to have been written by a K√°yastha named K√°ñchaṇa and ends with the words “of the illustrious Múlar√°ja.” ↑

18 The difference between 1052 and 1053 is probably only a few months. ↑

19 The fight with Muñja must have taken place about a.d. 1011 (S. 1067). As Ch√°muṇḍa started just after installing Vallabha the beginning of the reign must be before a.d. 997 as Tailapa who fought with Muñja died in that year. This is proved by a manuscript dated a.d. 994 (S. 1050) which gives the reigning king as Muñja. That Bhoja Muñja’s successor was ruling in a.d. 1014 (S. 1070) makes it probable that Muñja’s reign extended to a.d. 1011 (S. 1067). ↑

20 This Svayaṃvara and the list of attendant and rival kings seem imaginary. The Nadol chiefship was not important enough to draw kings from the countries named. ↑

21 The text has son but Bhíma was Durlabha’s nephew not his son. ↑

22 By sowing cowries Kulachandra may have meant to show the cheapness of Aṇahilav√°ḍa. Bhoja’s meaning was that as shells are money, to sow shells was to sow M√°lwa wealth in Gujar√°t. If Kulachandra had sown salt all would have melted, and no trace been left. [This seems a symbolic later-stage explanation. The sense seems to be shell-sowing keeps the Aṇahilav√°ḍa guardians in place since guardians can live in shells: salt-sowing scares the guardian spirits and makes the site of the city a haunt of demons. Bhoja saw that thanks to his general the Luck of Aṇahilav√°ḍa would remain safe in the shells.] ↑

23 The Prabandhachint√°maṇi tells other stories of the relations between Bhíma and Bhoja. Once when Gujar√°t was suffering from famine Bhíma heard that Bhoja was coming with a force against Gujar√°t. Alarmed at the news Bhíma asked D√°mara his minister of peace and war to prevent Bhoja coming. D√°mara went to M√°lwa, amused the king by witty stories, and while a play was being acted in court degrading and joking other kings, something was said regarding Tailapa of Telingana. On this Damara reminded the king that the head of his grandfather Muñja was fixed at Tailap’s door. Bhoja grew excited and started with an army against Telingana. Hearing that Bhíma had come against him as far as Bhímapura (?) Bhoja asked D√°mara to prevent Bhíma advancing further. D√°mara stopped Bhíma by taking him an elephant as a present from Bhoja. The Prabandhachint√°maṇi gives numerous other stories showing that at times the relations between Bhoja and Bhíma were friendly. ↑

24 See above page 9. ↑

25 See above page 160. ↑

26 With this silence compare the absence (Reinaud’s Mémoire Sur l’Inde, 67) of any reference either in Sanskrit or in Buddhist books to the victories, even to the name, of Alexander the Great. Also in modern times the ignoring of British rule in the many inscriptions of Jain repairers of temples on Śatruñjaya hill who belong to British territory. The only foreign reference is by one merchant of Daman who acknowledges the protection of the Phirangi j√°ti Puratak√°la P√°tasahi the king of the Firangis of Portugal. Bühler in Epigraphia Indica, II. 36. ↑

27 Elliot and Dowson, II. 468ff. Sir H. M. Elliot gives extracts for this expedition from the T√°rikh-i-Alfi, Tabak√°t-i-Akbari, Tabak√°t-i-N√°siri, and Rauzatu-s-saf√°. ↑

28 Since the earliest times Hindus have held eclipse days sacred. According to the Mah√°bh√°rata the Y√°davas of Dw√°rk√° came to Soman√°tha for an eclipse fair. Great fairs are still held at Soman√°tha on the K√°rtika and Chaitra (December and April) fullmoons. ↑

29 This old Indian idea is expressed in a verse in an inscription in Soman√°tha P√°tan itself. ↑

30 Ten thousand must be taken vaguely. ↑

31 Compare Sachau’s Alberuni, II. 104. Every day they brought Soman√°tha a jug of Ganges water and a basket of Kashmir flowers. Soman√°tha they believed cured every inveterate sickness and healed every desperate and incurable disease. The reason why Soman√°tha became so famous was that it was a harbour for those who went to and fro from Sofala in Zanzibar to China. It is still the practice to carry Ganges water to bathe distant gods. ↑

32 These must be the local Sompura Br√°hmans who still number more than five hundred souls in Soman√°tha Patan. ↑

33 Shaving is the first rite performed by pilgrims. ↑

34 Dancers are now chiefly found in the temples of Southern India. ↑

35 Mahmúd seems to have crossed the desert from Mult√°n and Bah√°walpur to Bik√°nír and thence to Ajmír. ↑

36 Apparently Delv√°da near Un√°. Mahmúd’s route seems to have been from Aṇahilav√°ḍa to Modhera and M√°ndal, thence by the Little Ran near P√°tri and Baj√°na, and thence by Jh√°l√°v√°ḍ Gohelv√°ḍ and B√°briav√°ḍ to Delv√°d√°. ↑

37 The waves still beat against the walls of the ruined fort of Soman√°tha. ↑

38 This shows that the temple was a building of brick and wood. According to Alberuni (Sachau, II. 105) the temple was built about a hundred years before Mahmúd’s invasion. An inscription at Patan states that Bhímadeva I. (a.d. 1022–1072) rebuilt the Soman√°tha temple of stone. In Dr. Bhagv√°nl√°l’s opinion the first dynasty in Gujar√°t to make stone buildings were the Solaṅkis. Before them buildings and temples were of wood and brick. ↑

39 Of the fate of the great Liṅga Alberuni (Sachau, II. 103) writes: Prince Mahmúd ordered the upper part to be broken. The rest with all its coverings and trappings of gold jewels and embroidered garments he transported to Ghazni. Part of it together with the brass Chakravarti or Vishṇu of Th√°nesvar has been thrown into the hippodrome of the town: part lies before the mosque for people to rub their feet on. ↑

40 The next paragraph relating to Mahmúd’s return will be found on page 249 of the same volume of Sir H. Elliott’s work. ↑

41 Khandahat which must have been on the coast has not been identified. The description suggests some coast island in the gulf of Kacch. By the Girn√°r route forty parasangs that is 240 miles would reach the Kacch coast. Kanthkot in V√°gad in east Kacch suits well in sound and is known to have been a favourite resort of the Solaṅkis. But the ebb and flow of the tide close to it are difficult to explain. The identification with Kanthkot is favoured by Dr. Bühler. Colonel Watson (K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 80) prefers G√°ndhvi on the K√°thi√°v√°ḍa coast a few miles north-east of Mi√°ni. M. Reinaud and Dr. Weil suggest Gandh√°r in Broach on the left bank of the mouth of the Dh√°dhar river. Sir H. Elliot (I. 445 and II. 473) prefers Khandad√°r at the north-west angle of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. ↑

42 According to Ferishta (Bombay Persian Ed. I. 57, Briggs’ Translation, I. 74) Mahmúd stayed and meant to make his capital at Aṇahilav√°ḍa not at Soman√°tha. That Mahmúd did stay at Aṇahilav√°ḍa the Martyr’s Mound and the Ghazni Mosque in Patan are evidence. Still the mound was probably raised and the mosque may at least have been begun in honour of the capture of Aṇahilav√°ḍa on the journey south. Traces of a second mosque which is said to have had a tablet recording Mahmúd of Ghazni as the builder have recently (1878) been found at Munjpur about twenty-five miles south-east of R√°dhanpur. ↑

43 Briggs’ Ferishta, I. 75. This account of the D√°bshilíms reads more like a tradition than an historical record. It is to be noted that the authors both of the Áin-i-Akbari (a.d. 1583) and of the Mirat-i-Ahmadí (a.d. 1762) give Ch√°muṇḍa as king at the time of Mahmúd’s invasion. Their statements cannot weigh against Ibn Asír’s account. Compare Dr. Bühler’s remarks in Ind. Ant. VI. 184. Of Mahmúd’s return to Ghazni (a.d. 1026) the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari says: ‘When Mahmúd resolved to return from Soman√°tha he learned that Parama Dev, one of the greatest R√°j√°s of Hindust√°n, was preparing to intercept him. The Sult√°n, not deeming it advisable to contend with this chief, went towards Mult√°n through Sindh. In this journey his men suffered much in some places from scarcity of water in others from want of forage. After enduring great difficulties he arrived at Ghazni in a.d. 1029 (H. 417).’ This Parama Dev would seem to be the Parm√°ra king of Ábu who could well block the Ajmir-Gujar√°t route. The route taken by Mahmúd must have passed by Mansúra near Br√°hman√°b√°d, Bh√°tia, and Mult√°n. It must have been in the crossing of the great desert that he suffered so severely from scarcity of water and forage. Ferishta (Briggs, I. 75) says that many of Mahmúd’s troops died raging mad from the intolerable heat and thirst. The historian Muhammad Ufi (a.d. 1200) alleges (Elliot, II. 192) that two Hindus disguised as countrymen offered themselves as guides and led the army three days’ march out of the right course, where they were saved only by Mahmúd’s miraculous discovery of a pool of sweet water. [This tale of the self-sacrificing Br√°hman or priest and the miraculous find of water has gathered round Mahmúd as the latest of myth centres. It is Herodotus’ (Book III. 154–158) old Zopyrus tale (Rawlinson’s Seventh Monarchy, 318); it is revived in honour of the Great Kush√°n Kanishka, a.d. 78 (Beruni in Elliot, II. 11), of the Sassanian Firoz a.d. 457–483 (Rawlinson’s Seventh Monarchy, 318), and of a certain king of Z√°bulist√°n or Ghazni of uncertain date (Elliot II. 170). Similarly the puzzling Dabshilím tale seems to be peculiar neither to Gujar√°t nor to Mahmúd of Ghazni. It seems a repetition of the tale of Dabshilím the man of the royal race, who, according to the Panchatantra or Fables of Pilpai, was chosen successor of Porus after Alexander the Great’s Viceroy had been driven out. [Compare Reinaud’s Mémoire Sur l’Inde, 127–128.] The Tabak√°t-i-N√°sirí (a.d. 1227) adds (Elliot, II. 475) that the guide devoted his life for the sake of Soman√°tha and this account is adopted by Ferishta, Briggs’ Translation, I. 78. ↑

44 Vasahiis Pr√°krit for Vasati that is residence. The word is used to mean a group of temples. ↑

45 Several later mentions of a Tripurushapr√°s√°da show there was only one building of that name. The statement that the great Múlar√°ja I. built a Tripurushapr√°s√°da seems a mistake, due to a confusion with prince Múlar√°ja. ↑

46 Meaning a large number of Bhils of whom Ásh√° was the head. ↑

47 Forbes’ R√°s M√°l√° (New Ed.), 79. ↑

48 Probably a Bhíl goddess. The name does not sound Sanskrit. ↑

49 In one passage the Prabandhachint√°maṇi calls these princes half-brothers of Udaya. Further details show that they were half-brothers of one another and sons of Udaya. ↑

50 This Jayakeśi is Jayakeśi I. son of Shashṭhadeva (Śuchakeśi) the third of the Goa K√°dambas. Jayakeśi’s recorded date a.d. 1052 (S. 974) fits well with the time of Karṇa (Fleet’s K√°narese Dynasties, 91). The Prabandhachint√°maṇi tells the following story of the death of Jayakeśi. Jayakeśi had a favourite parrot whom he one day asked to come out of his cage and dine with him. The parrot said: The cat sitting near you will kill me. The king seeing no cat replied: If any cat kills you I too will die. The parrot left his cage, ate with the king, and was killed by the cat. Jayakeśi made ready his funeral pyre, and, in spite of his minister’s prayers, taking the dead parrot in his hand laid himself on the funeral pyre and was burned. ↑

51 Chandrapura is probably Chand√°var near Gokarn in North K√°nara. ↑

52 R√°s M√°l√° (New Edition), 83. ↑

53 Kielhorn’s Report on Sanskrit Manuscripts for 1881 page 22. ↑

54 Duśśala was sixth in descent from Vigrahar√°ja the enemy of Múlar√°ja from whom Karṇa was fifth in descent. ↑

55 The date of his installation is given by the author of the Vich√°raśreṇi as Vikrama S. 1150. ↑

56 Ásap√°la and Kum√°rap√°la appear to be local chiefs. ↑

57 Compare Forbes’ R√°s M√°l√°, I. 118–153. ↑

58 Goa K√°d√°mba inscriptions say that Jagaddeva was the cousin of the Goa K√°damba king Vijay√°rka the nephew of Miy√°nalladeví and call him by courtesy the younger brother of Vijay√°rka’s son Jayakeśi II. He would seem to have been held in esteem by Vijay√°rka and his son Jayakeśi, to have then gone for some time to Siddhar√°ja, and after leaving Siddhar√°ja to have transferred his services to Perm√°di. His being called Param√°ra may be due to his connection with Perm√°di. Fleet’s K√°narese Dynasties, 91. ↑

59 Seventy-two a favourite number with Indian authors. ↑

60 Prabandhachint√°maṇi and Kum√°rap√°lacharita. ↑

61 Dr. Kielhorn’s Report on Sanskrit Manuscripts for 1881 page 22. ↑

62 The Kum√°rap√°lacharita says that the title was assumed on the conquest of Barbaraka. The verse is:

सिद्धो बर्बरकश्वास्य सिद्धराजस्ततोभवत्‌

that is, by him the demon Barbaraka was vanquished, therefore he became Siddhar√°ja The Lord of Magical Power. ↑

63 Ind. Ant. IV. 265. ↑

64 This Perm√°di may be the Goa K√°damba chief Perm√°di Śivachitta (a.d. 1147–1175), who was heir-apparent in the time of Siddhar√°ja, or the Sinda chief Perm√°di who was a cotemporary of Siddhar√°ja and flourished in a.d. 1144. ↑

65 Ind. Ant. IV. 2. Regarding Barbaraka Doctor Bühler remarks in Ind. Ant. VI. 167: ‘The Varvarakas are one of the non-Aryan tribes which are settled in great numbers in North Gujar√°t, Koli, Bhíl, or Mer.’ Siddhar√°ja’s contests with the Barbarakas seem to refer to what Tod (Western India, 173 and 195) describes as the inroads of mountaineers and foresters on the plains of Gujar√°t during the eleventh and twelfth centuries. To attempt to identify Bhut Barbar or Varvar is hazardous. The name Barbar is of great age and is spread from India to Morocco. Wilson (Works, VII. 176) says: The analogy between Barbaras and barbarians is not in sound only. In all Sanskrit authorities Barbaras are classed with borderers and foreigners and nations not Hindu. According to Sir Henry Rawlinson (Ferrier’s Caravan Journeys, 223 note) tribes of Berbers are found all over the east. Of the age of the word Canon Rawlinson (Herodotus, IV. 252) writes: Barbar seems to be the local name for the early race of Accad. In India Ptolemy (a.d. 150; McCrindle’s Edn. 146) has a town Barbarei on the Indus and the Periplus (a.d. 247; McCrindle’s Ed. 108) has a trade-centre Barbarikon on the middle mouth of the Indus. Among Indian writings, in the Ram√°yaṇa (Hall in Wilson’s Works, VII. 176 Note *) the Barbaras appear between the Tukh√°ras and the Kambojas in the north: in the Mah√°bh√°rata (Muir’s Sanskrit Texts, I. 481–2) in one list Var-varas are entered between S√°varas and Śakas and in another list (Wilson’s Works, VII. 176) Barbaras come between Kiratas and Siddhas. Finally (As. Res. XV. 47 footnote) Barbara is the northmost of the Seven Konkanas. The names Barbarei in Ptolemy and Barbarikon in the Periplus look like some local place-name, perhaps Bambhara, altered to a Greek form. The Hindu tribe names, from the sameness in sound as well as from their position on the north-west border of India, suggest the Mongol tribe Ju√°n-Ju√°n or Var-Var, known to the western nations as Avars, who drove the Little Yuechi out of Balkh in the second half of the fourth century, and, for about a hundred years, ruled to the north and perhaps also to the south of the Hindu Kush. (Specht in Journal Asiatique 1883. II. 390–410; Howorth in Jour. R. A. S. XXI. 721–810.) It seems probable that some of these Var-Vars passed south either before or along with the White Húṇas (a.d. 450–550). Var, under its Mongol plural form Avarti (Howorth, Ditto 722), closely resembles Avartiya one of the two main divisions of the K√°this of Kacch (Mr. Erskine’s List in J. Bom. Geo. Soc. II. 59–60 for Aug. 1838). That among the forty-seven clans included under the Avartiyas four (Nos. 30, 35, 42, and 43) are Babariyas, suggests that the K√°this received additions from the Var-Vars at different times and places. Dr. Bühler (Ind. Ant. VI. 186) thinks that the Babaro or Barbar or Var-Var who gave trouble to Siddhar√°ja represent some early local non-Aryan tribe. The fact that they are called R√°kshasas and Mlecchas and that they stopped the ceremonies at Sidhpur north of Aṇahilav√°ḍa seems rather to point to a foreign invasion from the north than to a local uprising of hill tribes. Though no Musalm√°n invasion of Gujar√°t during the reign of Siddhar√°ja is recorded a Jesalmir legend (Forbes’ R√°s M√°l√°, I. 175) tells how Lanja Bijirao the Bhatti prince who married Siddhar√°ja’s daughter was hailed by his mother-in-law as the bulwark of Aṇahilav√°ḍa against the power of the king who grows too strong. This king may be B√°halim the Indian viceroy of the Ghaznavid Bahr√°m Sh√°h (a.d. 1116–1157). B√°halim (Elliot, II. 279; Briggs’ Ferista, I. 151) collected an army of Arabs, Persians, Afgh√°ns, and Khiljis, repaired the fort of N√°gor in the province of Sew√°lik, and committed great devastations in the territories of the independent Indian rulers. He threw off allegiance to Ghazni and advancing to meet Bahr√°m Sh√°h near Mult√°n was defeated and slain. Except that they were northerners and that B√°halim’s is the only known invasion from the north during Siddhar√°ja’s reign nothing has been found connecting Barbar and B√°halim. At the same time that the Barbar or Var-Var of the Gujar√°t writers may have been non-Hindu mercenaries from the north-west frontier whom Siddhar√°ja admitted as Hindu subjects is made not unlikely by two incidents preserved by the Muhammadan historians. The T√°rikh-i-Sor√°th (Bayley’s Gujar√°t, 35 Note *) tells how in a.d. 1178 from the defeated army of Shah√°b-ud-din Ghori the Turkish Afgh√°n and Moghal women were distributed the higher class to high caste and the commoner to low caste Hindus. Similarly how the better class of male captives were admitted among Chak√°val and Wadh√°l R√°jputs and the lower among Kh√°nts, Kolis, B√°brias, and Mers. Again about thirty years later (a.d. 1210) when his Turk mercenaries, who were not converted to Isl√°m, revolted against Shams-ud-dín Altamsh they seized Delhi and built Hindu temples (Elliot, II. 237–239). These cases seem to make it likely that among B√°halim’s mercenaries were some un-Islamised North Indian Var-Vars and that they were admitted into Hinduism by Siddhar√°ja and as the story states served him as other R√°jputs. Some of the new-comers as noted above seem to have merged into the K√°this. Others founded or joined the B√°bari√°s who give their name to B√°bari√°v√°ḍa a small division in the south of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. Though the tribe is now small the 72 divisions of the B√°bari√°s show that they were once important.
