One of their leading divisions preserves the early form Var (K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 132–133) and supports their separate northern origin, which is forgotten in the local stories that they are descended from Jethv√°s and Ahirs and have a Br√°hman element in their ancestry. (Tod’s Western India, 413; K√°thi√°w√°r Gazetteer, 132–123.) Of the Var-Vars in their old seats a somewhat doubtful trace remains in the Barbaris a tribe of Haz√°r√°hs near Herat (Bellew in Imp. and As. Quar. Review Oct. 1891 page 328) and in the Panj√°b (Ibbetson’s Census, 538) Bh√°bras a class of Panj√°b Jains. ↑

66 Abhayatilaka Gaṇi who revised and completed the Dvy√°śraya in Vikrama S. 1312 (a.d. 1256) says, in his twentieth Sarga, that a new era was started by Kum√°rap√°la. This would seem to refer to the Siṃha era. ↑

67 The Kum√°rap√°lacharita states that Sajjana died before the temple was finished, and that the temple was completed by his son Paraśur√°ma. After the temple was finished Siddhar√°ja is said to have come to Soman√°tha and asked Paraśur√°ma for the revenues of Sorath. But on seeing the temple on Girn√°r he was greatly pleased, and on finding that it was called Karṇa-vih√°ra after his father he sanctioned the outlay on the temple. ↑

68 Ind. Ant. VI. 194ff. Dr. Bühler (Ditto) takes Avantín√°tha to mean Siddhar√°ja’s opponent the king of M√°lwa and not Siddhar√°ja himself. ↑

69 Archæological Survey Report, XXI. 86. ↑

70 Jour. B. A. Soc. (1848), 319. ↑

71 The original verse is महालयो महायात्रा महास्थानं महासरः यत्कृतं सिद्धराजेन क्रियते तन्न केनचित्‌ ॥ ↑

72 These, as quoted by R√°o S√°heb Mahípatr√°m Rúpr√°m in his Sadhara Jesangh, are, the erection of charitable feeding-houses every yojana or four miles, of Dabhoi fort, of a kuṇda or reservoir at Kapadvanj, of the M√°lavya lake at Dholk√°, of small temples, of the Rudramah√°laya, of the R√°ni’s step-well, of the Sahasraliṅga lake, of reservoirs at Sihor, of the fort of S√°el√°, of the Daśasahasra or ten thousand temples, of the Muṇa lake at Viramg√°m, of the gadhs or forts of Dadharapur, Vadhw√°n Anantapur and Chub√°ri, of the Sardh√°r lake, of the gadhs of Jhinjhuv√°ḍa, Virpur, Bh√°dula, V√°singapura, and Th√°n, of the palaces of Kandola and Sihi Jagapura, of the reservoirs of Ded√°dr√° and Kírtti-stambha and of Jitpur-Anantpura. It is doubtful how many of these were actually Siddhar√°ja’s works. ↑

73 One of the best preserved slabs was sent by Sir John Malcolm when Resident of M√°lwa to the Museum of the B. B. R. A. S., where it still lies. It has verses in twelfth century Prakrit in honour of a king, but nothing historical can be made out of it. ↑

74 See above page 170. ↑

75 Devasúri was born in S. 1134 (a.d. 1078), took díksh√° in S. 1152 (a.d. 1096), became a Súri in S. 1174 (a.d. 1118), and died on a Thursday in the dark half of Sr√°vaṇa S. 1226 (a.d. 1170). His famous disciple Hemachandra was born on the fullmoon of K√°rtika S. 1145 (a.d. 1089), became an ascetic in S. 1150 (a.d. 1094), and died in S. 1229 (a.d. 1173). ↑

76 The Pr√°krit local name was Âno, of which the Sanskritised forms would appear to be Arno, Arnava, Án√°ka, and Ánalla as given in the Hammíramah√°k√°vya. The genealogy of these kings of Ś√°kambhari or S√°mbhar is not settled. The Nadol copperplate dated Saṃvat 1218 gives the name of its royal grantor as Alan and of Alan’s father as M√°haraja (Tod’s Rajasth√°n, I. 804), the latter apparently a mistake for Anar√°ja which is the name given in the Dvy√°śraya. Alan’s date being V. 1218, the date of his father Ána would fit in well with the early part of Kum√°rap√°la’s reign. The order of the two names Álhana and Ánalla in the Hammíramah√°k√°vya would seem to be mistaken and ought to be reversed. ↑

77 Kodin√°r is a town in G√°ikw√°r territory in South K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. This temple of Ambik√° is noticed as a place of Jain pilgrimage by the sage Jinaprabhasúri in his Tírthakalpa and was a well-known Jain shrine during the Aṇahilav√°ḍa period. ↑

78 The Kum√°rap√°laprabandha has Kelambapattana and Kolambapattana probably Kolam or Quilon. ↑

79 The Kum√°rap√°laprabandha says that Udayana was appointed minister and V√°gbhaṭa general. Soll√° the youngest son of Udayana did not take part in politics. ↑

80 Kirtane’s Hammíramah√°k√°vya, 13. ↑

81 Dhavalakka or Dholka according to the Kum√°rap√°laprabandha. ↑

82 According to the Kum√°rap√°lacharita Kum√°rap√°la’s sister who was married to Ána having heard her husband speak slightingly of the kings of Gujar√°t took offence, resented the language, and bandied words with her husband who beat her. She came to her brother and incited him to make an expedition against her husband. ↑

83 The Dvy√°śraya does not say that Kum√°rap√°la’s sister was married to Ána. ↑

84 This was a common title of the Sil√°h√°ra kings. Compare Bombay Gazetteer, XIII. 437 note 1. ↑

85 Ámbaḍ√° is his proper name. It is found Sanskritised into Ámrabhaṭa and Ambaka. ↑

86 This is the K√°verí river which flows through Chikhli and Bals√°r. The name in the text is very like Karaben√° the name of the same river in the N√°sik cave inscriptions (Bom. Gaz. XVI. 571) Kal√°viní and Karaben√° being Sanskritised forms of the original K√°veri. Perhaps the K√°veri is the Akabarou of the Periplus (a.d. 247). ↑

87 Sausara or S√°sar seems the original form from which Samara was Sanskritised. S√°sar corresponds with the Mehr name Ch√°char. ↑

88 The Kum√°rap√°lacharita says that Samara was defeated and his son placed on the throne. ↑

89 The translation of the inscription runs: Steps made by the venerable Ámbaka, Saṃvat 1222. According to the Kum√°rap√°laprabandha the steps were built at a cost of a l√°kh of drammas a dramma being of the value of about 5 annas. According to the Prabandhachint√°maṇi an earthquake occurred when the king was at Girn√°r on his way to Soman√°tha. The old ascent of Girn√°r was from the north called Chhatraśil√° that is the umbrella or overhanging rocks. Hem√°ch√°rya said if two persons went up together the Chhatraśil√° rocks would fall and crush them. So the king ordered Ámrabhaṭa to build steps on the west or Jun√°gaḍh face at a cost of 63 l√°khs of drammas. ↑

90 The site of B√°haḍapura seems to be the ruins close to the east of P√°lit√°na where large quantities of conch shell bangles and pieces of brick and tile have been found. ↑

91 This would appear to be the Kalachuri king Gay√° Karṇa whose inscription is dated 902 of the Chedi era that is a.d. 1152. As the earliest known inscription of Gay√° Karṇa’s son Narasiṃhadeva is dated a.d. 1157 (Chedi 907) the death of Gay√° Karṇa falls between a.d. 1152 and 1157 in the reign of Kum√°rap√°la and the story of his being accidentally strangled may be true. ↑

92 So many marriages on one day points to the people being either Kaḍva Kunbis or Bharv√°ḍs among whom the custom of holding all marriages on the same day still prevails. ↑

93 The text of the inscription is:

(1) … पौषसुदीगुरौ अद्योह श्रीमदण-

(2) हिलपाटके [समस्त] राजावलीबिराजितपरमभट्टारकमहा-

(3) [राजाधिराजनिर्जित] साकंभरीभूपालश्रीमदवन्तिनाथश्रीमत्कु

(4) [मारपाल] … नियुक्तमहामात्यश्रीजसोधव—

(5) ल श्रीकरणादौ समस्तमुद्राव्यापारान्परिपन्थयतीत्येवं

(6) काले [प्रवर्तमाने महाराजा] धिराजश्रीकुमारपालदेवेन विज

(7) ….. श्रीमदुदयपुरो .. रोचकान्वये महाराज—

(8) पुत्र ….. महाराजपुत्रवसन्तपाल एवं अन

(9) ….. लिखिता यात्रा । अद्य सोमग्रहणपर्वणि

(10) … लयवने समाहृततीर्थोदके स्नात्वा जगद्गु

(11) … सुखपुण्यजयवृद्धये उदयपुरकारि

(12) …… कारापित देवश्री ……..

Lines broken below. ↑

94 Annals of R√°jasth√°n, I. 803. ↑

95 R√°s M√°l√° (New Edition), 154. ↑

96 R√°s M√°l√° (New Edition), 154. ↑

97 The text is:

यः कौबेरीमा तुरुष्कमैन्द्रीमा त्रिदिवापगां

याम्यामा विन्ध्यमा सिन्धुं पश्चमां यो हासाधयत्‌

 ↑

98 It is also interesting, if there is a foundation of fact to the tale, that this is the temple visited by the Persian poet Sa√°di (a.d. 1200–1230) when he saw the ivory idol of Soman√°tha whose arms were raised by a hidden priest pulling a cord. According to Sa√°di on pretence of conversion he was admitted behind the shrine, discovered the cord-puller, threw him into a well, and fled. Compare Journal Royal Asiatic Society Bengal VII.–2 pages 885–886. That Sa√°di ever visited Soman√°tha is doubtful. No ivory human image can ever have been the chief object of worship at Soman√°tha. ↑

99 From the Prabandhachint√°maṇi and the Kum√°rap√°lacharita. ↑

100 The head-quarters of the Dhandhuka sub-division sixty miles south-west of Ahmad√°b√°d. ↑

101 Another reading is L√°hiní. ↑

102 Prabandhachint√°maṇi. ↑

103

भववीजाङ्कुरजनना रागाद्याः क्षयमुपागता यस्य ।

ब्रह्मा वा विष्णुर्वा हरो जिनो वा नमस्तस्मै ॥

यत्र तत्र समये यथा तथा योसि सोस्यभिधया यया तया ।

वीतदोषकलुषः स चेद्भवानेक एव भगवन्नमोस्तु ते ॥

 ↑

104 संवत्‌ १२२९ वैशाखशुदि ३ सोमे अद्येह श्रीमदणहिल्लपष्ठके समस्तरजावलीविराजितमहाराजाधिराजपरमेश्वर अजयपालदेवकल्याणविजयराज्ये तत्पादपद्मोपजीविनि महामात्यश्रीसोमेश्वरे श्रीकरणादौ. ↑

105 Regarding the remarkable story that not long before their deaths both Hem√°ch√°rya and Kum√°rap√°la inclined towards if they did not become converts to Isl√°m (Tod’s Western India, 184) no fresh information has been obtained. Another curious saying of Tod’s (Ditto, 182) also remains doubtful. Kum√°rap√°la expelled the tribe of L√°r from his kingdom. That this tribe of L√°r can have had to do either with L√°ṭa or South Gujar√°t or with the caste of L√°d V√°nis seems unlikely. The alternative is P√°rsis from Lar on the Persian Gulf whom Tod (Annals of Rajasth√°n, I. 235) notices as sending an expedition from Laristh√°n to Gujar√°t. In this connection it is worthy of note that L√°r remained the seat of a Gueber prince till a.d. 1600 the time of Shah Abas (D’Herbelot Bib. Or. II. 477). A repetition of the P√°rsi riots (Cambay Gazetteer, VI. 215) may have been the cause of their expulsion from Gujar√°t. ↑

106 See the Dvy√°śraya. A Patan inscription lying at Ver√°val also calls Ajayap√°la the brother’s son of Kum√°rap√°la. ↑

107 It is stated in a grant of Bhíma II. dated S. 1283, that Ajayadeva, as he is there called, made the Sap√°dalaksha or S√°mbhar king tributary. Ind. Ant. VI. 199ff. ↑

108 The Udayapura inscription mentions Someśvara as the minister of Ajayap√°la in Saṃvat 1229 (a.d. 1173). See above page 193. ↑

109 The abuse of Ajayap√°la is explained if Tod’s statement (Western India, 191) that he became a Musalm√°n is correct. ↑

110 Fleet’s K√°narese Dynasties, 93. ↑

111 Chapter II. Verse 57. ↑

112 We know much less about this event than its importance deserves, for with the exception of a raid made in a.d. 1197 by one of the Ghori generals this victory secured Gujar√°t from any serious Muhammadan attack for more than a century. We learn from various grants made by Bhímadeva II. (Ind. Ant VI. 195, 198, 200, 201) that Múlar√°ja’s regular epithet in the Vaṃś√°valí was “He who overcame in battle the ruler of the Garjjanakas, who are hard to defeat”: and Dr. Bühler has pointed out (Ditto, 201) that Garjjanaka is a Sanskritising of the name Ghaznavi. As a matter of fact, however, the leader of the Musalm√°n army was Muhammad of Ghor, and the battle took place in a.d. 1178 (H. 574). One of the two Muhammadan writers who mentions the invasion (Muhammad ’Ufi, who wrote at Delhi about a.d. 1211) says that Muhammad was at first defeated, but invaded the country a second time two years later “and punished the people for their previous misconduct.” But this is only mentioned incidentally as part of an anecdote of Muhammad’s equity, and there is some confusion with Muhammad’s victory in the second battle of N√°r√°yan (in Jaipur territory) in a.d. 1192, as a better, though slightly later authority, Minh√°j-us-Sir√°j, speaks of no second expedition to Gujar√°t led by Muhammad himself. Minh√°j-us-Sir√°j’s account of the defeat is as follows (Elliott, II. 294): He (Muhammad) conducted his army by way of Uch and Mult√°n towards Nahrw√°l√°. The R√°í of Nahrw√°l√°, Bhímdeo, was a minor, but he had a large army and many elephants. In the day of battle the Muhammadans were defeated and the Sult√°n was compelled to retreat. This happened in the year 574 H. (1178 a.d.)”. Further on we read (Elliott, II. 300): “In 593 H. (1197 a.d.) he (Muhammad’s general Kutb-ud-dín) went towards Nahrw√°l√°, defeated R√°í Bhímdeo, and took revenge on the part of the Sult√°n.” As no conquest of the country is spoken of, this expedition was evidently a mere raid. The only inaccuracy in the account is the mention of Bhíma instead of Múlar√°ja as the king who defeated the first invasion.—(A. M. T. J.) ↑

113 Sarga II. Verse 47. ↑

114 Sarga II. Verse 60. ↑

115 The Vich√°raśreṇi also gives S. 1235 as the beginning of his reign. ↑

116 Elliot’s History of India, II. 294. This event properly belongs to the reign of Múlar√°ja. See above page 195 note 5. ↑

117 Ind. Ant. VI. 207. ↑

118 Chapter II. Verse 61. ↑

119 Kielhorn’s and Peterson’s Reports on Sanskrit Manuscripts. ↑

120 Ind. Ant. VI. 197. ↑

121 The text is दत्त्वास्मै दोष्यते युवराज्यं राज्यं चिरं कुरु. ↑

122 The text is चाहू राण that is चाहुमाण राणक. The term R√°ṇaka would show him to be a Choh√°n chief. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER III.

THE VÁGHELÁS

(a.d. 1219–1304).


Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Arṇor√°ja, a.d. 1170–1200. Arṇor√°ja, a.d. 1170–1200.While Bhímadeva II. (a.d. 1179–1242) struggled to maintain his authority in the north, the country between the S√°barmatí and the Narbad√° in the south as well as the districts of Dholk√° and Dhandhuk√° in the south-west passed to the V√°ghel√°s a branch of the Solaṅkis sprung from Án√°ka or Arṇor√°ja, the son of the sister of Kum√°rap√°la’s (a.d. 1143–1173) mother. In return for services to Kum√°rap√°la,1 Án√°ka, with the rank of a noble or S√°manta, had received the village of Vy√°ghrapalli or V√°ghel√°, the Tiger’s Lair, about ten miles south-west of Aṇahilav√°ḍa. It is from this village that the dynasty takes its name of V√°ghela.

Lavaṇapras√°da, a.d. 1200–1233.Án√°ka’s son Lavaṇapras√°da, who is mentioned as a minister of Bhímadeva II. (a.d. 1179–1242)2 held V√°ghel√° and probably Dhavalagadha or Dholk√° about thirty miles to the south-west. The Kírtikaumudí or Moonlight of Glory, the chief cotemporary chronicle,3 describes Lavaṇapras√°da as a brave warrior, the slayer of the chief of Nadul√° the modern N√°ndol in M√°rw√°r. “In his well-ordered realm, except himself the robber of the glory of hostile kings, robbers were unknown. The ruler of M√°lava invading the kingdom turned back before the strength of Lavaṇapras√°da. The southern king also when opposed by him gave up the idea of war.” The ruler of M√°lava or M√°lwa referred to was Sohaḍa or Subhaṭavarman.4 The southern king was the Devagiri Y√°dava Singhaṇa II. (a.d. 1209–1247).5

Lavaṇapras√°da married Madanar√°jñí and by her had a son named Víradhavala. As heir apparent Víradhavala, who was also called Víra V√°ghel√° or the V√°ghel√° hero,6 rose to such distinction as a warrior that in the end Lavaṇapras√°da abdicated in his favour. Probably to reconcile the people to his venturing to oppose his sovereign Bhímadeva, Lavaṇapras√°da gave out that in a dream the Luck of Aṇahilav√°ḍa [199]
Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Lavaṇapras√°da, a.d. 1200–1233. appeared bewailing her home with unlighted shrines, broken walls, and jackal-haunted streets, and called on him to come to her rescue.7 Though he may have gone to the length of opposing Bhímadeva by force of arms, Lavaṇapras√°da was careful to rule in his sovereign’s name. Even after Lavaṇapras√°da’s abdication, though his famous minister Vastup√°la considered it advisable, Víradhavala refused to take the supreme title. It was not until the accession of Víradhavala’s son Vísaladeva that the head of the V√°ghel√°s took any higher title than R√°ṇaka or chieftain. Lavaṇapras√°da’s religious adviser or Guru was the poet Someśvara the author of the Kírtikaumudí and of the Vastup√°lacharita or Life of Vastup√°la, both being biographical accounts of Vastup√°la. The leading supporters both of Lavaṇapras√°da and of Víradhavala were their ministers the two Jain brothers Vastup√°la and Tejaḥp√°la the famous temple-builders on Ábu, Śatruñjaya, and Girn√°r. According to one account Tejaḥp√°la remained at court, while Vastup√°la went as governor to Stambhatírtha or Cambay where he redressed wrongs and amassed wealth.8

One of the chief times of peril in Lavaṇapras√°da’s reign was the joint attack of the Devagiri Y√°dava Singhaṇa or Sinhaṇa from the south and of four M√°rw√°r chiefs from the north. Lavaṇapras√°da and his son Víradhavala in joint command marched south to meet Singhaṇa at Broach. While at Broach the V√°ghel√°s’ position was made still more critical by the desertion of the Godhraha or Godhr√° chief to M√°lwa and of the L√°ṭa or south Gujar√°t chief to Singhaṇa. Still Lavaṇapras√°da pressed on, attacked Singhaṇa, and gave him so crushing a defeat, that, though Lavaṇapras√°da had almost at once to turn north to meet the M√°lwa army, Singhaṇa retired without causing further trouble.9 Someśvara gives no reason for Singhaṇa’s withdrawal beyond the remark ‘Deer do not follow the lion’s path even when the lion has left it.’ The true reason is supplied by a Manuscript called Forms of Treaties.10 The details of a treaty between Sinhaṇa and Lavaṇapras√°da under date Saṃvat 1288 (a.d. 1232) included among the Forms seem to show that the reason why Sinhaṇa did not advance was that Lavaṇapras√°da and his son submitted and concluded an alliance.11 In this copy of the treaty Siṇhaṇadeva is called the great king of kings or paramount sovereign Mah√°r√°j√°dhir√°ja, while Lavaṇapras√°da, Sanskritised into Lavaṇy√°pras√°da is called a R√°na and a tributary chief Mah√°mandaleśvara. The place where the treaty was concluded [200]
Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Lavaṇapras√°da, a.d. 1200–1233. is styled “the victorious camp,” and the date is Monday the fullmoon of Vaiś√°kha in the year Saṃvat 1288 (a.d. 1232). The provisions are that, as before, each of the belligerents should confine himself to his own territory; neither of them should invade the possessions of the other; if a powerful enemy attacked either of them, they should jointly oppose him; if only a hostile general led the attack, troops should be sent against him; and if from the country of either any noble fled into the territory of the other taking with him anything of value he should not be allowed harbourage and all valuables in the refugee’s possession should be restored.12 His good fortune went with Lavaṇapras√°da in his attack on the M√°rw√°r chiefs whom he forced to retire. Meanwhile Śankha13 who is described as the son of the ruler of Sindh but who seems to have held territory in Broach, raised a claim to Cambay and promised Vastup√°la Lavaṇapras√°da’s governor, that, if Vastup√°la declared in his favour14, he would be continued in his government. Vastup√°la rejected Śankha’s overtures, met him in battle outside of Cambay, and forced him to retire. In honour of Vastup√°la’s victory the people of Cambay held a great festival when Vastup√°la passed in state through the city to the shrine of the goddess Ekalla Víra outside of the town.15

Another of the deeds preserved in the Forms is a royal copperplate grant by Lavaṇapras√°da or L√°vaṇyapras√°da of a village, not named, for the worship of Soman√°tha. Lavaṇapras√°da is described as the illustrious R√°ṇaka,16 the great chief, the local lord or Mandaleśvara, the son of the illustrious R√°ṇaka Ánalde born in the illustrious pedigree of the Chaulukya dynasty. The grant is noted as executed in the reign of Bhímadeva II.17 while one Bh√°bhuya was his great minister. Though Bhímadeva was ruling in a.d. 1232 (Saṃvat 1288) Lavaṇapras√°da apparently had sufficient influence to make grants of villages and otherwise to act as the real ruler of Gujar√°t. It was apparently immediately after this grant (a.d. 1232?) that Lavaṇapras√°da abdicated in favour of Víradhavala.18

Víradhavala, a.d. 1233–1238.Soon after his accession Víradhavala, accompanied by his minister Tejaḥp√°la, started on an expedition against his wife’s brothers S√°ngaṇa and Chamuṇḍa the rulers of V√°manasthalí or Vanthalí near Jun√°gaḍh. As in spite of their sister’s advice S√°ngaṇa and Chamuṇḍa refused to pay tribute the siege was pressed. Early in the fight the cry arose ‘Víradhavala is slain.’ But on his favourite horse Uparavaṭa, Víradhavala put himself at the head of his troops, slew both the brothers, and gained the [201]
Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Víradhavala, a.d. 1233–1238. hoarded treasure of Vanthalí.19 In an expedition against the chief of Bhadreśvara, probably Bhadresar in Kacch, Víradhavala was less successful and was forced to accept the Kacch chief’s terms. The chroniclers ascribe this reverse to three R√°jput brothers who came to Víradhavala’s court and offered their services for 3,00,000 drammas (about £7500). “For 3,00,000 drammas I can raise a thousand men” said Víradhavala, and the brothers withdrew. They went to the court of the Bhadresar chief, stated their terms, and were engaged. The night before the battle the brothers sent to Víradhavala saying ‘Keep ready 3000 men, for through a triple bodyguard we will force our way.’ The three brothers kept their word. They forced their way to Víradhavala, dismounted him, carried off his favourite steed Uparavaṭa, but since they had been his guests they spared Víradhavala’s life.20

Another of Víradhavala’s expeditions was to East Gujar√°t. Ghughula, chief of Godraha or Godhr√°, plundered the caravans that passed through his territory to the Gujar√°t ports. When threatened with punishment by Víradhavala, Ghughula in derision sent his overlord a woman’s dress and a box of cosmetics. The minister Tejaḥp√°la, who was ordered to avenge this affront, dispatched some skirmishers ahead to raid the Godhra cattle. Ghughula attacked the raiders and drove them back in such panic that the main body of the army was thrown into disorder. The day was saved by the prowess of Tejaḥp√°la who in single combat unhorsed Ghughula and made him prisoner. Ghughula escaped the disgrace of the woman’s dress and the cosmetic box with which he was decorated by biting his tongue so that he died. The conquest of Ghughula is said to have spread Víradhavala’s power to the borders of Mah√°r√°shtra.21 The chroniclers relate another success of Víradhavala’s against Muizz-ud-dín apparently the famous Muhammad Gori Sult√°n Muizz-ud-dín Bahramsh√°h, the Sult√°n of Delhi (a.d. 1191–1205)22 who led an expedition against Gujar√°t. The chief of Ábu was instructed to let the Musalm√°n force march south unmolested and when they were through to close the defiles against their return. The Gujar√°t army met the Musalm√°ns and the Ábu troops hung on their rear. The Musalm√°ns fled in confusion and cartloads of heads were brought to Víradhavala in Dholk√°. The chronicles give the credit of this success to Vastup√°la. They also credit Vastup√°la with a stratagem which induced the Sult√°n to think well of Víradhavala and prevented him taking steps to wipe out the disgrace of his defeat. Hearing that the Sult√°n’s mother, or, according to another story, the Sult√°n’s religious adviser, was going from Cambay to Makka Vastup√°la ordered his men to attack and plunder the vessels in which the pilgrimage was to be made. On the captain’s complaint Vastup√°la had the pirates arrested and the property restored. So grateful was the owner, whether mother or guide, that Vastup√°la was taken to Delhi and arranged a friendly treaty between his master and the Sult√°n.23 [202]


Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Víradhavala, a.d. 1233–1238. Their lavish expenditure on objects connected with Jain worship make the brothers Vastup√°la and Tejaḥp√°la the chief heroes of the Jain chroniclers. They say when the Musalm√°n trader Sayad was arrested at Cambay his wealth was confiscated. Víradhavala claimed all but the dust which he left to Vastup√°la. Much of the dust was gold dust and a fire turned to dust more of the Sayad’s gold and silver treasure. In this way the bulk of the Sayad’s wealth passed to Vastup√°la. This wealth Vastup√°la and his brother Tejaḥp√°la went to bury in Had√°laka in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. In digging they chanced to come across a great and unknown treasure. According to the books the burden of their wealth so preyed on the brothers that they ceased to care for food. Finding the cause of her husband Tejaḥp√°la’s anxiety Anupam√° said ‘Spend your wealth on a hill top. All can see it; no one can carry it away.’ According to the chroniclers it was this advice, approved by their mother and by Vastup√°la’s wife Lalit√°deví, that led the brothers to adorn the summits of Ábu, Girn√°r, and Śatruñjaya with magnificent temples.

The Śatruñjaya temple which is dedicated to the twenty-third Tírthaṅkara Nemin√°tha is dated a.d. 1232 (Saṃvat 1288) and has an inscription by Someśvara, the author of the Kírtikaumudí telling how it was built. The Girn√°r temple, also dedicated to Nemin√°tha, bears date a.d. 1232 (Saṃvat 1288). The Ábu temple, surpassing the others and almost every building in India in the richness and delicacy of its carving, is dedicated to Nemin√°tha and dated a.d. 1231 (Saṃvat 1287). Such was the liberality of the brothers that to protect them against the cold mountain air each of their masons had a fire near him to warm himself and a hot dinner cooked for him at the close of the day. The finest carvers were paid in silver equal in weight to the dust chiselled out of their carvings.24

The author Someśvara describes how he twice came to the aid of his friend Vastup√°la. On one occasion he saved Vastup√°la from a prosecution for peculation. The second occasion was more serious. Siṃha the maternal uncle of king Vísaladeva whipped the servant of a Jain monastery. Enraged at this insult to his religion Vastup√°la hired a R√°jput who cut off Siṃha’s offending hand. The crime was proved and Vastup√°la was sentenced to death. But according to the Jains the persuasions of Someśvara not only made the king set Vastup√°la free, but led him to upbraid his uncle for beating the servant of a Jain monastery. Soon after his release Vastup√°la was seized with fever. Feeling the fever to be mortal he started for Śatruñjaya but died on the way. His brother Tejaḥp√°la and his son Jayantap√°la burned his body on the holy hill, and over his ashes raised a shrine with the name Svarg√°rohanapr√°s√°da The shrine of the ascent into Heaven.25 [203]


Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Víradhavala, a.d. 1233–1238. In a.d. 1238 six years after his father’s withdrawal from power Víradhavala died. One hundred and eighty-two servants passed with their lord through the flames, and such was the devotion that Tejaḥp√°la had to use force to prevent further sacrifices.26

Vísaladeva, a.d. 1243–1261.Of Víradhavala’s two sons, Vírama Vísala and Prat√°pamalla, Vastup√°la favoured the second and procured his succession according to one account by forcing the old king to drink poison and preventing by arms the return to Aṇahilav√°ḍa of the elder brother Vírama who retired for help to J√°b√°lipura (Jabalpur). Besides with his brother’s supporters Vísala had to contend with Tribhuvanap√°la the representative of the Aṇahilav√°ḍa Solaṅkis. Unlike his father and his grandfather Vísala refused to acknowledge an overlord. By a.d. 1243 he was established as sovereign in Aṇahilav√°ḍa. A later grant a.d. 1261 (Saṃvat 1317) from Kaḍi in North Gujar√°t shows that Aṇahilav√°ḍa was his capital and his title Mah√°r√°j√°dhir√°ja King of Kings. According to his copperplates Vísaladeva was a great warrior, the crusher of the lord of M√°lwa, a hatchet at the root of the turbulence of Mew√°ḍ, a volcanic fire to dry up Singhaṇa of Devagiri’s ocean of men.27 Vísaladeva is further described as chosen as a husband by the daughter of Karṇ√°ṭa28 and as ruling with success and good fortune in Aṇahilav√°ḍa with the illustrious N√°gada as his minister.29 The bards praise Vísaladeva for lessening the miseries of a three years famine,30 and state that he built or repaired the fortifications of Vísalanagara in East and of Darbhavatí or Dabhoi in South Gujar√°t.

Arjuṇadeva, a.d. 1262–1274.During Vísaladeva’s reign V√°ghela power was established throughout Gujar√°t. On Vísaladeva’s death in a.d. 1261 the succession passed to Arjuṇadeva the son of Vísaladeva’s younger brother Prat√°pamalla.31 Arjuṇadeva proved a worthy successor and for thirteen years (a.d. 1262–1274; Saṃvat 1318–1331) maintained his supremacy. Two stone inscriptions one from Ver√°val dated a.d. 1264 (Saṃvat 1320) the other from Kacch dated a.d. 1272 (Saṃvat 1328) show that his territory included both Kacch and K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, and an inscription of his successor S√°raṅgadeva shows that his power passed as far east as Mount Ábu.

The Ver√°val inscription of a.d. 1264 (Saṃvat 1320), which is in the temple of the goddess Harsut√°,32 describes Arjuṇadeva as the king [204]
Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Arjuṇadeva, a.d. 1262–1274. of kings, the emperor (chakravartin) of the illustrious Chaulukya race, who is a thorn in the heart of the hostile king Niḥsankamalla, the supreme lord, the supreme ruler, who is adorned by a long line of ancestral kings, who resides in the famous Aṇahillap√°ṭaka. The grant allots certain income from houses and shops in Soman√°tha Patan to a mosque built by Piroz a Muhammadan shipowner of Ormuz which is then mentioned as being under the sway of Amír Rukn-ud-dín.33 The grant also provides for the expenses of certain religious festivals to be celebrated by the Shiite sailors of Soman√°tha Patan, and lays down that under the management of the Musalm√°n community of Soman√°tha any surplus is to be made over to the holy districts of Makka and Madina. The grant is written in bad Sanskrit and contains several Arabic Persian and Gujar√°ti words. Its chief interest is that it is dated in four eras, “in 662 of the Prophet Muhammad who is described as the teacher of the sailors, who live near the holy lord of the Universe that is Soman√°tha; in 1320 of the great king Vikrama; in 945 of the famous Valabhi; and in 151 of the illustrious Siṃha.” The date is given in these four different eras, because the Muhammadan is the donor’s era, the Saṃvat the era of the country, the Valabhi of the province, and the Siṃha of the locality.34 The Kacch inscription is at the village of Rav about sixty miles east of Bhúj. It is engraved on a memorial slab at the corner of the courtyard wall of an old temple and bears date a.d. 1272 (Saṃvat 1328). It describes Arjuṇadeva as the great king of kings, the supreme ruler, the supreme lord. It mentions the illustrious M√°ladeva as his chief minister and records the building of a step-well in the village of Rav.35

S√°raṅgadeva, a.d. 1275–1296.Arjuṇadeva was succeeded by his son S√°raṅgadeva. According to the Vich√°raśreṇi S√°raṅgadeva ruled for twenty-two years from a.d. 1274 to 1296 (Saṃvat 1331–1353). Inscriptions of the reign of S√°raṅgadeva have been found in Kacch and at Ábu. The Kacch inscription is on a p√°lia or memorial slab now at the village of Khokhar near Kanthkot which was brought there from the holy village of Bhadresar about thirty-five miles north-east of M√°ndvi. It bears date a.d. 1275 (Saṃvat 1332) and describes S√°raṅgadeva as the great king of kings, the supreme ruler, the supreme lord ruling at Aṇahillap√°ṭaka with the illustrious M√°ladeva as his chief minister.36 The Ábu inscription dated a.d. 1294 (Saṃvat 1350) in the temple of Vastup√°la regulates certain dues payable to the Jain temple and mentions S√°raṅgadeva as sovereign of Aṇahillap√°ṭaka and as having for vassal Vísaladeva ruler of the old capital of Chandr√°vati about twelve miles south of Mount Ábu.37 A third inscription dated a.d. [205]
Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
S√°raṅgadeva, a.d. 1275–1296. 1287 (Saṃvat 1343), originally from Soman√°tha, is now at Cintra in Portugal. It records the pilgrimages and religious benefactions of one Tripur√°ntaka, a follower of the Nakulíś√° P√°śupata sect, in the reign of S√°raṅgadeva, whose genealogy is given. A manuscript found in Ahmad√°b√°d is described as having been finished on Sunday the 3rd of the dark fortnight of Jyeshṭha in the Saṃvat year 1350, in the triumphant reign of S√°raṅgadeva the great king of kings, while his victorious army was encamped near Áś√°palli (Ahmad√°b√°d).38

Karṇadeva, a.d. 1296–1304.S√°raṅgadeva’s successor Karṇadeva ruled for eight years a.d. 1296–1304 (Saṃvat 1352–1360). Under this weak ruler, who was known as Ghelo or the Insane, Gujar√°t passed into Musalm√°n hands. In a.d. 1297 Alaf Kh√°n the brother of the Emperor Al√°-ud-dín Khilji (a.d. 1296–1317) with Nasrat Kh√°n led an expedition against Gujar√°t. They laid waste the country and occupied Aṇahilav√°ḍa. Leaving his wives, children, elephants, and baggage Karṇadeva fled to Ramadeva the Y√°dava chief of Devagiri.39 All his wealth fell to his conquerors. Among the wives of Karṇadeva who were made captive was a famous beauty named Kaul√°deví, who was carried to the harem of the Sult√°n. In the plunder of Cambay Nasrat Kh√°n took a merchant’s slave Malik K√°fur who shortly after became the Emperor’s chief favourite. From Cambay the Muhammadans passed to K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and destroyed the temple of Soman√°tha. In 1304 Alaf Kh√°n’s term of office as governor of Gujar√°t was renewed. According to the Mir√°t-i-Ahmadí after the renewal of his appointment, from white marble pillars taken from many Jain temples, Alaf Kh√°n constructed at Aṇahilav√°ḍa the J√°ma Masjid or general mosque.

In a.d. 1306 the Cambay slave K√°fur who had already risen to be Sult√°n Al√°-ud-dín’s chief favourite was invested with the title of Malik Naib and placed in command of an army sent to subdue the Dakhan. Alaf Kh√°n, the governor of Gujar√°t, was ordered to help Malik K√°fur in his arrangements. At the same time Kaul√°deví persuaded the Emperor to issue orders that her daughter Devaladeví should be sent to her to Delhi. Devaladeví was then with her father the unfortunate Karṇadeva in hiding in B√°gl√°n in N√°sik. Malik K√°fur sent a messenger desiring Karṇadeva to give up his daughter. Karṇadeva refused and Alaf Kh√°n was ordered to lead his army to the B√°gl√°n hills and capture the princess. While for two months he succeeded in keeping the Muhammadan army at bay, Karṇadeva received and accepted an offer for the hand of Devaladeví from the Devagiri Y√°dava chief Śankaradeva. On her way to Devagiri near Elura Devaladeví’s escort was attacked by a party of Alaf Kh√°n’s troops, and the lady seized and sent to Delhi where she was married to prince Khizar Kh√°n. [206]
Chapter III.
The V√°ghel√°s, a.d. 1219–1304
Karṇadeva, a.d. 1296–1304. Nothing more is known of Karṇadeva who appears to have died a fugitive.

Though the main cities and all central Gujar√°t passed under Musalm√°n rule a branch of the V√°ghel√°s continued to hold much of the country to the west of the S√°barmatí, while other branches maintained their independence in the rugged land beyond Amb√° Bhaw√°ní between Vírpur on the Mahí and Posin√° at the northmost verge of Gujar√°t.40

GENEALOGY OF THE VÁGHELÁS.

Dhavala,
a.d. 1160
Married Kum√°rap√°la’s Aunt.
Arṇor√°ja,
a.d. 1170
Founder of V√°ghela.
Lavaṇapras√°da,
a.d. 1200
Chief of Dholk√°.
Víradhavala,
a.d. 1233–1238
Chief of Dholk√°.
Vísaladeva,
a.d. 1243–1261
King of Aṇahilav√°ḍa.
Arjuṇadeva,
a.d. 1262–1274.
S√°raṅgadeva,
a.d. 1274–1295.
Karṇadeva or Ghelo,
a.d. 1296–1304.

1 Án√°ka survived Kum√°rap√°la and served also under Bhímadeva II. Seeing the kingdom of his weak sovereign divided among his ministers and chiefs Án√°ka strove till his death to re-establish the central authority of the Solaṅki dynasty. K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xiii. ↑

2 R√°s M√°l√° (New Edition), 200. ↑

3 Kírtikaumudí, Bombay Sanskrit Series Number XXV. ↑

4 Ind. Ant. VI. 188 footnote. According to Merutuṇga a cotemporary chronicler an epigram of Bhíma’s minister turned back Subhaṭavarman. ↑

5 Ind. Ant. VI. 188. ↑

6 According to one story Madanar√°jñí left her husband’s house taking Víradhavala with her, and went to live with Deva R√°ja Pattakíla the husband of her deceased sister. On growing up Víradhavala returned to his father’s house. R√°s M√°l√° (New Edition), 201. ↑

7 Dr. Bühler in Ind. Ant. VI. 189. ↑

8 According to the Kírtikaumudí, K√°thavate’s Ed. XIV. note 1, under Vastup√°la low people ceased to earn money by base means; the wicked turned pale; the righteous prospered. All honestly and securely plied their calling. Vastup√°la put down piracy, and, by building platforms, stopped the mingling of castes in milk shops. He repaired old buildings, planted trees, sank wells, laid out parks, and rebuilt the city. All castes and creeds he treated alike. ↑

9 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xv. ↑

10 The use of the date Monday the fullmoon of Vaiśakha, Saṃvat 1288 (a.d. 1232) in the second part of the Forms seems to shew that the work was written in a.d. 1232. ↑

11 Though the object is to give the form of a treaty of alliance, the author could not have used the names Sinhaṇa and Lavaṇapras√°da unless such a treaty had been actually concluded between them. Apparently Sinhaṇa’s invasion of Gujar√°t took place but a short time before the book of treaties was compiled. Bhand√°rkar’s Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts (1882–83), 40–41. ↑

12 Bhand√°rkar’s Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts (1882–83), 40. ↑

13 According to other accounts Śankha, a Broach chieftain, took up the cause of a certain Sayad or Musalm√°n merchant with whom Vastup√°la had quarrelled. In the fight Lunap√°la a Gola, one of Vastup√°la’s chief supporters, was slain and in his honour Vastup√°la raised a shrine to the Lord Lunap√°la. R√°s M√°l√° (New Edition), 201–202. ↑

14 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xv.–xvi. ↑

15 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xv.–xvi. ↑

16 The modern Gujar√°ti R√°ṇ√°. ↑

17 Bhímadeva’s name is preceded by the names of his ten Chaulukya predecessors in the usual order. The attributes of each are given as in published Chaulukya copperplates. Ind. Ant. VI. 180–213. ↑

18 Bhand√°rkar’s Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts (1882–83), 39. ↑

19 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xxiii. ↑

20 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xxiii. ↑

21 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xxiii.–xxiv. ↑

22 Elliot and Dowson, II. 209. ↑

23 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xxiv.–xxv. ↑

24 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xx.; J. B. R. A. S. XVIII. Number XLVIII. 28. The Jain writers delight in describing the magnificence of the pilgrimages which Vastup√°la conducted to the holy places. The details are 4500 carts, 700 palanquins, 1800 camels, 2900 writers, 12,100 white-robed and 1100 naked or sky-clad Jains, 1450 singers, and 3300 bards. K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xvi. ↑

25 K√°thavate’s Kírtikaumudí, xviii.–xix. ↑

26 R√°s M√°l√°, 202. ↑

27 Ind. Ant. VI. 191. The word for Mew√°ḍ is Medap√°ta the Med or Mher land. ↑

28 The Karn√°ta king would probably be Someśvara (a.d. 1252) or his son Narasiṃha III. (a.d. 1254) of the Hoysala Ball√°las of Dv√°rasamudra. Fleet’s K√°narese Dynasties, 64, 69. ↑

29 These details are mentioned in a grant of land in M√°ndal in Ahmad√°b√°d to Br√°hmans to fill a drinking fountain, repair temples, and supply offerings. Ind. Ant. VI. 210–213. ↑

30 R√°s M√°l√° (New Ed.), 212. A Jaina Patt√°vali or succession list of High-priests notices that the famine lasted for three years from Saṃvat 1315 (a.d. 1259). The text may be translated as follows: Vikrama Saṃvat 1315, three years’ famine the king (being) Vísaladeva. Bhandarkar’s Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts for 1883–84, 15, 323. ↑

31 See Ep. Ind. I. ↑

32 The inscription was first noticed by Colonel Tod: Rajasth√°n, I. 705: Western India, 506. ↑

33 This is not Sult√°n Rukn-ud-dín of the slave kings, who ruled from a.d. 1234 to a.d. 1235. Elliot and Dowson, II. ↑

34 All four dates tally. The middle of a.d. 1264 (Saṃvat 1320) falls in Hijra 662. As the Valabhi era begins in a.d. 318–319 and the Siṃha era in a.d. 1113, 945 of Valabhi and 151 of Siṃha tally with a.d. 1264. ↑

35 Bombay Government Selections CLII. New Series, 71. ↑

36 From an unpublished copy in the possession of R√°o S√°heb Dalpatram Pranjiwan Khakhar, late Educational Inspector, Kacch. Only the upper six lines of the inscription are preserved. ↑

37 Asiatic Researches, XVI. 311; R√°s M√°l√°, 213. ↑

38 Professor Bhandarkar’s Report for 1883–84, 17–18. ↑

39 The bardic story is that king Karṇa had two N√°gar Br√°hman ministers M√°dhava and Keśava. He slew Keśava and took M√°dhava’s wife from her husband. In revenge M√°dhava went to Delhi and brought the Muhammadans. After the Muhammadan conquest M√°dhava presented Al√°-ud-dín with 360 horses. In return M√°dhava was appointed civil minister with Alaf Kh√°n as military governor commanding a l√°kh of horsemen, 1500 elephants, 20,000 foot soldiers, and having with him forty-five officers entitled to use kettledrums. R√°s M√°l√°, 214. ↑

40 R√°s M√°l√°, 222. The Jh√°l√°s were firmly fixed in the plains between the Lesser Ran of Kacch and the Gulf of Cambay. The Koli branches of these clans with other tribes of pure or of adulterated aboriginal descent, spread over the Chunv√°l near Viramg√°m and appeared in many remote and inaccessible tracts of hill or forest. On the east, under the protection of a line of R√°jput princes, the banner of the goddess K√°li floated from the hill of P√°v√°gaḍ; while in the west the descendants of Kheng√°r held their famous fortress of Jun√°gaḍh from within its walls controlling much of the peninsula over which they had maintained undisputed sway. Chiefs of Jun√°gaḍh origin were scattered over the rest of the peninsula among whom were the Gohils of Gogo and Piram, and of the sea-washed province which from them derived its name of Gohilv√°d. ↑

PART II.

MUSALMÁN GUJARÁT.

a.d. 1297–1760.

This history of Musalm√°n Gujar√°t is based on translations of the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (a.d. 1611) and of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (a.d. 1756) by the late Colonel J. W. Watson. Since Colonel Watson’s death in 1889 the translations have been revised and the account enriched by additions from the Persian texts of Farishtah and of the two Mirăts by Mr. Fazl Lutfull√°h Farídi of Surat. A careful comparison has also been made with other extracts in Elliot’s History of India and in Bayley’s History of Gujar√°t. [207]

[Contents]

MUSALMÁN GUJARÁT.

a.d. 1297–1760.

INTRODUCTION.


Introduction.
Musalm√°n Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760. Muhammadan rule in Gujar√°t lasted from the conquest of the province by the Dehli emperor Al√°-ud-dín Khilji (a.d. 1295–1315), shortly before the close of the thirteenth century a.d., to the final defeat of the Mughal viceroy Momín Kh√°n by the Mar√°th√°s and the loss of the city of Áhmed√°b√°d at the end of February 1758.

This whole term of Musalm√°n ascendancy, stretching over slightly more than four and a half centuries, may conveniently be divided into three parts. The First, the rule of the early sovereigns of Dehli, lasting a few years more than a century, or, more strictly from a.d. 1297 to a.d. 1403; the Second, the rule of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, a term of nearly a century and three-quarters, from a.d. 1403 to a.d. 1573; the Third, the rule of the Mughal Emperors, when, for little less than two hundred years, a.d. 1573–1760, Gujar√°t was administered by viceroys of the court of Dehli.

Territorial Limits.In the course of these 450 years the limits of Gujar√°t varied greatly. In the fourteenth century the territory nominally under the control of the Musalm√°n governors of P√°tan (Aṇahilav√°ḍa) extended southwards from Jh√°lor, about fifty miles north of Mount Abu, to the neighbourhood of Bombay, and in breadth from the line of the M√°lwa and Kh√°ndesh hills to the western shores of peninsular Gujar√°t.1 The earlier kings of Áhmed√°b√°d (a.d. 1403–1450), content with establishing their power on a firm footing, did not greatly extend the limits of their kingdom. Afterwards, during the latter part of the fifteenth and the beginning of the sixteenth centuries (a.d. 1450–1530), the dominions of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings gradually spread till they included large tracts to the east and north-east formerly in the possession of the rulers of Kh√°ndesh and M√°lwa. Still later, during the years of misrule between a.d. 1530 and a.d. 1573, the west of Kh√°ndesh and the north of the Konkan ceased to form part of the kingdom of Gujar√°t. Finally, under the arrangements introduced by the emperor Akbar in a.d. 1583, more lands were restored to M√°lwa and Kh√°ndesh. With the exception of Jh√°lor and Sirohi on the north, Dungarpur and B√°nsv√°da on the north-east, and Alir√°jpur on [208]
Introduction.
Musalm√°n Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760. the east, since handed to R√°jput√°na and Central India, the limits of Gujar√°t remain almost as they were laid down by Akbar.

Sorath.Though, under the Musalm√°ns, peninsular Gujar√°t did not bear the name of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, it was then, as at present, considered part of the province of Gujar√°t. During the early years of Musalm√°n rule, the peninsula, together with a small portion of the adjoining mainland, was known as Sorath, a shortened form of Saurâshṭra, the name originally applied by the Hindus to a long stretch of sea-coast between the banks of the Indus and Daman.2 Towards the close of the sixteenth century the official use of the word Sorath was confined to a portion, though by much the largest part, of the peninsula. At the same time, the name Sorath seems then, and for long after, to have been commonly applied to the whole peninsula. For the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, writing as late as the middle of the eighteenth century (a.d. 1756: a.h. 1170), speaks of Sorath as divided into five districts or zill√°hs, H√°l√°r, K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, Gohilv√°ḍa, B√°bri√°v√°ḍa, and Jetv√°ḍa, and notices that though Nav√°nagar was considered a separate district, its tribute was included in the revenue derived from Sorath.3 In another passage the same writer thus defines Saur√°shṭra:

Saur√°shṭra or Sorath comprehends the Sark√°r of Sorath the Sark√°r of Isl√°mnagar or Nav√°nagar and the Sark√°r of Kachh or Bhujnagar. It also includes several zillahs or districts, Naiyad which they call Jatw√°r, H√°l√°r or Nav√°nagar and its vicinity, K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, Gohilv√°ḍa, B√°bri√°v√°ḍa, Chorv√°r, Panch√°l, Okh√°gir in the neighbourhood of Jagat otherwise called Dw√°rka, Prabh√°s Khetr or P√°tan Somn√°th and its neighbourhood, N√°ghír also called S√°lgogha, and the Nalk√°ntha.4

[209]


Introduction.
Musalm√°n Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760. The present Sorath stretches no further than the limits of Jun√°gaḍh, B√°ntwa, and a few smaller holdings.

K√°thi√°v√°ḍa.The name K√°thi√°v√°ḍa is of recent origin. It was not until after the establishment of Musalm√°n power in Gujar√°t that any portion of the peninsula came to bear the name of the tribe of K√°this. Even as late as the middle of the eighteenth century, the name K√°thi√°v√°ḍa was applied only to one of the sub-divisions of the peninsula. In the disorders which prevailed during the latter part of the eighteenth century, the K√°this made themselves conspicuous. As it was from the hardy horsemen of this tribe that the tribute-exacting Mar√°th√°s met with the fiercest resistance, they came to speak of the whole peninsula as the land of the K√°this. This use was adopted by the early British officers and has since continued.

Under the kings, 1403–1573.Under the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, as it still is under British rule, Gujar√°t was divided politically into two main parts; one, called the kh√°lsah or crown domain administered directly by the central authority; the other, on payment of tribute in service or in money, left under the control of its former rulers. The amount of tribute paid by the different chiefs depended, not on the value of their territory, but on the terms granted to them when they agreed to become feudatories of the kings of Áhmed√°b√°d. Under the Gujar√°t Sult√°ns this tribute was occasionally collected by military expeditions headed by the king in person and called mulkgíri or country-seizing circuits.

States.The internal management of the feudatory states was unaffected by their payment of tribute. Justice was administered and the revenue collected in the same way as under the Aṇahilapur kings. The revenue consisted, as before, of a share of the crops received in kind, supplemented by the levy of special cesses, trade, and transit dues. The chief’s share of the crops differed according to the locality; it rarely exceeded one-third of the produce, it rarely fell short of one-sixth. From some parts the chief’s share was realised directly from the cultivator by agents called mantris; from other parts the collection was through superior landowners.5

Districts.The Áhmed√°b√°d kings divided the portion of their territory which was under their direct authority into districts or sark√°rs. These districts were administered in one of two ways. They were either assigned to nobles in support of a contingent of troops, or they were set apart as crown domains and managed by paid officers. The officers placed in charge of districts set apart as Crown Lands.crown domains were called muktiă.6 Their chief duties were to preserve the peace and to collect the revenue. For the maintenance of order, a body of soldiers from the army head-quarters at Áhmed√°b√°d was detached for service in each of these divisions, and placed under the command of the district governor. At the same time, in addition to the presence of this detachment of regular troops, every district contained certain [210]
Introduction.
Under the kings, a.d. 1403–1573. fortified outposts called th√°n√°s, varying in number according to the character of the country and the temper of the people. These posts were in charge of officers called th√°nad√°rs subordinate to the district governor. They were garrisoned by bodies of local soldiery, for whose maintenance, in addition to money payments, a small assignment of land was set apart in the neighbourhood of the post. On the arrival of the tribute-collecting army the governors of the districts through which it passed were expected to join the main body with their local contingents. At other times the district governors had little control over the feudatory chiefs in the neighbourhood of their charge.

Fiscal.For fiscal purposes each district or sark√°r was distributed among a certain number of sub-divisions or pargan√°hs, each under a paid official styled √°mil or tahsild√°r. These sub-divisional officers realised the state demand, nominally one-half of the produce, by the help of the headmen of the villages under their charge. In the sharehold and simple villages of North Gujar√°t these village headmen were styled patels or according to Musalm√°n writers mukaddams and in the simple villages of the south they were known as des√°is. They arranged for the final distribution of the total demand in joint villages among the shareholders, and in simple villages from the individual cultivators.7 The sub-divisional officer presented a statement of the accounts of the villages in his sub-division to the district officer, whose record of the revenue of his whole district was in turn forwarded to the head revenue officer at court. As a check on the internal management of his charge, and especially to help him in the work of collecting the revenue, with each district governor was associated an accountant. Further that each of these officers might be the greater check on the other, king Áhmed I. (a.d. 1412–1443) enforced the rule that when the governor was chosen from among the royal slaves the accountant should be a free man, and that when the accountant was a slave the district governor should be chosen from some other class. This practise was maintained till the end of the reign of Muzaffar Sh√°h (a.d. 1511–1525), when, according to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, the army became much increased, and the ministers, condensing the details of revenue, farmed it on contract, so that many parts formerly yielding one rupee now produced ten, and many others seven eight or nine, and in no place was there a less increase than from ten to twenty per cent. Many other changes occurred at the same time, and the spirit of innovation creeping into the administration the wholesome system of checking the accounts was given up and mutiny and confusion spread over Gujar√°t.8

Assigned Lands.The second class of directly governed districts were the lands assigned to nobles for the maintenance of contingents of troops. As in other parts of India, it would seem that at first these assignments were for specified sums equal to the pay of the contingent. When such assignments were of long standing, and were large enough to swallow the whole revenue of a district, it was natural to simplify the [211]
Introduction.
Under the kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Assigned Lands. arrangement by transferring the collection of the revenue and the whole management of the district to the military leader of the contingent. So long as the central power was strong, precautions were doubtless taken to prevent the holder of the grant from unduly rackrenting his district and appropriating to himself more than the pay of the troops, or from exercising any powers not vested in the local governors of districts included within the crown domains. As in other parts of India, those stipulations were probably enforced by the appointment of certain civil officers directly from the government to inspect the whole of the noble’s proceedings, as well in managing his troops as in administering his lands.9 The decline of the king’s power freed the nobles from all check or control in the management of their lands. And when, in a.d. 1536, the practice of farming was introduced into the crown domains, it would seem to have been adopted by the military leaders in their lands, and to have been continued till the annexation of Gujar√°t by the emperor Akbar in a.d. 1573.

Under the Mughals, a.d. 1573–1760.It was the policy of Akbar rather to improve the existing system than to introduce a new form of government. After to some extent contracting the limits of Gujar√°t he constituted it a province or sûbah of the empire, appointing to its Administration.government an officer of the highest rank with the title of sûbahd√°r or viceroy. As was the case under the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, the province continued to be divided into territories managed by feudatory chiefs, and Crown Lands.districts administered by officers appointed either by the court of Dehli or by the local viceroy. The head-quarters of the army remained at Áhmed√°b√°d, and detachments were told off and placed under the orders of the officers in charge of the directly administered divisions. These district governors, as before, belonged to two classes, paid officers responsible for the management of the crown domains and military leaders in possession of lands assigned to them in pay of their contingent of troops. The governors of the crown domains, who were now known as faujd√°rs or commanders, had, in addition to the command of the regular troops, the control of the outposts maintained within the limits of their charge. Like their predecessors they accompanied the viceroy in his yearly circuit for the collection of tribute.

As a check on the military governors and to help them in collecting the revenue, the distinct class of account officers formerly established by king Áhmed I. (a.d. 1412–1443) was again introduced. The head of this branch of the administration was an officer, second in rank to the viceroy alone, appointed direct from the court of Dehli with the title of div√°n. Besides acting as collector-general of the revenues of the province, this officer was also the head of its civil administration. His title div√°n is generally translated minister. And though the word minister does not express the functions of the office, which corresponded more nearly with those of a chief secretary, it represents with sufficient accuracy the relation in which the holder of the office of div√°n generally stood to the viceroy. [212]


Introduction.
Under the Mughals, a.d. 1573–1760.
Revenue Officials. Revenue Officials.For its revenue administration each district or group of districts had its revenue officials called amíns who corresponded to the collector of modern times. There were also amíns in the customs department separate from those whose function was to control and administer the land revenue. Beneath the amín came the √°mil10 who carried on the actual collection of the land revenue or customs in each district or pargan√°h, and below the √°mil were the f√°îls, mushrifs, or k√°rkúns that is the revenue clerks. The √°mil corresponded to the modern m√°mlatd√°r, both terms meaning him who carries on the amal or revenue management. In the leading ports the √°mil of the customs was called mutasaddi that is civil officer.

Village Officers.The √°mil or m√°mlatd√°r dealt directly with the village officials, namely with the mukaddam or headman, the patw√°ri or lease manager, the k√°núngo or accountant, and the hav√°ld√°r or grain-yard guardian. The hav√°ld√°r superintended the separation of the government share of the produce; apportioned to the classes subject to forced labour their respective turns of duty; and exercised a general police superintendence by means of subordinates called pas√°it√°s or vartani√°s. In ports under the mutasaddi was a harbour-master or sh√°h-bandar.

Des√°is.Crown sub-divisions had, in addition, the important class called des√°is. The des√°is’ duty appears at first to have been to collect the sal√°mi or tribute due by the smaller chiefs, landholders, and v√°nt√°d√°rs or sharers. For this, in Akbar’s time, the des√°i received a remuneration of 2½ per cent on the sum collected. Under the first viceroy Mírza Ázíz Kokalt√°sh (a.d. 1573–1575) this percentage was reduced to one-half of its former amount, and in later times this one-half was again reduced by one-half. Though the Muhammadan historians give no reason for so sweeping a reduction, the cause seems to have been the inability of the des√°is to collect the tribute without the aid of a military force. Under the new system the des√°i seems merely to have kept the accounts of the tribute due, and the records both of the amount which should be levied as tribute and of other customary rights of the crown. In later times the des√°is were to a great extent superseded by the district accountants or majmud√°rs, and many des√°is, especially in south Gujar√°t, seem to have sunk to patels.

Land Tax.Up to the viceroyalty of Mírza Ísa Tarkh√°n (a.d. 1642–1644), the land tax appears to have been levied from the cultivator in a fixed sum, but he was also subject to numerous other imposts. Land grants in wazífah carried with them an hereditary title and special exemption from all levies except the land tax. The levy in kind appears to have ceased before the close of Mughal rule. In place of a levy in kind each village paid a fixed sum or jama through the district accountant or majmud√°r who had taken the place of the des√°i. As in many cases the jama really meant the lump sum at which the crown villages were assessed and farmed to the chiefs and patels, on the collapse of the empire many villages thus farmed to chiefs and landlords were [213]
Introduction.
Under the Mughals, a.d. 1573–1760.
Land Tax. retained by them with the connivance of the majmud√°rs des√°is and others.

Justice.The administration of justice seems to have been very complete. In each kasbah or town k√°zis, endowed with glebe lands in addition to a permanent salary, adjudicated disputes among Muhammadans according to the laws of Isl√°m. Disputes between Muhammadans and unbelievers, or amongst unbelievers, were decided by the department called the sad√°rat, the local judge being termed a sadr. The decisions of the local k√°zis and sadrs were subject to revision by the k√°zi or sadr of the súbah who resided at Áhmed√°b√°d. And as a last resort the Áhmed√°b√°d decisions were subject to appeal to the K√°zi-ul-Kuzz√°t and the Sadr-ûs-Sudûr at the capital.

Fiscal.The revenue appears to have been classed under four main heads: 1. The Khaz√°nah-i-Ámirah or imperial treasury which comprehended the land tax received from the crown pargan√°hs or districts, the tribute, the five per cent customs dues from infidels, the import dues on stuffs, and the s√°yer or land customs including transit dues, slave market dues, and miscellaneous taxes. 2. The treasury of arrears into which were paid government claims in arrear either from the √°mils or from the farmers of land revenue; tak√°vi advances due by the raiyats; and tribute levied by the presence of a military force. 3. The treasury of charitable endowments. Into this treasury was paid the 2½ per cent levied as customs dues from Muhammadans.11 The pay of the religious classes was defrayed from this treasury. 4. The treasury, into which the jaziah or capitation tax levied from zimmís or infidels who acknowledged Muhammadan rule, was paid. The proceeds were expended in charity and public works. After the death of the emperor Farrukhsiyar (a.d. 1713–1719), this source of revenue was abolished. The arrangements introduced by Akbar in the end of the sixteenth century remained in force till the death of Aurangzíb in a.d. 1707. Then trouble and perplexity daily increased, till in a.d. 1724–25, Hamíd Kh√°n usurped the government lands, and, seeking to get rid of the servants and assignments, gradually obtained possession of the records of the registry office. The keepers of the records were scattered, and yearly revenue statements ceased to be received from the districts.12

Assigned Lands.Akbar continued the system of assigning lands to military leaders in payment of their contingents of troops. Immediately after the annexation in a.d. 1573, almost the whole country was divided among the great nobles.13 Except that the revenues of certain tracts were [214]
Introduction.
Under the Mughals, a.d. 1573–1760.
Assigned Lands. set aside for the imperial exchequer the directly governed districts passed into the hands of military leaders who employed their own agents to collect the revenue. During the seventeenth century the practice of submitting a yearly record of their revenues, and the power of the viceroy to bring them to account for misgovernment, exercised a check on the management of the military leaders. And during this time a yearly surplus revenue of £600,000 (Rs. 60,00,000) from the assigned and crown lands was on an average forwarded from Gujar√°t to Dehli. In the eighteenth century the decay of the viceroy’s authority was accompanied by the gradually increased power of the military leaders in possession of assigned districts, till finally, as in the case of the Naw√°bs of Broach and Surat, they openly claimed the position of independent rulers.14

Minor Offices.Of both leading and minor officials the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi supplies the following additional details. The highest officer who was appointed under the seal of the minister of the empire was the provincial div√°n or minister. He had charge of the fiscal affairs of the province and of the revenues of the kh√°lsa or crown lands, and was in some matters independent of the viceroy. Besides his personal salary he had 150 saw√°rs for two provincial th√°n√°s Arjanpur and Khamb√°lia. Under the div√°n the chief officers were the píshk√°r div√°n his first assistant, who was appointed under imperial orders by the patent of the div√°n, the daroghah or head of the office, and the sharf or mushrif and tehwild√°r of the daftar kh√°n√°hs, who presided over the accounts with munshis and muharrirs or secretaries and writers. The k√°zis, both town and city, with the sanction of the emperor were appointed by the chief law officer of the empire through the chief law officer of the province. They were lodged by the state, paid partly in cash partly in land, and kept up a certain number of troopers. In the k√°zis’ courts wakíls or pleaders and muftís or law officers drew 8 as. to Re. 1 a day. Newly converted Musalm√°ns also drew 8 as. a day. The city censor or muhtasib had the supervision of morals and of weights and measures. He was paid in cash and land, and was expected to keep up sixty troopers. The news-writer, who was sometimes also bakhshi or military paymaster, had a large staff of news-writers called w√°kiâh-nig√°r who worked in the district courts and offices as well as in the city courts. He received his news-reports every evening and embodied them in a letter which was sent to court by camel post. A second staff of news-writers called saw√°níhnig√°r reported rumours. A third set were the hark√°r√°s on the viceroy’s staff. Postal chaukis or stations extended from Áhmed√°b√°d to the Ajmír frontier, each with men and horse ready to carry the imperial post which reached Sh√°h Jeh√°n√°b√°d or Dehli in seven days. A line of posts also ran south through Broach to the Dakhan. The faujd√°rs or military police, who were sometimes commanders of a thousand and held estates, controlled both the city and the district police. The kotw√°l or head of the city night-watch was appointed by the viceroy. He had fifty troopers and a hundred foot. In the treasury department were the amín or chief, the d√°roghah, the [215]
Introduction.
Under the Mughals, a.d. 1573–1760.
Minor Offices. mushrif, the treasurer, and five messengers. In the medical department were a Yún√°ni or Greek school and a Hindu physician, two under-physicians on eight and ten annas a day, and a surgeon. The yearly grant for food and medicine amounted to Rs. 2000.15

Land Tenures.Besides the class of vernacular terms that belong to the administration of the province, certain technical words connected with the tenure of land are of frequent occurrence in this history. For each of these, in addition to the English equivalent which as far as possible has been given in the text, some explanation seems necessary. During the period to which this history refers, the superior holders of the land of the province belonged to two main classes, those whose claims dated from before the Musalm√°n conquest and those whose interest in the land was based on a Musalm√°n grant. By the Musalm√°n historians, landholders of the first class, who were all Hindus, are called zamínd√°rs, while landholders of the second class, Musalm√°ns as a rule, are spoken of as j√°gírd√°rs. Though the term zamínd√°r was used to include the whole body of superior Hindu landholders, in practice a marked distinction was drawn between the almost independent chief, who still enjoyed his Hindu title of r√°ja, r√°val, r√°v, or j√°m, and the petty claimant to a share in a government village, who in a Hindu state would have been known as a gar√°si√°.16

Hereditary Hindu Landholders.The larger landholders, who had succeeded in avoiding complete subjection, were, as noticed above, liable only for the payment of a certain fixed sum, the collection of which by the central power in later times usually required the presence of a military force. With regard to the settlement of the claims of the smaller landholders of the superior class, whose estates fell within the limits of the directly administered districts, no steps seem to have been taken till the reign of Áhmed Sh√°h I. (a.d. 1411–1443). About the year a.d. 1420 the peace of his kingdom was so broken by agrarian disturbances, that Áhmed Sh√°h agreed, on condition of their paying tribute and performing military service, to re-grant to the landholders of the zamínd√°r class as hereditary possessions a one-fourth share of their former village lands. The portion so set apart was called v√°nta or share, and the remainder, retained as state land, was called talpat. This agreement continued till, in the year a.d. 1545, during the reign of Mahmúd Sh√°h II. (a.d. 1536–1553), an attempt was made to annex these private shares to the crown. This measure caused much discontent and disorder. It was reversed by the emperor Akbar who, as part of the settlement of the province in a.d. 1583, restored their one-fourth share to the landholders, and, except that the Mar√°th√°s [216]
Introduction.
Under the Mughals, a.d. 1573–1760.
Hereditary Hindu Landholders. afterwards levied an additional quit-rent from these lands, the arrangements then introduced have since continued in force.17

Levies.During the decay of Musalm√°n rule in Gujar√°t in the first half of the eighteenth century, shareholders of the gar√°sia class in government villages, who were always ready to increase their power by force, levied many irregular exactions from their more peaceful neighbours, the cultivators or inferior landholders. These levies are known as vol that is a forced contribution or p√°l that is protection. All have this peculiar characteristic that they were paid by the cultivators of crown lands to petty marauders to purchase immunity from their attacks. They in no case partook of the nature of dues imposed by a settled government on its own subjects. Tora gar√°s, more correctly toda gar√°s, is another levy which had its origin in eighteenth century disorder. It was usually a readymoney payment taken from villages which, though at the time crown or kh√°lsa, had formerly belonged to the gar√°sia who exacted the levy. Besides a readymoney payment contributions in kind were sometimes exacted.

Service Lands.The second class of superior landholders were those whose title was based on a Musalm√°n grant. Such grants were either assignments of large tracts of land to the viceroy, district-governors, and nobles, to support the dignity of their position and maintain a contingent of troops, or they were allotments on a smaller scale granted in reward for some special service. Land granted with these objects was called j√°gír, and the holder of the land j√°gírd√°r. In theory, on the death of the original grantee, such possessions were strictly resumable; in practice they tended to become hereditary. No regular payments were required from holders of j√°gírs. Only under the name of peshkash occasional contributions were demanded. These occasional contributions generally consisted of such presents as a horse, an elephant, or some other article of value. They had more of the nature of a freewill offering than of an enforced tribute. Under the Musalm√°ns contributions of this kind were the only payments exacted from proprietors of the j√°gírd√°r class. But the Mar√°th√°s, in addition to contributions, imposed on j√°gírd√°rs a regular tribute, similar to that paid by the representatives of the original class of superior Hindu landholders.

Under Musalm√°n rule great part of Gujar√°t was always in the hands of j√°gírd√°rs. So powerful were they that on two occasions under the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, in a.d. 1554 and a.d. 1572, the leading [217]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760. nobles distributed among themselves the entire area of the kingdom.18 Again, during the eighteenth century, when Mughal rule was on the decline, the j√°gírd√°rs by degrees won for themselves positions of almost complete independence.19

Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.The changes in the extent of territory and in the form of administration illustrate the effect of the government on the condition of the people during the different periods of Musalm√°n rule. The following summary of the leading characteristics of each of the main divisions of the four-and-a-half centuries of Musalm√°n ascendancy may serve as an introduction to the detailed narrative of events.

Under the Early Viceroys, 1297–1403.On conquering Gujar√°t in a.d. 1297 the Musalm√°ns found the country in disorder. The last kings of Aṇahilapur or P√°tan, suffering under the defects of an incomplete title, held even their crown lands with no firmness of grasp, and had allowed the outlying territory to slip almost entirely from their control. Several of the larger and more distant rulers had resumed their independence. The Bhíls and Kolis of the hills, forests, and rough river banks were in revolt. And stranger chiefs, driven south by the Musalm√°n conquests in Upper India, had robbed the central power of much territory.20 The records of the early Musalm√°n governors (a.d. 1297–1391) show suspicion on the side of the Dehli court and disloyalty on the part of more than one viceroy, much confusion throughout the province, and little in the way of government beyond the exercise of military force. At the same time, in spite of wars and rebellions, the country, in parts at least, seems to [218]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760. have been well cultivated, and trade and manufactures to have been flourishing.21

Under the Kings, 1403–1573.The period of the rule of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings (a.d. 1403–1573) contains two divisions, one lasting from a.d. 1403 to a.d. 1530, on the whole a time of strong government and of growing power and prosperity; the other the forty-three years from a.d. 1530 to the conquest of the province by the emperor Akbar in a.d. 1573, a time of disorder and misrule. In a.d. 1403 when Gujar√°t separated from Dehli the new king held but a narrow strip of plain. On the north were the independent chiefs of Sirohi and Jh√°lor, from whom he occasionally levied contributions. On the east the R√°ja of Ídar, another R√°jput prince, was in possession of the western skirts of the hills and forests, and the rest of that tract was held by the mountain tribes of Bhils and Kolis. On the west the peninsula was in the hands of nine or ten Hindu tribes, probably tributary, but by no means obedient.22 In the midst of so unsettled and warlike a population, all the efforts of Muzaffar I., the founder of the dynasty, were spent in establishing his power. It was not until the reign of his successor Áhmed I. (a.d. 1412–1443) that steps were taken to settle the different classes of the people in positions of permanent order. About the year a.d. 1420 two important measures were introduced. Of these one assigned lands for the support of the troops, and the other recognised the rights of the superior class of Hindu landholders to a portion of the village lands they had formerly held. The effect of these changes was to establish order throughout the districts directly under the authority of the crown. And though, in the territories subject to feudatory chiefs, the presence of an armed force was still required to give effect to the king’s claims for tribute, his increasing power and wealth made efforts at independence more hopeless, and gradually secured the subjection of the greater number of his vassals. During the latter part of the fifteenth and the first quarter of the sixteenth century the power of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings was at its height. At that time their dominions included twenty-five divisions or sark√°rs. Among nine of these namely P√°tan, Áhmed√°b√°d, Sunth, Godhra, Ch√°mp√°ner, Baroda, Broach, N√°ndod or R√°jpípla, and Surat the central plain was distributed. In addition in the north were four divisions, Sirohi, Jh√°lor, Jodhpur, and N√°gor now in south-west and central R√°jput√°na; in the north-east two, Dúngarpur and B√°nsv√°da, now in the extreme [219]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Under the Kings, 1403–1573. south of R√°jput√°na; in the east and south-east three, Nandurb√°r now in Kh√°ndesh, Mulher or B√°gl√°n now in N√°sik, and R√°m Nagar or Dharampur now in Surat; in the south four, Danda-R√°japuri or Janjira, Bombay, Bassein, and Daman now in the Konkan; in the west two, Sorath and Nav√°nagar now in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa; and Kachh in the north-west. Besides the revenues of these districts, tribute was received from the rulers of Ahmednagar, Burh√°npur, Ber√°r, Golkonda, and Bij√°pur, and customs dues from twenty-five ports on the western coast of India and from twenty-six foreign marts, some of them in India and others in the Persian Gulf and along the Arabian coast.23 The total revenue from these three sources is said in prosperous times to have amounted to a yearly sum of £11,460,000 (Rs. 11,46,00,000). Of this total amount the territorial revenue from the twenty-five districts yielded £5,840,000 (Rs. 5,84,00,000), or slightly more than one-half. Of the remaining £5,620,000 (Rs. 5,62,00,000) about one-fifth part was derived from the Dakhan tribute and the rest from customs-dues.24

The buildings at Áhmed√°b√°d, and the ruins of Ch√°mp√°ner and Mehmúd√°b√°d, prove how much wealth was at the command of the sovereign and his nobles, while the accounts of travellers seem to show that the private expenditure of the rulers was not greater than the kingdom was well able to bear. The Portuguese traveller Duarte Barbosa, who was in Gujar√°t between a.d. 1511 and a.d. 1514, found the capital Ch√°mp√°ner a great city, in a very fertile country of abundant provisions, with many cows sheep and goats and plenty of fruit, so that it was full of all things.25 Áhmed√°b√°d was still larger, very rich and well [220]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Under the Kings, 1403–1573. supplied, embellished with good streets and squares, with houses of stone and cement. It was not from the interior districts of the province that the Áhmed√°b√°d kings derived the chief part of their wealth, but from those lying along the coast, which were enriched by manufactures and commerce.26 So it was that along the shores of the gulf of Cambay and southward as far as Bombay the limit of the Gujar√°t kingdom, besides many small sea-ports, Barbosa chooses out for special mention twelve ‘towns of commerce, very rich and of great trade.’ Among these was Diu, off the south coast of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, yielding so large a revenue to the king as to be ‘a marvel and amazement.’ And chief of all Cambay, in a goodly, fertile, and pretty country full of abundant provisions; with rich merchants and men of great prosperity; with craftsmen and mechanics of subtle workmanship in cotton, silk, ivory, silver, and precious stones; the people well dressed, leading luxurious lives, much given to pleasure and amusement.27

The thirty-eight years between the defeat of king Bah√°dur by the emperor Hum√°yún in a.d. 1535 and the annexation of Gujar√°t by Akbar in a.d. 1573 was a time of confusion. Abroad, the superiority of Gujar√°t over the neighbouring powers was lost, and the limits of the kingdom shrank; at home, after the attempted confiscation (a.d. 1545) of their shares in village lands the disaffection of the superior landowners became general, and the court, beyond the narrow limits of the crown domains, ceased to exercise substantial control over [221]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760. either its chief nobles or the more turbulent classes. In spite of these forty years of disorder, the province retained so much of its former prosperity, that the boast of the local historians that in a.d. 1573 Gujar√°t was in every respect allowed to be the finest country in Hindust√°n is supported by the details shortly afterwards (a.d. 1590) given by Abul Fazl in the Áin-i-Akbari. The high road from P√°tan to Baroda was throughout its length of 150 miles (100 kos) lined on both sides with mango trees; the fields were bounded with hedges; and such was the abundance of mango and other fruit trees that the whole country seemed a garden. The people were well housed in dwellings with walls of brick and mortar and with tiled roofs; many of them rode in carriages drawn by oxen; the province was famous for its painters, carvers, inlayers, and other craftsmen.28
