Under the Mughals, 1573–1760.Like the period of the rule of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, the period of Mughal rule contains two divisions, a time of good government lasting from a.d. 1573 to a.d. 1700, and a time of disorder from a.d. 1700 to a.d. 1760. Under the arrangements introduced by the emperor Akbar in a.d. 1583, the area of the province was considerably curtailed. Of its twenty-five districts nine were restored to the states from which the vigour of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings had wrested them; J√°lor and Jodhpur were transferred to R√°jput√°na; N√°gor to Ajmír; Mulher and Nandurb√°r to Kh√°ndesh; Bombay, Bassein, and Daman were allowed to remain under the Portuguese; and Danda-R√°japuri (Jinjira) was made over to the Niz√°msh√°hi (a.d. 1490–1595) rulers of the Dakhan Ahmednagar. Of the remaining sixteen, Sirohi, Dungarpur, and B√°nsv√°da now in R√°jput√°na, Kachh, Sûnth in Rewa K√°ntha, and R√°mnagar (Dharampur) in Surat were, on the payment of tribute, allowed to continue in the hands of their Hindu rulers. The ten remaining districts were administered directly by imperial officers. But as the revenues of the district of Surat had been separately assigned to its revenue officer or mutasaddi, only nine districts with 184 sub-divisions or pargan√°hs were entered in the collections from the viceroy of Gujar√°t. These nine districts were in continental Gujar√°t, P√°tan with seventeen sub-divisions, Áhmed√°b√°d with thirty-three, Godhra with eleven, Ch√°mp√°ner with thirteen, Baroda with four, Broach with fourteen, and R√°jpipla (N√°ndod) with twelve. In the peninsula were Sorath with sixty-two and Nav√°nagar with seventeen sub-divisions. This lessening of area seems to have been accompanied by even more than a corresponding reduction in the state demand. Instead of £5,840,050 (Rs. 5,84,00,500), the revenue recovered in a.d. 1571, two years before the province was annexed, under the arrangement introduced by the emperor Akbar, the total amount, including the receipts from Surat and the tribute of the six feudatory [222]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Under the Mughals, 1573–1760. districts, is returned at £1,999,113 (Rs. 1,99,91,130) or little more than one-third part of what was formerly collected.29

According to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi this revenue of £1,999,113 (Rs. 1,99,91,130) continued to be realised as late as the reign of Muhammad Sh√°h (a.d. 1719–1748). But within the next twelve years (a.d. 1748–1762) the whole revenue had fallen to £1,235,000 (Rs. 1,23,50,000). Of £1,999,113 (Rs. 1,99,91,130), the total amount levied by Akbar on the annexation of the province, £520,501 (Rs. 52,05,010), or a little more than a quarter, were set apart for imperial use and royal expense; £55,000 (Rs. 5,50,000) were assigned for the support of the viceroy and the personal estates of the nobles, and the remainder was settled for the pay of other officers of rank and court officials. Nearly £30,000 (Rs. 3,00,000) were given away as rewards and pensions to religious orders and establishments.30 [223]


Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Under the Mughals, 1573–1760. Besides lightening the state demand the emperor Akbar introduced three improvements: (1) The survey of the land; (2) The payment of the headmen or mukaddams of government villages; and (3) The restoration to small superior landholders of the share they formerly enjoyed in the lands of government villages. The survey which was entrusted to R√°ja Todar Mal, the revenue minister of the empire, was completed in a.d. 1575. The operations were confined to a small portion of the whole area of the province. Besides the six tributary districts which were unaffected by the measure, Godhra in the east, the western peninsula, and a large portion of the central strip of directly governed lands were excluded, so that of the 184 sub-divisions only 64 were surveyed. In a.d. 1575, of 7,261,849 acres (12,360,594 bigh√°s), the whole area measured, 4,920,818 acres (8,374,498 bigh√°s) or about two-thirds were found to be fit for cultivation, and the remainder was waste. In those parts of the directly governed districts where the land was not measured the existing method of determining the government share of the produce either by selecting a portion of the field while the crop was still standing, or by dividing the grain heap at harvest time, was continued. In surveyed districts the amount paid was determined by the area and character of the land under cultivation. Payment was made either in grain or in money, according to the instructions issued to the revenue-collectors, ‘that when it would not prove oppressive the value of the grain should be taken in ready money at the market price.’31 The chief change in the revenue management was that, instead of each year calculating the government share from the character of the crop, an uniform demand was fixed to run for a term of ten years.

Another important effect of this survey was to extend to cultivators in simple villages the proprietary interest in the soil formerly enjoyed only by the shareholders of joint villages. By this change the power of the military nobles to make undue exactions from the cultivators in their assigned lands was to some extent checked. It was, perhaps, also an indirect effect of this more definite settlement of the crown demand that the revenue agents of government and of the holders of assigned lands, finding that the revenues could be realised without their help, refused to allow to the heads of villages certain revenue dues which, in return for their services, they had hitherto enjoyed. Accordingly, in a.d. 1589–90, these heads of villages appealed to government and Akbar decided that in assigned districts as well as in the crown domains from the collections of government lands two-and-a-half per cent should be set apart as a perquisite for men of this class.32 [224]


Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Under the Mughals, 1573–1760. When the heads of villages laid their own private grievance before government, they also brought to its notice that the Koli and R√°jput landowners, whose shares in government villages had been resumed by the crown in a.d. 1545, had since that time continued in a state of discontent and revolt and were then causing the ruin of the subjects and a deficiency in the government collections. An inquiry was instituted, and, to satisfy the claims of landowners of this class, it was agreed that, on furnishing good security for their conduct and receiving the government mark on their contingent of cavalry, they should again be put in possession of a one-fourth share of the land of government villages. While the province was managed agreeably to these regulations, says the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, its prosperity continued to increase.33

Though these measures did much to check internal disorder, Gujar√°t, for several years after it came under Mughal control, continued disturbed by insurrections among the nobles, and so imperfectly protected from the attacks of foreign enemies that between the years a.d. 1573 and 1609 each of its three richest cities, Áhmed√°b√°d Cambay and Surat, was in turn taken and plundered.34 During the rest [225]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Under the Mughals, 1573–1760. of the seventeenth century, though the country was from time to time disturbed by Koli and R√°jput risings, and towards the end of the century suffered much from the raids of the Mar√°th√°s, the viceroys were, on the whole, able to maintain their authority, repressing the outbreaks of the disorderly classes, and enforcing the imperial claims for tribute on the more independent feudatory chiefs. Throughout the greater part of the seventeenth century the general state of the province seems to have been prosperous. Its cities were the wonder of European travellers. Surat, which only since the transfer of Gujar√°t to the Mughal empire had risen to hold a place among its chief centres of trade, was, in a.d. 1664, when taken by Shiv√°ji, rich enough to supply him with plunder in treasure and precious stones worth a million sterling35; and at that time Cambay is said to have been beyond comparison greater than Surat, and Áhmed√°b√°d much richer and more populous than either.36

From the beginning of the eighteenth century disorder increased. Unable to rely for support on the imperial court, the viceroys failed to maintain order among the leading nobles, or to enforce their tribute from the more powerful feudatories. And while the small Koli and R√°jput landholders, freed from the control of a strong central power, were destroying the military posts, taking possession of the state share of village lands, and levying dues from their more peaceful neighbours, the burden of the Mar√°tha tribute was year by year growing heavier. During the last ten years of Musalm√°n rule so entirely did the viceroy’s authority forsake him, that, according to the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, when the great landholders refused to pay their tribute, the viceroy had no power to enforce payment. And so faithless had the great landowners become that the viceroy could not pass the city gate without an escort.37 [226]


Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Self-governed Zamínd√°rs. The above summary contains frequent references to three classes of zamínd√°rs: (1) The zamínd√°rs of the self-governed states; (2) The greater zamínd√°rs of the crown districts; and (3) The lesser zamínd√°rs of the crown districts.

Self-governed Zamínd√°rs.In the case of the zamínd√°rs of self-governed states the principle was military service and no tribute. The author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi says that finally the zamínd√°rs of the self-governed states ceased to do service. In spite of this statement it seems probable that some of this class served almost until the complete collapse of the empire, and that tribute was rarely levied from them by an armed force. In the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi account of the office of súbahd√°r or n√°zim sûbah the following passage occurs: When occasion arose the n√°zims used to take with their armies the contingents of the R√°n√°s of Udepur Dúngarpur and B√°nsv√°da, which were always permanently posted outside their official residences (in Áhmed√°b√°d). This shows that these great zamínd√°rs had official residences at the capital, where probably their contingents were posted under wakíls or agents. It therefore seems probable that their tribute too would be paid through their representatives at the capital and that a military force was seldom sent against them. Accordingly notices of military expeditions in the tributary sark√°rs are rare though they were of constant occurrence in the crown districts.

Crown Zamínd√°rs.The position of the zamínd√°rs of the kh√°lsa or crown districts was very different from that of the zamínd√°rs of self-governed territories. The kh√°lsa zamínd√°rs had been deprived of the greater portion of their ancestral estates which were administered by the viceregal revenue establishment. In some instances their capitals had been annexed. Even if not annexed the capital was the seat of faujd√°r who possessed the authority and encroached daily on the rights and privileges of the chieftain. The principal chiefs in this position were those of R√°jpípla and Ídar in Gujar√°t and the J√°m of Nav√°nagar in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. Of the three, R√°jpipla had been deprived of his capital N√°ndod and of all the fertile districts, and was reduced to a barren sovereignty over rocks, hills and Bhíls at R√°jpípla. Ídar had suffered similar treatment and the capital was the seat of a Muhammadan faujd√°r. Nav√°nagar, which had hitherto been a tributary sark√°r, was during the reign of Aurangzíb made a crown district. But after Aurangzíb’s death the J√°m returned to his capital and again resumed his tributary relations.

Smaller Zamínd√°rs.The lesser holders, including gr√°si√°s w√°nt√°d√°rs and others, had suffered similar deprivation of lands and were subject to much encroachment from the government officials. Throughout the empire widespread discontent prevailed among subordinate holders of this description as well as among all the zamínd√°rs of the crown districts, so that the successes of Shiv√°ji in the Dakhan found ardent sympathisers even in Gujar√°t. When the zamínd√°rs saw that this Hindu rebel was strong enough to pillage Surat they began to hope that a day of deliverance was near. The death of Aurangzíb (a.d. 1707) was the signal for these restless spirits to bestir themselves. When the Mar√°th√°s began regular inroads they were hailed as deliverers from the yoke [227]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Smaller Zamínd√°rs. of the Mughal. The R√°jpípla chief afforded them shelter and a passage through his country. The encouragement to anarchy given by some of the R√°jput viceroys who were anxious to emancipate themselves from the central control further enabled many chieftains gir√°si√°s and others to absorb large portions of the crown domains, and even to recover their ancient capitals. Finally disaffected Muhammadan faujd√°rs succeeded in building up estates out of the possessions of the crown and founding the families which most of the present Muhammadan chieftains of Gujar√°t represent.

Mar√°tha Ascendancy, 1760–1802.When the imperial power had been usurped by the Mar√°tha leaders, the chiefs who had just shaken off the more powerful Mughal yoke were by no means disposed tamely to submit to Mar√°tha domination. Every chief resisted the levy of tribute and Momín Kh√°n reconquered Áhmed√°b√°d. In this struggle the Mar√°th√°s laboured under the disadvantage of dissensions between the Peshwa and the G√°ikw√°r. They were also unaware of the actual extent of the old imperial domain and were ignorant of the amount of tribute formerly levied. They found that the faujd√°rs, who, in return for Mar√°tha aid in enabling them to absorb the crown pargan√°hs, had agreed to pay tribute, now joined the zamínd√°rs in resisting Mar√°tha demands, while with few exceptions the des√°is and majmud√°rs either openly allied themselves with the zamínd√°rs or were by force or fraud deprived of their records. G√°ikw√°r Saved by British Alliance, 1802.So serious were the obstacles to the collection of the Mar√°tha tribute that, had it not been for the British alliance in a.d. 1802, there seems little doubt that the G√°ikw√°r would have been unable to enforce his demands in his more distant possessions. The British alliance checked the disintegration of the G√°ikw√°r’s power, and the permanent settlement of the tribute early in this century enabled that chief to collect a large revenue at a comparatively trifling cost. Not only were rebels like Malh√°rr√°o and K√°noji suppressed, but powerful servants like Vithalr√°v Dev√°ji, who without doubt would have asserted their independence, were confirmed in their allegiance and the rich possessions they had acquired became part of the G√°ikw√°r’s dominions.

Power of Chiefs.It must not be supposed that while the larger chiefs were busy absorbing whole pargan√°hs the lesser chiefs were more backward. They too annexed villages and even Mughal posts or th√°n√°hs, while w√°nt√°d√°rs or sharers absorbed the talpat or state portion, and, under the name of tora gar√°s,38 daring spirits imposed certain rights over crown villages once their ancient possessions, or, under the name of p√°l or vol, enforced from neighbouring villages payments to secure immunity from pillage. Even in the Baroda district of the thirteen Mughal posts only ten now belong to the G√°ikw√°r, two having been conquered by gir√°si√°s and one having fallen under Broach. In Saur√°shṭra except R√°npur and Gogha and those in the Amreli district, not a single Mughal post is in the possession either of the British Government or of the [228]
Introduction.
Condition of Gujar√°t, a.d. 1297–1760.
Power of Chiefs. G√°ikw√°r. A reference to the Mughal posts in other parts of Gujar√°t shows that the same result followed the collapse of Musalm√°n power.

Power of Local Chiefs.Since the introduction of Musalm√°n rule in a.d. 1297 each successive government has been subverted by the ambition of the nobles and the disaffection of the chiefs. It was thus that the Gujar√°t Sult√°ns rendered themselves independent of Dehli. It was thus that the Sult√°n’s territories became divided among the nobles, whose dissensions reduced the province to Akbar’s authority. It was thus that the chiefs and local governors, conniving at Mar√°tha inroads, subverted Mughal rule. Finally it was thus that the G√°ikw√°r lost his hold of his possessions and was rescued from ruin solely by the power of the British. [229]

1 The first notice of the exercise of sovereignty by the Musalm√°n rulers of Gujar√°t over lands further south than the neighbourhood of Surat is in a.d. 1428, when king Áhmed I. (a.d. 1412–1443) contested with the Dakhan sovereign the possession of M√°him (north latitude 19° 40′; east longitude 72° 47′). As no record remains of a Musalm√°n conquest of the coast as far south as Danda R√°japuri or Janjira, about fifty miles south of Bombay, it seems probable that the North Konkan fell to the Musalm√°ns in a.d. 1297 as part of the recognised territories of the lords of Aṇahilapura (P√°tan). R√°s M√°l√°, I. 350. One earlier reference may be noted. In a.d. 1422 among the leading men slain in the battle of S√°rangpur, about fifty miles north-east of Ujjain in Central India, was S√°vant chief of Danda R√°japuri that is Janjíra. Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text), 40, and Farishtah (Persian Text), II. 468. ↑

2 The details of Akbar’s settlement in a.d. 1583 show Sorath with sixty-three subdivisions and Nav√°nagar (Isl√°mnagar) with seventeen. Similarly in the Áin-i-Akbari (a.d. 1590) Sorath with its nine divisions includes the whole peninsula except Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa in the north, which was then part of Áhmed√°b√°d. Gladwin, II. 64 and 66–71. ↑

3 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 418. ↑

4 Naiyad is the present Naiyadk√°ntha about ten miles south-west of R√°dhanpur containing Jatv√°r and V√°rahi in the west near the Ran and spreading east to Sami and Munjpur thirty to forty miles south-west of P√°tan. H√°l√°r is in the north-west of the peninsula; K√°thi√°v√°ḍa in the centre; Gohilv√°ḍa in the south-east; B√°bri√°v√°ḍa south-west of Gohilv√°ḍa; Chor√°r or Chorv√°r north-west of Vir√°val; Panch√°l in the north-east centre; Okh√°gir or Okh√°mandal in the extreme west. Nalk√°ntha is the hollow between K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and the mainland. Besides these names the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi gives one more district in Sorath and others in Gujar√°t. The name he gives in Sorath is N√°gher or N√°ghír which he says is also called S√°lgogah. S√°lgogah is apparently Si√°lbet and its neighbourhood, as Kodin√°r, M√°dhúpúr, Chingaria, and Pata in south K√°thi√°v√°ḍa are still locally known as Nagher, a tract famous for its fruitfulness. The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi contains the following additional local names: For Kadi thirty-five miles north-west of Áhmed√°b√°d, Dand√°i; for Dholka twenty-five miles south-west of Áhmed√°b√°d, Pr√°th-Nagri; for Cambay, T√°mb√°nagri; for Víramg√°m forty miles north-west of Áhmed√°b√°d, Jh√°l√°w√°r; for Múnjpur twenty-two miles south-east of R√°dhanpur and some of the country between it and Patan, P√°rpas; for the tract ten miles south-east of R√°dhanpur to the neighbourhood of P√°tan, Kakrez; for the town of R√°dhanpur in the P√°lanpur Political Superintendency and its neighbourhood, V√°gaḍh; for the town of P√°lanpur and its neighbourhood up to Dísa and D√°ntiv√°da, Dh√°nd√°r; for B√°l√°sinor forty-two miles east of Áhmed√°b√°d with a part of Kapadvanj in the Kaira district, Mas√°lwaḍa; for Baroda, P√°rkher; for the subdivision of Jambúsar in the Broach district fifteen miles north-west of Broach city, K√°nam; for Alimohan that is Chhota Udepur and the rough lands east of Godhra, P√°lw√°ra. ↑

5 R√°s M√°la, I. 241. ↑

6 Maktaă and ikt√°ă, the district administered by a muktiă, come from the Arabic root kata√°, he cut, in allusion to the public revenue or the lands cut and apportioned for the pay of the officers and their establishments. ↑

7 Further particulars regarding these village headmen are given below. ↑

8 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 192; Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Persian Text, 44. ↑

9 Elphinstone’s History, 76. ↑

10 In M√°rw√°r and in the north and north-east this official was styled tahsíld√°r and in the Dakhan kam√°vísd√°r. ↑

11 Zak√°t, literally purification or cleansing, is the name of a tax levied from Muslims for charitable purposes or religious uses. In the endowments-treasury the customs dues from Muslims at 2½ per cent (the technical 1 in 40) as contrasted with the five per cent levied from infidels (the technical 2 in 40) were entered. Hence in these accounts zak√°t corresponds with customs dues, and is divisible into two kinds khushki zak√°t or land customs and tari zak√°t or sea customs. ↑

12 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 93. Though under the Mughal viceroys the state demand was at first realized in grain, at the last the custom was to assess each sub-division, and probably each village, at a fixed sum or jama. The total amount for the sub-division was collected by an officer called majmud√°r, literally keeper of collections, the village headmen, patels or mukaddams, being responsible each for his own village. ↑

13 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 325. ↑

14 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 341. ↑

15 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi Persian Text page 115. ↑

16 The title r√°ja is applicable to the head of a family only. The payment of tribute to the Mughals or Mar√°th√°s does not affect the right to use this title. R√°na and r√°v seem to be of the same dignity as r√°ja. R√°val is of lower rank. The sons of r√°j√°s, r√°n√°s, r√°vs, and r√°vals are called kuvars and their sons th√°kurs. The younger sons of th√°kurs became bhumi√°s that is landowners or gar√°si√°s, that is owners of gar√°s or a mouthful. J√°m is the title of the chiefs of the J√°deja tribe both of the elder branch in Kachh and of the younger branch in Nav√°nagar, or Little Kachh in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. R√°s M√°l√°, II. 277. ↑

17 Under the Mar√°th√°s the title zamínd√°r was bestowed on the farmers of the land revenue, and this practice was adopted by the earlier English writers on Gujar√°t. In consequence of this change small landholders of the superior class, in directly administered districts, came again to be called by their original Hindu name of gar√°sia. Mr. Elphinstone (History, 79 and note 13) includes under the term zamínd√°r: (1) half-subdued chieftains, (2) independent governors of districts, and (3) farmers of revenue. He also notices that until Aurangzíb’s time such chiefs as enjoyed some degree of independence were alone called zamínd√°rs. But in Colonel Walker’s time, a.d. 1805, at least in Gujar√°t (Bombay Government Selections, XXXIX. 25) the term zamínd√°r included des√°is, majmud√°rs (district accountants), patels, and tal√°tis (village clerks). ↑

18 Details of a.d. 1571 given in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi show that the chief nobles were bound to furnish cavalry contingents varying from 4000 to 25,000 horse, and held lands estimated to yield yearly revenues of £160,000 to £1,620,000. Bird’s Gujar√°t, 109–127. ↑

19 According to the European travellers in India during the seventeenth century, provincial governors, and probably to some extent all large holders of service lands, employed various methods for adding to the profits which the assigned lands were meant to yield them. Of these devices two seem to have been specially common, the practice of supporting a body of horse smaller than the number agreed for, and the practice of purveyance that is of levying supplies without payment. Sir Thomas Roe, from a.d. 1615 to 1618 English ambassador at the court of the emperor Jeh√°ngír, gives the following details of these irregular practices: ‘The P√°tan (that is Patna in Bengal) viceroy’s government was estimated at 5000 horse, the yearly pay of each trooper being £20 (Rs. 200), of which he kept only 1500, being allowed the surplus as dead pay. On one occasion this governor wished to present me with 100 loaves of the finest sugar, as white as snow, each loaf weighing fifty pounds. On my declining, he said, ‘You refuse these loaves, thinking I am poor; but being made in my government the sugar costs me nothing, as it comes to me gratis.’ Sir Thomas Roe in Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 282–284. The same writer, the best qualified of the English travellers of that time to form a correct opinion, thus describes the administration of the Musalm√°n governors of the seventeenth century: ‘They practise every kind of tyranny against the natives under their jurisdiction, oppressing them with continual exactions, and are exceedingly averse from any way being opened by which the king may be informed of their infamous proceedings. They grind the people under their government to extract money from them, often hanging men up by the heels to make them confess that they are rich, or to ransom themselves from faults merely imputed with a view to fleece them.’ Sir Thomas Roe in Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 338. ↑

20 Of these settlements the principal was that of the R√°thoḍ chief who in the thirteenth century established himself at Ídar, now one of the states of the Mahi K√°ntha. In the thirteenth century also, Gohils from the north and Sodha Parm√°rs and K√°this from Sindh entered Gujar√°t. R√°s M√°la, II. 269. ↑

21 Gujar√°t of about the year a.d. 1300 is thus described: ‘The air of Gujar√°t is healthy, and the earth picturesque; the vineyards bring forth blue grapes twice a year, and the strength of the soil is such that the cotton plants spread their branches like willow and plane trees, and yield produce for several years successively. Besides Cambay, the most celebrated of the cities of Hind in population and wealth, there are 70,000 towns and villages, all populous, and the people abounding in wealth and luxuries.’ Elliot’s History of India, III. 31, 32, and 43. Marco Polo, about a.d. 1292, says: ‘In Gujar√°t there grows much pepper and ginger and indigo. They have also a great deal of cotton. Their cotton trees are of very great size, growing full six paces high, and attaining to an age of twenty years.’ Yule’s Edition, II. 328. The cotton referred to was probably the variety known as devkap√°s Gossypium religiosum or peruvianum, which grows from ten to fifteen feet high, and bears for several years. Royle, 149–150. ↑

22 Elphinstone’s History, 762. ↑

23 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 110, 129, and 130. ↑

24 The passage from the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Bird 109, is: ‘A sum of 25 l√°khs of húns and one kror of ibr√°híms, that were two parts greater, being altogether nearly equal to 5 krors and 62 l√°khs of rupees, was collected from the Dakhan tribute and the customs of the European and Arab ports.’ The word hún, from an old Karn√°tak word for gold, is the Musalm√°n name for the coin known among Hindus as var√°ha or the wild-boar coin, and among the Portuguese as the pagoda or temple coin. Prinsep Ind. Ant. Thomas’ Ed. II. U. T. 18. The old specimens of this coin weigh either 60 grains the m√°da or half pagoda, or 120 grains the hún or full pagoda. Thomas, Chron. Pat. Ks. II. 224, note. The star pagoda, in which English accounts at Madras were formerly kept, weighs 52·56 grains, and was commonly valued at 8s. or Rs. 4 (Prinsep as above). At this rate in the present sum the 25 l√°khs of húns would equal one kror (100 l√°khs) of rupees. The ibr√°hími, ‘two parts greater than the hún,’ would seem to be a gold coin, perhaps a variety of the Persian ashrafi (worth about 9s. English. Marsden, N. O. 455). Taking the two parts of a hún as f√°nams or sixteenths, this would give the ibr√°hími a value of Rs. 4¼, and make a total customs revenue of 425 l√°khs of rupees. This statement of the revenues of the kingdom is, according to the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, taken from such times as the power of the Gujar√°t kings continued to increase. The total revenue of the twenty-five districts (£5,840,000) is the amount recovered in the year a.d. 1571. But the receipts under the head of Tribute must have been compiled from accounts of earlier years. For, as will be seen below, the neighbouring kings ceased to pay tribute after the end of the reign of Bah√°dur (a.d. 1536). Similarly the customs revenues entered as received from Daman and other places must have been taken from the accounts of some year previous to a.d. 1560. ↑

25 The remains at Ch√°mp√°ner in the British district of the Panch Mah√°ls are well known. Of Mehmúd√°b√°d, the town of that name in the district of Kaira, eighteen miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d, a few ruins only are left. In a.d. 1590 this city is said to have contained many grand edifices surrounded with a wall eleven miles (7 kos) square with at every ¾ mile (½ kos) a pleasure house, and an enclosure for deer and other game. (Áin-i-Akbari: Gladwin, II. 64.) The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi makes no special reference to the sovereign’s share of the revenue. The greater part of the £5,620,000 derived from tribute and customs would probably go to the king, besides the lands specially set apart as crown domains, which in a.d. 1571 were returned as yielding a yearly revenue of £900,000 (900,000,000 tank√°s). This would bring the total income of the crown to a little more than 6½ millions sterling. ↑

26 So Sikandar Lodi emperor of Dehli, a.d. 1488–1517, is reported to have said: ‘The magnificence of the kings of Dehli rests on wheat and barley; the magnificence of the kings of Gujar√°t rests on coral and pearls.’ Bird, 132. ↑

27 The twelve Gujar√°t ports mentioned by Barbosa are: On the south coast of the peninsula, two: Patenixi (P√°tan-Somn√°th, now Ver√°val), very rich and of great trade; Surati-Mangalor (Mangrul), a town of commerce, and Diu. On the shores of the gulf of Cambay four: Gogari (Gogha), a large town; Barbesy (Broach); Guand√°ri or Gandar (Gandh√°r), a very good town; and Cambay. On the western coast five: Ravel (R√°nder), a rich place; Surat, a city of very great trade; Denvy (Gandevi), a place of great trade; Baxay (Bassein), a good seaport in which much goods are exchanged; and Tanamayambu (Th√°na-M√°him), a town of great Moorish mosques, but of little trade. (Stanley’s Barbosa, 59–68). The only one of these ports whose identification seems doubtful is Ravel, described by Barbosa (page 67) as a pretty town of the Moors on a good river, twenty leagues south of Gandh√°r. This agrees with the position of R√°nder on the T√°pti, nearly opposite Surat, which appears in Al Bírúni (a.d. 1030) as R√°hanur one of the capitals of south Gujar√°t and is mentioned under the name R√°nir, both in the Áin-i-Akbari (a.d. 1590) and in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi for the year a.d. 1571, as a place of trade, ‘in ancient times a great city.’ In his description of the wealth of Cambay, Barbosa is supported by the other European travellers of the fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries. According to Nicolo de Conti (a.d. 1420–1444), the town, including its suburbs, was twelve miles in circuit abounding in spikenard, lac, indigo, myrobalans, and silk. Athanasius Nikotin (a.d. 1468–1474) found it a manufacturing place for every sort of goods as long gowns damasks and blankets; and Varthema (a.d. 1503–1508) says it abounds in grain and very good fruits, supplying Africa Arabia and India with silk and cotton stuffs; ‘it is impossible to describe its excellence.’ Barbosa’s account of Áhmed√°b√°d is borne out by the statement in the Áin-i-Akbari (Gladwin, II. 63) that the whole number of the suburbs (pur√°s) of the city was 360, and in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, that it once contained 380 suburbs each of considerable size, containing good buildings and markets filled with everything valuable and rare, so that each was almost a city. Bird, 311. ↑

28 Gladwin’s Áin-i-Akbari, II. 62–63. Compare Terry (Voyage, 80, 131) in 1615: Gujar√°t a very goodly large and exceeding rich province with, besides its most spacious populous and rich capital Áhmed√°b√°d, four fair cities Cambay Baroda Broach and Surat with great trade to the Red Sea, Achin, and other places. At the same time (Ditto, 179–180) though the villages stood very thick, the houses were generally very poor and base, all set close together some with earthen walls and flat roofs, most of them cottages miserably poor little and base set up with sticks rather than timber. ↑

29 The decrease in the Mughal collections from Gujar√°t compared with the revenues of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings may have been due to Akbar’s moderation. It may also have been due to a decline in prosperity. Compare Roe’s (1617) account of Toda about fifty miles south-east of Ajmír. It was the best and most populous country Roe had seen in India. The district was level with fertile soil abounding in corn cotton and cattle and the villages were so numerous and near together as hardly to exceed a kos from each other. The town was the best built Roe had seen in India tiled two-storied houses good enough for decent shopkeepers. It had been the residence of a R√°jput R√°ja before the conquests of Akbar Sh√°h and stood at the foot of a good and strong rock about which were many excellent works of hewn stone, well cut, with many tanks arched over with well-turned vaults and large and deep descents to them. Near it was a beautiful grove two miles long and a quarter of a mile broad all planted with mangoes tamarinds and other fruit trees, divided by shady walks and interspersed with little temples and idol altars with many fountains wells and summer houses of carved stone curiously arched so that a poor banished Englishman might have been content to dwell there. This observation may serve universally for the whole country that ruin and devastation operate everywhere. For since the property of all has become vested in the king no person takes care of anything so that in every place the spoil and devastations of war appear and nowhere is anything repaired. Roe in Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 320–321. ↑

30 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t. Another detailed statement of the revenue of Gujar√°t given in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, apparently for the time when the author wrote (a.d. 1760) gives: Revenue from crown lands £2,107,518; tribute-paying divisions or sark√°rs £12,700; Mahí K√°ntha tribute £178,741; V√°trak K√°ntha tribute £159,768; and S√°bar K√°ntha tribute £121,151; in all £2,579,878: adding to this £20,000 for Kachh, £40,000 for Dungarpur, and £5000 for Sirohi, gives a grand total of £2,644,878. According to a statement given by Bird in a note at page 108 of his History, the revenue of Gujar√°t under Jeh√°ngir (a.d. 1605–1627) averaged £1,250,000; under Aurangzíb (a.d. 1658–1707) £1,519,622; and under Muhammad Sh√°h (a.d. 1719–1748) £1,218,360. In this passage the revenue under the emperor Akbar (a.d. 1556–1605) is given at £66,845. This total is taken from Gladwin’s Áin-i-Akbari. But at vol. II. page 73 of that work there would seem to be some miscalculation; for while the total number of d√°ms (​1⁄40​th of a rupee) is 43,68,02,301, the conversion into rupees is Rs. 10,96,123 instead of Rs. 1,09,20,057½. The corresponding returns given by Mr. Thomas (Rev. of the Mog. Emp. page 52) are under Akbar, a.d. 1594, £1,092,412; under Sh√°h Jah√°n, a.d. 1648, £1,325,000; and under Aurangzíb, a.d. 1658 £2,173,220, a.d. 1663–1666 £1,339,500, a.d. 1697 £2,330,500, and a.d. 1707 £1,519,623. The varieties in the currency employed in different parts of the accounts cause some confusion in calculating the Gujar√°t revenue. Under the Áhmed√°b√°d kings the accounts were kept in t√°nk√°s or ​1⁄100​ of rupees, while under the Mughals d√°ms or ​1⁄45​th of a rupee took the place of t√°nk√°s. The revenues from Surat Baroda Broach and other districts south of the M√°hi were returned in changízis, a coin varying in value from something over ⅔rds of a rupee to slightly less than ½; the revenues from R√°dhanpur and Morvi were entered in mahmúdis, a coin nearly identical in value with the changízi, while, as noticed above, the tribute and customs dues are returned in a gold currency, the tribute in huns of about 8s. (Rs. 4) and the customs in ibr√°hímís of 9s. (Rs. 4½). ↑

31 Áin-i-Akbari (Gladwin), I. 305. The Áin-i-Akbari mentions four ways of calculating the state share in an unsurveyed field: (1) to measure the land with the crops standing and make an estimate; (2) to reap the crops, collect the grain in barns, and divide it according to agreement; (3) to divide the field as soon as the seed is sown; and (4) to gather the grain into heaps on the field and divide it there. ↑

32 The men to whom this 2½ per cent was granted are referred to in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi as des√°is. Whatever doubt may attach to the precise meaning of the term des√°i it seems clear that it was as village headmen that the des√°is petitioned for and received this grant. These des√°is were the heads of villages with whom, as noticed above, the government agent for collecting the revenue dealt, and who, agreeing for the whole village contribution, themselves carried out the details of allotment and collection from the individual cultivators. In the sharehold villages north of the Narbada, the headman who would be entitled to this 2½ per cent was the representative of the body of village shareholders. South of the Narbada, in villages originally colonised by officers of the state, the representatives of these officers would enjoy the 2½ per cent. In south Gujar√°t the des√°is or heads of villages also acted as district hereditary revenue officers; but it was not as district hereditary revenue officers, but as heads of villages, that they received from Akbar this 2½ per cent assignment. In north Gujar√°t there were des√°is who were only district revenue officers. These men would seem to have received no part of Akbar’s grant in 1589–90, for as late as a.d. 1706 the emperor Aurangzíb, having occasion to make inquiries into the position of the des√°is, found that hitherto they had been supported by cesses and illegal exactions, and ordered that a stop should be put to all such exactions, and a fixed assignment of 2½ per cent on the revenues of the villages under their charge should be allowed them. It does not appear whether the Surat des√°is succeeded in obtaining Aurangzíb’s grant of 2½ per cent as district revenue officers in addition to Akbar’s (a.d. 1589) assignment of 2½ per cent as heads of villages. ↑

33 Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 409. ↑

34 Áhmed√°b√°d (a.d. 1583) by Muzaffar Sh√°h the last king of Gujar√°t; Cambay (a.d. 1573) by Muhammad Husain Mirza; and Surat (a.d. 1609) by Malik Ambar the famous general of the king of Amednagar. In such unsettled times it is not surprising that the European travellers of the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries, between Áhmed√°b√°d and Cambay found native merchants marching in large weekly caravans which rested at night within a space barricaded by carts. (Kerr, IX. 127 and 201.) The English merchants, on their way from one factory to another, were accompanied by an escort, and, in spite of their guard, were on more than one occasion attacked by large bands of R√°jputs. (Kerr, IX. 127, 187, 201, 203.) As regards the state of the different parts of the province, Nicholas Ufflet, who went from Agra to Surat about 1610, describes the north, from Jh√°lor to Áhmed√°b√°d, as throughout the whole way a sandy and woody country, full of thievish beastly men, and savage beasts such as lions and tigers; from Áhmed√°b√°d to Cambay the road was through sands and woods much infested by thieves; from Cambay to Broach it was a woody and dangerous journey; but from Broach to Surat the country was goodly, fertile, and full of villages, abounding in wild date trees. (Kerr, VIII. 303.) Passing from the mouth of the T√°pti to Surat Mr. Copland (24th Dec. 1613) was delighted to see at the same time the goodliest spring and harvest he had ever seen. ‘Often of two adjoining fields, one was as green as a fine meadow, and the other waving yellow like gold and ready to be cut down, and all along the roads were many goodly villages.’ (Kerr, IX. 119.) At that time the state of north-east Gujar√°t was very different. Terry, 1617 (Voyage, 404), describes the passage of nineteen days from M√°ndu near Dh√°r to Áhmed√°b√°d as short journeys in a wilderness where a way had to be cut and made even and the great space required for the Mughal’s camp rid and made plain by grubbing up trees and bushes. And between Cambay and Áhmed√°b√°d De la Valle, a.d. 1623 (Travels, Hakluyt Ed. I. 92), resolved to go with the k√°fila since the insecurity of the ways did not allow him to go alone. Still at that time Gujar√°t as a whole (see above page 220 note 2) was an exceeding rich province, a description which twenty years later (1638) is borne out by Mandelslo (Travels, French Edition, 56): No province in India is more fertile; none yields more fruit or victuals. With the boast of the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (a.d. 1756) that Gujar√°t was the richest province in India compare Kh√°fi Khan’s (a.d. 1719) remark (Elliot, VII. 530): This rich province which no other province in India can equal. ↑

35 Orme’s Historical Fragments, 12. ↑

36 The following are some of the notices of Áhmed√°b√°d and Cambay by the European travellers of the seventeenth century: Cambay, 1598, trade so great that if he had not seen it he would not have believed it possible (Cæsar Frederick); 1623, indifferent large with sufficiently spacious suburbs and a great concourse of vessels (De la Valle, Hakluyt Edition, I. 66–67); 1638, beyond comparison larger than Surat (Mandelslo, 101–108); 1663–1671, twice as big as Surat (Baldæus in Churchill, III. 506). Áhmed√°b√°d, 1598, a very great city and populous (Cæsar Frederick); 1623, competently large with great suburbs, a goodly and great city, with large fair and straight but sadly dusty streets (De la Valle, Hakluyt Edition, I. 95); 1627, large and beautiful with many broad and comely streets, a rich and uniform baz√°r, and shops redundant with gums perfumes spices silks cottons and calicoes (Herbert’s Travels, 3rd Edition, 66); 1638, great manufactures, satin and velvet, silk and cotton (Mandelslo, 80); 1695, the greatest city in India, nothing inferior to Venice for rich silks and gold stuffs (Gemelli Careri in Churchill, IV. 188). ↑

37 Bird, 411. ↑

38 The usual explanation of toda gar√°s is the word toda meaning the beam-end above each house door. The sense being that it was a levy exacted from every house in the village. A more likely derivation is toda a heap or money-bag with the sense of a ready-money levy. Toda differed from vol in being exacted from the gar√°s or land once the property of the levier’s ancestors. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER I.

EARLY MUSALMÁN GOVERNORS.

a.d. 1297–1403.


Chapter I.
Early Musalm√°n Governors.
Al√°-ud-dín Khilji Emperor, 1295–1315.
Ulugh Kh√°n, 1297–1317. Al√°-ud-dín Khilji Emperor, 1295–1315.Except the great expedition of Mahmúd Ghaznawi against Somn√°th in a.d. 10241; the defeat of Muhammad Muiz-ud-dín or Shah√°b-ud-dín Ghori by Bhím Dev II. of Aṇahilav√°ḍa about a.d. 11782; and the avenging sack of Aṇahilav√°ḍa and defeat of Bhím by Kutb-ud-dín Eibak in a.d. 1194, until the reign of Al√°-ud-dín Khilji in a.d. 1295–1315, Gujar√°t remained free from Muhammadan interference.3 Ulugh Kh√°n, 1297–1317.In a.d. 1297, Ulugh Kh√°n, general of Al√°-ud-dín and Nasrat Kh√°n Wazír were sent against Aṇahilav√°ḍa. They took the city expelling Karan W√°ghela, usually called Ghelo The Mad, who took refuge at Devgaḍh with R√°mdeva the Y√°dav sovereign of the north Dakhan.4 They next seized Khamb√°t (the modern Cambay), and, after appointing a local governor, returned to Dehli. From this time Gujar√°t remained under Muhammadan power, and Ulugh Kh√°n, a man of great energy, by repeated expeditions consolidated the conquest and established Muhammadan rule. The K√°naddeva R√°sa says that he plundered Somn√°th, and there is no doubt that he conquered Jh√°lor (the ancient Jh√°lindar) from the Songarha Choh√°ns.5 After Ulugh Kh√°n had governed Gujar√°t for about twenty years, at the instigation of Malik K√°fur, he was recalled and put to death by the emperor Al√°-ud-dín.6

Ain-ul-Mulk Governor, 1318.Ulugh Kh√°n’s departure shook Muhammadan power in Gujar√°t, and Kam√°l-ud-dín, whom Mub√°rak Khilji sent to quell the disturbances, was slain in battle. Sedition spread till Ain-ul-Mulk Mult√°ni arrived [230]
Chapter I.
Early Musalm√°n Governors.
Muhammad Tughlak Emperor, 1325–1351.
Ain-ul-Mulk Governor, 1318. with a powerful army, defeated the rebels and Order Established, 1318.restored order. He was succeeded by Zafar Kh√°n, who after completing the subjection of the country was recalled, and his place supplied by His√°m-ud-dín Parm√°r.7 This officer, showing treasonable intentions, was imprisoned and succeeded by Malik W√°jid-ud-dín Kuraishi, who was afterwards ennobled by the title of T√°j or Sadr-ul-Mulk. Khusraw Kh√°n Parm√°r was then appointed governor, but it is not clear whether he ever joined his appointment. The next governor to whom reference is made is T√°j-ul-Mulk Governor, 1320.T√°j-ul-Mulk, who about a.d. 1320, was, for the second time, chosen as governor by Sult√°n Ghi√°s-ud-dín Tughlak. He was succeeded by Malik Mukbil, who held the titles of Kh√°n Jah√°n and N√°ib-i-Mukht√°r, and who was appointed by Muhammad Tughlak Emperor, 1325–1351.Sult√°n Muhammad Tughlak, a.d. 1325–1351. Subsequently the same emperor granted the government of Gujar√°t to Áhmad Ay√°z, Malik Mukbil continuing to act as his deputy. Afterwards when Áhmad Ay√°z, who received the title of Khw√°jah Jah√°n, proceeded as governor to Gujar√°t, Malik Mukbil acted as his minister. And about a.d. 1338, when Khw√°jah Jah√°n was sent against the emperor’s nephew Karsh√°sp and the R√°ja of Kampila8 who had sheltered him, Malik Mukbil succeeded to the post of governor. On one occasion between Baroda and Dabhoi Malik Mukbil, who was escorting treasure and a caravan of merchants to Dehli, was plundered by some bands of the Amír√°ni Sadah or Captains of Hundreds freelances and freebooters, most of them New Musalm√°ns or Mughal converts, and the rest Turk and Afgh√°n adventurers. This success emboldened these banditti and for several years they caused loss and confusion in Gujar√°t. At last, about a.d. 1346, being joined by certain Muhammadan nobles and Hindu chieftains, they broke into open rebellion and defeated one Ázíz, who was appointed by the emperor to march against them. The Emperor Quells an Insurrection, 1347.In the following year, a.d. 1347, Muhammad Tughlak, advancing in person, defeated the rebels, and sacked the towns of Cambay and Surat. During the same campaign he drove the Gohil chief Mokher√°ji out of his stronghold on Piram Island near Gogha on the Gulf of Cambay, and then, landing his forces, after a stubborn conflict, defeated the Gohils, killing Mokher√°ji and capturing Gogha. Afterwards Muhammad Tughlak left for Daulat√°b√°d in the Dakhan, and in his absence the chiefs and nobles under Malik Túgh√°n, a leader of the Amír√°ni Sadah, again rebelled, and, obtaining possession of P√°tan, imprisoned Muîzz-ud-dín the viceroy. The insurgents then plundered Cambay, and afterwards laid siege to Broach. Muhammad Tughlak at once marched for Gujar√°t and relieved Broach, Malik Túgh√°n retreating to Cambay, whither he was followed by Malik Yúsuf, whom the emperor sent in pursuit of him. In the battle that ensued near Cambay, Malik Yúsuf was defeated and slain, and [231]
Chapter I.
Early Musalm√°n Governors.
Muhammad Tughlak Emperor, 1325–1351.
T√°j-ul-Mulk Governor, 1320. all the prisoners, both of this engagement and those who had been previously captured, were put to death by Malik Túgh√°n. Among the prisoners was Muîzz-ud-dín, the governor of Gujar√°t. Muhammad Tughlak now marched to Cambay in person, whence Malik Túgh√°n retreated to P√°tan, pursued by the emperor, who was forced by stress of weather to halt at As√°wal.9 Eventually the emperor came up with Malik Túgh√°n near Kadi and gained a complete victory, Malik Túgh√°n fleeing to Thatha in Sindh. Subdues Girn√°r and Kachh, 1350.To establish order throughout Gujar√°t Muhammad Tughlak marched against Girn√°r,10 reduced the fortress,11 and levied tribute from the chief named Kheng√°r. He then went to Kachh, and after subduing that country returned to Sorath. At Gondal he contracted a fever, and before he was entirely recovered, he advanced through Kachh into Sindh with the view of subduing the Sumra chief of Thatha, who had sheltered Malik Túgh√°n. Before reaching Thatha he succumbed to the fever, and died in the spring of a.d. 1351. Shortly before his death he appointed Niz√°m-ul-Mulk to the government of Gujar√°t.

Fírúz Tughlak Emperor, 1351–1388.In a.d. 1351, Fírúz Tughlak succeeded Muhammad Tughlak on the throne of Dehli. Shortly after his accession the emperor marched to Sindh and sent a force against Malik Túgh√°n. About a.d. 1360 he again advanced to Sindh against J√°m B√°bunia. From Sindh he proceeded to Gujar√°t, where he stayed for some months. Zafar Khan Governor, 1371.Next year, on leaving for Sindh for the third time, he bestowed the government of Gujar√°t on Zafar Kh√°n in place of Niz√°m-ul-Mulk. On Zafar Kh√°n’s death, in a.d. 1373 according to Farishtah and a.d. 1371 according to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, he was succeeded by his son Dary√° Kh√°n who appears to have governed by a deputy named Shams-ud-dín Anwar Kh√°n. In a.d. 1376, besides presents of elephants horses and other valuables, one Shams-ud-dín D√°mgh√°ní offered a considerable advance on the usual collections from Gujar√°t. As Dary√° Kh√°n would not agree to pay this sum he was displaced and Shams-ud-dín D√°mgh√°ní was appointed governor. Finding himself unable to pay the stipulated amount this officer rebelled and withheld the revenue. Fírúz Tughlak sent an army against him, and by the aid of the chieftains and people, whom he had greatly oppressed, Shams-ud-dín was slain. The government of the province was then entrusted to Farhat-ul-Mulk R√°sti Kh√°n. Farhat-ul-Mulk Governor, 1376–1391.In about a.d. 1388, a noble named Sikandar Kh√°n was sent to supersede Farhat-ul-Mulk, but was defeated and slain by him. As the emperor Fírúz Tughlak died shortly after no notice was taken of Farhat-ul-Mulk’s conduct and in the short reign of Fírúz’s successor Ghi√°s-ud-dín Tughlak, no change was made in the government of Gujar√°t. During the brief rule of Abu Bakr, Farhat-ul-Mulk continued [232]
Chapter I.
Early Musalm√°n Governors.
Muhammad Tughlak II. Emperor, 1391–1393. undisturbed. Muhammad Tughlak II. Emperor, 1391–1393.But in a.d. 1391, on the accession of N√°sir-ud-dín Muhammad Tughlak II., a noble of the name of Zafar Kh√°n was appointed governor of Gujar√°t, and despatched with an army to recall or, if necessary, expel Farhat-ul-Mulk.

This Zafar Kh√°n was the son of Wajíh-ul-Mulk, of the T√°nk tribe of R√°jputs who claim to be of Suryavansi descent and together with the Gurjjaras appear from very early times to have inhabited the plains of the Punj√°b. Of Wajíh-ul-Mulk’s rise to power at the Dehli court the following story is told. Before he sat on the throne of Dehli, Fírúz Tughlak, when hunting in the Punj√°b, lost his way and came to a village near Th√°nesar, held by chieftains of the T√°nk tribe. He was hospitably entertained by two brothers of the chief’s family named S√°h√°ran and S√°dhu, and became enamoured of their beautiful sister. When his hosts learned who the stranger was, they gave him their sister in marriage and followed his fortunes. Afterwards Fírúz persuading them to embrace Isl√°m, conferred on Sah√°ran the title of Wajíh-ul-Mulk, and on S√°dhu the title of Shamshír Kh√°n. Finally, in a.d. 1351, when Fírúz Tughlak ascended the throne, he made Shamshír Kh√°n and Zafar Kh√°n, the son of Wajíh-ul-Mulk, his cup-bearers, and raised them to the rank of nobles.

Zafar Kh√°n Governor, 1391–1403.In a.d. 1391, on being appointed viceroy, Zafar Kh√°n marched without delay for Gujar√°t. In passing N√°gor12 he was met by a deputation from Cambay, complaining of the tyranny of R√°sti Kh√°n. Consoling them, he proceeded to P√°tan, the seat of government, and thence marched against R√°sti Kh√°n. Battle of Jitpur; Farhat-ul-Mulk Slain, 1391.The armies met near the village of Khambhoi,13 a dependency of P√°tan, and Farhat-ul-Mulk R√°sti Kh√°n was slain and his army defeated. To commemorate the victory, Zafar Kh√°n founded a village on the battle-field, which he named Jítpur (the city of victory), and then, starting for Cambay, redressed the grievances of the people.

Zafar Kh√°n Attacks Ídar, 1393.Zafar Kh√°n’s first warlike expedition was against the R√°v of Ídar,14 who, in a.d. 1393, had refused to pay the customary tribute, and this chief he humbled. The contemporary histories seem to show that the previous governors had recovered tribute from all or most of the chiefs of Gujar√°t except from the R√°v of Jun√°gaḍh15 and the R√°ja of R√°jpípla,16 who had retained their independence. Zafar Kh√°n now planned an expedition against the celebrated Hindu shrine of Somn√°th, but, hearing that Ádil Kh√°n of Ásír-Burh√°npur had invaded Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r,17 he moved his troops in that direction, and Ádil Kh√°n retired to Ásir.18 [233]
Chapter I.
Early Musalm√°n Governors.
Zafar Kh√°n Governor, 1391–1403. Exacts Tribute from Jun√°gaḍh, 1394.In a.d. 1394, he marched against the R√°v of Jun√°gaḍh and exacted tribute. Afterwards, proceeding to Somn√°th, he destroyed the temple, built an Assembly Mosque, introduced Isl√°m, left Musalm√°n law officers, and established a th√°na or post in the city of P√°tan Somn√°th or Deva P√°tan. He now heard that the Hindus of M√°ndu19 were oppressing the Muslims, and, accordingly, marching thither, he beleaguered that fortress for a year, but failing to take it contented himself with accepting the excuses of the R√°ja. From M√°ndu he performed a pilgrimage to Ajmír.20 Here he proceeded against the chiefs of S√°mbhar and Dandw√°na, and then attacking the R√°jputs of Delv√°ḍa and Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa,21 he defeated them, and returned to P√°tan in a.d. 1396. About this time his son T√°t√°r Kh√°n, leaving his baggage in the fort of P√°nipat,22 made an attempt on Dehli. But Ikb√°l Kh√°n took the fort of P√°nipat, captured T√°t√°r Kh√°n’s baggage, and forced him to withdraw to Gujar√°t. Lays Siege to Ídar Fort, 1397.In a.d. 1397, with the view of reducing Ídar, Zafar Kh√°n besieged the fort, laying waste the neighbouring country. Before he had taken the fort Zafar Kh√°n received news of Timúr’s conquests, and concluding a peace with the Ídar R√°ja, returned to P√°tan.23 In a.d. 1398, hearing that the Somn√°th people claimed independence, Zafar Kh√°n led an army against them, defeated them, and Establishes Isl√°m at Somn√°th, 1398.established Isl√°m on a firm footing. [234]

1 Somn√°th (north latitude 20° 55′; east longitude 70° 23′), the temple of Mah√°dev ‘Lord of the Moon,’ near the southern extremity of the peninsula of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. ↑

2 Aṇahilav√°ḍa (north latitude 23° 48′; east longitude 72° 2′), Nehrw√°la or P√°tan, on the south bank of the Sarasvatí river, sixty-five miles north-east of Ahmed√°b√°d, was from a.d. 746 to a.d. 1298 the capital of the R√°jput dynasties of Gujar√°t. As a result of Muhammad Ghori’s defeat the T√°rikh-i-Sorath (Burgess, 112–113) states that the Turkish Afgh√°n and Mughal prisoners, according to the rule of the Kurăan (XXIV. 25) were distributed, the wicked women to the wicked men and the good women to the good men. Of the male prisoners the better class after having their heads shaved were enrolled among the Chak√°wal and W√°dhel tribes of R√°jputs. The lower class were allotted to the Kolis, Kh√°nts, B√°bri√°s, and Mers. All were allowed to keep their wedding and funeral ceremonies and to remain aloof from other classes. ↑

3 The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi gives an account of an expedition by one Alifkh√°n a noble of Sult√°n Sanjar’s against Aṇahilav√°ḍa in a.d. 1257. He is said to have built the large stone mosque without the city. Alifkh√°n returned unsuccessful, but not without levying tribute. ↑

4 Devgaḍh near Daulatabad in the Dakhan, about ten miles north-west of Aurang√°b√°d (north latitude 19° 57′; east longitude 75° 18′). The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi has Devgaḍh Chandah, which is in the Central Provinces. ↑

5 Jh√°lor (north latitude 25° 23′; east longitude 72° 40′) in the R√°jput state of Jodhpur, seventy miles south-west by south from the city of Jodhpur. ↑

6 Bayley (Gujar√°t, 39 note) shows strong ground for holding that, though Gujar√°t was conquered by Ulugh Kh√°n a brother of Al√°-ud-dín, its first governor was not Ulugh Kh√°n but Álp Kh√°n a brother-in-law of Al√°-ud-dín. According to this account Ulugh Kh√°n died in a.d. 1299 and Álp Kh√°n at Malik K√°fúr’s instigation was killed in a.d. 1315. Zi√° Barni (Elliot, III. 169) supports this account. ↑

7 According to Zi√° Barni (Elliot, III. 218) His√°m-ud-dín was the mother’s brother, according to others he was the brother of Hasan afterwards Khusraw Kh√°n Parm√°r the favourite of Mub√°rak Sh√°h. On coming to Gujar√°t His√°m-ud-dín collected his Parm√°r kindred and revolted, but the nobles joining against him seized him and sent him to Dehli. To their disgust Mub√°rak in his infatuation for His√°m-ud-dín’s nephew or brother, after slapping His√°m-ud-dín on the face set him at liberty. ↑

8 In the Karn√°tak, probably on the Tungabhadra near Vijay√°nagar. Briggs’ Muhammadan Power in India, I. 418 and 428. Briggs speaks of two Kampil√°s one on the Ganges and the other on the Tungabhadra near Bij√°nagar. ↑

9 As√°wal (north latitude 23° 0′; east longitude 72° 36′), a town of some size, afterwards, a.d. 1413, made the capital of the Musalm√°n kings of Gujar√°t and called Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

10 Girn√°r (north latitude 21° 30′; east longitude 70° 42′), in the Sorath sub-division of the peninsula of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. ↑

11 Both the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi and the T√°ríkh-i-Fírúz Sh√°hi say that the fortress was taken. The Úparkot or citadel of Jun√°gaḍh, in the plain about two miles west of Mount Girn√°r, is probably meant. ↑

12 N√°gor (north latitude 27° 10′; east longitude 73° 50′), in the R√°thoḍ state of Jodhpur, eighty miles north-east of Jodhpur city. ↑

13 The Tabak√°t-i-Akbari has Kh√°npur or K√°npur. The place is Khambhoi about twenty miles west of P√°tan. ↑

14 Ídar is the principal state of the Mahi K√°ntha. The town of Ídar is in north latitude 23° 50′ and east longitude 73° 3′. ↑

15 Jun√°gaḍh in the Sorath sub-division of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. This is Briggs’ R√°i of Jehrend. Jun√°gaḍh was formerly called Jirangaḍ, both names meaning ancient fortress. ↑

16 R√°jpípla is in the Rewa K√°ntha division of Gujar√°t. ↑

17 Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r now form part of the British district of Kh√°ndesh. ↑

18 Ásir, now Ásírgaḍ (north latitude 21° 26′; east longitude 76° 26′), beyond the north-eastern frontier of Kh√°ndesh. ↑

19 M√°ndu (north latitude 22° 20′; east longitude 75° 27′), one of the most famous forts in India, the capital of the Path√°n dynasty of M√°lwa, a.d. 1404–1561, stands on the crest of the Vindhyas about twenty-five miles south of Dh√°r. During a considerable part of the fifteenth century M√°ndu was either directly or indirectly under Gujar√°t. An account of M√°ndu is given in the Appendix. ↑

20 Ajmír (north latitude 26° 29′; east longitude 74° 43′), the chief town of the district of the same name to which S√°mbhar and Dandw√°na belong. ↑

21 Delv√°ḍa and Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa are somewhat difficult. The context suggests either Jh√°lor in M√°rw√°r or Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa in the extreme south-east of R√°jput√°na south of Kotah. The combination Delv√°ḍa and Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa seems to favour K√°thi√°v√°ḍa since there is a Delv√°ḍa in the south of the peninsula near Diu and a Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa in the north-east. But the Delv√°da of the text can hardly be near Diu. It apparently is Delv√°da near Eklingji about twenty miles north of Udepur. The account of Áhmed Sh√°h’s expedition to the same place in a.d. 1431 (below page 239) confirms this identification. ↑

22 P√°nipat (north latitude 29° 23′; east longitude 77° 2′), seventy-eight miles north of Dehli. ↑

23 Farishtah (II. 355) calls the Ídar chief Ranbal. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER II.

ÁHMEDÁBÁD KINGS.

a.d. 1403–1573.


Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573. The rule of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings extends over 170 years and includes the names of fifteen sovereigns. The period may conveniently be divided into two parts. The first, lasting for a little more than a century and a quarter, when, under strong rulers, Gujar√°t rose to consequence among the kingdoms of Western India; the second, from a.d. 1536 to a.d. 1573, an evil time when the sovereigns were minors and the wealth and supremacy of Gujar√°t were wasted by the rivalry of its nobles.

The date on which Zafar Kh√°n openly threw off his allegiance to Dehli is doubtful. Farishtah says he had the Friday prayer or khutbah repeated in his name after his successful campaign against Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa and Delv√°ḍa in a.d. 1396. According to the Mirăt-i-Sikandari he maintained a nominal allegiance till a.d. 1403 when he formally invested his son T√°t√°r Kh√°n with the sovereignty of Gujar√°t, under the title of N√°sir-ud-dín Muhammad Sh√°h.

Muhammad I. 1403–1404.On ascending the throne in a.d. 1403, Muhammad Sh√°h made As√°wal his capital, and, after humbling the chief of N√°ndoḍ or N√°dot in R√°jpipla, marched against Dehli by way of P√°tan. On his way to P√°tan the king sickened and died. His body was brought back to P√°tan, and the expedition against Dehli came to nothing. It seems probable that this is a courtly version of the tale; the fact being that in a.d. 1403 T√°t√°r Kh√°n imprisoned his father at As√°wal, and assumed the title of Muhammad Sh√°h, and that T√°t√°r Kh√°n’s death was caused by poison administered in the interest, if not at the suggestion, of his father Zafar Kh√°n.1

Zafar Kh√°n reigns as Muzaffar, 1407–1419.After the death of Muhammad Sh√°h, Zafar Kh√°n asked his own younger brother Shams Kh√°n Dand√°ni to carry on the government, but he refused. Zafar Kh√°n accordingly sent Shams Kh√°n Dand√°ni to N√°gor in place of Jal√°l Kh√°n Khokhar, and in a.d. 1407–8, at Bírpur, at the request of the nobles and chief men of the country, himself formally mounted the throne and assumed the title of Muzaffar Sh√°h. At this time Álp Kh√°n, son of Dil√°war Kh√°n of M√°lwa, was rumoured to have poisoned his father and ascended the throne with the title of Sult√°n Hushang Ghori. On hearing this Muzaffar Sh√°h marched against [235]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Muzaffar, 1407–1419. Hushang and besieged him in Dh√°r.2 On reducing Dh√°r Muzaffar handed Hushang to the charge of his brother Shams Kh√°n, on whom he conferred the title of Nasrat Kh√°n. Hushang remained a year in confinement, and Músa Kh√°n one of his relations usurped his authority. On hearing this, Hushang begged to be released, and Muzaffar Sh√°h not only agreed to his prayer, but sent his grandson Áhmed Kh√°n with an army to reinstate him. This expedition was successful; the fortress of M√°ndu was taken and the usurper Músa Kh√°n was put to flight. Áhmed Kh√°n returned to Gujar√°t in a.d. 1409–10. Meanwhile Muzaffar advancing towards Dehli to aid Sult√°n Mahmúd (a.d. 1393–1413), prevented an intended attack on that city by Sult√°n Ibr√°hím of Jaunpur. On his return to Gujar√°t Muzaffar led, or more probably despatched, an unsuccessful expedition against Kambhkot.3 In the following year (a.d. 1410–11), to quell a rising among the Kolis near As√°val, Muzaffar placed his grandson Áhmed Kh√°n in command of an army. Áhmed Kh√°n camped outside of P√°tan. He convened an assembly of learned men and asked them whether a son was not bound to exact retribution from his father’s murderer. The assembly stated in writing that a son was bound to exact retribution. Armed with this decision, Áhmed suddenly entered the city, overpowered his grandfather, and forced him to drink poison. The old Kh√°n said: ‘Why so hasty, my boy. A little patience and power would have come to you of itself.’ He advised Áhmed to kill the evil counsellors of murder and to drink no wine. Remorse so embittered Áhmed’s after-life that he was never known to laugh.

Ahmed I. 1411–1441.On his grandfather’s death, Áhmed succeeded with the title of N√°sir-ud-dunya Wad-dín Abúl fateh Áhmed Sh√°h. Shortly after Áhmed Sh√°h’s accession, his cousin Moid-ud-dín Fírúz Kh√°n, governor of Baroda, allying himself with His√°m or Niz√°m-ul-Mulk Bhand√°ri and other nobles, collected an army at Naḍi√°d in Kaira, and, laying claim to the crown, defeated the king’s followers. Jívand√°s, one of the insurgents, proposed to march upon P√°tan, but as the others refused a dispute arose in which Jívand√°s was slain, and the rest sought and obtained Áhmed Sh√°h’s forgiveness. Moid-ud-dín Fírúz Kh√°n went to Cambay and was there joined by Masti Kh√°n, son of Muzaffar Sh√°h, who was governor of Surat: on the king’s advance they fled from Cambay to Broach, to which fort Áhmed Sh√°h laid siege. As soon as the king arrived, Moid-ud-dín’s army went over to the king, and Masti Kh√°n also submitted. After a few days Áhmed Sh√°h sent for and forgave Moid-ud-dín, and returned to As√°wal victorious and triumphant.

Builds Áhmed√°b√°d, 1413.In the following year (a.d. 1413–14)4 Áhmed Sh√°h defeated Ása Bhíl, chief of As√°wal, and, finding the site of that town suitable for his capital, he changed its name to Áhmed√°b√°d, and busied himself [236]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed I. 1411–1441. in enlarging and fortifying the city.5 During this year Moid-ud-dín Fírúz Kh√°n and Masti Kh√°n again revolted, and, joining the Ídar R√°ja, took shelter in that fortress. Defeats the Ídar Chief, 1414.A force under Fateh Kh√°n was despatched against the rebels, and finally Fírúz Kh√°n and the Ídar R√°ja were forced to flee by way of Kher√°lu a town in the district of Kadi. Moid-ud-dín now persuaded Rukn Kh√°n governor of Mod√°sa, fifty miles north of Áhmed√°b√°d, to join. They united their forces with those of Badri-ûl√°, Masti Kh√°n, and Ranmal R√°ja of Ídar and encamped at Rangpura an Ídar village about five miles from Mod√°sa and began to strengthen Mod√°sa and dig a ditch round it. The Sult√°n camped before the fort and offered favourable terms. The besieged bent on treachery asked the Sult√°n to send Niz√°m-ul-Mulk the minister and certain other great nobles. The Sult√°n agreed, and the besieged imprisoned the envoys. After a three days’ siege Mod√°sa fell. Badri-ûl√° and Rukn Kh√°n were slain, and Fírúz Kh√°n and the R√°ja of Ídar fled. The imprisoned nobles were released unharmed. The R√°ja seeing that all hope of success was gone, made his peace with the king by surrendering to him the elephants, horses and other baggage of Moid-ud-dín Fírúz Kh√°n and Masti Kh√°n, who now fled to N√°gor, where they were sheltered by Shams Kh√°n Dand√°ni. Áhmed Sh√°h after levying the stipulated tribute departed. Moid-ud-dín Fírúz Kh√°n was afterwards slain in the war between Shams Kh√°n and R√°na Mokal of Chitor. Suppresses a Revolt, 1414.In a.d. 1414–15 Uthm√°n Áhmed and Sheikh Malik, in command at P√°tan, and Sulaim√°n Afgh√°n called Ázam Kh√°n, and Ísa S√°l√°r rebelled, and wrote secretly to Sult√°n Hushang of M√°lwa, inviting him to invade Gujar√°t, and promising to seat him on the throne and expel Áhmed Sh√°h. They were joined in their rebellion by Jh√°la Satars√°lji6 of P√°tdi and other chiefs of Gujar√°t. Áhmed Sh√°h despatched Latíf Kh√°n and Niz√°m-ul-Mulk against Sheikh Malik and his associates, while he sent Im√°d-ul-Mulk against Sult√°n Hushang, who retired, and Im√°d-ul-Mulk, after plundering M√°lwa, returned to Gujar√°t. Latíf Kh√°n, pressing in hot pursuit of Satars√°l and Sheikh Malik, drove them to Sorath. The king returned with joyful heart to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Spread of Isl√°m, 1414.Though, with their first possession of the country, a.d. 1297–1318, the Muhammadans had introduced their faith from P√°tan to Broach, the rest of the province long remained unconverted. By degrees, through the efforts of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, the power of Isl√°m became more directly felt in all parts of the province. Many districts, till then all but independent, accepted the Musalm√°n faith at the hands of Áhmed Sh√°h, and agreed to the payment of a regular tribute. In a.d. 1414 he led an army against the R√°v of Jun√°gaḍh and defeated him. The R√°v retired to the hill fortress of Girn√°r. Áhmed Sh√°h, though unable to capture the hill, gained the fortified citadel of Jun√°gaḍh. Finding further resistance vain, the chief tendered his submission, and Jun√°gaḍh was admitted among the tributary states. [237]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed I. 1411–1441. This example was followed by the greater number of the Sorath chiefs, who, for the time, resigned their independence. Sayad Ábûl Khair and Sayad K√°sim were left to collect the tribute, and Áhmed Sh√°h returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. Next year he marched against Sidhpur,7 and in a.d. 1415 advanced from Sidhpur to Dh√°r in M√°lwa. Áhmed I. Quells a Second Revolt, 1416.At this time the most powerful feudatories were the R√°v of Jun√°gaḍh, the R√°val of Ch√°mp√°ner,8 the R√°ja of N√°ndoḍ, the R√°v of Ídar, and the R√°ja of Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa. Trimbakd√°s of Ch√°mp√°ner, Púnja of Ídar, Siri of N√°ndod, and Mandlik of Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, alarmed at the activity of Áhmed Sh√°h and his zeal for Isl√°m, instigated Sult√°n Hushang of M√°lwa to invade Gujar√°t. Áhmed Sh√°h promptly marched to Mod√°sa,9 forced Sult√°n Hushang of M√°lwa to retire, and broke up the conspiracy, reproving and pardoning the chiefs concerned. About the same time the Sorath chiefs withheld their tribute, but the patience and unwearied activity of the king overcame all opposition. When at Mod√°sa Áhmed heard that, by the treachery of the son of the governor, N√°sír of Asír and Gheir√°t or Ghazni Kh√°n of M√°lwa had seized the fort of Th√°lner in Sirpur in Kh√°ndesh, and, with the aid of the chief of N√°ndoḍ, were marching against Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r. Áhmed sent an expedition against Nasír of Asír under Malik Mahmúd Barki or Turki. When the Malik reached N√°ndoḍ he found that Gheirat Kh√°n had fled to M√°lwa and that Nasír had retired to Th√°lner. The Malik advanced, besieged and took Th√°lner, capturing Nasír whom Áhmed forgave and dignified with the title of Kh√°n.10

After quelling these rebellions Áhmed Sh√°h despatched Niz√°m-ul-Mulk to punish the R√°ja of Mandal near Viramg√°m, and Expedition against M√°lwa, 1417.himself marched to M√°lwa against Sult√°n Hushang, whom he defeated, capturing his treasure and elephants. In a.d. 1418, in accordance with his policy of separately engaging his enemies, Attacks Ch√°mp√°ner, 1418.Áhmed Sh√°h marched to chastise Trimbakdas of Ch√°mp√°ner, and though unable to take the fortress he laid waste the surrounding country. In a.d. 1419 he ravaged the lands round Sankheda11 and built a fort there and a mosque within the fort; he also built a wall round the town of M√°ngni,12 and then marched upon M√°ndu. On the way ambassadors from Sult√°n Hushang met him suing for peace, and Áhmed Sh√°h, returning towards Ch√°mp√°ner, again laid waste the surrounding country. During the following year (a.d. 1420) he remained in Ahmed√°b√°d bringing his own dominions into thorough subjection by establishing fortified posts and by humbling the chiefs and destroying their strongholds. Among other works he built the forts of Dohad13 on the [238]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed I. 1411–1441. M√°lwa frontier and of Jítpur in Lún√°v√°ḍa.14 In a.d. 1421 he repaired the fort in the town of Kahreth, otherwise called Meimún in Lún√°v√°ḍa, which had been built by Ulugh Kh√°n Sanjar in the reign of Sult√°n Al√°-ud-dín (a.d. 1295–1315) and changed the name to Sult√°npur. War with M√°lwa, 1422.He next advanced against M√°lwa and took the fort of Mesar. After an unsuccessful siege of M√°ndu he went to Ujjain.15 From Ujjain he returned to M√°ndu, and failing to capture M√°ndu, he marched against S√°rangpur.16 Sult√°n Hushang sent ambassadors and concluded a peace. In spite of the agreement, while Áhmed Sh√°h was returning to Gujar√°t, Sult√°n Hushang made a night attack on his army and caused much havoc. Áhmed Sh√°h, collecting what men he could, waited till dawn and then fell on and defeated the M√°lwa troops, who were busy plundering. Sult√°n Hushang took shelter in the fort of S√°rangpur to which Áhmed Sh√°h again laid siege. Failing to take the fort Áhmed retreated towards Gujar√°t, closely followed by Sult√°n Hushang, who was eager to wipe out his former defeat. On Hushang’s approach, Áhmed Sh√°h, halting his troops, joined battle and repulsing Hushang returned to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Defeats the Ídar Chief, 1425.In a.d. 1425 Áhmed Sh√°h led an army against Ídar, defeating the force brought to meet him and driving their leader to the hills. Ídar was always a troublesome neighbour to the Áhmed√°b√°d kings and one difficult to subdue, for when his country was threatened, the chief could retire to his hills, where he could not easily be followed. As a permanent check on his movements, Áhmed Sh√°h, in a.d. 1427, built the fort of Ahmednagar,17 on the banks of the H√°thmati, eighteen miles south-west of Ídar. In the following year the Ídar chief, R√°v Púnja, attacked a foraging party and carried off one of the royal elephants. He was pursued into the hills and brought to bay in a narrow pathway at the edge of a steep ravine. Púnja was driving back his pursuers when the keeper of the Sult√°n’s elephant urged his animal against the R√°v’s horse. The horse swerving lost his foothold and rolling down the ravine destroyed himself and his rider.18

During the two following years Áhmed Sh√°h abstained from foreign conquests, devoting himself to improving his dominions and to working out a system of paying his troops. The method he finally adopted was payment half in money and half in land. This arrangement attached the men to the country, and, while keeping them dependent on the state, enabled them to be free from debt. Further to keep his officials in check he arranged that the treasurer should be one of the king’s slaves while the actual paymaster was a native of the particular locality. He also appointed √°mils that is sub-divisional revenue officers. After R√°v Púnja’s death Áhmed Sh√°h marched upon Ídar, and did not return until R√°v Púnja’s son agreed to pay an annual tribute of £300 (Rs. 3000). In the following year, according to Farishtah (II. 369) in spite of the young chiefs promise [239]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed I. 1411–1441. to pay tribute, Áhmed Sh√°h attacked Ídar, took the fort, and built an assembly mosque. Fearing that their turn would come next the chief of Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa and K√°nha apparently chief of Dungarpur fled to Nasír Kh√°n of Asír. Nasír Kh√°n gave K√°nha a letter to Áhmed Sh√°h B√°hmani, to whose son Al√°-ud-dín N√°sír’s daughter was married, and having detached part of his own troops to help K√°nha they plundered and laid waste some villages of Nandurb√°r and Sult√°npur. Sult√°n Áhmed sent his eldest son Muhammad Kh√°n with Mukarrabul Mulk and others to meet the Dakhanis who were repulsed with considerable loss. On this Sult√°n Áhmed B√°hmani, under Kadr Kh√°n Dakhani, sent his eldest son Al√°-ud-dín and his second son Kh√°n Jeh√°n against the Gujar√°tis. Kadr Kh√°n marched to Daulat√°b√°d and joining Nasír Kh√°n and the Gujar√°t rebels fought a great battle near the pass of M√°nek Púj, six miles south of N√°ndgaon in N√°sik. The confederates were defeated with great slaughter. The Dakhan princes fled to Daulat√°b√°d and K√°nha and Nasír Kh√°n to Kalanda near Ch√°lisgaum in south Kh√°ndesh.

Recovers M√°him, 1429;In the same year (a.d. 1429), on the death of Kutub Kh√°n the Gujar√°t governor of the island of M√°him, now the north part of the island of Bombay,19 Áhmed Sh√°h B√°hmani smarting under his defeats, ordered Hasan Izzat, otherwise called Malik-ut-Tujj√°r, to the Konkan and by the Malik’s activity the North Konkan passed to the Dakhanis. On the news of this disaster Áhmed Sh√°h sent his youngest son Zafar Kh√°n, with an army under Malik Iftikh√°r Kh√°n, to retake M√°him. A fleet, collected from Diu Gogha and Cambay sailed to the Konkan, attacked Th√°na20 by sea and land, captured it, and regained possession of M√°him. In a.d. 1431 Áhmed Sh√°h advanced upon Ch√°mp√°ner, and Áhmed Sh√°h Bahmani, anxious to retrieve his defeat at M√°him, marched an army into and B√°gl√°n, 1431.B√°gl√°n21 and laid it waste. This news brought Áhmed Sh√°h back to Nandurb√°r. Destroying N√°ndod he passed to Tambol, a fort in B√°gl√°n which Áhmed Sh√°h B√°hmani was besieging, defeated the besiegers and relieved the fort. He then went to Th√°na, repaired the fort, and returned to Gujar√°t by way of Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r. In a.d. 1432, after contracting his son Fateh Kh√°n in marriage with the daughter of the R√°i of M√°him to the north of Bassein Áhmed Sh√°h marched towards N√°gor, and exacted tribute and presents from the R√°val of Dúngarpur.22 From Dúngarpur he went to Mew√°r, enforcing his [240]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed I. 1411–1441. claims on Búndi and Kota, two H√°ra R√°jput states in south-east R√°jput√°na. He then entered the Delv√°da country, levelling temples and destroying the palace of R√°na Mokalsingh, the chief of Chitor. Thence he invaded N√°gor in the country of the R√°thoḍs, who submitted to him. After this he returned to Gujar√°t, and during the next few years was warring principally in M√°lwa, where, according to Farishtah, his army suffered greatly from pestilence and famine. Áhmed died in a.d. 1441 in the fifty-third year of his life and the thirty-third of his reign and was buried in the mausoleum in the M√°nek Chauk in Áhmed√°b√°d. His after-death title is Khûdaig√°n-i-Maghfûr the Forgiven Lord in token that, according to his merciful promise, Allah the pitiful, moved by the prayer of forty believers, had spread his forgiveness over the crime of Áhmed’s youth, a crime bewailed by a lifelong remorse.

Sult√°n Áhmed is still a name of power among Gujar√°t Musalm√°ns. He is not more honoured for his bravery, skill, and success as a war leader than for his piety and his justice. His piety showed itself in his respect for three great religious teachers Sheikh Rukn-ud-dín the representative of Sheikh Moín-ud-dín the great Khw√°jah of Ajmír, Sheikh Áhmed Khattu who is buried at Sarkhej five miles west of Áhmed√°b√°d, and the Bukh√°ran Sheikh Burh√°n-ud-dín known as Kutbi Álam the father of the more famous Sh√°h Álam. Of Áhmed’s justice two instances are recorded. Sitting in the window of his palace watching the S√°barmati in flood Áhmed saw a large earthen jar float by. The jar was opened and the body of a murdered man was found wrapped in a blanket. The potters were called and one said the jar was his and had been sold to the headman of a neighbouring village. On inquiry the headman was proved to have murdered a grain merchant and was hanged. The second case was the murder of a poor man by Áhmed’s son-in-law. The K√°zi found the relations of the deceased willing to accept a blood fine and when the fine was paid released the prince. Áhmed hearing of his son-in-law’s release said in the case of the rich fine is no punishment and ordered his son-in-law to be hanged.23
