Muhammad II. 1441–1452.Áhmed Sh√°h was succeeded by his generous pleasure-loving son Muhammad Sh√°h, Ghi√°s-ud-dunya Wad-dín, also styled Zarbaksh the Gold Giver. In a.d. 1445 Muhammad marched against Bír R√°i of Ídar, but on that chief agreeing to give him his daughter in marriage, he confirmed him in the possession of his state. His next expedition was against K√°nha R√°i of Dúngarpur, who took refuge in the hills, but afterwards returned, and paying tribute, was given charge of his country. Muhammad married Bíbi Mughli, daughter of J√°m Júna of Thatha in Sindh. She bore a son, Fateh Kh√°n, who was afterwards Sult√°n Mahmúd Begada. In a.d. 1450, Muhammad marched upon Ch√°mp√°ner, and took the lower fortress. Gang√°d√°s of Ch√°mp√°ner had a strong ally in Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji, the ruler of M√°lwa, and on his approach Muhammad Sh√°h retired to Godhra,24 and Mahmúd [241]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Muhammad II. 1441–1452. Khilji continued his march upon Gujar√°t at the head of 80,000 horse. Muhammad Sh√°h was preparing to fly to Diu, when the nobles, disgusted at his cowardice, caused him to be poisoned. Muhammad Sh√°h’s after-death title is Khûd√°ig√°n-i-Karím the Gracious Lord.

Kutb-ud-dín, 1451–1459.In a.d. 1451 the nobles placed Muhammad’s son Jal√°l Kh√°n on the throne with the title of Kutb-ud-dín. Meanwhile Sult√°n Mahmúd of M√°lwa had laid siege to Sult√°npur.25 Malik Al√°-ud-dín bin Sohr√°b Kutb-ud-dín’s commander surrendered the fort, and was sent with honour to War with M√°lwa, 1451.M√°lwa and appointed governor of M√°ndu. Sult√°n Mahmúd, marching to S√°rsa-P√°lri, summoned Broach, then commanded by Sídi Marj√°n on behalf of Gujar√°t. The Sídi refused, and fearing delay, the M√°lwa Sult√°n after plundering Baroda proceeded to Naḍi√°d, whose Br√°hmans astonished him by their bravery in killing a mad elephant. Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h now advancing met Sult√°n Mahmúd at Battle of Kapadvanj, 1454.Kapadvanj,26 where, after a doubtful fight of some hours, he defeated Sult√°n Mahmúd, though during the battle that prince was able to penetrate to Kutb-ud-dín’s camp and carry off his crown and jewelled girdle. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari ascribes Kutb-ud-dín’s victory in great measure to the gallantry of certain inhabitants of Dholka27 called Darw√°ziyahs. Muzaffar Kh√°n, who is said to have incited the M√°lwa Sult√°n to invade Gujar√°t, was captured and beheaded, and his head was hung up at the gate of Kapadvanj. On his return from Kapadvanj Kutb-ud-dín built the magnificent Hauzi Kutb or K√°nkariya Tank about a mile to the south of Áhmed√°b√°d. According to the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 50–57) this war between M√°lwa and Gujar√°t was controlled by the spiritual power of certain holy teachers. The war was brought on by the prayers of Sheikh Kam√°l M√°lwi, whose shrine is in Áhmed√°b√°d behind Khud√°wand Kh√°n’s mosque near Sh√°h-i-Álam’s tomb, who favoured M√°lwa. Kutb-ud-dín’s cause was aided by the blessing of Kutbi Álam who sent his son the famous Sh√°h Álam time after time to persuade Kam√°l to be loyal to Gujar√°t. At last Kam√°l produced a writing said to be from heaven giving the victory to M√°lwa. The young Sh√°h Álam tore this charter to shreds, and, as no evil befel him, Kam√°l saw that his spiritual power paled before Sh√°h Álam and fell back dead. Sh√°h Álam against his will accompanied Kutb-ud-dín some marches on his advance to Kapadvanj. Before leaving the army Sh√°h Álam blessed a mean camp elephant and ordered him to destroy the famous M√°lwa champion elephant known as the Butcher. He also, against his wish for he knew the future, at the Sult√°n’s request bound his own sword round Kutb-ud-dín’s waist. In the battle the commissariat elephant ripped the Butcher and some years later Kutb-ud-dín by accident gashed his knee with the saint’s sword and died. [242]


Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Kutb-ud-dín, 1451–1459. War with N√°gor, 1454–1459.In the same year Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji attempted to conquer N√°gor then held by Fírúz Kh√°n, a cousin of the Áhmed√°b√°d Sult√°n. Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h despatched an army under the command of Sayad At√°ull√°h, and, as it drew near S√°mbhar,28 the M√°lwa Sult√°n retired and shortly after Fírúz Kh√°n died. Kúmbha R√°na of Chitor29 now began interfering in the N√°gor succession on behalf of Shams Kh√°n, who had been dispossessed by his brother Muj√°hid Kh√°n, and expelled Muj√°hid. But as Shams Kh√°n refused to dismantle the fortifications of N√°gor, the Chitor chief collected an army to capture N√°gor, while Shams Kh√°n repaired to Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h for aid and gave that sovereign his daughter in marriage. Upon this Kutb-ud-dín sent R√°i Anupchand M√°nek and Malik Gad√°i with an army to N√°gor to repulse the R√°na of War with Chitor, 1455–1459.Chitor. In a battle near N√°gor the Gujar√°t troops were defeated, and the R√°na after laying waste the neighbourhood of that city, returned to Chitor. In a.d. 1455–56, to avenge this raid, Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h marched against Chitor. On his way the Devra R√°ja of Sirohi30 attended Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h’s camp, praying him to restore the fortress of Ábu,31 part of the ancestral domain of Sirohi, which the R√°na of Chitor had wrested from his house. The king ordered one of his generals, Malik Shaâb√°n, to take possession of Ábu and restore it to the Devra chieftain, while he himself continued to advance against Kumbhalmer. Malik Shaâb√°n was entangled in the defiles near Ábu, and defeated with great slaughter, and shortly after Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h, making a truce with Chitor, retired to his own country. On his return the M√°lwa sovereign proposed that they should unite against Chitor, conquer the R√°na’s territories, and divide them equally between them. Kutb-ud-dín agreed and in a.d. 1456–57 marched against the R√°na by way of Ábu, which fortress he captured and handed to the Devra R√°ja.32 Next, advancing upon Kumbhalmer, he plundered the country round, and then turned towards Chitor. On his way to Chitor, he was met by the R√°na, and a battle was fought, after which the R√°na fell back on his capital, and was there besieged by the Gujar√°t army. The siege was not pressed, and, on the R√°na agreeing to pay tribute and not to harass N√°gor, Kutb-ud-dín withdrew to Gujar√°t, where he gave himself up to licentious excess. Meanwhile, the R√°na by ceding Mandisor33 to M√°lwa, came to terms with the Sult√°n of M√°ndu, and within three months attacked N√°gor. Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h, though so overcome with drink as to be unable to sit his horse, mustered his troops and started in a palanquin. As soon as the R√°na heard that the Gujar√°t army was in motion he retired, and the king returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. In a.d. 1458, he again led an army by way of Sirohi [243]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Kutb-ud-dín, 1451–1459. and Kumbhalmer against Chitor, and laid waste the country. Soon after his return, according to one account by an accidental sword wound, according to another account poisoned by his wife, Kutb-ud-dín died in May a.d. 1459 after a reign of seven years and seven days. He was brave with a sternness of nature, which, under the influence of wine, amounted to fierceness. His after-death title is Sult√°n-i-Gh√°zi the Warrior King.

Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513.On the death of Kutb-ud-dín Sh√°h, the nobles raised to the throne his uncle D√°úd, son of Áhmed Sh√°h. But as D√°úd appointed low-born men to high offices and committed other foolish acts, he was deposed, and in a.d. 1459 his half-brother Fateh Kh√°n the son of Muhammad Sh√°h, son of Áhmed Sh√°h by Bíbi Mughli a daughter of J√°m Júna of Thatha in Sindh, was seated on the throne at the age of little more than thirteen with the title of Mahmúd Sh√°h.

The close connection of Fateh Kh√°n with the saintly Sh√°h Álam is a favourite topic with Gujar√°t historians. According to the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 66–70) of his two daughters J√°m Júna intended Bíbi Mughli the more beautiful for the Saint and Bíbi Mirghi the less comely for the Sult√°n. By bribing the J√°m’s envoys the king secured the prettier sister. The enraged Saint was consoled by his father who said: My son, to you will come both the cow and the calf. After Muhammad II.’s death, fear of Kutb-ud-dín’s designs against the young Fateh Kh√°n forced Bíbi Mughli to seek safety with her sister, and on her sister’s death she married the Saint. Kutb-ud-dín made several attempts to seize Fateh Kh√°n. But by the power of the Saint when Kutb-ud-dín attempted to seize him, Fateh Kh√°n in body as well as in dress became a girl. According to one account Kutb-ud-dín met his death in an attempt to carry off Fateh Kh√°n. As he rode into the Saint’s quarter Death in the form of a mad camel met the king. The king struck at the phantom, and his sword cleaving the air gashed his knee. This was the Saint’s sword, which against his will, for he knew it would be the death of the king, Kutb-ud-dín forced Sh√°h Álam to bind round him before the battle of Kapadvanj.

Defeats a Conspiracy, 1459.The death of his uncle, the late Sult√°n D√°úd, who had become a religious devotee, relieved Fateh Kh√°n of one source of danger. Shortly after certain of the nobles including Seiful Mulk, Kabír-ud-dín Sult√°ni surnamed Akd-ul-Mulk, Burh√°n-ul-Mulk and His√°m-ul-Mulk represented to the Sult√°n that the minister Shaâb√°n Im√°d-ul-Mulk contemplated treason and wished to set his son on the throne. Having seized and imprisoned the minister in the Bhadra citadel and set five hundred of their trusted retainers as guards over him, the rebels retired to their homes. At nightfall Abdull√°h, the chief of the elephant stables, going to the young Sult√°n represented to him that the nobles who had imprisoned Im√°d-ul-Mulk were the real traitors and had determined to place Habíb Kh√°n, an uncle of the Sult√°n’s, on the throne. The Sult√°n consulting his mother and some of his faithful friends ordered Abdull√°h at daybreak to equip all his elephants in full armour and draw them up in the square before the Bhadra. He then seated himself on the throne and in a voice of feigned anger ordered one of the courtiers to bring out Shaâb√°n Im√°d-ul-Mulk, that he might wreak his vengeance [244]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. upon him. As these orders were not obeyed the Sult√°n rose, and walking up the Bhadra called: “Bring out Shaâb√°n!” The guards brought forth Im√°d-ul-Mulk, and the Sult√°n ordered his fetters to be broken. Some of the nobles’ retainers made their submission to the Sult√°n, others fled and hid themselves. In the morning, hearing what had happened, the refractory nobles marched against the Sult√°n. Many advised the Sult√°n to cross the S√°barmati by the postern gate and retire from the city, and, after collecting an army, to march against the nobles. Giving no ear to these counsels the young Sult√°n ordered Abdull√°h to charge the advancing nobles with his six hundred elephants. The charge dispersed the malcontents who fled and either hid themselves in the city or betook themselves to the country. Some were killed, some were trampled by the Sult√°n’s orders under the elephants’ feet, and one was pardoned.34 His religious ardour, his love of justice, his bravery, and his wise measures entitle Mahmúd to the highest place among the Gujar√°t kings. One of the measures which the Mirăt-i-Sikandari specially notices is his continuance of land grants to the son of the holder, and in cases where there was no male issue of half the grant to the daughter. His firm policy of never ousting the landholder except for proved oppression or exaction was productive of such prosperity that the revenue increased two, three and in some cases tenfold. The roads were safe from freebooters and trade was secure. A rule forbidding soldiers to borrow money at interest is favourably noticed. Improves the Soldiery, 1459–1461.A special officer was appointed to make advances to needy soldiers with the power to recover from their pay in fixed instalments.35 Mahmúd also devoted much attention to the culture of fruit trees.36 In a.d. 1461, or a.d. 1462 according to Farishtah, Niz√°m Sh√°h B√°hmani (a.d. 1461–1463), king of the Dakhan, whose country had been invaded by Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji of M√°lwa, applied for help to the Gujar√°t king. Helps the King of the Dakhan, 1461.Mahmúd Sh√°h at once started to Niz√°m Sh√°h’s aid, and on his way receiving another equally pressing letter from the Dakhan sovereign, and being joined by the B√°hmani general Khw√°j√°h Jeh√°n G√°w√°n, he [245]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. pushed on with all speed by way of Burh√°npur.37 When Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji heard of his approach, he retired to his own country by way of Gondw√°na,38 from thirst and from the attacks of the Gonds, losing 5000 to 6000 men. The king of Gujar√°t, after receiving the thanks of the Dakhan sovereign, returned to his own dominions. In a.d. 1462 Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji made another incursion into the Dakhan at the head of 90,000 horse, plundering and laying waste the country as far as Daulat√°b√°d. Again the Dakhan sovereign applied for help to Mahmúd Sh√°h, and on hearing of Mahmúd’s advance the M√°lwa Sult√°n retired a second time to his own dominions. Mahmúd Sh√°h now wrote to the M√°lwa Sult√°n to desist from harassing the Dakhan, threatening, in case of refusal, to march at once upon M√°ndu. His next expedition was against the pirate zamínd√°rs of the hill fort of Barûr and the bandar of Dûn or D√°h√°nu, whose fort he took, and after imposing an annual tribute allowed the chief to continue to hold his hundred villages.39

Expedition against Jun√°gaḍh, 1467.Mahmúd Sh√°h next turned his thoughts to the conquest of the mountain citadel of Girn√°r in central K√°thi√°v√°ḍa.40 In a.d. 1467 he made an attack on the fort of Jun√°gaḍh, and receiving the submission of R√°v Mandlik, the local ruler, returned to his capital. In the following year, hearing that the Jun√°gaḍh chief continued to visit his idol temple in state with a golden umbrella and other ensigns of royalty, Mahmúd despatched an army to Jun√°gaḍh, and the chief sent the obnoxious umbrella to the king, accompanied by fitting presents. In a.d. 1469 Mahmúd once more sent an army to ravage Sorath, with the intention of finally conquering both Jun√°gaḍh and Girn√°r. While Mahmúd was on the march the R√°v Mandlik suddenly joined him, and asking why the Sult√°n was so bent on his destruction when he had committed no fault, agreed to do whatever Mahmúd might command. The king replied there is no fault like infidelity, and ordered the R√°v to embrace Isl√°m. The chief, now thoroughly alarmed, fled by night and made his way into Girn√°r. Capture of Girn√°r, 1472.In a.d. 1472–73 after a siege of nearly two years, forced by the failure of his stores, he quitted the fort and handing the keys to the king, repeated after him the Muhammadan profession of faith. Though the R√°v’s life was spared Sorath from this date became a crown possession, and was governed by an officer appointed by the king and stationed at Jun√°gaḍh. At the close of the war Mahmúd Sh√°h repaired the fort Jeh√°npan√°h, the present outer or town wall of Jun√°gaḍh, and, charmed with the beauty of the neighbourhood, settled sayads and learned men at Jun√°gaḍh and other towns [246]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. in Sorath. He induced the nobles to build houses, himself raised a palace and made the new city his capital under the name of Mustaf√°bad and enforced his claims as overlord on all the neighbouring chiefs. It is true that in the times of Áhmed Sh√°h these chieftains, including even the Jun√°gaḍh R√°v himself, had paid tribute. But Mahmúd established Áhmed√°b√°d rule so firmly that the duty of collecting the tribute was entrusted to an officer permanently settled in the country. The author of the Mirăt-i-Sikandari dilates on the dense woods round Jun√°gaḍh, full of mango, r√°en, j√°mbu, gúlar, √°mli, and √°onla41 trees, and notes that this forest tract was inhabited by a wild race of men called Kh√°nts.42

Disturbances in Ch√°mp√°ner, 1472.During Mahmúd Sh√°h’s prolonged absence from his capital, Malik Jam√°l-ud-dín was appointed governor of Áhmed√°b√°d, with the title of Muh√°fiz Kh√°n that is Care-taker. At this time Jesingh, son of Gang√°d√°s the chief of Ch√°mp√°ner, harassed the country round P√°v√°gaḍ. The king appointed Bah√°-ul-Mulk, who had the title of Im√°d-ul-Mulk, to the command of Sankheda; Malik S√°rang Kiw√°m-ul-Mulk to the command of Godhra; and T√°j Kh√°n bin S√°l√°r to the command of Norkha and D√°khna on the M√°hi. In consequence of these precautions Jesingh abstained from rebellion. At this time the R√°v Mandlik received the title of Kh√°n Jah√°n, and lands were bestowed on him, while the golden idols, which had been taken from the Jun√°gaḍh temples, were broken and distributed among the soldiers.

Conquest of Kachh.Mahmúd Sh√°h’s next expedition was against the turbulent inhabitants of the confines of Sindh. These were J√°dej√°s, though they are described as R√°jputs of the Sumra and Sodha tribes.43 They appear to have readily submitted, and to have voluntarily sent men to Jun√°gaḍh to be instructed in Isl√°m and to settle in Gujar√°t. Shortly afterwards they again became troublesome, and the king advancing into Kachh completely defeated them. About this time a learned man, Mulla Mahmúd Samarkandi, on his way from the Dakhan to Central Asia, complained to the king that he had been robbed by the pirates of Jagat or Dw√°rka.44 On hearing of this outrage Mahmúd Sh√°h marched to Jagat Destroyed.Jagat, took the fort, and destroyed the idol temples. The pirates, in the first instance, retired to the island of Shankhod√°ra or Bet, but from this, too, after a stout resistance they were driven with great slaughter. The king built a mosque at Jagat, entrusted the government to Farhat-ul-Mulk, and himself returned to Jun√°gaḍh. Before this Dw√°rka had never been conquered. Bhím, the R√°j√° of Dw√°rka, was sent to Muh√°fiz Kh√°n, the governor of Áhmed√°b√°d, with orders that he was to be hewn in pieces and a piece fastened to every gate of the city. After settling the affairs of Sorath, the king turned [247]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. his face towards Áhmed√°b√°d. On the way hearing that a fleet of Malab√°r craft were annoying the Gujar√°t ports, he marched to Gogha, equipped a fleet to oppose the pirates, and stopping at Cambay returned to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Conspiracy, 1480.In a.d. 1480, when Mahmúd Sh√°h was at Jun√°gaḍh, Khud√°wand Kh√°n and others, who were weary of the king’s constant warfare, incited his eldest son Áhmed to assume royal power. But Im√°d-ul-Mulk, by refusing to join, upset their plans, and on the king’s return the conspiracy was stamped out. In the previous year (a.d. 1479) Mahmúd Sh√°h sent an army to ravage Ch√°mp√°ner, which he was determined to conquer. About this time, hearing that the neighbourhood was infested with robbers, he founded the city of Mehmúd√°b√°d on the banks of the V√°trak, about eighteen miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d. In a.d. 1482 there was a partial famine in Gujar√°t, and the Ch√°mp√°ner country being exempt from scarcity the commandant of Mor√°mli or Rasúl√°b√°d, a post in the G√°ckw√°r’s S√°onli district on the Ch√°mp√°ner frontier, made several forays across the border. In return the chief attacked the commandant and defeated him, killing most of his men and capturing two elephants and several horses. On hearing this Mahmúd Sh√°h set out for Baroda with a powerful army. When Mahmúd reached Baroda the R√°val of War against Ch√°mp√°ner, 1482–1484.Ch√°mp√°ner, becoming alarmed, sent ambassadors and sued for forgiveness. The king rejected his overtures, saying: ‘Except the sword and the dagger no message shall pass between me and you.’45 The R√°val made preparations for a determined resistance, and sent messengers to summon Ghi√°s-ud-dín Khilji of M√°lwa to his aid. To prevent this junction Mahmúd Sh√°h entrusted the siege to his nobles and marched to Dohad, on which Sult√°n Ghi√°s-ud-dín withdrew to M√°ndu. On his return from Dohad the Sult√°n began building a J√°ma Mosque at Ch√°mp√°ner to show that he would not leave the place till he had taken the hill-fort of P√°v√°gaḍ. After the siege had lasted more than twenty months (April 1483–December 1484), the Musalm√°ns noticed that for an hour or two in the morning most of the R√°jputs were off duty bathing and dressing. A morning assault was planned and the first gate carried. Then Malik Ay√°z Sult√°ni finding a practicable breach passed through with some of his men and took the great gate. The R√°val and his R√°jputs, throwing their women children and valuables into a huge fire, rushed out in a fierce but unavailing charge.46

Capture of P√°v√°gaḍ, 1484.The R√°val and his minister Dúngarshi fell wounded into the conqueror’s hands, and, on refusing to embrace Isl√°m, were put to death. The R√°val’s son, who was entrusted to Seif-ul-Mulk, and instructed by him in the Muhammadan religion, afterwards, in the reign of Muzaffar Sh√°h (a.d. 1523–1526), was ennobled by the title of Niz√°m-ul-Mulk. On the capture of P√°v√°gaḍ in a.d. 1484, Mahmúd Sh√°h built a wall round the town of Ch√°mp√°ner, and made it his capital under the name of Muhammad√°b√°d. Under Mahmúd’s orders the neighbourhood [248]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. became stocked with mangoes, pomegranates, figs, grapes, sugarcane, plantains, oranges, custard apples, khirnis or r√°ens (Mimusops indica or hexandra), jackfruit, and cocoapalms, as well as with roses, chrysanthemums, jasmins, champ√°s, and sweet pandanus. A sandal grove near Ch√°mp√°ner is said to have had trees large enough to help the Musalm√°n nobles to build their mansions. At the instance of the Sult√°n a Khur√°s√°ni beautified one of the gardens with fountains and cascades. A Gujar√°ti named H√°lur learning the principle improved on his master’s design in a garden about four miles west of Ch√°mp√°ner, which in his honour still bears the name H√°lol.47

In Mahmúd’s reign an instance is mentioned of the form of compensation known as valtar. Some merchants bringing horses and other goods for sale from Ir√°k and Khur√°s√°n were plundered in Sirohi limits. The king caused them to give in writing the price of their horses and stuffs, and paying them from his own treasury recovered the amount from the R√°ja of Sirohi.

The Kh√°ndesh Succession, 1508.In a.d. 1494–95 Mahmúd went against Bah√°dur Kh√°n Gíl√°ni, a vassal of the Bahmanis, who from Goa and D√°bhol48 had so harassed the Gujar√°t harbours that, from the failure of the supply of betelnut, coriander seed had to be eaten with betel leaves. The Bahmani Sult√°n, fearing the consequences to himself, marched against Bah√°dur Kh√°n, and, capturing him alive, struck off his head, and sent it to the Gujar√°t monarch, who returned to his own country. In a.d. 1499–1500, hearing that N√°sir-ud-dín of M√°lwa had killed his father Ghi√°s-ud-dín and seated himself on the throne, the Sult√°n prepared to advance against him, but was appeased by N√°sir-ud-dín’s humble attitude. The next seven years passed without any warlike expedition. In a.d. 1507, near Daman on his way to Cheul, Mahmúd heard of the victory gained at Cheul over the Portuguese by the Gujar√°t squadron under Malik Ay√°z Sult√°ni, in concert with the Turkish fleet.49 In a.d. 1508 Mahmúd succeeded in placing his nephew Mir√°n Muhammad Ádil Kh√°n F√°rúki on the throne of Ásir-Burh√°npur. From 1508 Mahmúd remained at his capital till his death in December a.d. 1513 at the age of sixty-seven years and three months, after a reign of fifty-four years and one month. Mahmúd was buried at Sarkhej,50 and received [249]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. the after-death title of Khúd√°ig√°n-i-Halím or the Meek Lord. Immediately before his death Sult√°n Mahmúd was informed that Sh√°h Ism√°il Safawi of Persia had sent him a friendly embassy headed by Y√°dg√°r Beg Kazil-b√°sh. As the Kazil-b√°shes were known to be Shíahs the Sult√°n, who was a staunch Sunni, prayed that he might not be forced to see a Shíah’s face during his last days. His prayer was heard. He died before the Persian embassy entered the city.51 During the last days of Sult√°n Mahmúd, Sayad Muhammad of Jaunpur, who claimed to be the Mahdi or Messiah, came from Jaunpur and lodged in T√°jkh√°n S√°l√°r’s mosque near the Jam√°lpur gate of Áhmed√°b√°d. His sermons drew crowds, and were so persuasive that he gained a large body of followers, who believed his eloquence to be due to h√°l or inspiration. Mahmúd’s ministers persuaded him not to see the Jaunpur preacher. [250]


Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd I. (Begada), 1459–1513. Mahmúd Begada’s court was adorned by several pious and high-minded nobles. In life they vied with one another in generous acts; and after death, according to the Persian poet Urfi, they left their traces in the characters and carvings of stone walls and marble piles. First among these nobles the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 132, 142) mentions D√°war-ul-Mulk, whose god-fearing administration made his estates so prosperous that they were coveted by princes of the blood. As Th√°nad√°r of Amron in north K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, he spread the light of Isl√°m from Morvi to Bhúj, and after his death his fame as a spirit-ruling guardian drew hosts of sick and possessed to his shrine near Morvi. The second was Malik Ay√°z, governor of Diu, who built the strong fortress afterwards reconstructed by the Portuguese. He also built a tower on an under-water rock, and from the tower drew a massive iron chain across the mouth of the harbour. A substantial bridge over the creek, that runs through the island of Diu, was afterwards destroyed by the Portuguese. The third was Khud√°wand Kh√°n Ālím, the founder of Ālímpura a suburb to the south of Áhmed√°b√°d, adorned with a mosque of sandstone and marble. He introduced the cultivation of melons figs and sugarcane into Gujar√°t from Bij√°pur. The fourth was Im√°d-ul-Mulk Āsas who founded Ísanpur, a suburb between Sh√°h Álam’s suburb of Isl√°mpur and Batwa, and planted along the road groves of khirnis and mangoes. The fifth was T√°jkh√°n S√°l√°r, so loved of his peers that after his death none of them would accept his title. The sixth was Malik S√°rang Kiw√°m-ul-Mulk, a R√°jput by birth, the founder of the suburb of S√°rangpur and its mosque to the east of Áhmed√°b√°d. The seventh and eighth were the Khur√°s√°ni brothers Aâzam and Moâzzam, who built a cistern, a mosque, and a tomb between Áhmed√°b√°d and Sarkhej.

Besides Khalíl Kh√°n, who succeeded him, Mahmúd had three sons: Muhammad K√°la, Áp√° Kh√°n, and Áhmed Kh√°n. K√°la, son of R√°ni Rúp Manjhri died during his father’s lifetime as did his mother, who was buried in M√°nek Chauk in Áhmed√°b√°d in the building known as the R√°ni’s Hazíra. The second son Áp√° Kh√°n was caught trespassing in a noble’s harím, and was ordered by the Sult√°n to be poisoned. The third son was the Áhmed Kh√°n whom Khud√°wand Kh√°n sought to raise to the throne during Sult√°n Mahmúd’s lifetime.

Muzaffar II. 1513–1526.Muhammad was succeeded by Khalíl Kh√°n, the son of R√°ni Hír√°b√°i the daughter of a R√°jput chieftain named N√°ga R√°na who lived on the bank of the Mahi. On ascending the throne, at the age of twenty-seven, Khalíl adopted the title of Muzaffar Sh√°h. For some time before his father’s death, Prince Khalíl Kh√°n had been living at Baroda and shortly after his accession he visited that neighbourhood, and founded a town which he named Daulat√°b√°d. In a.d. 1514 R√°v Bhím, the son of R√°v Bh√°n of Ídar, Expedition against Ídar, 1514.defeated Ain-ul-Mulk, governor of P√°tan, who was coming to Áhmed√°b√°d to pay his respects to the king. This officer had turned aside to punish the R√°v for some disturbance he had created, but failing in his purpose, was himself defeated. On the approach of Muzaffar Sh√°h, Ídar was abandoned by the R√°v, who made his peace with difficulty and only by agreeing to pay a heavy tribute. Meanwhile the king marched to Godhra, and so to M√°lwa by way of Dohad, whose fort he caused to be repaired, and soon after went on to Dh√°r. [251]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Muzaffar II. 1513–1526. After a short stay in M√°lwa, thinking it mean to take advantage of the distracted condition of Mahmúd of M√°lwa, who was at war with his nobles, Muzaffar returned to Muhammad√°b√°d (Ch√°mp√°ner). At this time R√°imal, nephew of the late R√°v Bhím of Ídar, expelled the R√°v’s son Bh√°rmal by the aid of his father-in-law R√°na S√°nga of Chitor, and succeeded to the chieftainship of Ídar. The king was displeased at the interference of the R√°na, and directed Niz√°m Kh√°n, the governor of Ahmednagar, to expel R√°imal and reinstate Bh√°rmal. Niz√°m Kh√°n took Ídar and gave it to Bh√°rmal. R√°imal betook himself to the hills where Niz√°m Kh√°n incautiously pursuing and engaging him lost many men. When the rains were over the Sult√°n visited Ídar. Shortly after, Niz√°m Kh√°n, the governor of Ahmednagar, fell sick and was called to court. He left Ídar in charge of Zahír-ul-Mulk at the head of a hundred horse. R√°imal made a sudden raid on Ídar and killed Zahír-ul-Mulk and twenty-seven of his men. On hearing of this reverse Sult√°n Muzaffar ordered Niz√°m Kh√°n to destroy Bíj√°pur.52 Disturbances in M√°lwa, 1517.In a.d. 1517, the nobles of M√°lwa besought Muzaffar’s interference, alleging that the Hindu minister Med√°ni R√°i was planning to depose the M√°lwa Sult√°n, Mahmúd Khilji, and usurp the throne. Muzaffar Sh√°h promised to come to their help, and shortly after Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji, escaping from the surveillance of Med√°ni R√°i, himself sought the aid of the Gujar√°t monarch. In a.d. 1518 Muzaffar Sh√°h marched by Godhra into M√°lwa, and on his arrival at Dh√°r, that town was evacuated by Med√°ni R√°i. The Gujar√°t king next besieged M√°ndu and Med√°ni R√°i summoned the Chitor R√°na to his aid. Capture of M√°ndu, 1518.When the R√°na had reached S√°rangpur, Muzaffar Sh√°h detaching a force caused the R√°na to retire, while the Gujar√°t soldiers exerted themselves so strenuously that they captured M√°ndu, recovering the girdle which Kutb-ud-dín had lost at the battle of Kapadvanj. This conquest virtually placed M√°lwa in Muzaffar’s power, but he honourably restored the kingdom to Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji, and, withdrawing to Gujar√°t, proceeded to Muhammad√°b√°d. In a.d. 1519, news was received of the defeat and capture of Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji by the R√°na of Chitor. Muzaffar Sh√°h sent a force to protect M√°ndu. But the R√°na, who distinguished himself by releasing the Sult√°n of M√°lwa and keeping his son in his stead as a hostage, enjoyed continued good fortune. Some time before these events a bh√°t or bard in the presence of Niz√°m Kh√°n, the governor of Ídar, boasted that the R√°na of War with Chitor, 1519.Chitor would never fail to help R√°na R√°imal of Ídar. The angry governor said ‘Whose dog is R√°na S√°nga to help R√°imal while we are here.’ Niz√°m Kh√°n called a dog S√°nga, chained him in the fort, and dared the R√°na to carry him away. His successes enabled S√°nga to answer the challenge. In consequence of dissensions at head-quarters Niz√°m Kh√°n withdrew to Ahmednagar leaving a small garrison in Ídar. When R√°na S√°nga appeared before Ídar the garrison resisted but were slain to a man. The R√°na advanced to Ahmednagar and severely defeated Niz√°m Kh√°n who withdrew to Áhmed√°b√°d, while the R√°na plundered Vish√°lnagar.53 In a.d. 1521, Malik Ay√°z Sult√°ni, the governor of [252]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Muzaffar II. 1513–1526. The R√°na of Chitor Submits, 1521.Sorath, was sent with a large and carefully equipped force to revenge this inroad. Dissensions between Malik Ay√°z and the Gujar√°t nobles prevented this expedition doing more than burn and despoil both Dungarpur and B√°nsv√°da. Muzaffar Sh√°h, greatly displeased with the result, was preparing to march against Chitor, when he was dissuaded by a submissive embassy from that chief, who sent his son to Áhmed√°b√°d with valuable presents for the king. Shortly afterwards, on the death of Malik Ay√°z, Muzaffar Sh√°h confirmed his elder son Malik Is-h√°k in his father’s rank and possessions. Malik Is-h√°k remained in Sorath which was confirmed as his j√°gir. In the following year the Sult√°n went about his dominions strengthening his frontier posts, especially the fort of Mod√°sa, which he rebuilt. About a.d. 1524 prince B√°h√°dur Kh√°n, ostensibly dissatisfied with the smallness of his estates but really to remove himself from the jealousy of his brother Sikandar who being appointed heir-apparent was seeking his life, left Gujar√°t and withdrew to Hindust√°n. King Muzaffar, after formally appointing his son Sikandar Kh√°n his heir, Dies, 1526.died at Áhmed√°b√°d in a.d. 1526, after a reign of fourteen years and nine months. Muzaffar was buried in the shrine of Sheikh Áhmed Khattu at Sarkhej near his father’s grave. He was the most learned and one of the most pious of the Áhmed√°b√°d Sult√°ns. So extreme an abstainer was he that not only during his whole life did he eschew intoxicating drugs and liquor but he never again rode a favourite horse because the horse was cured by a draught of wine. He was an accomplished musician, a finished horseman, a practised swordsman, and withal so modest and humble in his dress and temper that observing once to a favourite page how simple and yet graceful his own turban was the boy laughed: ‘Ay, if the turbans of Mullahs and Bohoras are graceful, then is your Majesty’s.’ The Sult√°n said ‘I should have been proud to have my turban likened to a Mullah’s, why compare it with the headdress of a schismatic Bohora.’ Muzaffar was careful never to pain the feelings of those around him. He suspected Kiw√°m-ul-Mulk who was in charge of his drinking water but contented himself with breathing over the water one of the verses of the Kurâ√°n which make poison harmless.54 During his reign cultivation increased so much in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa that it became necessary to reserve certain waste land for pasture. In 1526 the rains held off so long that famine began to rage. The Sult√°n exclaimed, ‘Oh Allah! If thou scourgest the country for the sins of its king take his life and spare thy creatures.’ The prayer was heard and the soul of the guardian Sult√°n passed in a flood of gracious rain.55

Sikandar, 1526.After Sikandar Sh√°h had been in power a few months he was murdered by Im√°d-ul-Mulk Khush Kadam, who seated a younger brother of Sikandar’s, named N√°sir Kh√°n, on the throne with the title of Mahmúd II. 1526.Mahmúd II. and governed on his behalf. The only event of Sikandar’s reign was the destruction of an army sent against his brother [253]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd II. 1526. Latíf Kh√°n who was helped by R√°na Bhím of Munga.56 The nobles deserted Im√°d-ul-Mulk’s cause, and prince Bah√°dur, 1527–1536.B√°h√°dur Kh√°n, returning to Gujar√°t from Hindust√°n, was joined by many supporters prominent among whom was T√°j Kh√°n, proprietor of Dhandhuka. Bah√°dur marched at once on Ch√°mp√°ner, captured and executed Im√°d-ul-Mulk and poisoning N√°sir Kh√°n ascended the throne in a.d. 1527 with the title of Bah√°dur Sh√°h. His brother Latíf Kh√°n, aided by R√°ja Bhím of the Kohistan or hill land of P√°l,57 now asserted his claim to the throne. He was defeated, and fell wounded into the hands of the Gujar√°t army and died of his wounds and was buried at H√°lol. R√°ja Bhím was slain. As Bhím’s successor R√°isingh plundered Dohad, a large force was sent against him, commanded by T√°j Kh√°n, who laid waste R√°isingh’s country and dismantled his forts. Soon after Bah√°dur Sh√°h visited Cambay, and found that Malik Is-h√°k the governor of Sorath had, in the interests of the Portuguese, attempted to seize Diu but had been repulsed by the Gujar√°t admiral Mahmúd Áka. The Sult√°n entrusted Diu to Kiw√°m-ul-Mulk and Jun√°gaḍh to Muj√°hid Kh√°n Bhíkan and returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. In 1527 he enforced tribute from Ídar and the neighbouring country. During one of his numerous expeditions he went to hunt in N√°ndod and received the homage of the R√°ja. Portuguese Intrigues, 1526.As the Portuguese were endeavouring to establish themselves on the coast of Sorath, and, if possible, to obtain Diu, the king was constantly at Cambay Diu and Gogha to frustrate their attempts, and he now directed the construction of the fortress of Broach. At this time Muhammad Kh√°n, ruler of Asír and Burh√°npur, requested Bah√°dur’s aid on behalf of Im√°d-ul-Mulk, ruler of Ber√°r. Bah√°dur Sh√°h started at once and at Nandurb√°r was joined by Muhammad Kh√°n Asíri, and thence proceeded to Burh√°npur, where he was met by Im√°d Sh√°h from G√°valgad. Kh√°ndesh Affairs, 1528.After certain successes he made peace between Burh√°n Niz√°m Sh√°h and Im√°d Sh√°h G√°vali, and returned to Gujar√°t. J√°m Fírúz the ruler of Tatha in Sindh now sought refuge with Bah√°dur Sh√°h from the oppression either of the Ghoris or of the [254]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Bah√°dur, 1527–1536. Mughals and was hospitably received. In a.d. 1528 Bah√°dur made an expedition into the Dakhan which ended in a battle at Daulat√°b√°d. The issue of this battle seems to have been unfavourable as hardly any reference to the campaign remains. Next year (a.d. 1529) at the request of Jaâfar or Khizr Kh√°n, son of Im√°d Sh√°h G√°vali, who was sent to Gujar√°t to solicit Bah√°dur’s help, he again marched for the Dakhan. As he passed through Muler Biharji the R√°ja of B√°gl√°n gave him his daughter in marriage and in return received the title of Bahr Kh√°n. From B√°gl√°n Bahr Kh√°n was told off to ravage Cheul which by this time had fallen into the hands of the Portuguese. Bah√°dur himself advanced to Ahmednagar, took the fort and destroyed many of the buildings. Purandhar also was sacked of its stores of gold.58 From Ahmednagar Bah√°dur Sh√°h passed to Burh√°npur, and there his general Kaisar Kh√°n gained a victory over the united forces of Niz√°m Sh√°h, Malik Beríd, and Ain-ul-Mulk. After having the public sermon read in his name both in Ahmednagar and in Burh√°npur Bah√°dur returned to Gujar√°t and for some time refrained from interfering in the affairs of the Dakhan.

Turks at Diu, 1526–1530.Between a.d. 1526 and 1530 certain Turks under one Mústafa came to Gujar√°t, traders according to one account according to another part of a Turkish fleet expected to act against the Portuguese. Diu was assigned them as a place of residence and the command of the island was granted to Malik Túgh√°n, son of Malik Ay√°z, the former governor. In a.d. 1530 the king marched to N√°gor, and gave an audience both to Prathir√°j R√°ja of Dúngarpur and to the ambassadors from R√°na Ratansi of Chitor. The R√°na’s ambassadors complained of encroachments on Chitor by Mahmúd of M√°lwa. Mahmúd promised to appear before Bah√°dur to explain the alleged encroachments. Bah√°dur waited. At last as Mahmúd failed to attend Bah√°dur said he would go and meet Mahmúd. He invested M√°ndu and received with favour certain deserters from Mahmúd’s army. The fortress fell and Sult√°n Mahmúd and his seven sons were captured. The success of the siege was due to Bah√°dur’s personal prowess. Capture of M√°ndu, 1530.He scaled an almost inaccessible height and sweeping down from it with a handful of men took the fort, a feat which for daring and dash is described as unsurpassed in the history of Musalm√°n Gujar√°t.59 After passing the rainy season at M√°ndu Bah√°dur Sh√°h went to Burh√°npur to visit his nephew Mir√°n Muhammad Sh√°h. At Burh√°npur Bah√°dur under the influence of the great priest-statesman Sh√°h T√°hir, was reconciled with Burh√°n Niz√°m and gave him the royal canopy he had taken from M√°lwa. Bah√°dur offered Sh√°h T√°hir the post of minister. Sh√°h T√°hir declined saying he must make a pilgrimage to Makkah. He retired to Ahmednagar and there converted Burh√°n Niz√°m Sh√°h to the Shíâh faith.60 In the same year, hearing that M√°nsingji, R√°ja of [255]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Bah√°dur, 1527–1536. Halvad,61 had killed the commandant of Das√°da Bah√°dur despatched Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n against him. Víramg√°m and M√°ndal were reft from the Jh√°la chieftains, and ever after formed part of the crown dominions. When Sult√°n Mahmúd Khilji and his sons were being conveyed to the fortress of Ch√°mp√°ner, R√°isingh, R√°ja of P√°l, endeavoured to rescue them. The attempt failed, and the prisoners were put to death by their guards. In a.d. 1531, on Bah√°dur’s return from Burh√°npur to Dh√°r, hearing that Silehdi the R√°jput chief of R√°isin in east M√°lwa kept in captivity certain Muhammadan women who had belonged to the harím of Sult√°n N√°sir-ud-dín of M√°lwa, Bah√°dur marched against him and forced him to surrender and embrace Isl√°m. The chief secretly sent to the R√°na of Chitor for aid and delayed handing over R√°isin. On learning this Bah√°dur despatched a force to keep Chitor in check and pressed the siege. At his own request, Silehdi was sent to persuade the garrison to surrender. But their reproaches stung him so sharply, that, joining with them, and after burning their women and children, they sallied forth sword in hand and were all slain. R√°isin fell into Bah√°dur’s hands, and this district together with those of Bhilsa and Chanderi were entrusted to the government of Sult√°n Álam Lodhi. The king now went to Gondw√°na to hunt elephants, and, after capturing many, employed his army in reducing G√°graun and other minor fortresses.62 In a.d. 1532 he advanced against Chitor, but raised the siege on receiving an enormous ransom. Shortly afterwards his troops took the strong fort of Rantanbhur.63 About this time on receipt of news that the Portuguese were usurping authority the Sult√°n repaired to Diu. Before he arrived the Portuguese had taken to flight, leaving behind them an enormous gun which the Sult√°n ordered to be dragged to Ch√°mp√°ner.

Quarrel with Hum√°yún, 1532.Before a.d. 1532 was over Bah√°dur Sh√°h quarrelled with Hum√°yún, emperor of Delhi. The original ground of quarrel was that Bah√°dur Sh√°h had sheltered Sult√°n Muhammad Zam√°n Mírza the grandson of a daughter of the emperor B√°bar (a.d. 1482–1530). Hum√°yún’s anger was increased by an insolent answer from the Gujar√°t king. Without considering that he had provoked a powerful enemy, Bah√°dur Sh√°h again laid siege to Chitor, and though he heard that Hum√°yún had arrived at Gw√°lior, he would not desist from the siege. Fall of Chitor, 1535.In March 1535 Chitor fell into the hands of the Gujar√°t king but near Mandasúr his army was shortly afterwards routed by Hum√°yún. According to one account, the failure of the Gujar√°t army was due to Bah√°dur and his nobles being spell-bound by looking at a heap of salt and some cloth soaked in indigo which were mysteriously left before Bah√°dur’s tent by an unknown elephant. The usual and probably true explanation is that Rúmi Kh√°n the Turk, head of the Gujar√°t artillery, betrayed Bah√°dur’s interest.64 Still though Rúmi Kh√°n’s treachery may have had a share in Bah√°dur’s defeat it seems probable that in valour, discipline, and tactics the Gujar√°t army was [256]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Bah√°dur, 1527–1536. inferior to the Mughals. Mughal Conquest of Gujar√°t, 1535.Bah√°dur Sh√°h, unaccustomed to defeat, lost heart and fled to M√°ndu, which fortress was speedily taken by Hum√°yún. From M√°ndu the king fled to Ch√°mp√°ner, and finally took refuge in Diu. Ch√°mp√°ner fell to Hum√°yún, and the whole of Gujar√°t, except Sorath, came under his rule. At this time Sher Sh√°h Súr revolted, in Bih√°r and Jaunpur, and Hum√°yún returned to Agra to oppose him leaving his brother Hind√°l Mírza in Áhmed√°b√°d, K√°sam Beg in Broach, and Y√°dg√°r N√°sir Mírza in P√°tan. Are Driven Out, 1536.As soon as Hum√°yún departed, the country rose against the Mughals, and his old nobles requested the king to join them. Bah√°dur joined them, and, defeating the Mughals at Kaníj near Mahmúd√°b√°d, expelled them from Gujar√°t. During Hum√°yún’s time of success Bah√°dur Sh√°h, being forced to court the The Portuguese at Diu, 1536.Portuguese, had granted them leave to erect a factory in Diu. Instead of a factory the Portuguese built a fort. When he recovered his kingdom, Bah√°dur, repenting of his alliance with the Portuguese, went to Sorath to persuade an army of Portuguese, whom he had asked to come to his assistance, to return to Goa. When the Portuguese arrived at Diu five or six thousand strong the Sult√°n hoping to get rid of them by stratagem, repaired to Diu and endeavoured to get the viceroy into his power. The viceroy excused himself, and in return invited the king to visit his ship. Death of Bah√°dur, 1536.Bah√°dur agreed, and on his way back was attacked and slain, in the thirty-first year of his life and the eleventh of his reign. According to the author of the Mirăt-i-Sikandari the reason of Bah√°dur’s assassination was that a paper from him to the kings of the Dakhan, inviting them to join him in an alliance against the Portuguese, had fallen into the hands of the Portuguese viceroy. Whatever may have been the provocation or the intention, the result seems to show that while both sides had treacherous designs neither party was able to carry out his original plan, and the end was unpremeditated, hurried on by mutual suspicions.65 Up to the defeat of Sult√°n Bah√°dur by Hum√°yún, the power of Gujar√°t was at its height. Cadets of noble R√°jput houses, Prithir√°j, the nephew of R√°na S√°nga of Chitor, and Narsingh Deva the cousin of the R√°ja of Gw√°lior, were proud to enrol themselves as the Sult√°n’s vassals. The R√°ja of Bagl√°na readily gave Bah√°dur Sh√°h his daughter. J√°m Fírúz of Tatha in Sindh and the sons of Bahlúl Lodhi were suppliants at his court. M√°lwa was a dependency of Gujar√°t and the Niz√°m Sh√°his of Ahmednagar and Nasírkhan of Burh√°npur acknowledged him as overlord, while the F√°rúkis of Kh√°ndesh were dependent on Bah√°dur’s constant help.66

Muhammad II. (Ásíri), 1536.On the death of king Bah√°dur in a.d. 1536, the nobles of Gujar√°t invited his sister’s son Muhammad Sh√°h Ásíri to succeed him. Muhammad Sh√°h died shortly after his accession, and the nobles conferred the crown on Mahmúd Kh√°n, son of Latíf Kh√°n, brother of Bah√°dur Sh√°h, and he ascended the throne in a.d. 1536, when only eleven years of age. The government of the country was carried on by Darya Kh√°n and Im√°d-ul-Mulk, who kept the king under [257]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd II. 1536–1554. strict surveillance. Darya Kh√°n resolved to overthrow Im√°d-ul-Mulk and acquire supreme power. With this object he obtained an order from the king, whom, on the pretence of a hunting expedition, he removed from Áhmed√°b√°d, directing Im√°d-ul-Mulk to retire to his estates in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa. Six months later, taking the Sult√°n with him, Darya Kh√°n led an army into Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, and defeating Im√°d-ul-Mulk in a battle at P√°tri, fifty two miles west of Áhmed√°b√°d, pursued him to Burh√°npur, and there defeated Im√°d-ul-Mulk’s ally the ruler of Kh√°ndesh and forced Im√°d-ul-Mulk to fly to M√°lwa.67 After this success Darya Kh√°n became absorbed in pleasure, and resigned the management of the kingdom to Álam Kh√°n Lodhi. The king, dissembling his dissatisfaction at the way he was treated, pretended to take no interest in affairs of state. Álam Kh√°n Lodhi, seeing the carelessness of Darya Kh√°n, began to entertain ambitious designs, and retiring to his estate of Dhandhúka invited the king to join him. Mahmúd Sh√°h, believing him to be in earnest, contrived to escape from surveillance and joined Álam Kh√°n. Escapes from Control.On discovering the king’s flight, Darya Kh√°n raised to the throne a descendant of Áhmed Sh√°h by the title of Muzaffar Sh√°h, and striking coin in his name set out with an army towards Dhandhúka. Álam Kh√°n and the king met him at Dhúr in Dholka, and a battle was fought in which Mahmúd and Álam Kh√°n were defeated. The king fled to R√°npur, and thence to P√°li√°d, while Álam Kh√°n fled to S√°dra. Darya Kh√°n occupied Dhandhuka; but his men, dissatisfied at being placed in opposition to the king, rapidly deserted, some joining Álam Khan and some Mahmúd Sh√°h. Soon after the king joined Álam Khan and marched on Áhmed√°b√°d, whither Darya Kh√°n had preceded them. The citizens closed the gates against Darya Kh√°n, but he forced an entry by way of the Burh√°npur wicket. Hearing of the king’s approach Darya Kh√°n fled to Mub√°rak Sh√°h at Burh√°npur, leaving his family and treasure in the fortress of Ch√°mp√°ner.

Chooses Evil Favourites.The king entered Áhmed√°b√°d, and soon after captured Ch√°mp√°ner. Álam Kh√°n now obtained the recall of Im√°d-ul-Mulk, who received a grant of Broach and the port of Surat. Shortly afterwards Mahmúd Sh√°h began to show favour to men of low degree, especially to one Charji, a birdcatcher, whom he ennobled by the title of Muh√°fiz Kh√°n. Charji counselled Mahmúd to put to death Sult√°n Al√°-ud-dín Lodhi and Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, two of the principal nobles; and the king, without consulting his ministers, caused these men to be executed. The nobles joining together besieged Mahmúd Sh√°h in his palace, and demanded that Muh√°fiz Kh√°n should be surrendered to them, but the king refused to give him up. The nobles then demanded an audience, and this the king granted, Muh√°fiz Kh√°n, though warned of his danger, being foolishly present. On entering the royal presence Álam Kh√°n signalled to his followers to slay Muh√°fiz, and he was killed in spite of the king’s remonstrances. Mahmúd then attempted to kill himself, but was prevented and placed under guard, and the chief nobles took it in turn to watch him. Strife soon arose between Álam Kh√°n and Muj√°hid [258]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd II. 1536–1554. Kh√°n and his brother, and the two latter nobles contrived the king’s escape and sacked the houses of Álam Kh√°n and his followers. Álam Kh√°n escaped to Peth√°pur in the Mahi K√°ntha. He then joined Darya Kh√°n, whom he called from the Dakhan, and obtained help in money from Im√°d-ul-Mulk of Surat and from Álp Kh√°n of Dholka. Im√°d-ul-Mulk wrote to the Sult√°n asking forgiveness for the rebels. Quarrels among the Nobles.But before the Sult√°n, who was mercifully disposed, could grant them pardon, Álam Kh√°n and Darya Kh√°n again committed themselves by acts of open revolt. The Sult√°n displeased with the part Im√°d-ul-Mulk had taken in the rising summoned him to Ch√°mp√°ner where, with the Sult√°n’s connivance, his camp was given over to pillage. The Sult√°n disclaimed all knowledge of this attack and at Im√°d-ul-Mulk’s request allowed him to go on pilgrimage to Makkah. In a.d. 1545 as he was preparing to start for Makkah Im√°d-ul-Mulk was killed. He was succeeded in Surat by Khud√°wand Kh√°n Rúmi, who had held Surat under him, and who, in spite of Portuguese opposition and intrigue, had five years before completed the building of Surat Castle.68 Meanwhile Álam Kh√°n and Darya Kh√°n were driven from Gujar√°t and forced to take shelter with the sovereign of Dehli. The king now appointed as his own minister Afzal Kh√°n, the minister of the late Bah√°dur Sh√°h, and though Afzal Kh√°n lived in retirement, his counsel was taken on measures of importance. Other great nobles were Sayad Mub√°rak, Fateh Kh√°n Baloch, and Abdul Karím Kh√°n, who received the title of Ítim√°d Kh√°n, and was so entirely in the Sult√°n’s confidence that he was admitted to the harem. Mahmúd now consulted Ásif Kh√°n as to the propriety of conquering M√°lwa. Disturbances, 1545.Ásif Kh√°n advised him rather to deprive the R√°jput chiefs and proprietors of their w√°ntas or hereditary lands. The attempt to follow this advice stirred to resistance the chief men of Ídar, Sirohi, Dúngarpur, B√°nsv√°ḍa, Lún√°v√°ḍa, R√°jpípla, Dohad, and the banks of the Mahi. The king strengthened his line of outposts, establishing one at Sirohi and another at Ídar, besides fresh posts in other places. At the same time he began to persecute the Hindus, allowing them to be killed on the slightest pretence, branding R√°jputs and Kolis, forcing them to wear a red rag on the right sleeve, forbidding them to ride in Áhmed√°b√°d, and punishing the celebration of Holi and Diw√°li.69 In a.d. 1554 Burh√°n, a servant of the king’s, conceived the idea of killing him and reigning in his stead. Death of Mahmúd, 1554.He accordingly gave his master an intoxicating drug, and when he was overcome with sleep stabbed him to the heart. Then summoning the principal nobles in the king’s name, he put to death Ásaf Kh√°n the prime minister and twelve others, and endeavoured to have himself accepted as Sult√°n. No one aided him; even his [259]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Mahmúd II. 1536–1554. accomplices deserted him. Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi,70 Ulugh Kh√°n, and others joined to oppose him, and when marching against them he was cut down by Shirw√°n Kh√°n. Mahmúd’s persecutions had raised such bitter hate among the Hindus, that they regarded Burh√°n as a saviour, and after Burh√°n’s death are said to have made a stone image of him and worshipped it.71 Mahmúd moved his capital from Áhmed√°b√°d to Mehmud√°b√°d, eighteen miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d where he built a palace and enclosed a deer park. At each corner of the park he raised a palace the stone walls and ceilings of which were ornamented with beautiful and precious gold traceries and arabesques.72 His strict regard for public morals led him to forbid Muhammadan women visiting saints’ tombs as the practice gave rise to irregularities. He died at the age of twenty-eight after a reign of eighteen years.

Ahmed II. 1554–1561.On the death of Burh√°n, the nobles elected as sovereign a descendant of the stock of Áhmed Sh√°h of the name of Áhmed Kh√°n, and proclaimed him king by the title of Áhmed Sh√°h II. At the same time they agreed that, as the king was young, Ítim√°d Kh√°n Regent.Ítim√°d Kh√°n should carry on the government and they further divided the country among themselves, each one undertaking to protect the frontiers and preserve the public peace. Mub√°rak Sh√°h of Kh√°ndesh, considering this a good opportunity, preferred a claim to the crown and marched to the frontier. An army led by the chief Gujar√°t nobles and accompanied by the young king met the invaders at the village of R√°npur Kotri√° in Broach, the Gujar√°t army encamping on the north bank and the Kh√°ndesh army on the south bank of the Narbada. N√°sir-ul-Mulk, one of the Gujar√°t nobles, taking certain of his friends into his confidence, determined to remain neutral till the battle was over and then to fall on the exhausted troops and possess himself of both kingdoms. Sayad Mub√°rak, a descendant of the saint Sh√°hi Álam, who led the van of the Gujar√°t army, becoming aware of N√°sir-ul-Mulk’s design opened communications with Mub√°rak Sh√°h of Kh√°ndesh and induced him to withdraw.73 N√°sir-ul-Mulk, who still aspired to supreme power, gaining several nobles to his side near Baroda, surprised and defeated the forces of Ítim√°d Kh√°n and Sayad Mub√°rak. The Sayad withdrew to his estate of Kapadvanj and he was joined by Ítim√°d Kh√°n, while N√°sir-ul-Mulk, taking Sult√°n Áhmed with him to Áhmed√°b√°d, assumed the entire government of the country. After a short time he assembled an army and marched against Sayad Mub√°rak and Ítim√°d Kh√°n encamping at Kamand, the village now called Od K√°mod, ten miles north-east of Áhmed√°b√°d at the head of 50,000 horse. Ítim√°d feared to attack so [260]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed II. 1554–1561. strong a force. But Sayad Mub√°rak, who knew of the defection of Ulugh Kh√°n and Im√°d-ul-Mulk, surprised N√°sir-ul-Mulk’s army at night. During the confusion Ulugh Kh√°n and Im√°d-ul-Mulk, disgusted with the assumption of N√°sir-ul-Mulk, deserted him and bringing the young Sult√°n with them joined Sayad Mub√°rak and Ítim√°d Kh√°n. N√°sir-ul-Mulk was forced to fly, and after a short time died in the mountains of P√°l.74 Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk, Fateh Kh√°n Balúch, and Hasan Kh√°n Dakhani now set up another king, a descendant of Áhmed, named Sh√°hu. A battle was fought near Mehmúd√°b√°d in which Sh√°hu and his supporters were defeated and Hasan Kh√°n Dakhani was slain. Before the battle Fateh Kh√°n Balúch had been induced to forsake Sh√°hu, and Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk, taking Sh√°hu with him, fled. The nobles now divided Gujar√°t into the following shares:

Partition of the Province.

Áhmed Sh√°h for Private Purse Áhmed√°b√°d and the Daskrohi sub-division.
Ítim√°d Kh√°n and Party K√°di, Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, Pitl√°d, Naḍi√°d, Bhil, R√°dhanpur, Sami, Múnjpur, Godhra, and Sorath.
Sayad Mub√°rak and Party P√°tan and Cambay, with its Chor√°si or 84 villages, Dholka, Gogha, and Dhandhúka. Ch√°mp√°ner, Sarn√°l, B√°l√°sinor, and Kapadvanj.
Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi and Party Broach, Baroda, and Surat as far as the Sult√°npur-Nandurb√°r frontier.
Nobles under Ítim√°d Kh√°n Mod√°sa and surrounding districts.

Of these shares Ítim√°d Kh√°n bestowed the country of Sorath on T√°t√°r Kh√°n Ghori; the districts of R√°dhanpur, Sami, and Múnjpur on Fateh Kh√°n Balúch; Naḍi√°d on Malik-ush-Shark, and some of the dependencies of Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa on Álaf Kh√°n Habshi. Sayad Mub√°rak conferred the territory of P√°tan on Músa Kh√°n and Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di, Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi bestowed the district of Baroda on Álaf Kh√°n Habshi and the port of Surat on his wife’s brother Khud√°wand Kh√°n Rúmi.

Dissensions.About this time (a.d. 1552) Álam Kh√°n returned, and, through the influence of Sayad Mub√°rak, was allowed to remain. The Sayad gave him and Ázam Hum√°yún Ch√°mp√°ner, and Ítim√°d Kh√°n gave Godhra to Álp Kh√°n Khatri, a follower of Álam Kh√°n. Álam Kh√°n and Ítim√°d Kh√°n shortly after expelled Álaf Kh√°n Habshi from Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, and he fled to Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi at Broach, and at his intercession Álaf Kh√°n received the Bhil district. Álam Kh√°n’s success tempted him to try and get rid of Ítim√°d Kh√°n and govern in his stead. Ítim√°d Kh√°n, discovering his intention, made him leave the city and live in his own house in the As√°wal suburb. Álam Kh√°n now made overtures to Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi and became very friendly with him. One day Álam Kh√°n proposed to get rid of Ítim√°d Kh√°n; [261]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed II. 1554–1561. but seeing that Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi did not take to his proposal, he next endeavoured to ruin Sayad Mub√°rak. But when the Gujar√°t army marched against him the Sayad made peace, and Álam Kh√°n’s intrigues being apparent, he was attacked and compelled to fly. He now went to Ber√°r and sought aid of Mub√°rak Sh√°h, who marched an army towards the Gujar√°t frontier. The Gujar√°t nobles, taking Áhmed Sh√°h with them, advanced to oppose him, and he retired. Álam Kh√°n now repaired to Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di at P√°tan, and they together seized Ítim√°d Kh√°n’s district of Kadi, but, through the exertions of Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk, Álam Kh√°n was slain and Sher Kh√°n forced to retire to P√°tan. Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi and Ítim√°d Kh√°n now carried on the government, but dissension springing up between them, Ítim√°d Kh√°n fled to Mub√°rak Sh√°h in Kh√°ndesh, and induced him to lead an army against Gujar√°t. The nobles, fearing this combination, made peaceful overtures and it was eventually settled that the lands of Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r handed to Kh√°ndesh, 1560.Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r should be given to Mub√°rak Sh√°h, and that Ítim√°d Kh√°n should be restored to his former position. Since this date the districts of Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r have been permanently severed from Gujar√°t and have formed a part of Kh√°ndesh, to which province they now belong. Áhmed Sh√°h, finding himself more strictly guarded than ever, contrived to flee to Sayad Mub√°rak at Sayadpur, who, though vexed at his coming, would not refuse him shelter. At this time H√°ji Kh√°n, a Dehli noble, on his way from Chitor to help Hum√°yún, passed through Gujar√°t with a well equipped force, and arrived at P√°tan. The Gujar√°t nobles, especially Ítim√°d Kh√°n and Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi, conceiving that he came at the Sayad’s invitation, and that the flight of the king was part of the Defeat and Death of Sayad Mub√°rak.plot, determined to crush the Sayad ere H√°ji Kh√°n could join him, and on their march to Sayadpur meeting Sayad Mub√°rak near Mehmúd√°b√°d defeated him. The Sayad fell and was buried on the field of battle. His estates were resumed, though eventually Dholka was restored to his son Sayad Mír√°n.

Death of Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi.The army and the two protectors returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. Dissensions again sprang up between them, and Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi summoned to his aid his son Changíz Kh√°n from Broach, while Ítim√°d Kh√°n sent for T√°t√°r Kh√°n Ghori from Sorath. T√°t√°r Kh√°n arrived first and Ítim√°d Kh√°n further strengthened by contingents from the Faul√°dis of P√°tan and Fateh Kh√°n Balúch from R√°dhanpur ordered Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi to return to his estate; and he, seeing it would be useless for him to contend against so overwhelming a force, retired to his possessions at Broach. Shortly after, having marched against Surat at the request of the inhabitants who were wearied of the tyranny of Khud√°wand Kh√°n, he was decoyed by that chief to an entertainment and was there assassinated. His son Changíz Kh√°n marched against Surat to take vengeance for his father’s death, and, finding the fortress too strong for him, summoned to his aid the Portuguese, to whom, as the price of their assistance, he Daman District ceded to the Portuguese, 1550.surrendered the districts of Daman and Sanj√°n.75 The Portuguese, bringing a strong [262]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Ahmed II. 1554–1561. fleet up the T√°pti, cut off the supplies, and Khud√°wand Kh√°n was forced to surrender, and was slain by Changíz Kh√°n in revenge for his father’s death. Shortly afterwards Changíz Kh√°n quarrelled with Jhujh√°r Kh√°n Habshi of Baroda because the Habshi had installed his nephew, son of Alif Kh√°n Habshi, without consulting Changíz. Jhujh√°r and his nephew being defeated fled to Ítim√°d Kh√°n, who allotted them a grant of land. At this time Fateh Kh√°n Balúch, the proprietor of R√°dhanpur and Sami, was Ítim√°d Kh√°n’s chief supporter, and with his assistance Ítim√°d Kh√°n marched to besiege Changíz Kh√°n in Broach. T√°t√°r Kh√°n Ghori and other nobles, fearing lest Ítim√°d Kh√°n should become too powerful, endeavoured to make peace. As their efforts failed, T√°t√°r Kh√°n wrote to the Faul√°dis to attack Fateh Kh√°n Balúch. They did so, and Fateh Kh√°n, after being defeated near R√°dhanpur, took refuge in the fort of Fatehkot or Dhúlkot, which is close to the town. Ítim√°d Kh√°n raised the siege of Broach and came to Áhmed√°b√°d, where he busied himself in checking the intrigues of king Áhmed, who was doing all in his power to become independent. Assassinated, 1560.Finally, in a.d. 1560–61, at the instigation of Wajíh-ul-Mulk and Razí-ul-Mulk Ítim√°d Kh√°n caused Áhmed II. to be assassinated. The murder took place in the house of Wajíh-ul-Mulk. The Sult√°n’s body was thrown on the sands of the S√°barmati and the story circulated that the Sult√°n had been killed by robbers. Áhmed’s nominal reign had lasted about eight years.

Muzaffar III. 1561–1572.Ítim√°d Kh√°n then raised to the throne a youth, whom he styled Muzaffar Sh√°h III., and who, he asserted, was a posthumous A Minor.son of Mahmúd Sh√°h,76 and then marched towards P√°tan to take his revenge on the Faul√°dis for their attack on Fateh Kh√°n Balúch. The nobles unwilling to crush the Faul√°dis, fearing lest their turn might come next, entered into secret correspondence with them, and withdrew when battle was joined. The nobles were now independent in their respective j√°girs, in which according to the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari they allowed no interference though still owning nominal allegiance to the throne.77 Ítim√°d Kh√°n, forced to return unsuccessful to Áhmed√°b√°d, with a view of again attacking the Faul√°dis, summoned T√°t√°r Kh√°n Ghori from Jun√°gaḍh. The nobles remained aloof, and even T√°t√°r [263]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Muzaffar III. 1561–1572. Kh√°n Ghori made excuses, which so exasperated Ítim√°d Kh√°n that he sought to slay him. T√°t√°r Kh√°n escaped to Sorath, and there openly sided with the Faul√°dis. Sayad Mír√°n also left Áhmed√°b√°d for his estate at Dholka, and joining T√°t√°r Kh√°n at R√°npur they both went over to the Faul√°dis at P√°tan. Ítim√°d Kh√°n and the Faul√°dis.Meanwhile Ítim√°d Kh√°n, again collecting an army, marched once more towards P√°tan. He was met by the Faul√°dis near the village of Jhot√°n√°, about thirty miles south of P√°tan, where he was defeated and compelled to return to Áhmed√°b√°d. Sayad Mír√°n now intervened and made peace. Ítim√°d Kh√°n still thirsting for revenge on the Faul√°dis, invited Changíz Kh√°n, son of Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi, to the capital, and by courteous treatment induced him to join in another expedition against the Faul√°dis. Like the other nobles Changíz Kh√°n was lukewarm; and as Músa Kh√°n Faul√°di died while Ítim√°d Kh√°n was marching on P√°tan, Changíz Kh√°n assigned this as a reason for not proceeding further, averring that it was not fit to war with people in misfortune. Ítim√°d Kh√°n perforce returned to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Though Ítim√°d Kh√°n had disgusted the nobles, both by causing the assassination of Áhmed Sh√°h and by his enmity with the Faul√°dis, as he had charge of Muzaffar Sh√°h and possession of the capital, the government of the country was in his hands. The Mírz√°s, 1571.At this time the Mírz√°s,78 who were the sons of Sult√°n Hussain of Khur√°s√°n, quarrelling with Jal√°l-ul-dín Muhammad Akbar, entered Gujar√°t, and joined Changíz Kh√°n. Changíz Kh√°n now proposed to Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di that they should expel Ítim√°d Kh√°n and divide Gujar√°t between them, the capital and the country south of the S√°barmati falling to the share of Changíz Kh√°n, and that to the north to Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di. Sher Kh√°n agreed, and Changíz Kh√°n joining him they marched on Áhmed√°b√°d. Sayad Mir√°n induced Sher Kh√°n to stay in Kadi. But Changíz Kh√°n refused to listen to him, and a They Defeat Ítim√°d Kh√°n.battle was fought between him, Ítim√°d Kh√°n, and the Sayad on the right bank of the Kh√°ri about eight miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d. Ítim√°d Kh√°n was defeated, and fled with the king to Mod√°sa, while Changíz Kh√°n took possession of the capital. Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di now advanced to the S√°barmati, and, after dividing the province as had been agreed, Sher Kh√°n retired to Kadi. Ítim√°d Kh√°n entreated Mír√°n Muhammad Sh√°h, king of Kh√°ndesh, to march to his aid, and Changíz Kh√°n invited Ítim√°d Kh√°n to return. He came to Mehmud√°b√°d, where hearing that Muhammad Sh√°h had sustained a defeat and retired to his own country, he took Muzaffar Sh√°h with him and returned through Mod√°sa to Dungarpur. Changíz Kh√°n remained in Áhmed√°b√°d, and Sher Kh√°n withdrew to Kadi. After this success all the chief nobles of Gujar√°t, including the Habshis, joined Changíz Kh√°n, who was now at the zenith of his power, and began to think of subduing Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di, [264]
Chapter II.
Áhmed√°b√°d Kings, a.d. 1403–1573.
Muzaffar III. 1561–1572. who on his part was anxious and fearful. At this time Bijli Kh√°n a Habshi eunuch who was offended with Changíz Kh√°n, because he had resumed the grant of Cambay, persuaded Álíf Kh√°n and Jhujh√°r Kh√°n Habshi that Changíz Kh√°n had determined to kill them. The Habshi Kh√°ns, resolving to be beforehand, invited Changíz Kh√°n, with whom they were intimate, to play a game of chaug√°n or polo.79 Changíz agreed and when near the Farhat-ul-Mulk mosque, between the Bhadar and the Three Gates, Álíf Kh√°n, after making Jhujh√°r Kh√°n a signal, attracted Changíz Kh√°n’s notice to the horse on which he was riding saying it was the best of the last batch imported from the Persian Gulf. Death of Changíz Kh√°n.As Changíz Kh√°n turned to look at the horse, Jhujh√°r Kh√°n cut him down. The Habshis now plundered Changíz Kh√°n’s house, while the Mírz√°s, mounting, went south and took possession of Broach, Baroda, and Ch√°mp√°ner. Sher Kh√°n advanced from Kadi, and ordered the Habshis to hand him over Áhmed√°b√°d. While treating with him the Habshis secretly summoned Ítim√°d Kh√°n, who, returning with Muzaffar Sh√°h, entered the city. It was arranged that Ítim√°d Kh√°n should take the place of Changíz Kh√°n, and that the division of Gujar√°t between Changíz Kh√°n and Sher Kh√°n should be maintained. Ítim√°d Kh√°n found the Habshis so domineering that he withdrew from public affairs. Afterwards Álaf Kh√°n and Jhujh√°r Kh√°n, quarrelling over the division of Changíz Kh√°n’s property, Álaf Kh√°n left Áhmed√°b√°d and joined Sher Kh√°n, who, advancing from Kadi, laid siege to Áhmed√°b√°d. Ítim√°d Kh√°n now sought aid from the Mírz√°s, and Mírza Ibr√°hím Husain marched from Broach and harassed Sher Kh√°n’s army with his Mughal archers.

Ítim√°d Kh√°n and the Emperor Akbar, 1572.At the same time Ítim√°d Kh√°n turned for help to the emperor Akbar, who, glad of any pretext for driving the Mírz√°s from their place of refuge in Gujar√°t, was not slow in availing himself of Ítim√°d Kh√°n’s proposal. Early in July 1572 he started for Áhmed√°b√°d, and with his arrival in the province, the history of Gujar√°t as a separate kingdom comes to an end. [265]

1 Compare Farishtah, II. 355–356. After his death Muhammad was known as Khud√°ig√°n-i-Shahíd, Our Lord the Martyr, according to the custom of the Sult√°ns of Dehli, all of whom had three names, their family name, their throne name, and their after-death name whose letters contain the date of the monarch’s decease. Thus the emperor Akbar’s after-death title is Ársh Áshi√°ni, The Holder of the Heavenly Throne; the emperor Jeh√°ngír’s is Jannat Mak√°ni, The Dweller in Heaven; the emperor Sh√°h Jeh√°n’s is Firdaus Mak√°ni, He Whose Home is Paradise; and the emperor Aurangzíb’s is Khuld Mak√°ni, The Occupier of the Eternal Residence. Similarly the after-death title of Muzaffar Sh√°h, T√°t√°r Kh√°n’s father, is Khûd√°ig√°n-i-Kabir, The Great Lord. ↑

2 Dh√°r (north latitude 22° 35′; east longitude 75° 20′), the capital of the state of Dh√°r thirty-three miles west of Mhow in Central India. ↑

3 The Tabak√°t-i-Akbari has Kanthkot a dependency of Kachh. This is probably correct. ↑

4 The date is doubtful: Farishtah (II. 630) gives a.d. 1412, the Áin-i-Akbari (Blochman’s Edition, I. 507) a.d. 1411. ↑

5 Four Áhmeds who had never missed the afternoon prayer helped to build Áhmed√°b√°d: Saint Sheikh Áhmed Khattu, Sult√°n Áhmed, Sheikh Áhmed, and Mulla Áhmed. Compare Bombay Gazetteer, IV. 249 note 5. ↑

6 Called in the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari the R√°ja of Mandal. ↑

7 Sidhpur (north latitude 23° 50′; east longitude 72° 20′), on the Sarasvatí, fifty-eight miles north of Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

8 Ch√°mp√°ner (north latitude 22° 30′; east longitude 73° 30′) in the British district of the Panch Mah√°ls, from a.d. 1483 to a.d. 1560 the chief city of Gujar√°t, now in ruins. ↑

9 Mod√°sa (north latitude 23° 27′; east longitude 73° 21′), fifty miles north-east of Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

10 Mirăt-i-Sikandari Persian Text, 34, 35; Farishtah, II. 363, 364. ↑

11 Sankheda is on the left bank of the Or river about twenty miles south-east of Baroda. ↑

12 M√°ngni M√°kani or M√°nki, famous for its witches, eight miles east of Sankheda. Mr. J. Pollen, I.C.S., LL.D. Compare Bom. Gov. Rec. N. S. XXIII. 98. ↑

13 Dohad (north latitude 22° 50′; east longitude 74° 15′), seventy-seven miles north-east of Baroda, now the chief town of the sub-division of the same name in the British district of the Panch M√°h√°ls. Mr. J. Pollen, I.C.S., LL.D. ↑

14 Jítpur about twelve miles north-east of B√°l√°sinor. ↑

15 Ujjain (north latitude 23° 10′; east longitude 75° 47′), at different times the capital of M√°lwa. ↑

16 S√°rangpur about fifty miles north-east of Ujjain. ↑

17 Ahmednagar (north latitude 23° 34′; east longitude 73° 1′) in the native state of Ídar. ↑

18 Mirăt-i-Sikandari Persian Text, 43. ↑

19 There are two M√°hims on the North Konkan coast, one about twenty-two miles north of Bassein (north latitude 19° 40′; east longitude 72° 47′), and the other in the northern extremity of the island of Bombay (north latitude 19° 2′; east longitude 72° 54′). The southern M√°him, to which Farishtah (II. 370–371) is careful to apply the term jazir√°h or island, is the town referred to in the text. The northern M√°him, now known as Kelva M√°him, was, as is noted in the text, the head-quarters of a Hindu chief. ↑

20 Th√°na (north latitude 19° 11′; east longitude 73° 6′), the head-quarters of the British district of that name, about twenty-four miles north-by-east of Bombay, was from the tenth to the sixteenth century a.d. the chief city in the Northern Konkan. ↑

21 B√°gl√°n, now called Sat√°na, is the northern sub-division of the British district of N√°sik. In a.d. 1590 the chief commanded 8000 cavalry and 5000 infantry. The country was famous for fruit. Áin-i-Akbari (Gladwin), II. 73. The chief, a R√°thoḍ, was converted to Isl√°m by Aurangzíb (a.d. 1656–1707). ↑

22 Dúngarpur (north latitude 23° 50′; east longitude 73° 50′) in R√°jput√°na, 150 miles north-west of Mhow. ↑

23 Mirăt-i-Sikandari Persian Text, 45, 46. ↑

24 Godhra (north latitude 22° 45′; east longitude 73° 36′), the chief town of the sub-division of that name in the British district of the Panch Mah√°ls. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 49) gives, probably rightly, Kothra a village of S√°unli or Savli about twenty miles north of Baroda. ↑

25 Sult√°npur (north latitude 21° 43′; east longitude 74° 40′), in the north of the Sh√°h√°da sub-division of the British district of Kh√°ndesh, till a.d. 1804 a place of consequence and the head-quarters of a large district. ↑

26 Kapadvanj (north latitude 23° 2′; east longitude 73° 9′), the chief town of the sub-division of that name in the British district of Kaira. ↑

27 Dholka (north latitude 22° 42′; east longitude 72° 25′), the chief town of the sub-division of that name in the British district of Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

28 S√°mbhar (north latitude 26° 53′; east longitude 75° 13′), a town in the province of Ajmír, about fifty-one miles north-north-east from the city of Ajmír. ↑

29 Chitor (north latitude 24° 52′; east longitude 74° 4′), for several centuries before a.d. 1567 the capital of the principality of Udepur. ↑

30 Sirohi (north latitude 24° 59′; east longitude 72° 56′), the capital of the principality of the same name in the province of Ajmír. ↑

31 Ábu (north latitude 24° 45′; east longitude 72° 49′) in the state of Sirohi. ↑

32 The R√°ja is called Kṛishṇa Kishan or K√°nh Devra. Ábu is still held by the Sirohi Devr√°s. ↑

33 Mandisor (north latitude 24° 4′; east longitude 75° 9′), the chief town of a district of the same name in the province of M√°lwa. ↑

34 Persian Text, Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 75–76. ↑

35 The Portuguese merchant and traveller Barbosa (a.d. 1511–1514) gives the following details of Mahmúd Begada’s cavalry: The Moors and Gentiles of this kingdom are bold riders, mounted on horses bred in the country, for it has a wonderful quantity. They ride on small saddles and use whips. Their arms are very thick round shields edged with silk; each man has two swords, a dagger, and a Turkish bow with very good arrows. Some of them carry maces, and many of them coats-of-mail, and others tunics quilted with cotton. The horses have housings and steel headpieces, and so they fight very well and are light in their movements. The Moorish horsemen are white and of many countries, Turks and Mamelukes, military slaves from Georgia Circassia and Mingrelia, Arabs Persians Khor√°s√°nis Turkomans, men from the great kingdom of Dehli, and others born in the country itself. Their pay is good, and they receive it regularly. They are well dressed with very rich stuffs of gold silk cotton and goat’s wool, and all wear caps on their heads, and their clothes long, such as morisco shirts and drawers, and leggings to the knee of good thick leather worked with gold knots and embroidery, and their swords richly ornamented with gold and silver are borne in their girdles or in the hands of their pages. Their women are very white and pretty: also very richly decked out. They live well and spend much money. Stanley’s Barbosa, 55–56. ↑

36 Mahmúd’s favourite trees were the mango √°mbo Mangifera indica, r√°en Mimusops hexandra, j√°mbu Eugenia jambolana, gúlar Ficus glomerata, tamarind √°mli Tamarindus indica, and the shrubby phyllanthus √°onla Emblica officinalis. ↑

37 Burh√°npur (north latitude 21° 18′; east longitude 76° 20′), under the Musalm√°ns the capital of Kh√°ndesh, now within the limits of the Ber√°rs. ↑

38 Gondw√°na, a large hilly tract lying between north latitude 19° 50′ and 24° 30′ and east longitude 77° 38′ and 87° 20′. ↑

39 The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, page 89) gives the hill fort of B√°rudar. The Persian r may be a miswritten g and the d a mistake for w that is Baguwar or Baguwarah. The seaport Dûn may be Dungri hill six miles from the coast. But Dûn for D√°h√°nu a well-known port in north Th√°na is perhaps more likely. Farishtah (Briggs, IV. 51) gives Bavur for Baru and Dura for Dûn. Compare Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Bayley’s Gujar√°t, page 178 note 2. ↑

40 Girn√°r the diadem of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. See above page 231 note 2. ↑

41 Mangifera indica, Mimusops hexandra, Eugenia jambolana, Ficus glomerata, Tamarindus indica, and Emblica officinalis. ↑

42 Kh√°nts are still found chiefly in Sor√°th. See Bombay Gazetteer, VIII. 142. ↑

43 The Tabak√°t-i-Akbari says they were J√°ts. Sir H. Elliot (History of India, I. 496) represents the Sumr√°s to be Agnikula R√°jputs of the Parm√°ra stock. The J√°dej√°s had been ruling in Kachh since a.d. 1350–1365. ↑

44 Dw√°rka (north latitude 22° 15′; east longitude 69°), on the north-western shore of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, famous for its temple of Kṛishṇa. ↑

45 The Tabak√°t-i-Akbari has ‘To-morrow the sword of adamant shall answer your message.’ ↑

46 Farishtah, II. 396–397. ↑

47 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 112–114. ↑

48 D√°bhol (north latitude 17° 34′; east longitude 73° 16′), on the north bank of the river V√°shishti (called Halewacko and Kalewacko by the early navigators. See Badger’s Varthema, page 114 note 1) in the British district of Ratn√°giri. About this time, according to Athanasius Nikitin (a.d. 1468–1474), D√°bhol was the great meeting place for all nations living along the coast of India and Ethiopia. In a.d. 1501 it was taken by the Portuguese. Between a.d. 1626 and 1630 an English factory was established here, but by the end of the century trade had left D√°bhol and has never returned. ↑

49 Cheul, now Revdanda (north latitude 18° 33′; east longitude 72° 59′), from about a.d. 1500 to 1650 a place of much trade. ↑

50 Mahmúd Begada greatly impressed travellers, whose strange tales of him made the king well-known in Europe. Varthema (1503–1508) thus describes his manner of living: ‘The king has constantly 20,000 horsemen.
