In the morning when he rises there come to his palace 50 elephants, on each of which a man sits astride, and the said elephants do reverence to the king, and, except this, they have nothing else to do. When the king eats, fifty or sixty kinds of instruments, drums trumpets flageolets and fifes play, and the elephants again do him reverence. As for the king himself, his mustachios under his nose are so long that he ties them over his head as a woman would tie her tresses, and he has a white beard that reaches to his girdle. As to his food, every day he eats poison (Hudibras’ Prince whose ‘daily food was asp and basilisk and toad’), not that he fills his stomach with it, but he eats a certain quantity, so that when he wishes to destroy any great person he makes him come before him stripped and naked, and then eats certain fruits which are called chofole (j√°iphal, nutmeg), like a muscatel nut. He also eats certain leaves called tamboli (p√°n or betel leaf; like the leaves of a sour orange, and with these he eats lime of oyster shells. When he has chewed this well he spurts it out on the person he wishes to kill, and so in the space of half an hour the victim falls to the ground dead. The Sult√°n has also three or four thousand women, and every night that he sleeps with one, she is found dead in the morning.’ Barbosa (a.d. 1511) goes further (Stanley’s Trans. 57), saying that so soaked was the king with poison that if a fly settled on his hand it swelled and immediately fell dead. This was the result of his early training. For, on Varthema’s companion asking how it was that the king could eat poison in this manner, certain merchants, who were older than the Sult√°n, answered that his father had fed him upon poison from his childhood. (Badger’s Varthema, 110.) Of the origin of Mahmúd’s surname Begada two explanations are given: (1) ‘From his mustachios being large and twisted like a bullock’s horn, such a bullock being called Begado; (2) that the word comes from the Gujar√°ti be, two, and gad, a fort, the people giving him this title in honour of his capture of Jun√°gaḍh (a.d. 1472) and Ch√°mp√°ner (a.d. 1484).’ (Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 202; Mirăt-i-Ahmedi Persian Text, 74.) Varthema’s account of the poison-eating is probably an exaggeration of the Sult√°n’s habit of opium-eating to which from his infancy he was addicted. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 751) speaks of the great physical power of Mahmúd and of his wonderful appetite. Mahmúd’s daily food weighed forty sers the ser being 15 bahlulis a little over half a pound. He used to eat about three pounds (5 sers) of parched gram to dessert. For breakfast, after his morning prayer, Mahmúd used to consume a cupfull of pure Makkah honey with a second cupfull of clarified butter and fifty small plantains called sohan kelas. At night they set by his bed two plates of sambús√°s or minced mutton sausages. In the morning Mahmúd seeing the empty plates used to give thanks: ‘Oh Allah,’ he said, ‘hadst thou not given this unworthy slave rule over Gujar√°t, who could have filled his stomach.’ His virile powers were as unusual as his appetite. The only woman who could bear his embraces unharmed was a powerful Abyssinian girl who was his great favourite. Of the wealth and weapons kept in store the Mirăt-i-Sikandari gives the following details regarding the great expedition against Jun√°gaḍh (Persian Text, 94): The Sult√°n ordered the treasurer to send with the army gold coins worth five krors, 1700 Egyptian Allemand Moorish and Khur√°s√°ni swords with gold handles weighing 2½ to 3 pounds (4–5 sers), 1700 daggers and poignards with gold handles weighing 1 to 1½ pounds (2–3 sers), and 2000 Arab and Turki horses with gold-embroidered housings. All this treasure of coin and weapons the Sult√°n spent in presents to his army (Ditto, 94–95). ↑

51 Ferishtah, II. 404. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 148, 149) calls the Persian ambassador Ibr√°hím Kh√°n. ↑

52 Farishtah, II. 408. ↑

53 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 166–167; Farishtah, II. 411. ↑

54 The verse supposed to possess the highest virtue against poison is the last verse of Chap. cvi. of the Kurâ√°n …. Serve the Lord of this House who supplieth them with food against hunger and maketh them free from fear. ↑

55 Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Pers. Manuscript), 174, 175, 194. ↑

56 Both the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (287) and Farishtah (II. 419) place Munga in Nandurb√°r-Sult√°npur. The further reference to R√°na Bhím of P√°l seems to apply to the same man as the R√°na Bhím of Munga. Munga may then be Mohangaḍ that is Chhota Udepur. ↑

57 Mirăt-i-Sikandari Persian Text, 225–226: Farishtah, II. 425–428. The Gujar√°t Musalm√°n historians give a somewhat vague application to the word P√°l which means a bank or step downwards to the plain. In the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (P√°hlanpur Edition, page 168) P√°lvar√°h, whose climate is proverbially bad, includes Godhra Ali Mohan and R√°jpípla that is the rough eastern fringe of the plain land of Gujar√°t from the Mahi to the Tapti. As the R√°ja of N√°ndod or R√°jpípla was the leading chief south of Ídar Colonel Watson took references to the R√°ja of P√°l to apply to the R√°ja of R√°jpípla. An examination of the passages in which the name P√°l occurs seems to show that the hill country to the east rather than to the south of P√°v√°gaḍ or Ch√°mp√°ner is meant. In a.d. 1527 Latíf Kh√°n the rival of Bah√°dur Sh√°h after joining the R√°ja Bhím in his kohistan or highlands of P√°l when wounded is taken into H√°lol. The same passage contains a reference to the R√°ja of N√°ndod as some one distinct from the R√°ja of P√°l. In a.d. 1531 R√°isingh of P√°l tried to rescue Mahmúd Khilji on his way from M√°ndu in M√°lwa to Ch√°mp√°ner. In a.d. 1551 N√°sir Kh√°n fled to Ch√°mp√°ner and died in the P√°l hills. These references seem to agree in allotting P√°l to the hills of B√°ria and of Mohan or Chhota Udepur. This identification is in accord with the local use of P√°l. Mr. Pollen, I.C.S., LL.D., Political Agent, Rewa K√°ntha, writes (8th Jan. 1895): Bhíls Kolis and traders all apply the word P√°l to the B√°ria P√°l which besides B√°ria takes in Sanjeli and the Nav√°nagar-Sali√°t uplands in Godhra. ↑

58 Purandhar about twenty miles south by east of Poona, one of the greatest of Dakhan hill forts. ↑

59 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 238, 239; Farishtah, II. 430. According to the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (239) the Sult√°n enquired on which side was the loftiest height. They told him that in the direction of Songad-Chitauri the hill was extremely high. These details show that the cliff scaled by Bah√°dur was in the extreme south-west of M√°ndu where a high nearly isolated point stretches out from the main plateau. For details see Appendix II. M√°ndu. ↑

60 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 241–242; Farishtah, II. 432. ↑

61 Halvad is a former capital of the chief of Dhr√°ngadhra in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. ↑

62 G√°graun in Central India about seventy miles north-east of Ujjain. ↑

63 Rantanbhúr about seventy-five miles south by east of Jaipur. ↑

64 Mirăt-i-Sikandari Persian Text, 266, 268; Farishtah, II. 439. ↑

65 A detailed account of the death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur is given in the Appendix. ↑

66 Mirăt-i-Sikandari Persian Text, 233. Compare Farishtah, II. 427. ↑

67 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Persian Text, 292. ↑

68 A poet of the time, Mulla Muhammad of Astar√°b√°d, enshrined the date H. 947 (a.d. 1540) in the words:

SADD BUWAD BAR SÍNAH-O-JÁNAI FIRANGÍ ÍN BINÁI.
May this fabric press like a pillar on the breast and the life of the Frank.

Farishtah, II. 447. The letter values that make 947 are: S = 60, d = 4, b = 2, w = 6, d = 4, b = 2, r = 200, s = 60, y = 10, n = 50, h = 5, w = 6, j = 3, a = 1, n = 50, f = 80, r = 200, n = 50, g = 20, y = 10, a = 1, y = 10, n = 50, b = 2, n = 50, a = 1, y = 10. Total 947. ↑

69 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Persian Text, 326–27. ↑

70 This Im√°d-ul-Mulk is different from the Im√°d-ul-Mulk mentioned above (page 258) as receiving a grant of Broach and Surat. The latter had before this retired to Surat, and was killed there in a.d. 1545. (Bird, 266.) Im√°d-ul-Mulk II. who attacked Burh√°n, was originally called Malik Arsl√°n (Bird, 272). He is also called the leader of the Turks and Rúmi. This Im√°d-ul-Mulk Rúmi, who was the father of Changíz Kh√°n, was ultimately killed in a.d. 1560 at Surat by his own son-in-law Khud√°wand or Ikhtiy√°r Kh√°n. ↑

71 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Persian Text, 326–27. ↑

72 This seems to be the palace referred to in the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari (Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, V. 369): After his second settlement of Gujar√°t (a.d. 1573, H. 981) Akbar left Áhmed√°b√°d for Mehmud√°b√°d and rested in the lofty and fine palace of Sult√°n Mahmúd of Gujar√°t. ↑

73 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Persian Text, 332. ↑

74 For P√°l compare note 2 page 253. ↑

75 The fort of Daman was taken by the Portuguese in a.d. 1530, and, according to Portuguese accounts (Faria y Souza in Kerr’s Voyages, VI. 413) the country round was annexed by them in 1558. According to a statement in Bird’s History, 128, the districts surrendered by Changíz Kh√°n contained 700 towns (villages) yielding a yearly revenue of £430,000 (Rs. 43,00,000). Sanj√°n, since known as St. John’s Head (north latitude 20° 13′; east longitude 72° 47′), between Daman and Bassein, seems to be one of the two Sind√°ns, the other being in Kachh, mentioned by the ninth to twelfth century Arab geographers. According to Idrísi (Jaubert’s Edition, 172) the mainland Sind√°n was a great town with a large import and export trade and well peopled with rich warlike and industrious inhabitants. Idrísi’s (Elliot, I. 85) notice of an island of the same name to the east is perhaps a confused reference to the Kachh Sind√°n which is generally supposed to be the Sind√°n of the Arab geographers. In a.d. 842, Sind√°n then a city of some size, is mentioned by Al-Bil√°duri (Reinaud’s Fragments, 216–217) as having been taken by a Musalm√°n slave Fazl son of M√°h√°n. This Fazl is related to have sent an elephant from Sind√°n to the Khalífah Al Maamún the Abb√°si (a.d. 813–833) and to have built an Assembly Mosque at Sind√°n. (Al-Bil√°duri in Elliot, I. 129.) ↑

76 According to Abul Fazl (Akbarn√°ma, III. 404; Elliot, V. 730) Muzaffar was a base-born boy of the name of Nathu. ↑

77 Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot’s India, V. 339 note 2. ↑

78 These Mírz√°s were the great grandsons of a Muhammad Sult√°n Mírza, the ruler of Khur√°s√°n, who, on being driven out of his dominions, sought refuge in India. This prince and his family on the ground of their common descent from Taimûr, were entertained first by B√°bar (a.d. 1526–1531), and afterwards by Hum√°yún (a.d. 1531–1556). Before this quarrel Akbar had treated the Mírz√°s with great honour. Elliot’s History, VI. 122. ↑

79 The modern game of polo. Lane in his translation of the Thousand and One Nights (I. 76, 1883 Edition) calls it the golf-stick, but the nature of the game described there does not in any way differ from polo. Chaug√°n is the Persian and As-súlj√°n-wal-kurah the Arabic name for the game. ↑

[Contents]

CHAPTER III.

MUGHAL VICEROYS.

a.d. 1573–1758.


Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605. Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.To the nobles thus fighting among themselves, news was brought that the emperor Akbar was at Dísa. Ibr√°hím Husain Mírza returned to Broach and the army of the Faul√°dis dispersed. From Dísa the imperial troops advanced to P√°tan and thence to Jhot√°na thirty miles south of P√°tan. Sult√°n Muzaffar, who had separated from the Faul√°dis, fell into the hands of the emperor, who granted him his life but placed him under charge of one of his nobles named Karam Áli.1 When the imperial army reached Kadi, Ítim√°d Kh√°n, Ikhtiy√°r Kh√°n, Álaf Kh√°n, and Jhujh√°r Kh√°n met Akbar and Sayad H√°mid also was honoured with an audience at H√°jipur.2 The emperor imprisoned Álaf Kh√°n and Jhujh√°r Kh√°n Habshi and encouraged the other Gujar√°t nobles. Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk now fled to Lun√°v√°ḍa, and the emperor, fearing that others of the Gujar√°t nobles might follow his example, sent Ítim√°d Kh√°n to Cambay and placed him under the charge of Shahb√°z Kh√°n Kambo.3 From Áhmed√°b√°d Akbar advanced to Cambay. At this time Ibr√°hím Mírza held Baroda, Muhammad Husain Mírza held Surat, and Sh√°h Mírza held Ch√°mp√°ner. On leaving Cambay to expel the Mírzas, Akbar appointed Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh his first viceroy of Gujar√°t. At Baroda Akbar heard that Ibr√°hím Mírza had treacherously killed Rustam Kh√°n Rúmi, who was Changíz Kh√°n’s governor of Broach. The emperor recalled the detachment he had sent against Surat, and overtaking the Mírza at Sarn√°l or Th√°sra on the right bank of the Mahi about twenty-three miles north-east of Naḍi√°d, after a bloody conflict routed him. The Mírza fled by Ahmednagar to Sirohi, and Akbar rejoined his camp at Baroda. The emperor now sent a force under Sh√°h Kuli Kh√°n to invest the fort of Surat, and following in person pitched his camp at Gopi T√°lao, a suburb of that city. After an obstinate defence of one month and seventeen days, the garrison under Hamzab√°n, a slave of Hum√°yún’s who had joined the Mírz√°s, surrendered. Hamzab√°n was in treaty with the Portuguese. Under his invitation a large party of Portuguese came to [266]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605. Surat during the siege, but seeing the strength of the imperial army, represented themselves as ambassadors and besought the honour of an interview.4 Akbar captures Broach and Surat, and advances to Áhmed√°b√°d, 1573.While at Surat the emperor received from Bih√°r or Vih√°rji the R√°ja of Bagl√°na, Sharfuddín Husain Mírza whom the R√°ja had captured.5 After the capture of Surat, the emperor ordered the great Sulaim√°ni cannon which had been brought by the Turks with the view of destroying the Portuguese forts and left by them in Surat, to be taken to Ágra. Surat was placed in the charge of Kalíj Kh√°n. The emperor now advanced to Áhmed√°b√°d, where the mother of Changíz Kh√°n came and demanded justice on Jhujh√°r Kh√°n for having wantonly slain her son. As her complaint was just, the emperor ordered Jhujh√°r Kh√°n to be thrown under the feet of an elephant. Muhammad Kh√°n, son of Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di, who had fled to the Ídar hills, now returned and took the city of P√°tan, besieging the imperial governor, Sayad Áhmed Kh√°n B√°rha, in the citadel. At this time Mírza Muhammad Husain was at R√°npur near Dhandhúka. When Sher Kh√°n Faul√°di, who had taken refuge in Sorath, heard of Muhammad Kh√°n’s return to P√°tan, he met Mírza Muhammad Husain, and uniting their forces they joined Muhammad Kh√°n at P√°tan. The viceroy Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh with other nobles marched against them, and after a hard-fought battle, in which several of the imperial nobles were slain, Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh was victorious. Sher Kh√°n again took refuge in Sorath, and his son fled for safety to the Ídar hills, while the Mírza withdrew to the Kh√°ndesh frontier. As the conquest of Gujar√°t was completed, Akbar returned to Agra.

From a.d. 1573, the date of its annexation as a province of the empire, to a.d. 1758, the year of the final capture of Áhmed√°b√°d by the Mar√°th√°s, Gujar√°t remained under the government of officers appointed by the court of Dehli. Like the rule of the Áhmed√°b√°d kings, this term of 184 years falls into two periods: the first of 134 years from a.d. 1573 to the death of Aurangzíb in a.d. 1707, a time on the whole of public order and strong government; the second from a.d. 1707 to a.d. 1758, fifty-one years of declining power and growing disorder.

[Contents]

SECTION I.—a.d. 1573–1707.

Mirza Âzíz First Viceroy, 1573–1575.Before leaving Gujar√°t Akbar placed the charge of the province in the hands of Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh.6 At the same time the emperor rewarded his supporters by grants of land, assigning Áhmed√°b√°d with Pitl√°d and several other districts to the viceroy Mírza Âzíz, P√°tan to the Kh√°n-i-Kal√°n Mír Muhammad Kh√°n, and Baroda to Naw√°b Aurang Kh√°n. Broach was given to Kutb-ud-dín Muhammad, and Dholka Kh√°npur and Sami were confirmed to Sayad H√°mid and Sayad Mahmúd Bukh√°ri. As soon as the emperor was gone Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk [267]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Mirza Âzíz First Viceroy, 1573–1575. and Muhammad Kh√°n, son of Sher Kh√°n, who had taken shelter in the Ídar hills, issued forth, and the viceroy marched to Ahmednagar to hold them in check. Mírza Muhammad Husain advancing rapidly from the Nandurb√°r frontier, took the fort of Broach, and went thence to Cambay which he found abandoned by its governor Husain Kh√°n Karkar√°h, while he himself marched to Ahmednagar and Ídar against Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk. The viceroy ordered Sayad H√°mid Bukh√°ri, Naw√°b Naurang Kh√°n, and others to join Kutb-ud-dín Muhammad Kh√°n. They went and laid siege to Cambay, but Mírza Muhammad managed to evacuate the town and join Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk and Muhammad Kh√°n. After several unsuccessful attempts to scatter the enemy the viceroy retired to Áhmed√°b√°d, and the rebels laid siege to the city. Kutb-ud-dín Kh√°n, Sayad Mír√°n, and others of the imperial party succeeded in entering the city and joining the garrison. Insurrection Quelled by Akbar, 1573.After the siege had lasted two months, Akbar, making his famous 600 mile (400 kos) march in nine days from Agra, arrived before Áhmed√°b√°d, and, at once engaging the enemy, totally defeated them with the loss of two of their leaders Mírza Muhammad Husain and Ikhtiy√°r-ul-Mulk.

On the day before the battle Akbar consulting a Haz√°ra Afgh√°n versed in drawing omens from sheeps’ shoulder-blades, was told that victory was certain, but that it would be won at the cost of the life of one of his nobles. Seif Kh√°n, brother of Zein Kh√°n Koka, coming in prayed that he should be chosen to receive the crown of martyrdom. At the end of the day the only leading noble that was killed was Seif Kh√°n.7

After only eleven days’ stay, Akbar again entrusting the government of Gujar√°t to Mírza Âzíz Koka, returned to Agra. Mírza Âzíz Koka did not long continue viceroy. In a.d. 1575, in consequence of some dispute with the emperor, he retired into private life. Mírza Kh√°n Second Viceroy, 1575–1577.On his resignation Akbar conferred the post of viceroy on Mírza Kh√°n, son of Behr√°m Kh√°n, who afterwards rose to the high rank of Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n or chief of the nobles. As this was Mírza Kh√°n’s first service, and as he was still a youth, he was ordered to follow the advice of the deputy viceroy, Wazír Kh√°n, in whose hands the administration of the province remained during the two following years. Survey by R√°ja Todar Mal.Soon after the insurrection of 1573 was suppressed the emperor sent R√°ja Todar Mal to make a survey settlement of the province. In a.d. 1575 after the survey was completed Wajíh-ul-Mulk Gujar√°ti was appointed díw√°n or minister. Some historians say that in a.d. 1576 Wazír Kh√°n relieved Mírza Âzíz Koka as viceroy, but according to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi [268]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Mírza Kh√°n Second Viceroy, 1575–1577. Mirza Kh√°n held office with Wazír Kh√°n as his deputy. One Pr√°gd√°s, a Hindu, succeeded Wajíh-ul-Mulk as díw√°n. Troops were sent to reduce the N√°ndod and Ídar districts, and the fort of Sirohi was captured by Tarsu Kh√°n, the military governor of P√°tan. Afterwards, through the intervention of Pah√°r Kh√°n J√°lori, the Sirohi R√°ja, at an interview with R√°ja Todar Mal, presented £6000 (Rs. 12,000) and other articles and was allowed to serve the provincial governor of Gujar√°t with 1500 horse.8

During Wazír Kh√°n’s administration Muzaffar Husain Mírza, son of Ibr√°hím Husain Mírza, raised an insurrection in Gujar√°t. This Mírza Muzaffar was as an infant carried to the Dakhan from Surat shortly before its investment by Akbar. He lived peacefully till under the influence of an ambitious retainer Mihr Ali by name, he gathered an army of adventurers and entered Nandurb√°r. Wazír Kh√°n distrusting his troops shut himself in a fortress, and wrote to R√°ja Todar Mal, who was in P√°tan settling revenue affairs. The Mírza defeated the imperial forces in Nandurb√°r and failing to get possession of Cambay marched straight to Áhmed√°b√°d. On the advance of R√°ja Todar Mal the Mírza fell back on Dholka. The R√°ja and the Kh√°n pursuing defeated him, and he retired to Jun√°gaḍh. The R√°ja then withdrew, but the Mírza again advanced and besieged him in Áhmed√°b√°d. In an attempt to escalade the city wall Mihr Ali was killed. Muzaffar Mírza withdrew to Kh√°ndesh and the insurrection came to an end.

Shah√°b-ud-dín Third Viceroy, 1577–1583.In the end of a.d. 1577, as Wazír Kh√°n’s management was not successful, the post of viceroy was conferred upon Shah√°b-ud-dín Áhmed Kh√°n, the governor of M√°lwa. Shah√°b-ud-dín’s first step was to create new military posts and strengthen the old ones. At this time Fateh Kh√°n Shirw√°ni, the commander of Amín Kh√°n Ghori’s army, quarrelled with his chief, and, coming to Shah√°b-ud-dín, offered to capture the fort of Jun√°gaḍh. Sends a Force against Jun√°gaḍh.Shah√°b-ud-dín entertained his proposal, and sent his nephew Mírza Kh√°n and 4000 horse with him. When the troops crossed the Sorath frontier, they were met by envoys from Amín Kh√°n, agreeing, in his name, to pay tribute and surrender the country, provided he were permitted to retain the fortress of Jun√°gaḍh and were allotted a sufficient grant of land. Mírza Kh√°n rejected these proposals and continued his march against Jun√°gaḍh. Amín Kh√°n made a vigorous resistance and applied for aid to the J√°m of Nav√°nagar. At this juncture Fateh Kh√°n died, and Mírza Kh√°n went and besieged M√°ngrúl. The J√°m’s minister Is√° now joined Amín Kh√°n with 4000 horse, and he, quitting Jun√°gaḍh, marched to M√°ngrúl.9 On their approach Mírza Kh√°n retired to the town of [269]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Shah√°b-ud-dín Third Viceroy, 1577–1583. Kodin√°r10 followed by Amín Kh√°n. Here a pitched battle was fought, and Mírza Kh√°n was defeated with the loss of his baggage. Many of his men were slain, and he himself, being wounded, escaped with difficulty to Áhmed√°b√°d. Shah√°b ud-dín, who had meanwhile been giving his attention to revenue matters, and to the more correct measurement of the lands of the province, was rudely recalled from these peaceful occupations by his nephew’s defeat. At the same time news was brought of the escape of the former king, Muzaffar Kh√°n, who, eluding the vigilance of the imperial servants, appeared in Gujar√°t in a.d. 1583. Muzaffar remained for some time in the R√°jpípla country, and thence came to one Lúna or Lúmbha K√°thi, at the village of Khíri in the district of Sardh√°r in Sorath.

Ítim√°d Kh√°n Gujar√°ti Fourth Viceroy, 1583–4.Before he could march against Muzaffar, Shah√°b-ud-dín was recalled, and in a.d. 1583 or 158411 Ítim√°d Kh√°n Gujar√°ti was appointed viceroy. At this time a party of 700 or 800 Mughals, called Wazír Kh√°nis, separating from Shah√°b-ud-dín, remained behind in hope of being entertained by the new viceroy. As Ítim√°d Kh√°n declared that he was unable to take them into his service, they went off in a body and joined Muzaffar at Khíri, and he with them and three or four thousand K√°thi horse marched at once on Áhmed√°b√°d. On hearing this Ítim√°d Kh√°n, leaving his son Sher Kh√°n in Áhmed√°b√°d, followed Shah√°b-ud-dín to Kadi, and entreated him to return. Shah√°b-ud-dín at first affected indifference telling Ítim√°d that as he had given over charge he had no more interest in the province. After two days he consented to return if Ítim√°d stated in writing that the country was on the verge of being lost and that Ítim√°d being unable to hold it was obliged to relinquish charge to Shah√°b-ud-dín. Ítim√°d Kh√°n made the required statement and Shah√°b-ud-dín returned with him.12 Muzaffar captures Áhmed√°b√°d, 1583.Meanwhile Muzaffar Sh√°h reached Áhmed√°b√°d, which was weakly defended, and in a.d. 1583, after a brief struggle, took possession of the city. While the siege of Áhmed√°b√°d was in progress Shah√°b-ud-dín and Ítim√°d Kh√°n were returning, and were within a few miles of the city, when news of its capture reached them. They continued their advance, but had barely arrived at Áhmed√°b√°d when Muzaffar Sh√°h totally defeated them taking all their baggage. Seeing the issue of the fight, most of their army went over to Muzaffar Sh√°h, and the viceroy and Shah√°b-ud-dín with a few men fled to P√°tan. Kutb-ud-dín Muhammad Kh√°n Atkah, one of the imperial commanders, who was on the Kh√°ndesh frontier, now advanced by forced marches to Baroda. Muzaffar marched against him with a large army, recently strengthened by the union of the army of Sayad Daul√°t ruler of Cambay. Kutb-ud-dín threw himself into Baroda, and, in spite of the treachery of his troops, defended the city for some time. At last, on Muzaffar’s assurance that his life should be spared Kutb-ud-dín repaired to the enemies’ camp to treat for peace. On his arrival he was treated with respect, but next day was treacherously put to death. The fort of Broach was also at this [270]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n (Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n) Fifth Viceroy, 1583–1587. time traitorously surrendered to Muzaffar by the slaves of the mother of Naurang Kh√°n, fief-holder of the district.

Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n (Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n) Fifth Viceroy 1583–1587.On learning of the Gujar√°t insurrection the emperor, at the close of a.d. 1583, conferred the government of the province on Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n, son of Behr√°m Kh√°n, who had formerly (a.d. 1575) acted as viceroy. Muzaffar, who was still at Broach, hearing of the advance of the new viceroy with a large army, returned rapidly to Áhmed√°b√°d, and in a.d. 1584 fought a pitched battle with Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n between Sirkhej and Sh√°h Bhíkan’s tomb.13 In this engagement Defeat of Muzaffar, 1584.Muzaffar was entirely defeated, and fled to Cambay pursued by Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n. Muzaffar now hearing that Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n had been joined by Naurang Kh√°n and other nobles with the imperial army from M√°lwa, quitted Cambay, and made for his old place of shelter in R√°jpípla. Finding no rest in R√°jpípla, after fighting and losing another battle in the R√°jpípla hills, he fled first to P√°tan and then to Ídar, and afterwards again repaired to Lúmbha K√°thi in Khiri. In reward for these two victories, the emperor bestowed on Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n the title of Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n. Broach now submitted, and Muzaffar sought shelter with Amín Kh√°n Ghori at Jun√°gaḍh, by whom he was allotted the waste town of Gondal as a residence. Muzaffar made one more attempt to establish his power. He advanced to Morvi, and thence made a raid on R√°dhanpur and plundered that town, but was soon compelled to return to K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and seek safety in flight. Amín Kh√°n, seeing that his cause was hopeless, on pretence of aiding him, induced Muzaffar [271]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Mírza Abdúr-Rahím Kh√°n (Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n) Fifth Viceroy, 1583–1587. to give him about £10,000.14 When he had obtained the money, on one pretext or another, Amín Kh√°n withheld the promised aid. The Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n now marched an army into Sorath against Muzaffar. The J√°m of Nav√°nagar and Amín Kh√°n sent their envoys to meet the viceroy, declaring that they had not sheltered Muzaffar, and that he was leading an outlaw’s life, entirely unaided by them. The viceroy agreed not to molest them, on condition that they withheld aid and shelter from Muzaffar, and himself marched against him. When he reached Upleta, about fifteen miles north-west of the fortress of Jun√°gaḍh, the viceroy heard that Muzaffar had sought shelter in the Barda hills in the south-west corner of the peninsula. Advancing to the hills, he halted his main force outside of the rough country and sent skirmishing parties to examine the hills. Muzaffar had already passed through Nav√°nagar and across Gujar√°t to D√°nta in the Mahi K√°ntha. Here he was once more defeated by the Par√°ntij garrison, and a third time took refuge in R√°jpípla. The viceroy now marched on Nav√°nagar to punish the J√°m. The J√°m sent in his submission, and the viceroy taking from him, by way of fine, an elephant and some valuable horses, returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. He next sent a detachment against Ghazni Kh√°n of Jh√°lor who had favoured Muzaffar. Ghazni Kh√°n submitted, and no further steps were taken against him.

Ism√°íl Kuli Kh√°n Sixth Viceroy, 1587.In a.d. 1587 the Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n was recalled and his place supplied by Ism√°íl Kuli Kh√°n. Ism√°íl’s government lasted only for a few months, when he was superseded by Mírza Âziz Kokalt√°sh Seventh Viceroy, 1588–1592.Mírza Ázíz Kokalt√°sh, who was a second time appointed viceroy. In a.d. 1591, Muzaffar again returned to Sorath. Muzaffar seeks Refuge in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa.The viceroy, hearing that he had been joined by the J√°m, the Kachh chief, and Daulat Kh√°n Ghori the son of Amín Kh√°n, marched with a large army towards Sorath, and, halting at Víramg√°m, sent forward a detachment under Naurang Kh√°n, Sayad K√°sim, and other officers. Advancing as far as Morvi,15 Naurang Kh√°n entered into negotiations with the J√°m, who, however, refused to accede to the demands of the imperial commander. Is attacked by the Imperial Army.On this the viceroy joined Naurang Kh√°n with the bulk of his army, and after a short delay marched on Nav√°nagar. On his way, at the village of Dhokar near Nav√°nagar, Muzaffar and the J√°m opposed him, and an obstinate battle in which the imperialists were nearly worsted, ended in Muzaffar’s defeat. The son and minister of the J√°m were slain, and Muzaffar, the J√°m, and Daulat Kh√°n who was wounded, fled to the fortress of Jun√°gaḍh. The viceroy now advanced and plundered Nav√°nagar, and remaining there sent Naurang Kh√°n, Sayad K√°sím, and Gújar Kh√°n against Jun√°gaḍh. The day the army arrived before the fortress Daulat Kh√°n died of his wounds. Still the fortress held out, and though the viceroy joined them the siege made little progress as the imperial troops were in great straits for grain. The viceroy returned to Áhmed√°b√°d, and after seven or eight months again marched against Jun√°gaḍh. The J√°m, who was still a fugitive, sent envoys [272]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Mírza Âziz Kokalt√°sh Seventh Viceroy, 1588–1592. and promised to aid the viceroy if his country were restored to him. The viceroy assented on condition that, during the operations against Jun√°gaḍh, the J√°m should furnish his army with grain. The J√°m agreed to provide grain, and after a siege of three months the garrison surrendered.

News was next received that Muzaffar had taken refuge at Jagat.16 The viceroy at once sent Naurang Kh√°n and others with an army in pursuit. On reaching Jagat it was found that Muzaffar had already left for a village owned by a R√°jput named Sewa W√°dhel. Without halting Naurang Kh√°n started in pursuit, nearly surprising Muzaffar, Muzaffar Flies to Kachh.who escaping on horseback with a few followers, crossed to Kachh. Sewa W√°dhel covering Muzaffar’s retreat was surprised before he could put to sea and fought gallantly with the imperial forces till he was slain. Naurang Kh√°n then came to Ar√°mra, a village belonging to Singr√°m W√°dhel, R√°ja of Jagat, and after frustrating a scheme devised by that chief to entrap a body of the troops on board ship under pretence of pursuing Muzaffar’s family, led his men back to Jun√°gaḍh. The viceroy, hearing in what direction Muzaffar had fled, marched to Morvi, where the J√°m of Nav√°nagar came and paid his respects. At the same time the Kachh chief, who is called Kheng√°r by Farishtah and in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi and Bh√°ra in the Mirăt-i-Sikandri, sent a message that if the viceroy would refrain from invading his country and would give him his ancestral district of Morvi and supply him with a detachment of troops, he would point out where Muzaffar was concealed. The Kh√°n-i-Ázam agreed to these terms and the chief captured Muzaffar and handed him to the force sent to secure him. The detachment, strictly guarding the prisoner, were marching rapidly towards Morvi, when, on reaching Dhrol, about thirty miles east of J√°mnagar, under pretence of obeying a call of nature, Muzaffar withdrew and cut his throat with a razor, so that he died. Commits Suicide, 1591–92.This happened in a.d. 1591–92. The viceroy sent Muzaffar’s head to court, and though he was now recalled by the emperor, he delayed on pretence of wishing to humble the Portuguese. His real object was to make a pilgrimage to Makkah, and in a.d. 1592, after obtaining the necessary permission from the Portuguese, he started from Ver√°val.17 During this viceroyalty an imperial farm√°n ordered that the state share of the produce should be one-half and the other half should be left to the cultivator and further that from each half five per cent should be deducted for the village headmen. All other taxes were declared illegal, and it was provided that when lands or houses were sold, half the government demand should be realized from the seller and half from the buyer.

Sult√°n Mur√°d Baksh Eighth Viceroy, 1592–1600.The emperor, who was much vexed to hear of the departure of the viceroy, appointed prince Sult√°n Mur√°d Bakhsh in his stead with as his minister Muhammad S√°dikkh√°n one of the great nobles. In a.d. 1593–94 Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh returned from his pilgrimage and [273]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Akbar Emperor, 1573–1605.
Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh Ninth Viceroy, 1600–1606. repaired to court, and next year on prince Mur√°d Bakhsh going to the Dakhan, Súrajsingh was appointed his deputy. In a.d. 1594–95 Bah√°dur, son of the late Muzaffar Sh√°h, excited a rebellion, but was defeated by Súrajsingh. In a.d. 1600, owing to the death of Sult√°n Mur√°d, Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh Ninth Viceroy, 1600–1606.Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh was a third time appointed viceroy of Gujar√°t, and he sent Shams-ud-dín Husain as his deputy to Áhmed√°b√°d. Further changes were made in a.d. 1602 when Mírza Âzíz sent his eldest son Sh√°dm√°n as deputy; his second son Khurram as governor of Jun√°gaḍh; and Sayad B√°yazíd as minister. Khurram was afterwards relieved of the charge of Sorath and Jun√°gaḍh by his brother Abdull√°h.

Jeh√°ngír Emperor, 1605–1627.In a.d. 1605 Núr-ud-dín Muhammad Jeh√°ngír ascended the imperial throne. Shortly after his accession the emperor published a decree remitting certain taxes, and also in cases of robbery fixing the responsibility on the landowners of the place where the robbery was committed. The decree also renewed Akbar’s decree forbidding soldiers billetting themselves forcibly in cultivators’ houses. Finally it directed that dispensaries and hospital wards should be opened in all large towns. In the early days of Jeh√°ngír’s reign disturbance was caused in the neighbourhood of Áhmed√°b√°d by Bah√°dur a son of Muzaffar Sh√°h. Jeh√°ngír despatched Patrd√°s R√°ja Vikram√°jit as viceroy of Gujar√°t to put down the rising. The R√°ja’s arrival at Áhmed√°b√°d restored order. Some of the rebel officers submitting were reinstated in their commands: the rest fled to the hills.18 Kalíj Kh√°n Tenth Viceroy, 1606.On the R√°ja’s return Jeh√°ngír appointed Kalíj Kh√°n to be viceroy of Gujar√°t; but Kalíj Kh√°n never joined his charge, allowing Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh to act in his place. In a.d. 1606, on the transfer of Mírza Âzíz to the L√°hor viceroyalty, Sayad Murtaza Eleventh Viceroy, 1606–1609.Sayad Murtaza Kh√°n Bukh√°ri, who had recently been ennobled in consequence of crushing the rebellion under Jeh√°ngír’s son Khusrao, was entrusted with the charge of Gujar√°t, Sayad B√°yazíd being continued as minister. Sayad Murtaza, who is said to have further ingratiated himself with the emperor by the present of a magnificent ruby, appears to have been more of a scholar than a governor. His only notable acts were the repair of the fort of Kadi19 and the populating of the Bukh√°ra quarter of Áhmed√°b√°d. During his tenure of power disturbances broke out, and R√°i Gopin√°th, son of R√°ja Todar Mal, with R√°ja Sursingh of Jodhpur, were sent to Gujar√°t by way of M√°lwa Surat and Baroda. They overcame and imprisoned Kali√°n, chief of Belp√°r,20 but were defeated by the M√°ndwa21 chieftain, and withdrew to Áhmed√°b√°d. R√°i Gopin√°th, obtaining reinforcements, returned to M√°ndwa and succeeded in capturing the chief. He then marched against the rebellious Kolis of the K√°nkrej, and took prisoner their [274]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Jeh√°ngir Emperor, 1605–1627.
Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh Twelfth Viceroy, 1609–1611. leader, whom, on promising not to stir up future rebellions, he afterwards restored to liberty.

The first connection of the English with Gujar√°t dates from Sayad Murtaza’s viceroyalty. In a.d. 1608 he allowed Captain Hawkins to sell goods in Surat.

Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh Twelfth Viceroy, 1609–1611.In a.d. 1609 the Kh√°n-i-Ázam Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh was for the fourth time appointed viceroy of Gujar√°t. He was allowed to remain at court and send his son Jeh√°ngír Kúli Kh√°n as his deputy with Mohand√°s Div√°n and Masûd Beg Hamad√°ni.22 This was the beginning of government by deputy, a custom which in later times was so injurious to imperial interests.

Sack of Surat by Malik Âmbar, 1609.In 1609 Malik Âmbar, chief minister of Niz√°m Sh√°h’s court and governor of Daulat√°b√°d, invaded Gujar√°t at the head of 50,000 horse, and after plundering both the Surat and Baroda districts retired as quickly as he came. To prevent such raids a body of 25,000 men was posted at R√°mnagar23 on the Dakhan frontier, and remained there for four years. The details of the contingents of this force are:

The Viceroy of Áhmed√°b√°d 4000 Men.
The Nobles of his Court 5000 Men.,,
The Chiefs of S√°ler and Mulher (B√°gl√°n) 3000 Men.,,
The Son of the Kachh Chief 2500 Men.,,
The Chief of Nav√°nagar 2500 Men.,,
The Chief of Ídar 2000 Men.,,
The Chief of Dúngarpúr Now under the Hilly Tracts Agency, R√°jput√°na. 2000 Men.,,
The Chief of B√°nsv√°da 2000 Men.,,
The Chief of R√°mnagar (Dharampur) 1000 Men.,,
The Chief of R√°jipípla 1000 Men.,,
The Chief of Áli (Álir√°jpur under the Bhop√°war Agency) 300 Men.,,
The Chief of Mohan (a former capital of the state of Chhota Udepur in the Rewa K√°ntha) 350 Men.,,
Total 25,650 Men.

Abdull√°h Kh√°n Fírúz Jang Thirteenth Viceroy, 1611–1616.In a.d. 1611 Abdull√°h Kh√°n Bah√°dur Fírúz Jang was appointed thirteenth viceroy of Gujar√°t, with Ghi√°s-ud-dín as his minister, under orders to proceed to the Dakhan to avenge the recent inroad.24 The viceroy marched to the Dakhan but returned without effecting anything. In a.d. 1616, he was again, in company with prince Sh√°h [275]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Jeh√°ngir Emperor, 1605–1627.
Abdull√°h Kh√°n Fírúz Jang Thirteenth Viceroy, 1611–1616. Jeh√°n, directed to move against Ahmednagar. This second expedition was successful. The country was humbled, and, except Malik Ambar, most of the nobles submitted to the emperor. During this viceroy’s term of office an imperial decree was issued forbidding nobles on the frontiers and in distant provinces to affix their seals to any communications addressed to imperial servants.

Mukarrab Kh√°n Fourteenth Viceroy, 1616.In a.d. 1616 on their return to Dehli, Mukarrab Kh√°n, a surgeon who had risen to notice by curing the emperor Akbar and was ennobled by Jeh√°ngír, and who, since a.d. 1608, had been in charge of Surat or of Cambay, was appointed fourteenth viceroy of Gujar√°t, with Muhammad Safi as his minister. Elephant-hunting in the Panch Mah√°ls, 1616.In the following year (a.d. 1617) the emperor Jeh√°ngír came to Gujar√°t to hunt wild elephants in the Dohad forests. But owing to the density of the forest only twelve were captured. Early in a.d. 1618 he visited Cambay which he notes only vessels of small draught could reach and where he ordered a gold and silver tanka twenty times heavier than the gold mohar to be minted. From Cambay after a stay of ten days he went to Áhmed√°b√°d and received the R√°ja of Ídar. As the climate of Áhmed√°b√°d disagreed with him, Jeh√°ngír retired to the banks of the Mahi.25 Here the J√°m of Nav√°nagar came to pay homage, and presented fifty Kachh horses, a hundred gold mohars, and a hundred rupees, and received a dress of honour. The emperor now returned to Áhmed√°b√°d, where he was visited by R√°i Bh√°ra of Kachh, who presented 100 Kachh horses, 100 ashrafis26 and 2000 rupees. The R√°i, who was ninety years of age, [276]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Jeh√°ngir Emperor, 1605–1627.
Mukarrab Kh√°n Fourteenth Viceroy, 1616. had never paid his respects to any emperor. Jeh√°ngír, much pleased with the greatest of Gujar√°t Zamínd√°rs, who, in spite of his ninety years was hale and in full possession of all his senses, gave him his own horse, a male and female elephant, a dagger, a sword with diamond-mounted hilt, and four rings of different coloured precious stones. As he still suffered from the climate, the emperor set out to return to Ágra, and just at that time (a.d. 1618–19) he heard of the birth of a grandson, afterwards the famous Abúl Muzaffar Muhiyy-ud-dín Muhammad Aurangzíb who was born at Dohad in Gujar√°t.27 In honour of this event Sh√°h Jeh√°n held a great festival at Ujjain.

Prince Sh√°h Jeh√°n Fifteenth Viceroy, 1618–1622.Before the emperor started for Ágra, he appointed prince Sh√°h Jeh√°n fifteenth viceroy of Gujar√°t in the place of Mukarrab Kh√°n whose general inefficiency and churlish treatment of the European traders he did not approve. Muhammad Safi was continued as minister. As Sh√°h Jeh√°n preferred remaining at Ujjain he chose Rustam Kh√°n as his deputy; but the emperor, disapproving of this choice, selected R√°ja Vikram√°jit in Rustam Kh√°n’s stead. Shortly after, Sh√°h Jeh√°n Rebels, 1622–1623.in a.d. 1622–23, Sh√°h Jeh√°n rebelled, and in one of the battles which took place R√°ja Vikram√°jit was killed. Sh√°h Jeh√°n, during his viceroyalty, Builds the Sh√°hi B√°gh at Áhmed√°b√°d.built the Sh√°hi B√°gh and the royal baths in the Bhadar at Áhmed√°b√°d. After the death of Vikram√°jit, his brother succeeded as deputy viceroy. While Sh√°h Jeh√°n was still in rebellion, the emperor Sult√°n D√°war Baksh Sixteenth Viceroy, 1622–1624.appointed Sult√°n D√°war Baksh the son of prince Khusrao, sixteenth viceroy of Gujar√°t, Muhammad Safi being retained in his post of minister. Sh√°h Jeh√°n, who was then at M√°ndu in M√°lwa, appointed on his part Abdull√°h Kh√°n Bah√°dur Fírúz Jang viceroy and a kh√°jahsara or eunuch of Abdull√°h Kh√°n his minister. Sult√°n D√°war Baksh, the emperor’s nominee, was accompanied by Kh√°n-i-Ázam Mírza Âzíz Kokalt√°sh to instruct him in the management of affairs. Prince Sh√°h Jeh√°n had directed his minister to carry away all the treasure; but Muhammad Safi, who appears to have been a man of great ability, at once imprisoned the prince’s partisans in Áhmed√°b√°d, and, among others, captured the eunuch of Abdull√°h Kh√°n. When this news reached the prince at M√°ndu, he sent Abdull√°h Kh√°n Bah√°dur with an army to Gujar√°t by way of Baroda. Muhammad Safi Kh√°n met and defeated him, and forced him to fly and rejoin the prince at M√°ndu. For his gallant conduct Muhammad Safi received the title of Saif Kh√°n, with an increase in his monthly pay from £70 to £300 (Rs. 700–3000) and the command of 3000 horse. Meanwhile Sult√°n D√°war Baksh, with the Kh√°n-i-Ázam, arrived and assumed the charge of the government, but the Kh√°n-i-Ázam died soon after in a.d. 1624, and was buried at Sarkhej. Sult√°n D√°war Baksh was [277]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Jeh√°ngir Emperor, 1605–1627.
Saif Kh√°n Seventeenth Viceroy, 1624–1627. re-called, and Kh√°n Jeh√°n was appointed deputy viceroy with Yúsuf Kh√°n as his minister. On his arrival at Áhmed√°b√°d, prince Sh√°h Jeh√°n employed Kh√°n Jeh√°n in his own service, and sent him as his ambassador to the emperor. Saif Kh√°n, who acted for him, may be called the seventeenth viceroy, as indeed he had been the governing spirit for the last eight or ten years. He held the post of viceroy of Gujar√°t until the death of the emperor in a.d. 1627.

Sh√°h Jeh√°n Emperor, 1627–1658.On the death of the emperor Jeh√°ngir, his son Abul Muzaffar Shah√°b-ud-dín Sh√°h Jeh√°n ascended the throne. Remembering Saif Kh√°n’s hostility he at once caused him to be imprisoned, and Sher Kh√°n Túar Eighteenth Viceroy, 1627–1632.appointed Sher Kh√°n Túar eighteenth viceroy with Khw√°jah Hay√°t as his minister. When the emperor was near Surat, he appointed Mír Shams-ud-dín to be governor of Surat castle. In a.d. 1627, Sh√°h Jeh√°n on his way to Dehli visited Áhmed√°b√°d and encamped outside of the city near the K√°nkariya lake. Sher Kh√°n was advanced to the command of 5000 men, and received an increase of salary and other gifts. At the same time Kh√°n Jeh√°n was appointed his minister, and Mîrza Ísa Tarkh√°n was made viceroy of Thatta in Sindh. In a.d. 1628 Khw√°jah Abúl Hasan was sent to conquer the country of N√°sik and Sangamner which he ravaged, and returned after taking the fort of Ch√°ndoḍ and levying tribute from the chief of B√°gl√°n. In a.d. 1630, Jam√°l Kh√°n Kar√°wal came to the Gujar√°t-Kh√°ndesh frontier and captured 130 elephants in the Sult√°npur forests, seventy of which valued at a l√°kh of rupees were sent to Dehli. Famine, 1631–32.In a.d. 1631–32 Gujar√°t was wasted by the famine known as the Sati√°sio K√°l or ’87 famine. So severe was the scarcity that according to the B√°dsh√°h N√°ma, rank sold for a cake, life was offered for a loaf, the flesh of a son was preferred to his love. The emperor opened soup kitchens and alms-houses at Surat and Áhmed√°b√°d and ordered Rs. 5000 to be distributed.28

Isl√°m Kh√°n Nineteenth Viceroy, 1632.Sher Kh√°n was re-called in a.d. 1632, but died ere he could be relieved by Isl√°m Kh√°n, the nineteenth viceroy of Gujar√°t, along with whom Khw√°jah Jeh√°n was chosen minister. Isl√°m Kh√°n’s monthly salary was £400 (Rs. 4000), and his command was raised from 5000 to 6000. In a.d. 1632, Khw√°jah Jeh√°n went on pilgrimage to Makkah, and was succeeded as minister by Ágha Afzal with the title of Afzal Kh√°n. Afzal Kh√°n was soon appointed commander of Baroda, and Ri√°yat Kh√°n succeeded him as minister. The post of viceroy of Gujar√°t appears to have been granted to whichever of the nobles of the court was in a position to make the most valuable presents to the emperor. Disorder, 1632.Government became lax, the Kolis of the K√°nkrej committed excesses, and the J√°m of Nav√°nagar withheld his tribute. B√°kar Kh√°n Twentieth Viceroy, 1632.At this time B√°kar Kh√°n presented the emperor with golden and jewelled ornaments to the value of Rs. 2,00,000 and was appointed viceroy, Ri√°yat Kh√°n being continued as minister. In a.d. 1633 Sip√°hd√°r Kh√°n Twenty-first Viceroy, 1633.Sip√°hd√°r Kh√°n was appointed viceroy, and presented the emperor with costly embroidered velvet tents with golden posts worthy to hold the famous Takhti-T√°ús or Peacock Throne which was just completed at a cost of one kror of rupees. Ri√°yat Kh√°n was continued as minister. [278]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Sh√°h Jeh√°n Emperor, 1627–1658.
Saif Kh√°n Twenty-second Viceroy, 1633–1635. Saif Kh√°n Twenty-second Viceroy, 1633–1635.In a.d. 1635 Saif Kh√°n was appointed twenty-second viceroy, with Ri√°yat Kh√°n as minister. During Saif Kh√°n’s tenure of power Mírza Ísa Tarkh√°n received a grant29 of the province of Sorath, which had fallen waste through the laxity of its governors. Before he had been in power for more than a year Saif Kh√°n was recalled. As he was preparing to start, he died at Áhmed√°b√°d and was buried in Sh√°hi Álam’s shrine to which he had added the dome over the tomb and the mosque to the north of the enclosure.

Ázam Kh√°n Twenty-third Viceroy, 1635–1642.At the end of a.d. 1635 Ázam Kh√°n was appointed twenty-third viceroy, with Ri√°yat Kh√°n in the first instance, and afterwards with Mír Muhammad S√°bir, as minister. The men who had recently been allowed to act as viceroys had shown themselves unfit to keep in order the rebellious chiefs and predatory tribes of Gujar√°t. For this reason the emperor’s choice fell upon Ázam Kh√°n, a man of ability, who perceived the danger of the existing state of affairs, and saw that to restore the province to order, firm, even severe, measures were required. When Ázam Kh√°n reached Sidhpur, the merchants complained bitterly of the outrages of one K√°nji, a Chúnv√°lia Koli, who had been especially daring in plundering merchandise and committing highway robberies. Punishes the Kolis,Ázam Kh√°n, anxious to start with a show of vigour, before proceeding to Áhmed√°b√°d, marched against K√°nji, who fled to the village of Bh√°dar in the Kher√°lu district of Kadi, sixty miles north-east of Áhmed√°b√°d. Ázam Kh√°n pursued him so hotly that K√°nji surrendered, handed over his plunder, and gave security not only that he would not again commit robberies, but that he would pay an annual tribute of £1000 (Rs. 10,000). Ázam Kh√°n then built two fortified posts in the Koli country, naming one Ázam√°b√°d after himself, and the other Khalíl√°b√°d after his son. He next marched to K√°thi√°v√°ḍa30 and Subdues the K√°this.subdued the K√°this, who were continually ravaging the country near Dhandhúka, and to check them erected a fortified post called Sh√°hpúr, on the opposite side of the river to Chuda-R√°npur. Ágha F√°zil known as F√°zil Kh√°n, who had at one time held the post of minister, and had, in a.d. 1636, been appointed governor of Baroda, was now selected to command the special cavalry composing the bodyguard of prince Muhammad Aurangzíb. At the same time Sayad Ilahd√°d was appointed governor of Surat fort, Ísa Tarkh√°n remaining at Jun√°gaḍh. In a.d. 1637, Mír Muhammad S√°bir was chosen minister in place of Ri√°yat Kh√°n, and in a.d. 1638 Muîz-zul-Mulk was re-appointed to the command of Surat fort. Shortly after Ázam Kh√°n’s daughter was sent to Dehli, and espoused to the emperor’s son Muhammad Shuj√° Bah√°dur. In a.d. 1639, Ázam Kh√°n, who for his love of building was known as Udhai or the Whiteant, devoted his attention to establishing fortified posts to check rebellion and robbery in the country of the Kolis and the K√°this. So complete were his arrangements that people could travel safely all over Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, [279]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Sh√°h Jeh√°n Emperor, 1627–1658.
Ázam Kh√°n Twenty-third Viceroy, 1635–1642. K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, Nav√°nagar, and Kachh.Revolt of the J√°m of Nav√°nagar, 1640. The J√°m, who of late years had been accustomed to do much as he pleased, resented these arrangements, and in a.d. 1640 withheld his tribute, and set up a mint to coin koris.31 When Ázam Kh√°n heard of this, he marched with an army against Nav√°nagar, and, on arriving about three miles from the city, he sent the J√°m a peremptory order to pay the arrears of tribute and to close his mint, ordering him, if any disturbance occurred in that part of the country, at once to send his son to the viceroy to learn his will. He further ordered the J√°m to dismiss to their own countries all refugees from other parts of Gujar√°t. The J√°m being unable to cope with Ázam Kh√°n, acceded to these terms; and Ázam Kh√°n, receiving the arrears of tribute, returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. As Ázam Kh√°n’s stern and somewhat rough rule made him unpopular, Sayad J√°l√°l Bukh√°ri whose estates were being deserted from fear of him brought the matter to the emperor’s notice.

Ísa Tarkh√°n Twenty-fourth Viceroy, 1642–1644.In consequence in a.d. 1642 the emperor recalled Ázam Kh√°n and appointed in his place Mírza Ísa Tarkh√°n, then governor of Sorath, twenty-fourth viceroy of Gujar√°t. And as it was feared that in anger at being re-called Ázam Kh√°n might oppress some of those who had complained against him, this order was written by the emperor with his own hand. Thanks to Ázam Kh√°n’s firm rule, the new viceroy found the province in good order, and was able to devote his attention to financial reforms, among them the introduction of the share, bh√°gvat√°i, system of levying land revenue in kind. When Mírza Ísa Tarkh√°n was raised to be viceroy of Gujar√°t, he appointed his son In√°yatull√°h to be governor of Jun√°gaḍh, and Muiz-zul-Mulk to fill the post of minister. During the viceroyalty of Mírza Ísa Sayad Jal√°l Bukh√°ri a descendant of Saint Sh√°hi Álam was appointed to the high post of Sadr-us-Sudúr or chief law officer for the whole of India. This was a time of prosperity especially in Surat, whose port dues which were settled on the P√°dsh√°h Begam had risen from two and a half to five l√°khs. Mírza Ísa Tarkh√°n’s term of power was brief. In a.d. 1644 the emperor appointed prince Muhammad Aurangzíb to the charge of Gujar√°t, Muiz-zul-Mulk being ordered by the emperor to continue to act as his minister. An event of interest in the next year (a.d. 1645) is the capture of seventy-three elephants in the forests of Dohad and Ch√°mp√°ner.32 [280]


Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Sh√°h Jeh√°n Emperor, 1627–1658.
Prince Muhammad Aurangzíb Twenty-fifth Viceroy, 1644–1646. Prince Muhammad Aurangzíb Twenty-fifth Viceroy, 1644–1646.Prince Aurangzíb’s rule in Gujar√°t was marked by religious disputes. In 1644 a quarrel between Hindus and Musalm√°ns ended in the prince ordering a newly built (1638) temple of Chint√°man near Saraspur, a suburb of Áhmed√°b√°d, above a mile and a half east of the city, to be desecrated by slaughtering a cow in it. He then turned the building into a mosque, but the emperor ordered its restoration to the Hindus. In another case both of the contending parties were Musalm√°ns, the orthodox believers, aided by the military under the prince’s orders, who was enraged at Sayad R√°ju one of his followers joining the heretics, attacking and slaughtering the representatives of the Mahdawiyeh sect in Áhmed√°b√°d. Sayad R√°ju’s spirit, under the name of R√°jú Shahíd or R√°jú the martyr, is still worshipped as a disease-scaring guardian by the Pinj√°r√°s and Mansúris and Dúdhw√°las of Áhmed√°b√°d.33 Sh√°istah Kh√°n Twenty-sixth Viceroy, 1646–1648.In consequence of the part he had taken in promoting these disturbances, prince Aurangzíb was relieved and Sh√°istah Kh√°n appointed twenty-sixth viceroy of Gujar√°t. In the following year Muiz-zul-Mulk, who had till then acted as minister, was recalled, and his place supplied by H√°fiz Muhammad N√°sir. At the same time the governorship of Surat and Cambay was given to Áli Akbar of Ispah√°n. This Áli Akbar was a Persian horse merchant who brought to Agra seven horses of pure Arabian breed. For six of these Sh√°h Jeh√°n paid Rs. 25,000. The seventh a bay so pleased the emperor that he paid Rs. 15,000 for it, named it the Priceless Ruby, and considered it the gem of the imperial stud. In a.d. 1646 Áli Akbar was assassinated by a Hindu and Muiz-zul-Mulk succeeded him as governor of Surat and Cambay. Prince Muhammad D√°r√° Shikoh Twenty-seventh Viceroy, 1648–1652.As Sh√°istah Kh√°n failed to control the Gujar√°t Kolis, in a.d. 1648 prince Muhammad D√°r√° Shikoh was chosen viceroy, with Ghairat Kh√°n as his deputy and H√°fiz Muhammad N√°sir as minister, while Sh√°istah Kh√°n was sent to M√°lwa to relieve Sh√°h Naw√°z Kh√°n. While D√°r√° Shikoh was viceroy an ambassador landed at Surat from the court of the Turkish Sult√°n Muhammad IV. (a.d. 1648–1687).34 In a.d. 1651, Mír Yahy√° was appointed minister in place of H√°fiz Muhammad N√°sir, and in a.d. 1652 prince D√°r√° was sent to Kandah√°r. On [281]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Sh√°h Jeh√°n Emperor, 1627–1658.
Sh√°istah Kh√°n Twenty-eighth Viceroy, 1652–1654. Sh√°istah Kh√°n Twenty-eighth Viceroy, 1652–1654.the transfer of the prince Sh√°istah Kh√°n became viceroy for the second time, with Mír Yahy√° as minister and Sult√°n Y√°r governor of Baroda with the title of Himmat Kh√°n. Mírza Ísa Tarkh√°n was summoned to court from his charge of Sorath and his son Muhammad S√°lih was appointed his successor. In a.d. 1653 an ill-advised imperial order reducing the pay of the troopers, as well as of the better class of horsemen who brought with them a certain number of followers, created much discontent. During this year several changes of governors were made. Muhammad N√°sir was sent to Surat, Himmat Kh√°n to Dholka, the governor of Dholka to Baroda, Kutb-ud-dín to Jun√°gaḍh, Sayad Sheikhan son-in-law of Sayad Diler Kh√°n to Thar√°d under P√°tan, and Jagm√°l, the holder of S√°nand, to Dholka. In the same year Sh√°istah Kh√°n made an expedition against the Chunv√°lia Kolis, who, since Ázam Kh√°n’s time (a.d. 1642), had been ravaging Víramg√°m, Dholka, and Kadi, and raiding even as far as the villages round Áhmed√°b√°d.

Prince Mur√°d Bakhsh Twenty-ninth Viceroy, 1654–1657.In spite of Sh√°istah Kh√°n’s success in restoring order the emperor in a.d. 1654 appointed in his place prince Muhammad Mur√°d Bakhsh twenty-ninth viceroy of Gujar√°t. Di√°nat Kh√°n, and immediately after him Rehmat Kh√°n, was appointed minister in place of Mír Yahy√°. Muj√°hid Kh√°n Jh√°lori relieved Mír Shams-ud-dín as governor of P√°tan and Godhra was entrusted to Sayad Hasan, son of Sayad Diler Kh√°n, and its revenues assigned to him. When prince Mur√°d Bakhsh reached Jh√°bua35 on his way to Áhmed√°b√°d, the chief presented him with £1500 (Rs. 15,000) as tribute; and when he reached Áhmed√°b√°d, K√°nji, the notorious leader of the Chunv√°lia Kolis; surrendered through Sayad Sheikhan, and promised to remain quiet and pay a yearly tribute of £1000 (Rs. 10,000). Dildost, son of Sarfar√°z Kh√°n, was appointed to the charge of the post of Bíj√°pur under P√°tan; while Sayad Sheikhan was made governor of S√°dra and Píplod, and Sayad Áli paymaster, with the title of Radawi Kh√°n. Many other changes were made at the same time, the prince receiving a grant of the district of Jun√°gaḍh. One Pírjí, a Bohora, said to have been one of the richest merchants of Surat, is noted as sending the emperor four Arab horses and prince Mur√°d as presenting the emperor with eighteen of the famous Gujar√°t bullocks. During the viceroyalty of D√°r√° Shikoh sums of Rs. 1,00,000 to Rs. 2,00,000 used to be spent on articles in demand in Arabia. The articles were sent under some trustworthy officer and the proceeds applied to charitable purposes in the sacred cities.

Mur√°d proclaims himself Emperor, 1657.At the end of a.d. 1657, on the receipt of news that Sh√°h Jeh√°n was dangerously ill prince Mur√°d Bakhsh proclaimed himself emperor by the title of Murawwaj-ud-dín and ordered the reading of the Friday sermon and the striking of coin in his own name.36 His next step was to put to death the minister Áli Naki, and direct his men to seize the fort of Surat then held by his sister the Begam S√°hibah and to take possession of the property of the Begam. He imprisoned Abdul-Latíf, son of Isl√°m Kh√°n, an old servant of the empire. D√°r√° Shikoh representing Mur√°d’s conduct to the emperor obtained an order to [282]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Sh√°h Jeh√°n Emperor, 1627–1658.
K√°sam Kh√°n Thirtieth Viceroy, 1657–1659. K√°sam Kh√°n Thirtieth Viceroy, 1657–1659.transfer him to the governorship of the Ber√°rs. Mur√°d Bakhsh borrowing £55,000 (5½ l√°khs of rupees) from the sons of S√°ntid√°s Jauhari, £4000 (Rs. 40,000) from Ravíd√°s partner of S√°ntid√°s, and £8800 (Rs. 88,000) from S√°nmal and others, raised an army and arranged to meet his brother prince Aurangzíb, and with him march against the Mah√°r√°ja Jasvatsingh of Jodhpur and K√°sam Kh√°n, whom Sh√°h Jeh√°n had appointed viceroys of M√°lwa and Gujar√°t, and had ordered to meet at Ujjain and march against the princes. Victory of Mur√°d and Aurangzíb.Mur√°d Bakhsh and Aurangzíb, uniting their forces early in a.d. 1658, fought an obstinate battle with Jasvantsingh, in which they were victorious, and entered Ujjain in triumph. From Ujjain prince Mur√°d Bakhsh wrote Muâtamid Kh√°n his eunuch an order allotting to M√°nikchand £15,000 (Rs. 1,50,000) from the revenues of Surat, £10,000 (Rs. 1,00,000) from Cambay, £10,000 (Rs. 1,00,00) from Pitl√°d, £7500 (Rs. 75,000) from Dholka, £5000 (Rs. 50,000) from Broach, £4500 (Rs. 45,000) from Víramg√°m, and £3000 (Rs. 30,000) from the salt works, in all £55,000 (5½ l√°khs of rupees). Further sums of £4000 (Rs. 40,000) are mentioned as due to Ravid√°s partner of S√°ntid√°s, and £8800 (Rs. 88,000) to S√°nmal and others. From Ujjain the princes advanced on Agra. At Dholpúr they fought a still more obstinate battle with the imperial forces commanded by prince D√°r√° Shikoh and after a long and doubtful contest were victorious. Prince D√°r√° Shikoh fled to Dehli, and the princes advanced and took possession of Agra. After confining his father, Aurangzíb marched for Mathura, Aurangzíb confines Mur√°d, 1658.and having no further use of Mur√°d, he there seized and imprisoned him. From Mathura, Aurangzíb went to Dehli from which Dar√° Shikoh had meanwhile retired to L√°hor.

Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.In a.d. 1658, while his father was still alive, Aurangzíb assumed the imperial titles and ascended the throne. In a.d. 1659 he appointed Sh√°h Naw√°z Kh√°n Saf√°vi thirty-first viceroy of Gujar√°t, with Rahmat Kh√°n as minister. Sh√°h Naw√°z Kh√°n Saf√°vi Thirty-first Viceroy, 1659.On this occasion S√°ntid√°s received a decree directing that the provincial officials should settle his accounts and Kutb-ud-dín Kheshgi was appointed to Sorath. Sh√°h Naw√°z Kh√°n was the father-in-law of both Aurangzíb and Mur√°d Bakhsh. Shortly after his appointment, while Mur√°d’s wife was paying a visit to her father, Prince D√°r√° Rebels, 1659.prince D√°r√° Shikoh leaving Kachh, where he had been hospitably received by the R√°v, made a sudden descent on Gujar√°t. The viceroy, won over by the entreaties of his daughter who saw in the success of D√°r√° a hope of release for her husband, joined the prince who entered Áhmed√°b√°d. After raising funds from Surat and Áhmed√°b√°d he collected an army of 22,000 horse and appointing Sayad Áhmed deputy viceroy, marched towards Ajmír, once more to try his chance of empire. Is Defeated, 1659.He was defeated and fled to Áhmed√°b√°d, where Sard√°r Kh√°n, who had confined Sayad Áhmed, closed the gates of the city in his face. The unhappy prince retired to Kachh, but finding no support fled to Sindh, where he was treacherously seized and handed to his brother by the chief of Jún. Jasvantsingh Thirty-second Viceroy, 1659–1662.The emperor Aurangzíb, forgiving Jasvantsingh his opposition at Ujjain, conferred on him the government of Gujar√°t, and in the place of Rahmat Kh√°n appointed Makramat Kh√°n to act as minister. Sard√°r [283]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Jasvantsingh Thirty-second Viceroy, 1659–1662. Kh√°n was thanked for his loyal conduct and made governor of Broach. Praise was also given to Sher and Ábid of the B√°bi family. Presents were bestowed on Kutb-ud-dín, governor of Sorath, and, shortly after, for his refusal to help prince D√°r√°, Tam√°chi chief of Kachh was rewarded. These measures removed all signs of disaffection at the accession of Aurangzíb. A decree was issued directing Rahmat Kh√°n the minister to forbid the cultivation of the bhang plant. Mohtasibs or censors were appointed to prevent the drinking of wine or the use of intoxicating drugs and preparations. On the formal installation of Aurangzíb in a.d. 1658–59 the Áhmed√°b√°d K√°zi was ordered to read the sermon in his name. The K√°zi objected that Sh√°h Jeh√°n was alive. Sheikh Abdul Wahh√°b, a Sunni Bohora of Pattan, whom on account of his learning and intelligence Aurangzíb had made K√°zi of his camp, contended that the weakness and age of Sh√°h Jeh√°n made a successor necessary. The Bohora prevailed and the sermon was read in Aurangzíb’s name.

Jasvantsinghji sent against Shiv√°ji, 1662.In a.d. 1662 Jasvantsingh received orders to march to the Dakhan and join prince Muâzzam against Shiv√°ji the Mar√°tha leader; and Kutb-ud-dín, governor of Sorath, was directed to act for him in his absence. In this year Mah√°bat Kh√°n was appointed thirty-third viceroy of Gujar√°t, and Sard√°r Kh√°n, the governor of Broach, was sent to Ídar to suppress disturbances. Mah√°bat Kh√°n Thirty-third Viceroy, 1662–1663.About a.d. 1664 Ranmalji or Satars√°la J√°m of Nav√°nagar died, leaving by a R√°hthoḍ mother a child named L√°kha whom the late chief’s brother R√°isinghji with the aid of the R√°v of Kachh and other J√°dej√°s, set aside and himself mounted the throne. Malik Ísa, a servant of the family, took L√°kha to Áhmed√°b√°d and invoked the aid of the viceroy. Capture of Nav√°nagar (Isl√°mnagar), 1664.Kutb-ud-dín marching on Nav√°nagar, defeated and slew R√°isingh, took possession of Nav√°nagar, and annexed the territory, changing the name of the city into Isl√°mnagar. R√°isingh’s son, Tam√°chi, then an infant, escaped and was sheltered in Kachh. In the same year (a.d. 1664) a Balúch personating D√°r√° Shikoh, was joined by many Kolis, and disturbed the peace of the Chúnv√°l, now a portion of the Áhmed√°b√°d collectorate north of Víramg√°m. With the aid of Sherkh√°n B√°bi, Mah√°bat Kh√°n quelled these disturbances, and established two new military posts, one at G√°jna under Cambay and one at Belp√°r under Petl√°d.

In this year an imperial decree was received requiring the discontinuance of the following abuses: The charging of blackmail by executive subordinates; A tax on private individuals on their cutting their own trees; Forced purchases by state servants; The levy by local officers of a tax on persons starting certain crafts; The levy of a tax on laden carts and on cattle for sale; The closing of Hindu shops on the Jain Pachusan and at the monthly elevenths or Ek√°dasi; Forced labour; The exclusive purchase of new grain by revenue officers; The exclusive sale by officers of the vegetables and other produce of their gardens; A tax on the slaughtering of cattle in addition to that on their sale; Payments to the Ahmednagar Kolis to prevent Musalm√°ns praying in the Ahmednagar mosque; The re-opening of certain Hindu temples; The aggressive conduct and obscenity practised during the Holi and Div√°li holidays; The sale by Hindus of toy horses and elephants [284]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Mah√°bat Kh√°n Thirty-third Viceroy, 1662–1663. during Musalm√°n holidays; The exclusive sale of rice by certain rich Banias; The exclusive purchase by Imperial officers of roses for the manufacture of rosewater; The mixed gatherings of men and women at Musalm√°n shrines; The setting up of nezas or holy hands and the sitting of harlots on roadsides or in markets; The charging by revenue officers of scarcity rates; The special tax in Par√°ntij, Modasa, Vadnagar, Bisn√°pur, and Harsol on Musalm√°n owners of mango trees; The levy of duty both at Surat and Áhmed√°b√°d from English and Dutch merchants.37

Shiv√°ji Plunders Surat, 1664.In the same year (a.d. 1664) Shiv√°ji made a rapid descent on Surat, then undefended by walls, and, by plundering the city, created great alarm over the whole province. The viceroy Mah√°bat Kh√°n marched to Surat with the following chiefs and officers: Jagm√°l, proprietor of S√°nand; the governor of Dholka; Sh√°dimal, chief of Ídar; Sayad Hasan Kh√°n, governor of Ídar; Muhammad Ábid with 200 superior landholders of the district of Kadi; the R√°ja of Dúngarpur; Sabalsingh R√°ja of Wadhw√°n and other chiefs of Jh√°l√°v√°ḍh; L√°l Kali√°n chief of M√°ndva in the G√°ikw√°r’s dominions near Atarsumba; the chief of Elol under Ahmednagar in the Mahi K√°ntha Agency; Prathir√°j of Haldarv√°s; and the chief of Belp√°r. Before the viceroy’s army arrived at Surat Shiv√°ji had carried off his plunder to his head-quarters at R√°ygad.38 After remaining three months at Surat levying tribute from the superior landholders, the viceroy returned to Ahmed√°b√°d, and In√°yat Kh√°n, the revenue collector of Surat, built a wall round the town for its protection. About this time Kutb-ud-dín Kh√°n, governor of Sorath, was sent with an army to aid the Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsingh in the Dakhan and Sard√°r Kh√°n was appointed in his place. In a.d. 1666 the Mar√°th√°s again attacked and plundered Surat, and in the same year the deposed emperor Sh√°h Jeh√°n died. Aurangzíb attempted to induce the English to supply him with European artillerymen and engineers. The request was evaded. Copper Coinage Introduced, 1668.In this year the viceroy, Mah√°bat Kh√°n, in place of the old iron coins, introduced a copper coinage into Gujar√°t. Sard√°r Khan, the governor of Jun√°gaḍh, was put in charge of Isl√°mnagar (Nav√°nagar) and 500 additional horsemen were placed under him. Special checks by branding and inspection were introduced to prevent nobles and others keeping less than their proper contingent of horse. In the same year the cultivator who paid the rent was acknowledged to be the owner of the land and a system of strengtheners or tak√°wi after due security was introduced.

Kh√°n Jeh√°n Thirty-fourth Viceroy, 1668–1671.In a.d. 1668, Bah√°dur Kh√°n Kh√°n Jeh√°n, who had formerly been viceroy of Allah√°b√°d, was appointed viceroy of Gujar√°t, with H√°ji Shafi Kh√°n, and afterwards Khw√°jah Muhammad H√°shím, as his ministers. Kh√°n Jeh√°n joined his government in a.d. 1669, and in a.d. 1670 Shiv√°ji again plundered Surat. In a.d. 1670 Shiv√°ji made [285]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Kh√°n Jeh√°n Thirty-fourth Viceroy, 1668–1671. an attempt on Janjira,39 the residence and stronghold of the Sídi or Abyssinian admirals of Bíj√°pur. Sídi Y√°kút the Mughal Admiral, 1670.Sídi Y√°kút the commander of Janjira applied for aid to the governor of Surat. On his offering to become a vassal of the emperor and place his fleet at the emperor’s disposal, Sídi Y√°kút received the title of Y√°kút Kh√°n, and a yearly subsidy of £15,000 (Rs. 1,50,000) payable from the port of Surat. About the same time Sayad Diler Kh√°n, who had accompanied Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsingh to the Dakhan, was recalled by the viceroy Kh√°n Jeh√°n and appointed governor of Sorath in place of Sard√°r Kh√°n, who was sent to Ídar. Sayad Haidar, in charge of the military post of Haidar√°b√°d, about twenty-four miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d, reported that he had put down the rebellion but recommended that a small fort should be built. In a.d. 1670 the emperor summoned Diler Kh√°n to discuss Dakhan affairs, and sent him to the seat of war, replacing him in the government of Sorath by Sard√°r Kh√°n.

Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsingh Thirty-fifth Viceroy, 1671–1674.In a.d. 1671, Bah√°dur Kh√°n Kh√°n Jeh√°n was sent as viceroy to the Dakhan. He was relieved by the Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsingh, who, as viceroy, received an assignment of the districts of Dhandhúka and Pitl√°d. In a.d. 1673 through the intercession of the viceroy, J√°m Ṭam√°chi, the son of R√°isingh, on condition of serving the viceroy and of keeping order was restored to Nav√°nagar, and twenty-five villages were granted to certain dependent J√°deja R√°jputs. So long as the emperor Aurangzíb lived the city of Nav√°nagar (Isl√°mnagar) remained in the hands of a Musalm√°n noble, the J√°m residing at Khambh√°lia, a town about thirty miles south-west of the head-quarters of the state. In a.d. 1707, on Aurangzíb’s death, the J√°m was allowed to return to Nav√°nagar where he built a strong fort. Similarly so long as Aurangzíb lived, the J√°m forbore to work the pearl fisheries in the Gulf of Kachh, but afterwards again made use of this source of revenue. Early in 1674 an order issued forbidding the levy from Musalm√°ns of rah√°dari or transit dues, of taxes on fish vegetables grass firewood and other forest produce, on Muhammadan artisans, and many other miscellaneous dues. The officer in charge of Morví, which was then an imperial district, was ordered to strive to increase its population and revenue, and the chief of Porbandar, also an imperial district, on condition of service and of protecting the port was allowed a fourth share of its revenue. Much discontent was caused by enforcing an imperial order confiscating all wazífah land, that is all land held on religious tenure by Hindus.

Muhammad Amín Kh√°n Umdat-ul-Mulk Thirty-sixth Viceroy, 1674–1683.About the close of the year a.d. 1674, Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsinghji was relieved and sent to K√°bul, and Muhammad Amín Kh√°n Umdat-ul-Mulk, who had just been defeated at K√°bul, was appointed thirty-sixth viceroy of Gujar√°t, receiving an assignment of the districts of P√°tan and Víramg√°m. Among the military posts mentioned in the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi is that of S√°dra or Sh√°hdarah the present head-quarters of the Mahi K√°ntha Agency, also called Isl√°m√°b√°d,40 which was under the [286]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Muhammad Amín Kh√°n Umdat-ul-Mulk Thirty-sixth Viceroy, 1674–1683. command of Sayad Kam√°l, son of Sayad K√°mil. Increased Power of the B√°bi Family.The B√°bi family were now rising into importance. Muhammad Muzaffar, son of Sher Kh√°n B√°bi, was governor of Kadi, and Muhammad Mub√°riz, another son of Sher B√°bi, was in charge of one of the posts under Kadi. Kam√°l Kh√°n Jh√°lori, who had been removed from the government of P√°lanpur and replaced by Muhammad Fateh, was now restored to his former post. About the same time, at the representation of Mulla Hasan Gujar√°ti, twenty-one villages were taken from Bij√°pur and Kadi and P√°tan and formed into the separate division of Visalnagar. In a.d. 1676, the fort of Jun√°gaḍh was put into repair, and Sheikh Niz√°m-ud-dín Áhmed, minister of Gujar√°t, was sent to M√°lwa, and was succeeded by Muhammad Sharíf. The K√°nkrej Kolis were again rebellious, and Muhammad Amín Kh√°n Umdat-ul-Mulk went against them and remained four months in their country, subduing them and enforcing tribute. In the end of a.d. 1678, the viceroy paid his respects to the emperor at Ajmír. The emperor forbade the fining of Musalm√°n officials as contrary to the Muhammadan law and directed that if guilty of any fault they should be imprisoned or degraded from office, but not fined. An order was also given to change the name of the new Visalnagar district to Rasúlnagar.

At this time (a.d. 1679) the emperor was doing his utmost to crush both the R√°na of Udepur and the R√°thoḍs of M√°rw√°r. While the emperor was at Chitor, Bhímsing the R√°na’s youngest son raided into Gujar√°t plundering Vadnagar Visalnagar and other towns and villages. Revolt of Ídar, 1679.The chief of Ídar, thinking the opportunity favourable for regaining his independence, expelled the Muhammadan garrison from Ídar and established himself in his capital. Muhammad Amín Kh√°n sent Muhammad Bahlol Kh√°n Shirw√°ni who with the help of the Kasb√°tis of Par√°ntij re-took Ídar, and the chief pursued by Bahlol Kh√°n fled to the hills, where he died in a cave from want of his usual dose of opium to which he was much addicted. His body was found by a woodcutter who brought the head to Bahlol Kh√°n. The head was recognized by the chief’s widow, who from that day put on mourning. Muhammad Bahlol Kh√°n was much praised, and was appointed to the charge of Ídar, and at the same time the minister Muhammad Sharíf was succeeded by Abdúl Latíf.41

To this time belongs an imperial decree imposing the jazyah or head tax on all subjects not professing the Muhammadan faith, and another regulating the levy from Musalm√°ns of the zak√°t or poor rate.42 In 1681 a severe famine led to riots in Áhmed√°b√°d. As the [287]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Muhammad Amín Kh√°n Umdat-ul-Mulk Thirty-sixth Viceroy, 1674–1683. viceroy Muhammad Amín was returning in state from the Íd prayers Abu Bakr an Áhmed√°b√°d Sheikh instigated the people to throw stones and dust. The viceroy’s bodyguard attacked the mob, but owing to the viceroy’s forbearance no serious results followed. On hearing of the riot the emperor ordered the city to be put under martial law. The more politic viceroy contented himself by inviting Sheikh Abu Bakr and others to a banquet. After dinner he gave a piece of a poisoned watermelon to Abu Bakr, who died and the riot with him. In a.d. 1683 Muhammad Amín the viceroy died. According to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Muhammad Amín was one of the best of Gujar√°t governors. The emperor Aurangzíb used to say ‘No viceroy of mine keeps order like Amín Kh√°n.’

Mukht√°r Kh√°n Thirty-seventh Viceroy, 1683–1684Amín Kh√°n was succeeded by Mukht√°r Kh√°n as thirty-seventh viceroy, Abdul Latíf continuing to hold the office of minister. Fresh orders were passed forbidding import dues on merchandise, fruit, grass, firewood, and similar produce entering Áhmed√°b√°d. In 1682 a decree was received ordering pauper prisoners to be provided with rations and dress at the cost of the state. In 1683 the S√°barmati rose so high that the water reached as far as the Tín Darw√°zah or Triple Gateway in the west of Áhmed√°b√°d city. In consequence of disturbances in Sorath the viceroy called on the minister to advance funds for an expedition. The minister refused to make advances without special orders from the emperor. On a reference to court the minister was directed to make advances in emergent cases. In a.d. 1684, at the request of the inhabitants of that city Abdúr Rahm√°n Krori, the governor of Deva P√°tan, was removed and in his place Muhammad Sayad chose Sard√°r Kh√°n as governor of Sorath. In the following year on the death of Sard√°r Kh√°n at Thatha in Sindh, where he had gone as viceroy, he was, in the first instance, succeeded in the government of Sorath by Sayad Muhammad Kh√°n. Not long after Sorath was assigned as a personal estate to the emperor’s second son prince Muhammad Ázam Sh√°h Bah√°dur and during the prince’s absence Sh√°hwardi Kh√°n was sent to manage its affairs. Famine, 1684.In a.d. 1684 a famine in Gujar√°t raised the price of grain in Áhmed√°b√°d to such a degree that Sheikh Muhy-ud-dín, the son of the K√°zi and regulator of prices, was mobbed.

Shuj√°ât Kh√°n (K√°rtalab Kh√°n) Thirty-eighth Viceroy, 1684–1703.On the death of the viceroy in 1684 prince Muhammad Ázam Sh√°h was nominated to succeed him with K√°rtalab Kh√°n, governor of Sorath, as his deputy. Before the prince took charge K√°rtalab Kh√°n was raised to the post of viceroy, and Muhammad T√°hir appointed minister. In addition to his command as viceroy of Gujar√°t, K√°rtalab Kh√°n was afterwards placed in charge of Jodhpur. In this rearrangement besides his previous personal estate, the district of Petl√°d was assigned to prince Muhammad Ázam Sh√°h, and Sher Afghan Kh√°n, son of Sh√°hwardi Kh√°n, was appointed governor of Sorath. In a.d. [288]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Shuj√°ât Kh√°n (K√°rtalab Kh√°n) Thirty-eighth Viceroy, 1684–1703. 1687, Sher Afghan Kh√°n was relieved by Bahlol Shirw√°ni, but in the following year was restored to his command. In a.d. 1689, on the news of the death of its governor In√°yat Kh√°n, K√°rtalab Kh√°n started to settle the affairs of Jodhpur. As soon as he left Áhmed√°b√°d, a rumour spread that a new viceroy was coming, and the troops, with whom as well as with the people of Gujar√°t K√°rtalab was most popular, grew mutinous. He Quells a Mutiny, 1689.On hearing of this disturbance K√°rtalab Kh√°n at once returned to Áhmed√°b√°d and quelled the mutiny. His firmness so pleased the emperor that he gave him the title of Shujaât Kh√°n, and placed the governor of Jodhpur under his orders.
