Shujaât Kh√°n now proceeded to Jodhpur, where Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ, who had incited prince Abkar to rebellion, and Ajítsingh, the son of Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsingh, were causing disturbance. Finding that a strong resident governor was required to keep the insurgents in check, Shujaât Kh√°n appointed K√°zim Beg Muhammad Amín, a brave and resolute soldier, to be his deputy and returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. During this viceroyalty the pay of the leader or jam√°d√°r of a troop of fifty horse was fixed at £10 (Rs. 100); of a do-aspah or two-horse trooper at £6 (Rs. 60); and of an ek-aspah or one-horse trooper at £3 (Rs. 30) a month. An imperial order was also issued directing the levy on merchandise to be taken at the place and time of sale instead of the time and place of purchase. As this change caused loss to the revenue the old system was again adopted. In a.d. 1690 the minister Am√°nat Kh√°n, with the title of Ítim√°d Kh√°n, was made military governor of Surat, and Sayad Muhsín was chosen minister in his place. To prevent the peons of great officials extorting fees and dues officials were forbidden to entertain peons without payment.

Revolt of Mati√°s and Momn√°s, 1691.In the following year (a.d. 1691) an attempt on the part of the emperor to suppress a body of Musalm√°n sectarians led to a somewhat serious insurrection. Sayad Sh√°hji was the religious preceptor of the Mati√°s of Kh√°ndesh and the Momn√°s of Gujar√°t, two classes of converted Hindus closely allied to the Khoj√°s of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, all of them being followers of Sayad Im√°m-ud-dín an Ism√°îli√°h missionary who came to Gujar√°t during the reign of Mahmúd Begada (a.d. 1459–1513). Hearing that his followers paid obeisance to their veiled spiritual guide by kissing his toe, the emperor ordered the guide to be sent to court to be examined before the religious doctors. Afraid of the result of this examination, the Sayad committed suicide and was buried at Karamtah nine miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d. The loss of their leader so enraged his followers that, collecting from all sides, they marched against Broach, seized the fort, and slew the governor. The insurgents held the fort of Broach against the governor of Baroda who was sent to punish them, and for a time successfully resisted the efforts of his successor Nazar Áli Kh√°n. At last, at an unguarded spot, some of the besiegers stole over the city wall and opening the gates admitted their companions. The Momn√°s were defeated and almost all slain as they sought death either by the sword or by drowning to merit their saint’s favour in the next world.

Disturbances in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, 1692.In a.d. 1692 Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, during his tribute-gathering campaign in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa and Sorath, stormed the fort of Th√°n, the head-quarters [289]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Shuj√°ât Kh√°n (K√°rtalab Kh√°n) Thirty-eighth Viceroy, 1684–1703. of the plundering K√°this and after destroying the fort returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n was one of the ablest of Gujar√°t viceroys. He gave so much of his attention to the management of Jodhpur, that he used to spend about six months of every year in M√°rw√°r. He beautified Áhmed√°b√°d by building the college and mosque still known by his name near the L√°l Gate. In a.d. 1642 two hundred cart-loads of marble were received from the ancient buildings at P√°tan and the deputy governor Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi wrote that if a thousand cart-loads more were required they could be supplied from the same source. At this time the emperor ordered that Sheikh Akram-ud-dín, the local tax-collector, should levy the head tax from the Hindus of P√°lanpur and Jh√°lor. The viceroy deputed Muhammad Muj√°hid, son of Kam√°l Kh√°n Jh√°lori, governor of P√°lanpur to help in collecting. Disturbances in M√°rw√°r.As Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ was again stirring tumults and sedition in M√°rw√°r, the viceroy went to Jodhpur, and by confirming their estates to the chief vassals and landholders and guaranteeing other public measures on condition of service, persuaded them to abandon their alliance with Durg√°d√°s against whom he sent his deputy K√°zim Beg, who expelled him from M√°rw√°r. After appointing Kunv√°r Muhkamsingh, governor of Mertha in M√°rw√°r, Shuj√°ât Kh√°n returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. In a.d. 1693, at the request of Sher Afghan Kh√°n, governor of Sorath, the walls of the fort of Jagat were restored. In this year the viceroy went to Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa to exact tribute. On his return to Áhmed√°b√°d Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, governor of P√°tan, wrote to the viceroy, and at his request the forts of Kambhoi and S√°mprah were repaired. The viceroy now went to Jodhpúr and from that returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. A circumstance in connection with a sum of Rs. 7000 spent on the repairs of forts illustrates the close imperial supervision of provincial accounts. The item having come to imperial notice from the provincial disbursement sheets was disallowed as unfair and ordered to be refunded under the rule that such charges were to be met out of their incomes by the local governors and military deputy governors. Imperial officers were also from time to time deputed to collect from the books of the des√°i’s statements of provincial disbursements and receipts for periods of ten years that they might render an independent check. In this year the emperor hearing that Ajítsingh and Durg√°d√°s were again contemplating rebellion ordered the viceroy to Jodhpur. Muhammad Mub√°riz B√°bi was at the same time appointed deputy governor of Vadnagar, and an order was issued that the revenue of P√°tan should be paid to Shuj√°ât Kh√°n instead of as formerly into the imperial treasury. In this year also Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, governor of P√°tan, was succeeded by Mub√°riz Kh√°n B√°bi. Not long afterwards under imperial orders the viceroy directed Muhammad Mub√°riz B√°bi to destroy the Vadnagar temple of Hateshwar-Mah√°dev the N√°gar Br√°hmans’ special guardian.

In a.d. 1696, Muhammad Bahlol Shírw√°ni, governor of Baroda, died, and his place was supplied by Muhammad Beg Kh√°n. During this year the viceroy again went to Jodhpúr and remained there for some months. In a.d. 1697 Bul√°ki Beg the mace-bearer arrived from the imperial court to settle disputes connected with the Nav√°nagar succession, [290]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Shuj√°ât Kh√°n (K√°rtalab Kh√°n) Thirty-eighth Viceroy, 1684–1703. and to inquire into complaints made by the inhabitants of Sorath. In 1696 an imperial circular was addressed to all officers in charge of districts ordering them to show no respect or consideration for royalty in their efforts to capture or kill the rebel prince Akbar. Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ reconciled to the Emperor, 1697.About the same time Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ, in whose charge were the son and daughter of prince Akbar, made an application to Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, proposing a truce, and saying that he wished personally to hand the children to their grandfather. Shujaât Kh√°n agreed and Durg√°d√°s restored Akbar’s children to the emperor. Aurangzíb finding the children able to repeat the whole Kurâ√°n was much pleased with Durg√°d√°s, and made peace with him, assigning him as a personal estate the lands of Mertha in Jodhpur, and afterwards adding to this the grant of Dhandhúka and other districts of Gujar√°t. In consequence of a failure of crops the price of grain rose so high that the government share of the produce was brought to Áhmed√°b√°d and sold in public to the poor and needy. About this time Muhammad Mub√°riz B√°bi was killed by a Koli who shot him with an arrow while he was sacking the village of S√°mprah.43 Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi was appointed deputy governor of P√°tan in his stead.

In the same year it was reported to the emperor that the money-changers and capitalists of Áhmed√°b√°d in making payments passed money short of weight to poor men and in receiving charged an exchange of two to three tank√°s the rupee. The Súbah and minister were ordered to stop the currency of rupees more than two surkhs short.44

Scarcity, 1698.In a.d. 1698, on the death of Ítim√°d Kh√°n, his son Muhammad Muhsín was made minister, and he was ordered to hand the district of Mertha to Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ. Among other changes Muhammad Muním was raised to the command of the fort of Jodhpur and Khw√°j√°h Abdul Hamíd was appointed minister. Owing to a second failure of rain 1698 was a year of much scarcity in M√°rw√°r and north Gujar√°t. The accounts of this year notice a petition addressed to the viceroy by a Sinor Br√°hman, praying that he might not be seized as a carrier or labourer.45 In connection with some revenue and civil affairs, a difference of opinion arose between Shuj√°ât Kh√°n and Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, deputy governor of P√°tan. Safdar Kh√°n resigned, and, until a successor was appointed, Muhammad Bahlol Shírw√°ni was directed to administer the P√°tan district. In the same year the emperor bestowed the government of Sorath on Muhammad Beg Kh√°n. In a.d. 1699 Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ obtained from the emperor not only a pardon for Ajítsingh, son of the late Mah√°r√°ja Jasvantsingh, but procured him [291]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Shuj√°ât Kh√°n (K√°rtalab Kh√°n) Thirty-eighth Viceroy, 1684–1703. an assignment of lands in, as well as the official charge of, the districts of Jh√°lor and S√°chor in M√°rw√°r. Muj√°hid Kh√°n Jh√°lori, who as representing a family of landholders dating as far back as the Gujar√°t Sult√°ns, had held Jh√°lor and S√°chor, now received in their stead the lands in P√°lanpur and Dísa which his descendants still hold. In this year also (a.d. 1699) Am√°nat Kh√°n, governor of Surat, died, and the Mar√°th√°s making a raid into the province, Shuj√°ât Kh√°n sent Nazar Áli Kh√°n to drive them out. About this time an imperial order arrived, addressed to the provincial díw√°n directing him to purchase 1000 horses for the government at the average rate of £20 (Rs. 200).

Prince Muhammad Aâzam Thirty-ninth Viceroy, 1703–1705.In a.d. 1700 on the death of Fírúz Kh√°n Mew√°ti, deputy governor of Jodhpúr, the viceroy appointed in his place Muhammad Z√°hid from Víramg√°m. R√°ja Ajítsingh of M√°rw√°r was now ordered to repair to court, and as he delayed, a mohsal or speed fine was imposed upon him in agreement with Shuj√°ât Kh√°n’s directions. About this time an order came to Kam√°l Kh√°n Jh√°lori for the despatch to the emperor of some of the P√°lanpur chít√°hs or hunting leopards which are still in demand in other parts of India. In the same year the manager of Dhandhúka on behalf of Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ, asked the viceroy for aid against the K√°this, who were plundering that district. The viceroy ordered Muhammad Beg, governor of Sorath, to march against them. At this time Shuj√°ât Kh√°n despatched Nazar Áli Kh√°n with a large force to join the imperial camp which was then at Panh√°la in Kolh√°pur. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, who had so long and ably filled the office of viceroy in a most critical time, died in a.d. 1703. In his place prince Muhammad Aâzam Sh√°h, who was then at Dh√°r in M√°lwa, was appointed thirty-ninth viceroy of Gujar√°t, as well as governor of Ajmír and Jodhpur; and until his arrival the minister Khw√°j√°h Abdul Hamíd Kh√°n was ordered to administer the province. Owing to the recall of the late governor’s troops from many of the posts disorders broke out in the P√°tan districts and the Kolis plundered the country and made the roads impassable.

On his way from the Dakhan to Áhmed√°b√°d, the chief of Jh√°bua, a state now under the Bhop√°war Agency, paid his respects to the new viceroy and presented him with a tribute of £1600 (Rs. 16,000). Among other arrangements the prince sent to Jodhpur J√°far Kuli, son of K√°zim Beg, as deputy governor, and appointed Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ governor of P√°tan. Shortly after, on suspicion of his tampering with the R√°thoḍ R√°jputs, an order came from the emperor to summon Durg√°d√°s to the prince’s court at Áhmed√°b√°d, and there confine him or slay him.46 Intrigue against Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ, 1703.Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, who, in displeasure with Shuj√°ât Kh√°n had retired to M√°lwa, returned and offered to slay or capture Durg√°d√°s, who was accordingly invited to the prince’s court at Áhmed√°b√°d. Durg√°d√°s came and pitched his camp at the village of B√°reja on the S√°barmati near Áhmed√°b√°d. On the day Durg√°d√°s was to present himself, the prince, on pretence of a hunt, had ordered the attendance of a strong detachment of the army. [292]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Prince Muhammad Aâzam Thirty-ninth Viceroy, 1703–1705. When all was ready and Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi and his sons appeared mailed and gauntleted the prince sent for Durg√°d√°s. As this day was an eleventh or agi√°ras Durg√°d√°s had put off waiting on the prince until the fast was over. Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ Escapes.Growing suspicious of the number of messengers from the prince, he burned his tents and fled. Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi was sent in pursuit. He was overtaking Durg√°d√°s when Durg√°d√°s’ grandson praying his grandfather to make good his escape, stayed behind with a band of followers, charged the pursuers, and after a gallant combat, he and his R√°jputs were slain. The grandson of Durg√°d√°s was killed in a hand-to-hand fight with Sal√°bat Kh√°n, the son of Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi. Emerald rings are to this day worn by youths of the B√°bi families of North Gujar√°t in memory of the emerald earrings which adorned the young R√°jput and were afterwards worn by Sal√°bat as trophies of this fight. Meanwhile Durg√°d√°s had reached Unj√°h-Un√°wa, forty miles east of P√°tan, and from Unj√°h made his way to P√°tan. From P√°tan, taking his family with him, he retired to Thar√°d, and from that to M√°rw√°r, where he was afterwards joined by Ajítsingh of M√°rw√°r, whom the emperor opposed on the ground of illegitimacy. The imperial troops followed and took possession of P√°tan, putting to death the head of the city police.

In his old age the emperor Aurangzíb became more and more strict in religious matters. In 1702 an imperial order forbad the making of almanacs as contrary to the Muhammadan law. Hindus were also forbidden to keep Muhammadan servants.

Surat, 1700–1703.About this time (a.d. 1700) news arrived that the Mar√°th√°s with a force of 10,000 horse were threatening Surat from the foot of the K√°s√°ra pass and the confines of Sult√°npur and Nandurb√°r. The viceroy despatched a body of troops to guard Surat against their incursions. Disputes between the government and the Portuguese were also injuring the trade of the province. In a.d. 1701 the viceroy received an order from Court directing him to destroy the temple of Somn√°th beyond possibility of repair. The despatch adds that a similar order had been issued at the beginning of Aurangzíb’s reign. In a.d. 1703, at the request of the merchants of Gujar√°t, with the view of inducing the Portuguese to let ships from Surat pass unmolested and release some Musalm√°ns who had been imprisoned on their way back from Makkah, orders were issued that certain confiscated Portuguese merchandise should be restored to its owners. An imperial order was also received to encourage the art of brocade weaving in Áhmed√°b√°d. In a.d. 1704, Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi was raised to be governor of Bij√°pur, about fifty miles north-east of Áhmed√°b√°d. Sarand√°z Kh√°n was at the same time appointed to Sorath instead of Muhammad Beg Kh√°n, who was placed in charge of the lands round Áhmed√°b√°d. As the Mar√°th√°s once more threatened Surat, Mustafa Kuli, governor of Broach, was sent with 1000 horse to defend the city.

Certain passages in Aurangzíb’s letters to prince Aâzam when (a.d. 1703–1705) viceroy of Gujar√°t, show how keen and shrewd an interest the aged emperor maintained in the government of his viceroys. In Letter 19 he writes to prince Aâzam: To take the government of Sorath [293]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Prince Muhammad Aâzam Thirty-ninth Viceroy, 1703–1705. from Fateh Jang Kh√°n B√°bi and give it to your chamberlain’s brother is to break a sound glass vessel with your own hands. These B√°bis have been time out of mind a respected race in Gujar√°t and are well versed in the arts of war. There is no sense in giving the management of Sorath to anyone but to a B√°bi. Sorath is a place which commanders of five thousand like Hasan Álikh√°n and Safshikan Kh√°n have with difficulty administered. If your officers follow the principles laid down by the late Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, it will be well. If they do not, the province of Gujar√°t is such that if order is broken in one or two places, it will not soon be restored. For the rest you are your own master. I say not, do this or do that; look that the end is good, and do that which is easiest. In another passage (Letter 37 to the same prince Aâzam) Aurangzíb writes: You who are a well intentioned man, why do you not retaliate on oppressors? Over H√°jipúr Aminpúr and other posts where atrocities occur every day, and at Kapadvanj where the Kolis rob the highways up to the posts, you have made your chamberlain and artillery superintendent your commandant. He entrusted his powers to his carrion-eating and fraudulent relatives. Owing to his influence the oppressed cannot come to you …. You ought to give the command to one of the Gujar√°tis like Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi or one of the sons of Bahlúl Shírw√°ni who have earned reputations during the administration of the late Shuj√°ât Kh√°n and who are popular with the people. Else I tell you plainly that on the Day of Justice we shall be caught for neglecting to punish the oppressions of our servants.

Ibr√°hím Kh√°n Fortieth Viceroy, 1705.In a.d. 1705, as the climate of Gujar√°t did not agree with prince Aâzam, Ibr√°hím Kh√°n, viceroy of Kashmír, was appointed fortieth viceroy of Gujar√°t, and his son Zabardast Kh√°n, viceroy of L√°hor, was appointed to the government of Ajmír and Jodhpur. Prince Aâzam at once went to Burh√°npur in Kh√°ndesh, handing charge of Gujar√°t to the minister Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n until the new viceroy should arrive. Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ now asked for and received pardon. Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was ordered to restore the lands formerly granted to Durg√°d√°s, and Durg√°d√°s was directed to act under Abdúl Hamíd’s orders. In a.d. 1705 the emperor learned that Kh√°nji, a successor of Kutb the high priest of the Ism√°îlia Bohor√°s, had sent out twelve missionaries to win people to his faith, and that his followers had subscribed Rs. 1,14,000 to relieve those of their number who were imprisoned. The emperor ordered that the twelve missionaries should be secured and sent to him and appointed Sunni Mull√°s to preach in their villages and bring the Bohoras’ children to the Sunni form of faith.

The Mar√°th√°s enter Gujar√°t.About this time (a.d. 1705) the Mar√°th√°s, who had long been hovering on the south-east frontiers of the province, bursting into south Gujar√°t with an army 15,000 strong, under the leadership of Dhan√°ji J√°dhav, defeated the local forces and laid the country waste. Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n, who was then in charge of the province, ordered all governors of districts and officers in charge of posts to collect their men and advance to Surat. Between Nazar Áli Kh√°n and Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, the officers in command of this [294]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Ibr√°hím Kh√°n Fortieth Viceroy, 1705. army, an unfortunate jealousy prevailed. Not knowing where the Mar√°th√°s were to be found, they halted on the Narbada near the B√°ba Pi√°rah ford. Here they remained for a month and a half, the leaders contenting themselves with sending out spies to search for the enemy. At last, hearing of the approach of the Mar√°th√°s, they sent to head-quarters asking for artillery and other reinforcements. In reply, Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n, a man of hasty temper, upbraided them for their inactivity and for allowing so much time to pass without making their way to Surat. Battle of Ratanpúr. Defeat of the Musalm√°ns, 1705.Orders were accordingly at once issued for an advance, and the army next halted at Ratanpúr in R√°jpípla. Here, apparently from the jealousy of the commanders, the different chiefs pitched their camps at some distance from each other. Finding the enemy’s forces thus scattered, the Mar√°th√°s, under the command of Dhan√°ji J√°dhav, lost no time in advancing against them. First attacking the camp of Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, they defeated his troops, killed his son, and took prisoner the chief himself. Only a few of his men, with his nephew Muhammad Aâzam, escaped to the camp of Nazar Áli Kh√°n. Next, the Mar√°th√°s attacked the army under Muhammad Purdil Kh√°n Shirw√°ni; and it also they defeated. Of the Musalm√°n army those who were not slain, drowned in the Narbada, or captured, reached Broach in miserable plight, where they were relieved by Akbar Áli Kh√°n. Nazar Áli Kh√°n burned his tents and surrendered to the Mar√°th√°s, by whom he was well treated.

Battle of the B√°ba Pi√°rah Ford. Second Defeat of the Musalm√°ns, 1705.The Mar√°th√°s now heard that Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was coming with an army to oppose them. Thinking he would not risk a battle, they went to the B√°ba Pi√°rah ford, and there crossed the Narbada. That very day Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n, with Muhammad Sher and Muhammad Sal√°bat, sons of Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, and others came to the spot where the Mar√°th√°s were encamped. All night long they were harassed by the Mar√°th√°s, and next morning found the enemy ready for a general attack. The Muhammadans, weary with watching, dispirited from the defeats of Safdar Kh√°n, and inferior in number to their assailants, were repulsed and surrounded. The two sons of Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, and two other nobles, seeing that the day was lost, cut their way through the enemy and escaped, Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n, Nazar Áli Kh√°n, and many others were taken prisoners. The Mar√°th√°s plundered the Muhammadan camp, declared their right to tribute, levied sums from the adjacent towns and villages and extorted heavy ransoms which in the case of Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was fixed at as large a sum as £30,000 (Rs. 3 l√°khs). Koli Disturbances.The Kolis, seeing the disorganized state of Gujar√°t, began ravaging the country, and plundered Baroda for two days. At Áhmed√°b√°d Muhammad Beg Kh√°n, who had been appointed governor of Sorath, was recalled to defend the capital. When the news of the defeat at B√°ba Pi√°rah reached Dehli, the emperor despatched prince Muhammad Bid√°r Bakht with a large army to drive out the invaders. Before this force reached Gujar√°t the Mar√°th√°s had retired.

Prince Muhammad Bíd√°r Bakht Forty-First Viceroy, 1705–1706.Prince Muhammad Bíd√°r Bakht arrived in a.d. 1705 as forty-first viceroy, and appointed Am√°nat Kh√°n governor of the ports of Surat and Cambay. News was now received that Ajítsingh of Jodhpur and Veris√°lji of R√°jpípla were about to rebel, and the prince took [295]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Aurangzíb Emperor, 1658–1707.
Prince Muhammad Bíd√°r Bakht Forty-First Viceroy, 1705–1706. measures to check their plans. About this time the emperor, hearing that an attack had been made on the Muhammadan post at Dw√°rka, ordered the temple to be levelled to the ground. It seems doubtful whether this order was carried out. Nazar Áli Kh√°n, who had formerly enjoyed a grant of Halvad in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, had been driven out by Chandrasingh, chief of V√°nk√°ner; but, on condition of his expelling Chandrasingh, these lands were again granted to him. Kam√°l Kh√°n Jh√°lori, leaving under his son Fírúz Kh√°n at P√°lanpur a body of men for the defence of his charge, advanced to Áhmed√°b√°d to guard the city from Mar√°tha attack. He petitioned that according to Gujar√°t custom his troops should receive rations so long as they were employed on imperial service. To this request the emperor agreed and issued orders to the provincial minister. Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ again in Rebellion.Shortly after Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ took advantage of the general confusion to rejoin Ajítsingh, and an army was sent to Thar√°d against them. Ajítsingh was at first forced to retire. Finally he succeeded in defeating Kunvar Muhkamsingh, and marching on Jodhpur recovered it from Jaâfar Kuli, son of K√°zím Beg. Durg√°d√°s meanwhile had taken shelter with the Kolis. At the head of a band of robbers, meeting Sh√°h Kúli the son of K√°zím Beg on his way to join his appointment as deputy governor of P√°tan, Durg√°d√°s attacked and killed him. And soon after at Chani√°r in the Chunv√°l, laying in wait for Maâsúm Kúli, the governor of Víramg√°m, he routed his escort, Maâsum Kúli escaping with difficulty. On condition of being appointed governor of P√°tan Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi now offered to kill or capture Durg√°d√°s. His offer was accepted, and as from this time Durg√°d√°s is no more heard of, it seems probable that Safdar Kh√°n succeeded in killing him. Ibr√°hím Kh√°n Forty-second Viceroy, 1706.As the disturbed state of the province seemed to require a change of government Ibr√°hím Kh√°n, who had been appointed viceroy in the previous year, was ordered to join his post. This order he reluctantly obeyed in a.d. 1706.

[Contents]

SECTION II.—Fifty Years of Disorder, 1707–1757.

The Mar√°th√°s advance to Áhmed√°b√°d and levy Tribute, 1707.With the death of the emperor Aurangzíb, early in a.d. 1707, the period of strong government which had latterly from year to year been growing weaker came to an end. As soon as Aurangzíb’s death was known, the Mar√°th√°s under B√°l√°ji Vishvan√°th burst into east Gujar√°t, marching by Jh√°bua and Godhra, where they were ineffectually opposed by the governor Mur√°d Baksh. From Godhra they went to and plundered the town of Mahuda in Kaira, and proposed marching on Áhmed√°b√°d by way of Naḍi√°d. The viceroy prepared to resist them, and, enlisting special troops, camped outside of the city near the K√°nkariya lake. Of the warlike population on the north bank of the S√°barmati opposite Áhmed√°b√°d nearly eight thousand Musalm√°n horse and three thousand foot together with four thousand R√°jpúts and Kolis in three days gathered at the K√°nkariya camp. The viceroy was also joined by Abdúl H√°di Pandemal the viceroy’s minister, Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n provincial minister, Muhammad Beg Kh√°n, Nazar Áli Kh√°n, Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, and several other deputy governors with their retinues and artillery. Though strong in numbers the practised eye of the viceroy failed to find in the host that [296]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Bah√°dur Sh√°h I. Emperor, 1707–1712.
Ibr√°hím Kh√°n Forty-second Viceroy, 1706. firmness and unity of purpose which could alone ensure victory over the Mar√°tha hordes. The Mar√°th√°s did much mischief, plundering as far as Batva, only four-and-a-half miles from the viceroy’s camp. The author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, whose father was an actor in these scenes, describes the panic in the capital of Gujar√°t which since its capture by Muzaffar in a.d. 1583 had been free from the horrors of war. Crowds of scared and terror-stricken men, women and children laden with as much of their property as they could carry were pressing from the suburbs into the city. In the city the streets were crowded with squatters. The cries of parents bereft of children, added to the din and turmoil of the soldiery, was like the horror of the Day of Resurrection. The dejected faces of the soldiers beaten in the late engagements added to the general gloom. The viceroy, thoroughly alarmed, concluded a treaty with B√°l√°ji, and on receiving a tribute of £21,000 (Rs. 2,10,000) the Mar√°th√°s withdrew. Meanwhile, in the contest between the princes for the throne of Dehli, prince Muhammad Aâzam Sh√°h was defeated and slain, and prince Muhammad Muâzzam Sh√°h mounted the throne with the title of Bah√°dur Sh√°h. Ibr√°hím Kh√°n was confirmed in the post of viceroy of Gujar√°t, but, fearing that the emperor might be displeased at his concession of tribute to the Mar√°th√°s, he went to Dehli to explain his conduct, and there resigned office.

Gh√°zi-ud-dín Forty-third Viceroy, 1708–1710.In a.d. 1708, in consequence of Ibr√°hím Kh√°n’s resignation, Gh√°zi-ud-dín Kh√°n Bah√°dur Fírúz Jang was appointed forty-third viceroy of Gujar√°t. The leaning of the new emperor towards Shíâh tenets and his order to insert in the Friday sermon the words the lawful successor of the Prophet after the name of ‘Ali, the fourth Khalífah, besides giving general dissatisfaction, caused a small disturbance in Áhmed√°b√°d. On the first Friday on which the sermon was read the Túr√°ni or Turk soldiers publicly called on the preacher to desist on pain of death. The preacher disregarding their threats on the next Friday was pulled down from the pulpit by the Túr√°nis and brained with a mace. In the same year (a.d. 1708), hearing that the representative of Sh√°hi Álam had a copy of a Kurâan written by the Im√°m Áli Taki son of Músa Raz√° (a.d. 810–829), the emperor expressed a wish to obtain a sight of it, and the viceroy sent it to him at M√°ndu in charge of Sayad Âkil and Sal√°bat Kh√°n B√°bi. In a.d. 1709, Shariât Kh√°n, brother of Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n, was appointed minister in place of his brother, who obtained the office of chief K√°zi. Much treasure was sent to the imperial camp by order of the emperor. Ajítsingh of M√°rw√°r now rebelled and recovered Jodhpur. As the emperor wished to visit Ajmír the viceroy of Gujar√°t was directed to join him with his army. At this time the pay of a horseman is said to have been £3 8s. (Rs. 34) and of a footman 8s. (Rs. 4) a month. During his administration Fírúz Jang introduced the practice, which his successors continued, of levying taxes on grain piece-goods and garden produce on his own account, the viceroy’s men by degrees getting into their hands the whole power of collecting. In a.d. 1710, when on tour exacting tribute, the viceroy fell ill at D√°nta and was brought to Áhmed√°b√°d, where he died. As Fírúz Jang had not submitted [297]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Bah√°dur Sh√°h I. Emperor, 1707–1712.
Gh√°zi-ud-dín Forty-third Viceroy, 1708–1710. satisfactory accounts, his property was confiscated, and in a.d. 1711 Am√°nat Kh√°n, governor of Surat, was appointed deputy viceroy with the title of Shah√°mat Kh√°n. When Shah√°mat Kh√°n was levying tribute from the Kadi and Bij√°pur districts, he heard that a Mar√°tha force had advanced to the B√°ba Pi√°rah ford on the Narbada. He at once marched to oppose them, summoning Sayad Áhmed Gíl√°ni, governor of Sorath, to his assistance. When he reached Ankleshvar, the Mar√°th√°s met him, and a battle was fought in which the Mar√°th√°s were defeated. Shah√°mat Kh√°n then proceeded to Surat, and, after providing for its safety returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. In spite of their reverse at Ankleshvar the Mar√°th√°s from this time began to make yearly raids into Gujar√°t.

Jeh√°nd√°r Sh√°h Emperor, 1712–1713.In a.d. 1712, the emperor died, and was succeeded by his son Abúl Fateh Muîzz-ud-dín Jeh√°nd√°r Sh√°h, and Ásif-ud-daulah Asad Kh√°n Bah√°dur was appointed Ásif-ud-Daulah Forty-fourth Viceroy, 1712–13.forty-fourth viceroy of Gujar√°t. As Muhammad Beg Kh√°n, who was then at Kharkol, was a favourite of the new viceroy and through his interest was appointed deputy, he went to Áhmed√°b√°d, and Shah√°mat Kh√°n was transferred to M√°lwa as viceroy. In the meantime Muhammad Beg Kh√°n was appointed governor of Surat, and Sarbuland Kh√°n Bah√°dur was sent to Áhmed√°b√°d as deputy viceroy. On his way to Gujar√°t, Sarbuland Kh√°n was robbed in the S√°gb√°ra wilds to the east of R√°jpípla. On his arrival he promptly marched against the rebellious Kolis of the Chunv√°l and subdued them. At the end of the year, as Farrukhsiyar son of Ázím-us-Sh√°n, second son of the late emperor, was marching with a large army on the capital, Sarbuland Kh√°n returned to Dehli.

Farrukhsiyar Emperor, 1713–1719.This expedition of Farrukhsiyar was successful. He put Jeh√°nd√°r Sh√°h to death and mounted the throne in a.d. 1713. As he had been raised to the throne mainly by the aid of Sayads Husain Áli and Abdullah Kh√°n, the new emperor fell under the power of these nobles. Husain Áli was sent against Ajítsingh of M√°rw√°r, and concluded a treaty with that chief, whereby Ajítsingh engaged to send his son to court and to give his daughter to the emperor in marriage: and the marriage was solemnised in a.d. 1715. In a.d. 1714, shortly after this treaty was concluded, Ajítsingh sent his son Abheysingh to court, and on him in place of one Sayad Áhmed Gíl√°ni was conferred the post of governor of Sorath. Abheysingh remained at court and sent his deputy K√°yath Fatehsingh to Jun√°gaḍh. Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was appointed revenue officer of Surat. After some time he resigned his Surat office and went to court, where on being made superintendent of the shrine of Sheikh Ahmed Khattu he returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. In a.d. 1713 Muhtarim Kh√°n was appointed to succeed him in Surat. Early in a.d. 1714, Shah√°mat Kh√°n Forty-fifth Viceroy, 1713.Shah√°mat Kh√°n, who had been appointed forty-fifth viceroy of Gujar√°t, was superseded by D√°ud Kh√°n Panni as forty-sixth viceroy. The reckless courage of D√°ud Kh√°n Panni was renowned throughout India. His memory survives in the tales and proverbs of the Dakhan. On giving battle he used to show his contempt for his enemies by wearing nothing stronger than a muslin jerkin. So stern was his discipline that none of his Afgh√°n soldiers dared to touch a leaf of the standing crops where they were encamped. When at [298]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Farrukhsiyar Emperor 1713–1719.
D√°ud Kh√°n Panni Forty-sixth Viceroy, 1714–15. Áhmed√°b√°d he was either engaged in scattering the Kolis or in coursing with greyhounds. He preferred life under canvas on the S√°barmati sands to the viceregal surroundings of the Bhadar Palace. His civil work he used to trust to Dakhan Br√°hmans and Pandits. He was much devoted to the use of bhang. D√°ud Kh√°n Panni Forty-sixth Viceroy, 1714–15.Until D√°ud Kh√°n’s arrival Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was appointed viceroy and took charge of the province from Shah√°mat Kh√°n. At this time, on the security of R√°ja Muhkamsingh of N√°gor, a sum of £5000 (Rs. 50,000) was granted to the brother of Durg√°d√°s R√°thoḍ. In a.d. 1714 in Áhmed√°b√°d Harír√°m, the agent of Madan Gop√°l a successful North Indian banker, who came to Áhmed√°b√°d as treasurer with Fírúz Jang, while celebrating the Holi with his friends, seized a Musalm√°n gentleman and handled him with great roughness. Religious Riots in Áhmed√°b√°d, 1714.Aggrieved with this treatment the Musalm√°n complained to a preacher of much eloquence and influence, Mulla Muhammad Áli. The preacher took the Muslim to the Assembly Mosque and sent for Mulla Abdúl Âzíz the chief or leading member of the Sunni Bohora community. He answered the call with a strong party of his men, and on his way was joined by numbers of Musalm√°ns both soldiers and citizens. With cries of ‘Dín’ ‘Dín’ they went to the mosque and carried off the insulted man and the priest and the Bohora leader to the house of the K√°zi Khair-ul-l√°h. The K√°zi closed his doors against the crowd who returned abusing him to the Jewellers’ quarter pillaging and killing as they went. They next swarmed towards Madan Gop√°l’s Haveli in the Jewellers’ quarters. But the Nagarsheth Kapurchand Bhans√°li closed its strong gates and with his Musalm√°n soldiers met the swarm with firearms. The viceroy who was camped at the Sh√°hi B√°gh sent soldiers and under the influence of the leading citizens of both classes the disturbance was quelled. When the particulars of the riots were known in the imperial camp the Hindus, clamouring against Mulla Muhammad Áli and Sheikh Abdúl Âzíz Gujar√°ti, struck business and closed their shops. The emperor ordered mace-bearers to proceed to Gujar√°t and bring the Musalm√°n ringleaders together with the Hindu Nagarsheth Kapurchand Bhans√°li. Some Bohoras at the imperial camp, sending advance news to Áhmed√°b√°d, the Mullah and the Bohora Sheth and after him the Bhans√°li started for the imperial camp. On reaching the camp the Mulla, who was very impressive and eloquent, preached a sermon in the Assembly Mosque and his fame reaching the emperor he was called to court and asked to preach. He and the Sheth were now able to explain their case to the emperor and the Bhans√°li was imprisoned. It is said that the Bhans√°li made the Mulla the medium of his release and that he and the Bohora returned to Gujar√°t while the Mulla remained in honour at court till he died. About the same time a great flood in the S√°barmati did much damage.

Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was now chosen governor of Sorath in place of Abheysingh, and Momín Kh√°n was appointed from Dehli, governor of Surat, and was at the same time placed in charge of Baroda, Broach, Dholka, Petl√°d, and Naḍi√°d. D√°ud Kh√°n the viceroy now went into K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and Nav√°nagar to collect tribute, and on his return to Áhmed√°b√°d, married the daughter of the chief of Halvad in the [299]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Farrukhsiyar Emperor 1713–1719.
D√°ud Kh√°n Panni Forty-sixth Viceroy, 1714–15. Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa sub-division of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. It is related that this lady, who was with child, on hearing of D√°ud Kh√°n’s death cut open her womb and saved the child at the sacrifice of her own life.47 D√°ud Kh√°n, though an excellent soldier and strict disciplinarian failed to distinguish himself as a civil administrator. He introduced Dakhani pandits into official posts, who levied a fee called chithy√°man from landholders and took taxes from the holdings of Sayads and otherwise made themselves unpopular.

About this time Momín Kh√°n, governor of Surat, arrived in Gujar√°t, and placing his deputies in Petl√°d, Dholka, Baroda, and Naḍi√°d, went himself to Surat in a.d. 1715. Here he was opposed by the commandant of the fort, Zia Kh√°n, who was obliged to give way, his subordinate, Sayad K√°sim, being defeated by Fid√°-ud-dín Kh√°n. Further Riots in Áhmed√°b√°d, 1715.At this time much ill-feeling was caused by the plunder by Muhammadan troops of the shops of some Hindu merchants in Áhmed√°b√°d. On this account, and for other reasons, D√°ud Kh√°n was recalled, and Ghazni Kh√°n Jh√°lori was directed to act in his place until the arrival of a new viceroy. Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh Forty-seventh Viceroy, 1715–16.In this year, a.d. 1715, the Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh was appointed forty-seventh viceroy of Gujar√°t, and his son Kunvar Abheysingh was appointed governor of Sorath. Ajítsingh sent Vajer√°j Bhand√°ri to act as his deputy until his arrival, and Fatehsingh K√°yath was chosen deputy governor of Sorath. Perhaps one of the most remarkable appointments of this time was that of Haidar Kúli Kh√°n to be minister as well as military commandant of Baroda, N√°ndod, Arhar-M√°tar in the district48 of Kaira, and of the ports of Surat and Cambay. Haidar Kúli chose an officer to act for him as minister, and after appointing deputies in his different charges himself went to Surat.

The Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh, on reaching Áhmed√°b√°d, appointed Ghazni Kh√°n Jh√°lori governor of P√°lanpur and Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n B√°bi governor of R√°dhanpur.49 During this year an imperial order conferred on Haidar Kúli Kh√°n, Sorath and Gohilv√°ḍ or south-east K√°thi√°v√°ḍa50 then in charge of Fatehsingh, the viceroy’s deputy.51 On receiving this order Haidar sent Sayad Âkil as his deputy, and that officer went to Jambúsar, and, collecting men, set out to join his appointment. He [300]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Farrukhsiyar Emperor 1713–1719.
Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh Forty-seventh Viceroy, 1715–16. first camped at Loli√°nah, where the province of Sorath begins, and from Loli√°nah marched against P√°lit√°na and plundered the town. Disagreement between the Viceroy and Haidar Kúli Kh√°n, 1715.The viceroy, who was by no means well disposed to Haidar Kúli Kh√°n, sent a message that if any injury was done in Sorath he would take vengeance on the aggressors; and as neither Ajítsingh nor Haidar Kúli Kh√°n was of a very compliant temper, civil war was on the point of breaking out. By the help of Sal√°bat Kh√°n B√°bi, the deputy in Gohilv√°ḍa, matters were arranged, and Sayad Âkil returned from Sorath. Haidar was anxious to send Sal√°bat Kh√°n as deputy to Sorath. But as Sal√°bat demanded too high a salary, Raza Kúli, brother of the late governor of Baroda, was chosen. When this officer, with his brother Maâsúm Kúli, reached Amreli Fatehsingh, the viceroy’s deputy, evacuated Jun√°gaḍh. After this Haidar Kúli Kh√°n, in company with K√°zím Beg, governor of Baroda, marched against and defeated the chief of Munjpur, now under R√°dhanpur, who had refused to pay the usual tribute. The viceroy went to Sorath to collect the imperial revenue, and, owing to his excessive demands, met with armed resistance from the J√°m of Nav√°nagar. Finally, the matter of tribute was settled, and after visiting the shrine of Dw√°rka, the viceroy returned to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Kh√°n Daur√°n Nasrat Jang Bah√°dur Forty-eighth Viceroy, 1716–1719.In a.d. 1716, while the viceroy was at Dw√°rka, in consequence of numerous complaints against Ajítsingh and his M√°rw√°ri followers, the emperor sent Sams√°m-ud-daulah Kh√°n Daur√°n Nasrat Jang Bah√°dur as forty-eighth viceroy of Gujar√°t. As it was expected that Ajítsingh would not give up his government without a contest, an army was prepared to compel him to leave. On the arrival of the army Ajítsingh marched straight on Áhmed√°b√°d and encamped at Sarkhej, but Nahar Kh√°n persuaded him to retire to Jodhpur without giving battle. In a.d. 1717, after the departure of Ajítsingh, Haidar Kúli Khan, who had been appointed deputy viceroy, leaving Surat set out for Áhmed√°b√°d. When Haidar arrived at Petl√°d, some of the Áhmed√°b√°d nobles, among whom was Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, went out to meet him. A dispute arose between one of Haidar’s water carriers and a water-carrier in the army of the B√°bi, which increased to a serious affray, which from the camp followers spread to the soldiers and officers, and the B√°bi’s baggage was plundered. Safdar Kh√°n took serious offence, and returning to Áhmed√°b√°d collected his kinsmen and followers and marched against Haidar Kúli Kh√°n. In a battle fought on the following day Safdar Kh√°n was defeated. The other B√°bis escaped to P√°lanpur, and Safdar Kh√°n, who in the first instance had fled to Atarsumba, joined his party at P√°lanpur. Muhammad Fírúz Jh√°lori, governor of P√°lanpur, with the title of Ghazni Kh√°n, afterwards succeeded in reconciling the B√°bis and Haidar Kúli Kh√°n. Famine, 1719.a.d. 1719 was a year of great famine. Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n, who had filled so many appointments in Gujar√°t, went to court, and was made governor of Sorath. Haidar Kúli Kh√°n now marched against the Mahi Kolis. In the meantime news was received of the appointment of a new viceroy, and Ghazni Kh√°n, governor of P√°lanpur, was ordered to stay at Áhmed√°b√°d for the defence of the city. [301]


Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh Forty-ninth Viceroy, 1719–1721. Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.Early in a.d. 1719, the emperor Farrûkhsiyar was deposed and put to death by the Sayads; and a prince named Rafíâ-ud-Daraj√°t, a grandson of the emperor, was raised to the throne. Rafíâ-ud-Daraj√°t was put to death by the Sayads after a reign of three months, and his brother Rafíâ-ud-daulah, who succeeded him, also died after a few days’ reign. The Sayads then raised to the throne prince Raushan Akhtar with the title of Muhammad Sh√°h. Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh Forty-ninth Viceroy, 1719–1721.After the murder of Farrûkhsiyar, the most powerful vassal in the neighbourhood of Delhi was Ajítsingh of M√°rw√°r. To win him to their side the Sayads granted him the viceroyalty of Gujar√°t, and Míhr Áli Kh√°n was appointed to act for him until his arrival, while Muhammad Bah√°dur B√°bi, son of Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, was placed in charge of the police of the district immediately round Áhmed√°b√°d. Shortly after, through the influence of the Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh, N√°hir Kh√°n superseded Míhr Áli Kh√°n as deputy viceroy. N√°hir Kh√°n was also appointed to the charge of Dholka Dohad and Petl√°d, and made superintendent of customs. About this time the head tax was repealed, and orders were issued that its levy in Gujar√°t should cease.

Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r at Songaḍ, 1719.In the same year, a.d. 1719, Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r marched on Surat with a large army and defeated the imperial troops commanded by Sayad Âkil and Muhammad Pan√°h, the latter commander being taken prisoner and forced to pay a heavy ransom. Píl√°ji, finding Gujar√°t an easy prey, made frequent incursions, and taking Songaḍ in the extreme south-east established himself there. Míhr Áli Kh√°n, who had been acting for N√°hir Kh√°n, marched against and subdued the Kolis, who were committing piracy in the Mahi estuary. Decay of Imperial Power, 1720.From this year Mughal rule in Gujar√°t was doomed. Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r was established at Songaḍ, and in the anarchy that ensued, the great Gujar√°t houses of the B√°bis and Jh√°loris, as well as the newly arrived Momín Kh√°n, turned their thoughts to independence. Ajítsingh so hated Muhammadan rule that he secretly favoured the Mar√°th√°s, and strove to establish his own authority over such portions of Gujar√°t as bordered on M√°rw√°r. In after years, Sarbuland Kh√°n made a vigorous attempt to reassert imperial dominion, but the seeds of dissolution were sown and efforts at recovery were vain.

In a.d. 1720, Ajítsingh the viceroy sent Anopsingh Bhand√°ri to Gujar√°t as his deputy. In this year Niz√°m-ul-Mulk, viceroy of Ujjain, was superseded by Sayad Dil√°war Kh√°n. While Dil√°war Kh√°n was yet on the M√°lwa frontiers the Niz√°m desirous of possessing himself of the Dakhan and its resources retired to Burh√°npur pursued by Sayad Dil√°war Kh√°n, who giving battle was killed, the Niz√°m retiring to Aurang√°b√°d in the Dakhan. Álam Áli Kh√°n, deputy viceroy of the Dakhan, was directed to march against him, while from north Gujar√°t Anopsingh Bhand√°ri was ordered to send 10,000 horse to Surat, and N√°hir Kh√°n, the deputy viceroy, was instructed to proceed thither in person. The Niz√°m and Álam Áli Kh√°n met near B√°l√°pur in the Ber√°rs and a battle was fought in which the Niz√°m was successful and Álam Kh√°n was slain. At this time Anopsingh Bhand√°ri committed many oppressive acts, of which the [302]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh Forty-ninth Viceroy, 1719–1721. chief was the murder of Kapurchand Bhans√°li, the leading merchant of Áhmed√°b√°d. The cause of Kapurchand’s murder was that he had hired a number of armed retainers who used to oppose the Bhand√°ri’s orders and set free people unjustly imprisoned by him. To remove this meddler from his way the Bhand√°ri got him assassinated. Niz√°m-ul-Mulk Prime Minister, of the Empire, 1721.In a.d. 1721, Niz√°m-ul-Mulk was appointed prime minister of the empire, Abdúl Hamíd Kh√°n was recalled from Sorath, and in his stead Asad Kuli Kh√°n, with the title of Amir-ul-Umara, was appointed governor of Sorath and sent Muhammad Sharíf Kh√°n into Sorath as his deputy.

Haidar Kúli Kh√°n Fiftieth Viceroy, 1721–22.In a.d. 1721, in conjunction with Muhammad Amín and Sa√°dat Kh√°n, Haidar Kúli Kh√°n freed the emperor from the tyranny of the Sayads, and was rewarded with the title of Muîz-ud-daulah Haidar Kúli Kh√°n Bah√°dur Zafar Jang and the viceroyalty of Gujar√°t. He obtained the appointment of minister for his brother Jaâfar Kúli Kh√°n. Maâsúm Kúli Kh√°n was dignified by the title of Shuj√°ât Kh√°n Bah√°dur and appointed deputy viceroy. As soon as this change was notified, the people of Áhmed√°b√°d, who were discontented with the rule of Anopsingh, attacked his palace, the Bhadar, and he escaped with difficulty. Disorder in Áhmed√°b√°d, 1721.In consequence of the enmity between Haidar Kúli Kh√°n and the M√°rw√°ris, Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, the deputy viceroy, attacked the house of N√°hir Kh√°n who had been Ajítsingh’s minister, and forced him to pay £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh) and leave the city. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n next interfered with the lands of Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, the deputy governor of Godhra, and his brothers. On one of the brothers repairing to Dehli and remonstrating, Haidar Kúli, who, above all things, was a Muhammadan and anxious to strengthen himself with the Muhammadan nobility of Gujar√°t, restored their lands to the B√°bis. In consequence of this decision ill-feeling sprung up between Shuj√°ât Kh√°n and the B√°bis, and when Shuj√°ât Kh√°n went to exact tribute he forced Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, governor of Kaira, to pay a special fine of £1000 (Rs. 10,000). Shortly after one of the viceroy’s officers, K√°sím Áli Kh√°n, while employed against the Kolis of that part of the country, was killed at Peth√°pur. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n advanced, and revenged K√°sím Áli’s death by burning the town. Next, he passed into Sorath, and after exacting tribute, crossed to Kachh. The chief opposed him, and in the fight that followed was beaten and forced to pay about £22,500 (Rs. 2¼ l√°khs).52 In a.d. 1721, a Sayad was sent to Sorath as deputy governor in place of Muhammad Sharíf, and Haidar Kúli was appointed governor of Kadi, the Chúnv√°l, and Halvad (called Muhammadnagar), and put in charge of Thar√°d, Arjanpur, Bh√°mn√°rli, Peth√°pur, and Kher√°lu in place of Vakhatsingh, son of the Mah√°r√°ja Ajítsingh.

Leaves Dehli for Gujar√°t, 1722.Early in a.d. 1722, Niz√°m-ul-Mulk took up the office of prime minister of the empire, to which he had been appointed in the previous year. Strenuous efforts were made to embroil him with Haidar Kúli [303]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Haidar Kúli Kh√°n Fiftieth Viceroy, 1721–22. Kh√°n, as the Niz√°m’s austerity and craft were a source of not less anxiety to the Dehli court than Haidar Kúli’s more daring and restless ambition. Haidar Kúli Kh√°n, unable to contend with the Niz√°m, left Dehli and retired to Gujar√°t. On his way the villagers of Dabh√°li opposed him killing one of his chief men named Alif Beg Kh√°n. Haidar burned the village and put all the people to death, a severity which caused such terror that throughout his rule no difficulty was experienced in realizing tribute or in keeping the roads safe. About this time, among other changes, Muhammad Bah√°dúr, son of Sal√°bat Kh√°n B√°bi, was placed in charge of S√°dra and Vírpur, with the title of Sher Kh√°n. Shortly after his arrival the viceroy marched against and subdued the rebellious Kolis of the Chunv√°l, appointing Rustam Áli Kh√°n his governor there. Then, returning to Áhmed√°b√°d, he took up his residence in the Bhadra. Shows signs of Independence and is Recalled, 1722.There is little doubt that at this time Haidar Kúli aimed at bringing all Gujar√°t under his rule. He seized the imperial horses which passed through Áhmed√°b√°d on their way to Dehli, and confiscated many estates and gave them to his own men. On his way to enforce tribute from the Dungarpúr chiefs, he levied £8000 (Rs. 80,000) from Lun√°v√°ḍa. Through the mediation of the Udepur R√°na, and as he agreed to pay a tribute of £10,000 (1 l√°kh of rupees), the R√°val of Dungarpur escaped. Haidar Kúli next proceeded to Bij√°pur, north of Áhmed√°b√°d, but hearing that the emperor was displeased at his assumption of the power of giving and changing grants of land, he returned to Áhmed√°b√°d and restored several estates which he had confiscated. Niz√°m-ul-Mulk Fifty-first Viceroy, 1722.The court continued to distrust him, and at the close of a.d. 1722 appointed Jumlat-ul-Mulk Niz√°m-ul-Mulk fifty-first viceroy.

Haidar Kúli Kh√°n, finding himself no match for the Niz√°m, was induced to retire quietly, and accordingly left Gujar√°t by way of Dungarpur. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n and Rustam Áli Kh√°n accompanied him as far as Dungarpúr, and then returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. In the meantime the Niz√°m had reached Ujjain, and thence directed Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi to carry on the government till he should arrive, appointing at the same time his uncle H√°mid Kh√°n Deputy Viceroy; Momín Kh√°n Governor of Surat, 1722.H√°mid Kh√°n as deputy viceroy and Fidwi Kh√°n as minister. Subsequently the Niz√°m came to Gujar√°t and chose officers of his own for places of trust, the chief of whom was Momín Kh√°n, who was appointed governor of Surat. The Niz√°m then returned to Dehli, but, after a short time, disgusted with his treatment at court, he retired to the Dakhan, where, making Haidar√°b√°d his capital, he gradually began to act as an independent ruler. Meanwhile in Gujar√°t dissensions sprang up between H√°mid Kh√°n and other officers, but matters were arranged without any outbreak of hostility. Tribute was exacted from the chiefs on the banks of the V√°trak and from Modhera an unruly Koli village was burned down, and garrisons were placed in the Koli country. In a.d. 1723 Rustam Áli Kh√°n and Shuj√°ât Kh√°n were ordered from Dehli to march on Jodhpur, which they captured and plundered, and then returned to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Increase of Mar√°tha Power, 1723.In a.d. 1723 Pil√°ji G√°ikw√°r, who had been long hovering on the frontier, marched on Surat and was opposed by Momín Kh√°n, whom he defeated. After levying contributions from the surrounding country, [304]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. he returned to his head-quarters at Songad, and from this overran a considerable portion of the Surat territory, building several forts in the R√°jpípla country. At the same time K√°nt√°ji Kadam B√°nde, invading Gujar√°t from the side of Dohad, began to levy fixed contributions. Though before this occasional demands had often been made, a.d. 1723 was the first year in which the Mar√°th√°s imposed a regular tribute on Gujar√°t. Momín Kh√°n was now appointed provincial minister, and Rustam Áli Kh√°n succeeded him as revenue officer of Surat, and, as the Niz√°m had gone to the Dakhan without the emperor’s leave, Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730.Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk Sarbuland Kh√°n Bah√°dur Dil√°war Jang was appointed fifty-second viceroy of Gujar√°t. Appoints Shuj√°ât Kh√°n his Deputy.He selected Shuj√°ât Kh√°n as his deputy, and made other arrangements for the government of the province. H√°mid Kh√°n, uncle and deputy of the Niz√°m, prepared to oppose Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, but through the intervention of B√°bis Sal√°bat Kh√°n, Safdar Kh√°n, and Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, H√°mid Kh√°n evacuated the Bhadra, and withdrew to Dohad. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n now went to collect tribute, leaving Ibr√°hím Kúli Kh√°n at Áhmed√°b√°d, while R√°mr√°i was posted at Mahudha in Kaira, with orders to watch the movements of H√°mid Kh√°n. As the viceroy was in need of money, he farmed to one Jívan Jugal the districts of Jambúsar, Makbúl√°bad or Ámod about twenty-two miles north of Broach, Dholka, and Broach. In a.d. 1724, he came to Áhmed√°b√°d with Áli Muhammad Kh√°n father of the author of the Mir√°t-i-Áhmedi, as his private minister.

Niz√°m-ul-Mulk and Sarbuland Kh√°n.Rustam Áli, governor of Surat, having succeeded twice or thrice in defeating the Mar√°th√°s under Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r, now offered, in conjunction with his brother Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, that if 20,000 men were placed under their orders, they would march against the Niz√°m. The emperor accepted this offer, allowing Rustam Áli to draw on the Surat treasury to the extent of £20,000 (Rs. 2 l√°khs). Rustam Áli accordingly, with the aid of Áhmed Kúli his brother’s son, equipped an army. In the meantime the Niz√°m was not idle. He promised to K√°nt√°ji Kadam B√°nde a one-fourth share of the revenue of Gujar√°t, provided he should be able, in concert with H√°mid Kh√°n, to re-conquer the province from Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, who was now at Kadi, instead of following the advice of his minister and carefully watching H√°mid Kh√°n’s movements from Kapadvanj, went to a distant part of the province. H√°mid Kh√°n seeing his opportunity, united his forces with those of K√°nt√°ji Kadam, and marched to Kapadvanj. Sarbuland Kh√°n’s Deputy Defeated, 1724.Shuj√°ât Kh√°n hearing of this, advanced towards Áhmed√°b√°d and encamped at Dabhora under Bahyal, eighteen miles east of Áhmed√°b√°d and thence proceeded to Mota Medra, about six miles east of the capital. When he came so near Áhmed√°b√°d, many of his soldiers went without leave into the city to visit their families. The Mar√°th√°s attacked his rear guard, and his men giving way took to flight. H√°mid Kh√°n seeing that Shuj√°ât Kh√°n had but a small force, marched between him and the capital. A battle was fought, in which Shuj√°ât Kh√°n was slain, and his two sons Hasan Kúli and Mustafa Kúli were taken prisoners. Shuj√°ât Kh√°n’s head was cut off and sent to Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi, to be sent to Ibr√°hím Kúli his son, who was doing duty as commandant at Áhmed√°b√°d. H√°mid Kh√°n took up his quarters in [305]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. the Sh√°hi B√°gh, and got possession of all Áhmed√°b√°d except the city. H√°mid Kh√°n now sent a message to the emperor, that the Mar√°th√°s had been successful in defeating Shuj√°ât Kh√°n and conquering Gujar√°t, but that he had defended Áhmed√°b√°d against them. The emperor sent him a dress of honour, but after a few days discovered that H√°mid’s message was false. The Mar√°th√°s now marched through the country, collecting their chauth or one-fourth and their sardeshmukhi or one-tenth shares of the revenue. K√°nt√°ji went to Víramg√°m and besieged the town, but on the promise of one of the chief inhabitants to raise a sum of £35,000 (Rs. 3½ l√°khs) the Mar√°th√°s retired. H√°mid Kh√°n who was now independent began to bestow lands and districts many of which remained with the grantees and were never recovered by future governors. Ibr√°hím Kúli, son of Shuj√°ât Kh√°n, in revenge for his father’s death, determined to assassinate H√°mid Kh√°n. The attempt failed. H√°mid Kh√°n escaped and Ibr√°hím Kúli was slain.

The Mar√°th√°s engaged as Allies.Rustam Áli Kh√°n, governor of Surat, in the hope of being revenged on H√°mid Kh√°n, invited the aid of Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r, and it was agreed that they should meet on the north bank of the Narbada. Píl√°ji promised to aid Rustam Kh√°n, and the allied armies, crossing the Mahi, encamped at Aras in the plain between Anand and the Mahi. H√°mid Kh√°n, accompanied by Mír Nathu, Muhammad Sal√°bat Rohila, and K√°nt√°ji Kadam, marched to oppose Rustam Kh√°n. H√°mid Kh√°n also entered into secret negotiations with Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r, who resolved to remain neutral and side with the conqueror. Battle of Ar√°s. H√°mid Kh√°n defeated by Rustam Áli, 1723.A battle was fought, in which, though Pil√°ji took no part, H√°mid Kh√°n was defeated and put to flight, and Mír Nathu was killed. After the fight Rustam Áli remained on the field of battle and liberated his nephews, plundering H√°mid Kh√°n’s camp. Píl√°ji plundered Rustam Áli’s camp and then moved off, while K√°nt√°ji carried away what was left in the camp of H√°mid Kh√°n. H√°mid Kh√°n reproached K√°nt√°ji for his inactivity; but he pleaded in excuse that he was watching the mode of warfare amongst Muhammadans, and promised to attack Rustam Áli shortly. Mar√°th√°s join H√°mid Kh√°n against Rustam Áli.Now, as the Mar√°th√°s really desired to ruin Rustam Áli, who was their bitter foe, they after a few days surrounded him and cut off his supplies. Rustam Áli stood a blockade of eight days, and then forced his way through his enemies and went to N√°p√°d, about fourteen miles west of the V√°sad railway station in the Anand sub-division of the Kaira district, and thence through Kalamsar to N√°pa or N√°ba under Petl√°d. The Mar√°th√°s still pursuing Rustam Áli retired to Vasu under Petl√°d, ten miles east of Naḍi√°d and about twenty-five miles south of Áhmed√°b√°d, where he gave battle, and by a furious charge broke the Mar√°tha line. The Mar√°th√°s rallied, and Rustam Áli and his men were defeated, Rustam Áli being slain and his nephews again taken prisoners. Rustam was buried on the field of battle and his head sent to Áhmed√°b√°d.

H√°mid Kh√°n returned to Áhmed√°b√°d with the Mar√°th√°s, who saw that their only means of effecting a permanent footing in the province was by supporting him. H√°mid Kh√°n then assigned a one-fourth share of the revenue of the territory north of the Mahi to K√°nt√°ji, and to Píl√°ji a corresponding interest in the territory south of the Mahi, [306]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. including Surat and Baroda. After this H√°mid Kh√°n acted tyrannically. He extorted large sums from the rich, and poisoned the two sons of Shuj√°ât Kh√°n. When the news of K√°nt√°ji’s and Píl√°ji’s success reached the Dakhan, Trimbakr√°v Dh√°b√°de, son of Khander√°v Sen√°pati, came with a large army and laid siege to Cambay. While the siege was being pressed a quarrel among the Mar√°tha leaders culminated in strife and bloodshed. Trimbakr√°v Sen√°pati was wounded and the Mar√°tha army had to disperse and retire.53 Sal√°bat Kh√°n, leaving Áhmed√°b√°d, went to Víramg√°m, and after some time, placing his nephew at Víramg√°m, he went into Gohilv√°ḍa. When the news of the defeat and death of Rustam Áli reached Dehli, the emperor ordered Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk sent against the Mar√°th√°s, 1725.Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk to take a strong army and proceed in person to Gujar√°t and expel H√°mid Kh√°n and the Mar√°th√°s. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk marched on Gujar√°t with a large army, assisted by Mah√°r√°ja Abheysingh of Jodhpur, Chatarsingh R√°ja of Narwar in Bundelkhand, Gandrapsingh, and the Mah√°r√°na of Udepur. On his arrival at Ajmír Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk was received by his private minister Áli Muhammad Kh√°n, who afterwards joined Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n B√°bi in R√°dhanpur, and united their troops with those under Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk. At that time Sal√°bat Kh√°n was removed from his government, and Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi died. In obedience to the imperial order, Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk marched from Ajmír and came to the Gujar√°t frontier. On his approach H√°mid Kh√°n returned to Áhmed√°b√°d. He placed Rúpsingh and Sard√°r Muhammad Ghorni in charge of the city and himself withdrew to Mehmúd√°b√°d. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk now sent Sheikh Alíy√°r in advance with an army against Áhmed√°b√°d. When Sheikh Alíy√°r arrived before the city, Muhammad Ghorni, who was dissatisfied with H√°mid Kh√°n for bringing in the Mar√°th√°s, persuaded Rúpsingh to fly. H√°mid Kh√°n and other Mar√°th√°s Retire.In the meantime Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk with the main body of his forces reached Sidhpur. H√°mid Kh√°n, accompanied by a detachment of Mar√°tha horse, now returned to Áhmed√°b√°d; but Muhammad Ghorni closed the gates, and would not suffer him to enter the city. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk marched to Mes√°na. About this time Áli Muhammad Kh√°n, the father of the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, who was now with Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk at Mes√°na, advised him to conciliate the influential Muhammadan family of B√°bi. Under his advice, Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi was appointed governor of Víramg√°m, and Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n governor of P√°tan. Shortly afterwards Murlidhard√°s, the Gujar√°ti minister of H√°mid Kh√°n, deserted his master’s declining cause. When Kant√°ji heard that Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk had arrived at Peth√°pur, only eighteen miles from Áhmed√°b√°d, he retired to Mehmúd√°b√°d. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk enters Áhmed√°b√°d, 1725.Before the close of a.d. 1725, Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk reached Áhmed√°b√°d, where he was well received by the officials and merchants. [307]


Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. H√°mid Kh√°n and Kant√°ji, who had by this time reached the banks of the Mahi, were now joined by Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r. The Mar√°tha leaders, seeing that the only way to preserve their footing in the province was to espouse the cause of H√°mid Kh√°n, united their forces with his, and prepared to march on Áhmed√°b√°d. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk deputed his son Kh√°nahz√°d Kh√°n with an army to oppose them, and made several appointments, among other changes raising Áli Muhammad Kh√°n to the post of minister. Defeat of the Mar√°th√°s at Sojitra and Kapadvanj, 1725.Kh√°nahz√°d Kh√°n met the Mar√°th√°s near Sojitra, about ten miles north-west of Petl√°d, and defeated them, pursuing them as far as the Mahi. Then, returning, he was reinforced by his brother Sh√°h Naw√°z Kh√°n, and marched against the Mar√°th√°s, who were encamped at Kapadvanj. Another battle was fought, and the Mar√°th√°s were again defeated and pursued as far as the hills of Áli-Mohan now Chhota Udepur in the extreme east of the province. Kh√°nahz√°d Kh√°n now appointed Hasan-ud-dín governor of Baroda, Broach, Jambúsar, and Makbul√°b√°d. Mar√°tha Expedition against Vadnagar, 1725.Meanwhile Ant√°ji Bh√°skar, a Mar√°tha noble, entering Gujar√°t from the side of Ídar, laid siege to the town of Vadnagar, which, according to the old Gujar√°t proverb, with Umreth in the Kaira district, are the two golden feathers of the kingdom of Gujar√°t. Vadnagar was inhabited by wealthy Br√°hmans of the N√°gar caste who prayed Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk to march to their relief; but as both his sons were in pursuit of the other Mar√°tha bands defeated at Kapadvanj, the viceroy had no troops to spare from the Áhmed√°b√°d garrison. The N√°gars accordingly, seeing no prospect of help, paid a sum of £40,000 (Rs. 4 l√°khs) and Ant√°ji Bh√°skar retired. Kant√°ji and Píl√°ji, encouraged by this raid of Ant√°ji’s, entered Gujar√°t from different quarters. K√°nt√°ji again laid siege to Vadnagar. The N√°gars, unable to pay the contribution demanded, leaving their property fled and K√°nt√°ji in his attempts to unearth the buried treasure burned down the town. Shortly afterwards Umreth in the Kaira district suffered a similar fate at the hands of K√°nt√°ji. In one of his raids Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r advancing as far as Baroda was met by Kh√°nahz√°d Kh√°n, the son of the viceroy. Distrusting the issue of a battle Píl√°ji fled to Cambay, and from Cambay withdrew to Sorath. For these services the emperor raised Kh√°nahz√°d Kh√°n to the rank of a noble, with the title Gh√°lib Jang. About this time Áli Muhammad Kh√°n was dismissed from the post of minister, and in his stead first Muhammad Sayad Beg and afterwards Muhammad Sulaim√°n were appointed. Not long afterwards Áli Muhammad Kh√°n was again entrusted with a command and raised to be governor of Dholka.

Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk pays the Mar√°tha Tribute, 1726.The Mar√°th√°s retired to the Dakhan, but, returning in a.d. 1726, compelled Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk to confirm his predecessor’s grants in their favour. The emperor refused to acknowledge any cessions of revenue to the Mar√°th√°s; and the viceroy, hard pressed for money, unable to obtain support from the court and receiving little help from his impoverished districts, was forced to impose fresh taxes on the citizens of Áhmed√°b√°d, and at the same time to send an army to collect their tribute from the Mahi chiefs. As part of the agreement between Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk and the Mar√°tha chiefs Píl√°ji was to receive a share in the [308]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. revenue of the districts south of the Mahi. But Peshwa B√°jir√°v Bal√°l, to whom, as agent of his rival Khander√°v D√°bh√°de, Píl√°ji was obnoxious, sent Ud√°ji Pav√°r to drive Píl√°ji away. In this Ud√°ji was successful, and defeating Píl√°ji forced him to seek the aid of K√°nt√°ji. K√°nt√°ji, perceiving that if the Peshwa became supreme his own independence would suffer, joined Píl√°ji, and marching together upon Baroda they endeavoured, but without success, to prevent the Musalm√°n governor Sadr-ud-dín Kh√°n from entering the city. About this time want of funds forced Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk to sell the greater part of the Dholka district to different landholders.

Alliance with the Peshwa, 1727.In the following year, a.d. 1727, B√°jir√°v Peshwa began to negotiate with Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk, undertaking that if the one-fourth and one-tenth shares in the revenue of the province were guaranteed to him, he would protect Gujar√°t from other invaders. Though he did not consent to these proposals, the viceroy so far accepted the alliance of the Peshwa as to allow the governor of Baroda to aid Ud√°ji Pav√°r against Píl√°ji. Pil√°ji G√°ikw√°r obtains Baroda and Dabhoi, 1727.Pil√°ji and K√°nt√°ji outmanœuvred Ud√°ji and prevented him from effecting a junction with the governor of Baroda, who in the end was forced to abandon both that city and the stronghold of Dabhoi, while Ud√°ji retired to M√°lwa. Píl√°ji G√°ikw√°r now obtained possession of Baroda. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk, still sorely pressed for funds, marched into Sorath to exact tribute. On reaching Víramg√°m, Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, on behalf of the J√°m of Nav√°nagar, presented the viceroy with £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh), and for this service was rewarded with the gift of an elephant. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk then marched against Chh√°ya, the capital of the chief of Porbandar in the south-west of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. This chief, by putting to sea, hoped to escape the payment of tribute. But on hearing that the viceroy proposed to annex his territory and appoint an officer to govern it, he returned and agreed to pay a tribute of £4000 (Rs. 40,000).54 On his way back to Áhmed√°b√°d, Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk passed through Halvad in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa, and there married the daughter of Jh√°la Prat√°psingh, the chief of that district, whom he accordingly exempted from the payment of tribute. About this time the viceroy received orders from the emperor to restore certain land which he had confiscated, and as he neglected to obey, certain estates of his in the Panj√°b were resumed. Capture of Ch√°mp√°ner by the Mar√°th√°s, 1728.In the meantime Krishn√°ji, foster son of K√°nt√°ji, made a sudden attack upon Ch√°mp√°ner and captured that fortress, and from that time K√°nt√°ji’s agents remained permanently in Gujar√°t to collect his share of the tribute.

In a.d. 1728 the minister Momín Kh√°n died, and in his place the emperor selected Momín Kh√°n’s brother Abd-ul-Ghani Kh√°n. About this time Asad Áli, governor of Jun√°gaḍh, also died, and on his deathbed appointed Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi deputy governor of that fortress. Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n sent his son Sher Kh√°n B√°bi to act on his behalf. When the emperor heard of the death of Asad Áli, he appointed Ghul√°m Muhy-ud-dín Kh√°n, son of the late Asad Áli, governor. Ghul√°m Muhy-ud-dín did not proceed to Jun√°gaḍh but continued Sher Kh√°n B√°bi as his deputy. Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk, now [309]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. perceiving that neither Píl√°ji nor K√°nt√°ji afforded any protection to Gujar√°t, but rather pillaged it, closed with the offers of B√°jir√°v Peshwa, and Grant of Tribute to the Peshwa, 1729.in a.d. 1729 formally granted to him the one-fourth and one-tenth shares of the revenue of the province. The Peshwa accordingly sent his brother Chimn√°jir√°v to collect the tribute. Chimn√°ji plundered Dholka and the country near Ch√°mp√°ner, while Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk exacted tribute from the chiefs on the banks of the V√°trak. K√°nt√°ji now entered Gujar√°t and prepared for war in case Chimn√°ji and the viceroy should unite against him. His movements were not interfered with, and after collecting his share of the tribute, he retired to Sorath. The viceroy now marched against the Kolis, and after destroying many of them together with their wives and children, returned to Áhmed√°b√°d by way of Modasa and Ahmednagar. Ghul√°m Muhy-ud-dín Kh√°n, governor of Jun√°gaḍh, who had not yet proceeded to his command, appointed a second deputy. Through the influence of the viceroy this appointment was not confirmed, and instead Sher Kh√°n B√°bi, son of Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n, was placed in charge of that fortress.

Mulla Muhammad Áli raises a Disturbance at Surat, 1729.In Surat the year a.d. 1729 was marked by a severe flood in the T√°pti and by a somewhat serious local disturbance. The chief cause of the disturbance was Mulla Muhammad Áli, a rich Musalm√°n trader of Surat. This man who, as Ûmda-tut-tujj√°r or chief of the merchants, had already a special rank in the city, was tempted to take advantage of the disorders of the time to raise himself to the position of an independent ruler. With this object he chose as his head-quarters the island of Píram in the Gulf of Cambay, near the port of Gogha, and there spent considerable sums in strengthening the island and tempting settlers to place themselves under his protection. As Píram was not popular Mulla Muhammad fixed on the village of Athva, on the left bank of the T√°pti, about twelve miles from its mouth. Here he began to build a fort, but was ordered to desist by Sohr√°b Kh√°n, the governor of Surat, from which city the proposed stronghold was only three miles distant. Mulla Muhammad so far from obeying, persuaded Beglar-Beg Kh√°n the commander of the fort of Surat to side with him. Accordingly, next day, Beglar-Beg Kh√°n bombarded the governor Sohr√°b Kh√°n’s residence, proclaiming that his own brother Teghbeg Kh√°n was appointed governor of Surat. In the end Mulla Muhammad Áli induced the chief merchants of the city to pray for the removal of Sohr√°b who pending receipt of orders from the emperor was made to hand over his official residence in the city to Teg-Beg Kh√°n.

Naḍi√°d given in Farm, 1729.In the same year, a.d. 1729, Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n B√°bi was chosen governor of Petl√°d, Áli Muhammad Kh√°n was made collector of Áhmed√°b√°d, and Áli Muhammad’s son, the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi and his brother were appointed governor and superintendent of the customs of that district. Áli Muhammad Kh√°n shortly resigned and was succeeded by Rú-ín Kh√°n. At this time Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n B√°bi, while punishing the Kolis of B√°lor, probably Bh√°tod about fifteen miles east of Broach, was killed by a man of that tribe, and in revenge for his death the town of B√°lor was plundered. On the death of Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, at the request of Sal√°bat Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, his eldest son Kam√°l-ud-dín Kh√°n B√°bi received the districts of [310]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Sarbuland Kh√°n Fifty-second Viceroy, 1723–1730. Sami and Munjpur and the title of Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n. At the same time the second son, Muhammad Anwar, with the title of Safdar Kh√°n, was appointed to the government of R√°dhanpur. The viceroy now went to Naḍi√°d, where R√°i Kishand√°s, agent of Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, received the district of Petl√°d in farm. From Naḍi√°d Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk went to collect tribute from Sarḍ√°rsingh, the chief of Bh√°darva in the Rewa K√°ntha about fifteen miles north of Baroda, on the banks of the Mahi, who, after some fighting, agreed to pay a sum of £2000 (Rs. 20,000). On his way back to Áhmed√°b√°d the viceroy levied tribute from the chief of Umeta, fifteen miles west of Baroda. As R√°i Kishand√°s failed to pay the sum agreed on for the farm of Petl√°d, an order was issued for his imprisonment. To save himself from the indignity he committed suicide.

Athva Fort, 1730.When K√°nt√°ji returned from Sorath he camped at S√°nand, and his advanced guard carried off some of the viceroy’s elephants which were grazing there. Men were sent in pursuit, but in vain, and the Mar√°th√°s escaped. Meanwhile, at Surat, Mulla Muhammad Áli continued to build the fort at Athva. At last his accomplice, Beglar-Beg Kh√°n the commander of the Surat fort, began to perceive that if the Athva fort were completed the Mulla would be in a position to obstruct the trade of the port of Surat. He consequently ordered him to stop building. In spite of this the Mulla succeeded in persuading Sohr√°b Kh√°n to allow him to go on with his fort promising in return to get him confirmed as governor of Surat. Sohr√°b Kh√°n agreed, and the fort was completed, and Sohr√°b Kh√°n was duly appointed governor. As the fort was immediately below Surat the revenue of Surat was greatly diminished, and Sohr√°b Kh√°n, when it was too late, saw his mistake.

The Viceroy in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and Kachh, 1730.In a.d. 1730 Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk went into Gohilv√°ḍa in south-east K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and levied tribute from Bh√°vsingh, chief of Sihor; thence he proceeded to M√°dhupur, a town under Porbandar, and laid it waste. While engaged at M√°dhupur, Momín Kh√°n, son-in-law of the late Momín Kh√°n, owing to some misunderstanding with the viceroy suddenly set out for Áhmed√°b√°d and from Áhmed√°b√°d proceeded to Ágra. The viceroy now marched in the direction of Kachh and refusing the offer of a yearly tribute of about £33,000 (10,00,000 mahmúdis), advanced against Bhúj. He experienced great difficulty in crossing the Ran, and as the R√°o had cut off all supplies, and as at the same time news arrived of disturbances in Áhmed√°b√°d, he was obliged, after a month and a half, to retire to R√°dhanpur. Riots at Áhmed√°b√°d.The author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi was ordered to suppress the Áhmed√°b√°d riots, which had arisen out of the levy of some fresh taxes, and was invested with the title of Hasan Muhammad Kh√°n. In this year Udaikaran, Des√°i of Víramg√°m, was murdered by a Kasb√°ti55 of that town named Áli, and Sal√°b√°t Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, who was sent to investigate this murder, died on his way at P√°ldi, a village on the right bank of the S√°barmati opposite to Áhmed√°b√°d.

Mah√°r√°ja Abheysingh Fifty-third Viceroy, 1730–1733.News was now (a.d. 1730) received that Mah√°r√°ja Abheysingh of Jodhpur had been appointed viceroy and had reached P√°lanpur. [311]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Muhammad Sh√°h Emperor, 1721–1748.
Mah√°r√°ja Abheysingh Fifty-third Viceroy, 1730–1733. The friends of order endeavoured to arrange a peaceable transfer between the Mah√°r√°ja and the late viceroy, but Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk Resists the New Viceroy.Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk determined to try the chances of war, and prepared for resistance. At this time Mír Ism√°íl, deputy of Ghul√°m Muhy-ud-dín Kh√°n, arrived and took charge of the government of Jun√°gaḍh from Sher Kh√°n B√°bi. Mah√°r√°ja Abheysingh, after making various appointments, set out with his brother Vakhatsingh and 20,000 men to take over the government of Gujar√°t. When he reached P√°lanpur and saw that Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk was determined on resistance, he sent an order to Sard√°r Muhammad Ghorni appointing him his minister and directing him to take possession of the city of Áhmed√°b√°d and drive out the late viceroy. As Sard√°r Muhammad was not strong enough to carry out these orders he awaited the Mah√°r√°ja’s arrival. When the Mah√°r√°ja reached Sidhpur he was joined by Safdar Kh√°n B√°bi and Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n B√°bi from R√°dhanpur. They then advanced together to Ad√°laj, distant only about eight miles from the capital, their army increasing daily. Battle of Ad√°laj; the Mah√°r√°ja defeated by Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk, 1730.Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk was already encamped between Ad√°laj and the city, and on the approach of the Mah√°r√°ja a battle was fought in which the Mah√°r√°ja was defeated. Abheysingh changed his position, and another and bloodier engagement took place, in which both sides tried to kill the opposing commander. But as both Mub√°riz-ul-Mulk and the Mah√°r√°ja fought disguised as common soldiers, neither party succeeded.
