Towards the close of the year Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n started from Áhmed√°b√°d to collect tribute from the S√°barmati chiefs. Returning early in a.d. 1751, at the request of Jetha Patel a subordinate of Bh√°vsingh Des√°i, he proceeded to Banod or Vanod under Víramg√°m and reduced the village. Áli Muhammad Kh√°n, the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, who about this time was raised in rank with the title of Bah√°dur, states that owing to the Mar√°tha inroads most of the districts had passed entirely into their possession; in others according to agreements with Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n they held a half share. Consequently in spite of new taxes, the entire remaining income of the province was only four l√°khs of rupees, and it was impossible to maintain the military posts or control the rebellious Kolis.

The Peshwa and G√°ikw√°r, 1751.It was in this year (a.d. 1751) that the Peshwa, decoying D√°m√°jir√°v into his power, imprisoned him and forced him to surrender half of his rights and conquests in Gujar√°t. Taking advantage of the absence of the G√°ikw√°r and his army in the Dakhan, Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n marched into Sorath. He first visited Gogha, and then levying tribute in Gohilv√°ḍa advanced into K√°thi√°v√°ḍa and marched against Nav√°nagar, and, after collecting a contribution from the J√°m, returned to Áhmed√°b√°d: In the following year (a.d. 1752), as soon as the news reached Gujar√°t that the Mar√°th√°s’ share in the province had been divided between the Peshwa and G√°ikw√°r, Momín Kh√°n, who was always quarrelling with the G√°ikw√°r’s agent, sending Varajl√°l his steward to B√°l√°jir√°v Peshwa begged him to include Cambay in his share and send his agent in place of the G√°ikw√°r’s agent. B√°l√°jir√°v agreed, and from that time an agent of the Peshwa was established at Cambay. In the same year Raghun√°thr√°v, brother of the Peshwa, entering Gujar√°t took possession of the Rewa and Mahi K√°ntha districts and marched on Surat. Shiaji Dhangar was appointed in Shevakr√°m’s place as D√°m√°ji’s deputy, and Krishn√°ji came to collect the Peshwa’s share.

Broach Independent, 1752.Up to this time the city of Broach had remained part of the Niz√°m’s personal estate, managed by Abdúllah Beg, whom, with the title of Nek Álam Kh√°n, Ásif J√°h the late Niz√°m-ul-Mulk had chosen his deputy. On the death of Abdúllah Beg in a.d. 1752 the emperor appointed his son to succeed him with the same title as his father, while he gave to another son, named Mughal Beg, the title of Khertalab Kh√°n. During the contests for succession that followed upon the death of the Niz√°m in a.d. 1752, no attempt was made to enforce the Niz√°m’s claims on the lands of Broach; and for the future, except for the share of the revenue paid to the Mar√°th√°s, the governors of Broach were practically independent. [335]


Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Ahmed Sh√°h Emperor, 1748–1754. The Peshwa now sent P√°ndurang Pandit to levy tribute from his share of Gujar√°t, and that officer crossing the Mahi marched upon Cambay. Momín Kh√°n prepared to oppose him, but the Pandit made friendly overtures, and eventually Momín Kh√°n not only paid the sum of £700 (Rs. 7000) for grass and grain for the Pandit’s troops, but also lent him four small cannon. P√°ndurang Pandit Repulsed at Áhmed√°b√°d, 1752.P√°ndurang Pandit then marched upon Áhmed√°b√°d, and encamping near the K√°nkariya lake laid siege to the city which was defended by Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n. During the siege P√°ndurang Pandit, sending some troops, ravaged Níkol, part of the lands of Áli Muhammad Kh√°n Bah√°dur, the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi. Meanwhile, as the operations against Áhmed√°b√°d made no progress, P√°ndurang Pandit made offers of peace. These Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n accepted, and on receiving from Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n the present of a mare and a small sum of money under the name of entertainment, the Mar√°tha leader withdrew to Sorath.

Mar√°tha Invasion.About this time the Peshwa released D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r on his promise to help the Peshwa’s brother Raghun√°thr√°v, who was shortly afterwards despatched with an army to complete the conquest of Gujar√°t. Meanwhile Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n’s anxiety regarding the Mar√°th√°s was for a time removed by the departure of P√°ndurang Pandit. And, as the harvest season had arrived, he with his brother Zor√°war Kh√°n B√°bi, leaving Muhammad Mub√°riz Sherw√°ni behind as his deputy, set out from Áhmed√°b√°d to levy tribute from the chiefs of the S√°bar K√°ntha. Certain well informed persons, who had heard of Raghun√°thr√°v’s preparations for invading Gujar√°t, begged Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n not to leave the city but to depute his brother Zor√°war Kh√°n B√°bi to collect the tribute. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, not believing their reports, said that he would not go more than from forty-five to sixty miles from the city, and that, should the necessity of any more distant excursion arise, he would entrust it to his brother. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n then marched from the city, levying tribute until he arrived on the P√°lanpur frontier about seventy-five miles north of Áhmed√°b√°d. Here meeting Muhammad Bah√°dur Jh√°lori, the governor of P√°lanpur, Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n was foolishly induced to join him in plundering the fertile districts of Sirohi, till at last he was not less than 150 miles from his head-quarters. Meanwhile Raghun√°thr√°v, joining D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, entered suddenly by an unusual route into Gujar√°t, and news reached Áhmed√°b√°d that the Mar√°th√°s had crossed the Narbada. On this the townspeople sent messenger after messenger to recall Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, and building up the gateways prepared for defence, while the inhabitants of the suburbs, leaving their houses, crowded with their families into the city for protection. Raghun√°thr√°v, hearing that Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n and his army were absent from the city, pressed on by forced marches, and crossing the river Mahi despatched an advance corps under Vithal Sukhdev. Kos√°ji, proprietor of Naḍi√°d, at D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r’s invitation also marched towards Áhmed√°b√°d, plundering Mehmúd√°b√°d Khokhri, only three miles from the city. In the meantime Vithal Sukhdev reached Kaira, and taking with him the chief man of that place, Muhammad Daur√°n, son of Muhammad B√°bi, continued his march. He was shortly joined by Raghun√°thr√°v, and the combined forces now proceeded to Áhmed√°b√°d and encamped by the K√°nkariya [336]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Ahmed Sh√°h Emperor, 1748–1754. lake. Next day Raghun√°thr√°v moved his camp to near the tomb of Hazrat Sh√°h Bhíkan,59 on the bank of the S√°barmati to the south-west of the city. Raghun√°thr√°v now proceeded to invest the city, distributing his thirty to forty thousand horse into three divisions. The operations against the north of the city were entrusted to D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r; those on the east to Gop√°l Hari; while the troops on the south and west were under the personal command of Raghun√°thr√°v and his officers.

Return of Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n.After leaving Sirohi Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n had gone westwards to Thar√°d and V√°v, so that the first messengers failed to find him. One of the later messengers, M√°ndan by name, who had not left Áhmed√°b√°d until the arrival of Raghun√°thr√°v at the K√°nkariya lake, made his way to V√°v and Thar√°d, and told Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n what had happened. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n set out by forced marches for R√°dhanpur, and leaving his family and the bulk of his army at P√°tan, he pushed on with 200 picked horsemen to Kadi and from that to Áhmed√°b√°d, contriving to enter the city by night. He enters Áhmed√°b√°d.The presence of Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n raised the spirits of the besieged, and the defence was conducted with ardour. In spite of their watchfulness, a party of about 700 Mar√°th√°s under cover of night succeeded in scaling the walls and entering the city. Ere they could do any mischief they were discovered and driven out of the town with much slaughter. The bulk of the besieging army, which had advanced in hopes that this party would succeed in opening one of the city gates, were forced to retire disappointed. Raghun√°thr√°v now made proposals for peace, but Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n did not think it consistent with his honour to accept them. On his refusal, the Mar√°tha general redoubled his efforts and sprung several mines, but owing to the thickness of the city walls no practicable breach was effected. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n now expelled the Mar√°tha deputies, and Gallant Defence of the City.continuing to defend the city with much gallantry contrived at night to introduce into the town by detachments a great portion of his army from P√°tan. At length, embarrassed by want of provisions and the clamour of his troops for pay, he extorted £5000 (Rs. 50,000) from the official classes. As Jaw√°n Mard was known to have an ample supply of money of his own this untimely meanness caused great discontent. The official classes who were the [337]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Ahmed Sh√°h Emperor, 1748–1754. repository of all real power murmured against his rule and openly advocated the surrender of the city, and Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n Surrenders.Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, much against his will, was forced to enter into negotiations with Raghun√°thr√°v.

Raghun√°thr√°v was so little hopeful of taking Áhmed√°b√°d that he had determined, should the siege last a month longer, to depart on condition of receiving the one-fourth share of the revenue and a safe conduct. Had Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n only disbursed his own money to pay the troops, and encouraged instead of disheartening the official class, he need never have lost the city. At last to Raghun√°thr√°v’s relief, Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n was reduced to treat for peace through Vithal Sukhdev. It was arranged that the Mar√°th√°s should give Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n the sum of £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh) to pay his troops, besides presenting him with an elephant and other articles of value. It was at the same time agreed that the garrison should leave the city with all the honours of war. And that, for himself and his brothers, Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n should receive, free from any Mar√°tha claim, the districts of P√°tan, Vadnagar, Sami, Munjpur, Visalnagar, Thar√°d, Kher√°lu, and R√°dhanpur with Tervada and Bij√°pur. It was further agreed that one of Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n’s brothers should always serve the Mar√°th√°s with 300 horse and 500 foot, the expenses of the force being paid by the Mar√°th√°s. It was also stipulated that neither the Peshwa’s army nor his deputy’s, nor that of any commander should enter Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n’s territory, and that in Áhmed√°b√°d no Mar√°tha official should put up at any of the Kh√°n Bah√°dur’s mansions, new or old, or at any of those belonging to his brothers followers or servants. Finally that the estates of other members of the family, namely Kaira, Kasba M√°tar and B√°nsa Mahudha, which belonged to Muhammad Kh√°n, Kh√°n Daur√°n, and Ábid Kh√°n were not to be meddled with, nor were encroachments to be allowed on the lands of K√°yam Kúli Kh√°n or of Zor√°war Kh√°n. This agreement was signed and sealed by Raghun√°thr√°v, with D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r (half sharer), Malh√°rr√°v Holkar, Jye Ápa Sindhia, R√°mchandar Vithal Sukhdev, Sakh√°r√°m Bhagvant, and M√°dhavr√°v Gop√°lr√°v as securities. The Mar√°th√°s take Possession, 1753.The treaty was then delivered to Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, and he and his garrison, marching out with the honours of war, the Mar√°th√°s took possession of Áhmed√°b√°d on April 2nd, 1753.

Collect Tribute.On leaving Áhmed√°b√°d Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n retired to P√°tan. At Áhmed√°b√°d Raghun√°thr√°v with D√°m√°ji arranged for the government of the city, appointing Shripatr√°v his deputy. He then marched into Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa to levy tribute from the Limbḍi and Wadhw√°n chiefs; and was so far successful that Harbhamji of Limbḍi agreed to pay an annual tribute of £4000 (Rs. 40,000). As the rainy season was drawing near Raghun√°thr√°v returned to Dholka, while Patel Vithal Sukhdev forced Muhammad Bah√°dur, the governor of P√°lanpur, to consent to a payment of £11,500 (Rs. 1,15,000). From Dholka Raghun√°thr√°v went to T√°r√°pur, about twelve miles north of Cambay, and compelled Momín Kh√°n to submit to an annual payment of £1000 (Rs. 10,000). At the same time Áli Muhammad Kh√°n Bah√°dur, the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, was appointed collector of customs, and his former grants were confirmed and he was allowed to retain [338]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Ahmed Sh√°h Emperor, 1748–1754. his villages of Sayadpur and Kûj√°dh close to Áhmed√°b√°d, as well as the village of P√°nmûl in Bij√°pur. D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, after levying tribute in the V√°trak K√°ntha, went to Kapadvanj, which he took from Sher Kh√°n B√°bi. From Kapadvanj he passed to Naḍi√°d and appointed Shevakr√°i to collect his half share of the revenue of Gujar√°t. Mughal Coinage Ceases.In the Áhmed√°b√°d mint, coin ceased to be struck in the emperor’s name and the suburbs of the city which had been deserted during the siege were not again inhabited. The Kolis commenced a system of depredation, and their outrages were so daring that women and children were sometimes carried off and sold as slaves. After the rains were over (a.d. 1754) Shetuji, commander of the Áhmed√°b√°d garrison, and Shankarji, governor of Víramg√°m, were sent to collect tribute from Sorath. Though the imperial power was sunk so low, the emperor was allowed to confer the post of K√°zi of the city on K√°zi Rûkn-ul-Hak Kh√°n who arrived at Áhmed√°b√°d and assumed office. Failure of an Attempt on Cambay, 1753.At the close of the year Shripatr√°v, who was anxious to acquire Cambay, marched against Momín Kh√°n. After two doubtful battles in which the Mar√°th√°s gained no advantage, it was agreed that Momín Kh√°n should pay a sum of £700 (Rs. 7000), and Shripatr√°v departed from Áhmed√°b√°d early in a.d. 1754. The Kolis.When the Kolis heard of the ill success of the Mar√°th√°s at Cambay, they revolted and R√°ghoshankar was sent to subdue them. In an engagement near Luh√°ra in Bahyal in His Highness the G√°ikw√°r’s territory about eighteen miles east of Áhmed√°b√°d, R√°ghoshankar scattered the Kolis, but they again collected and forced the Mar√°th√°s to retire. At this time Shetuji and Shankarji returned from Sorath, where they had performed the pilgrimage to Dw√°rka. Shetuji was sent to the Bhíl district against the Kolis. He was unsuccessful, and was so ashamed of his failure that he returned to the Dakhan and Dandu D√°t√°tri was appointed in his place.

In this year died Nek Álam Kh√°n II. governor of Broach. He was succeeded by his brother Khertalab Kh√°n who expelled his nephew H√°mid Beg, son of Nek Álam Kh√°n. H√°mid Beg took refuge in Surat. At B√°l√°sinor a dispute arose between Sher Kh√°n B√°bi and a body of Arab mercenaries who took possession of a hill, but in the end came to terms. With the Peshwa’s permission his deputy Bhagvantr√°v marched on Cambay. But Varajl√°l, Momín Kh√°n’s steward, who was then at Poona, sent word to his master, who prepared himself against any emergency. When Bhagvantr√°v arrived at Cambay he showed no hostile intentions and was well received by Momín Kh√°n. Subsequently a letter from Bhagvantr√°v to S√°lim Jam√°d√°r at Áhmed√°b√°d ordering him to march against Cambay fell into Momín Kh√°n’s hands. He at once surrounded Bhagvantr√°v’s house and made him prisoner. Mar√°th√°s Attack Cambay, 1754.When the Peshwa heard that Bhagvantr√°v had been captured, he ordered Ganesh Ápa, governor of Jambusar, as well as the governors of Víramg√°m, Dhandhuka, and other places to march at once upon Cambay. They went and besieged the town for three months, but without success. Eventually Shripatr√°v, the Peshwa’s deputy, sent the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi to negotiate, and it was agreed that Bhagvantr√°v should be released and that no alteration should be made in the position of Momín Kh√°n. Shortly afterwards Shripatr√°v was recalled by the Peshwa and his place supplied by an [339]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Ahmed Sh√°h Emperor, 1748–1754. officer of the name of R√°gho. About this time Khertalab Kh√°n, governor of Broach, died, and quarrels arose regarding the succession. Ultimately Hamid Beg, nephew of Khertalab Kh√°n, obtained the post, and he afterwards received an imperial order confirming him as governor, and bestowing on him the title of Nekn√°m Kh√°n Bah√°dur.

Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759.At Dehli, during a.d. 1754, the emperor Áhmed Sh√°h was deposed, and Âzíz-ud-dín, son of Jah√°nd√°r Sh√°h, was raised to the throne with the title of Álamgír II. After his release Bhagvantr√°v established himself in the Cambay fort of N√°p√°d and not long after began to attack Momín Kh√°n’s villages. Contest with Momín Kh√°n Renewed, 1754.After several doubtful engagements peace was concluded on Momín Kh√°n paying £1000 (Rs. 10,000) on account of the usual share of the Mar√°th√°s which he had withheld. This arrangement was made through the mediation of Tuk√°ji, the steward of Sad√°shiv D√°modar, who had come to Gujar√°t with an army and orders to help Bhagvantr√°v. As Momín Kh√°n had no ready money Tuk√°ji offered himself as security and Bhagvantr√°v and Tuk√°ji withdrew to the Dakhan. Momín Kh√°n’s soldiery now clamoured for pay. As he was not in a position to meet their demands he sent a body of men against some villages to the west belonging to Limbḍi and plundered them, dividing the booty among his troops. In the following year, Momín Kh√°n takes Gogha, 1755.a.d. 1755, Momín Kh√°n went to Gogha, a port which, though at one time subordinate to Cambay, had fallen into the hands of Sher Kh√°n B√°bi, and was now in the possession of the Peshwa’s officers. Gogha fell and leaving a garrison of 100 Arabs under Ibr√°hím Kúli Kh√°n, Momín Kh√°n returned to Cambay, levying tribute. He then sent the bulk of his army under the command of Muhammad Zam√°n Kh√°n, son of Fid√°-ud-dín Kh√°n, and Varajl√°l his own steward, to plunder and collect money in Gohilv√°ḍa and K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. Here they remained until their arrears were paid off, and then returned to Cambay. After this Momín Kh√°n plundered several Petl√°d villages and finally, in concert with the Kolis of Dhowan, attacked Jambusar and carried off much booty. Momín Kh√°n next marched against Borsad, and was on the point of taking the fort when Say√°ji, son of D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, who lived at Baroda, hearing of Momín Kh√°n’s success, came rapidly with a small body of men to the relief of the fort and surprised the besiegers. The Muhammadan troops soon recovered from the effects of the surprise, and Say√°ji fearing to engage them with so small a force retired. On Say√°ji’s departure Momín Kh√°n raised the siege of Borsad and returned to Cambay.

Momín Kh√°n recovers Áhmed√°b√°d, 17th Oct. 1756.In the year a.d. 1756 the rains were very heavy, and the walls of Áhmed√°b√°d fell in many places. Momín Kh√°n, hearing of this as well as of the discontent of the inhabitants, resolved to capture the city. He sent spies to ascertain the strength of the garrison and set about making allies of the chief men in the province and enlisting troops. About this time R√°ghoji, the Mar√°tha deputy, was assassinated by a Rohilla. As soon as Momín Kh√°n heard of R√°ghoji’s death he sent his nephew, Muhammad Zam√°n Kh√°n, with some men in advance, and afterwards himself at the close of the year, a.d. 1756, marched from Cambay and camped on the V√°trak. From this camp they moved to Kaira, and from Kaira to Áhmed√°b√°d. After one or two fights in [340]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759. the suburbs the Muhammadans, finding their way through the breaches in the walls, opened the gates and entered the town. The Kolis commenced plundering, and a hand-to-hand fight ensued, in which the Mar√°th√°s were worsted and were eventually expelled from the city. The Kolis attempted to plunder the Dutch factory, but met with a spirited resistance, and when Shambhúr√°m, a N√°gar Br√°hman, one of Momín Kh√°n’s chief supporters, heard it he ordered the Kolis to cease attacking the factory and consoled the Dutch.

Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n allies himself with the Mar√°th√°s.In the meantime Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, who had been invited by the Mar√°th√°s to their assistance, set out from P√°tan, and when he arrived at Peth√°pur and M√°nsa he heard of the capture of Áhmed√°b√°d. On reaching Kalol he was joined by Harbhamr√°m, governor of Kadi. They resolved to send Zor√°war Kh√°n B√°bi to recall Sad√°shiv D√°modar, and to await his arrival at Víramg√°m. Shevakr√°m, the G√°ikw√°r’s deputy, had taken refuge at Dholka. Momín Kh√°n himself now advanced, and entering Áhmed√°b√°d on the 17th October 1756, appointed Shambhúr√°m his deputy. Sad√°shiv D√°modar now joined Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n at Víramg√°m, and at Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n’s advice it was resolved, before taking further steps, to write to the Peshwa for aid. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, although he held large service estates, charged the Mar√°th√°s £150 (Rs. 1500) a day for his troops. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n and the Mar√°th√°s then advanced to S√°nand and Jitalpur, and thence marched towards Cambay. On their way they were met, and, after several combats, defeated by a detachment of Momín Kh√°n’s army. Momín Kh√°n sent troops to overrun Kadi, but Harbhamr√°m, the governor of Kadi, defeated the force, and captured their guns. When the emperor heard of the capture of Gogha, he sent a sword as a present to Momín Kh√°n; and when the news of the capture of Áhmed√°b√°d reached Ágra, Momín Kh√°n received many compliments. B√°l√°jir√°v Peshwa on the other hand was greatly enraged at these reverses. He at once sent off Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra to Gujar√°t as his deputy, and D√°m√°ji and Khander√°v G√°ikw√°r also accompanied him with their forces. Momín Kh√°n refusing to give up Áhmed√°b√°d, prepared for defence. Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra, D√°m√°ji and Khander√°v G√°ikw√°r advanced, and, crossing the Mahi, reached Kaira. Here they were met by Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n and the rest of the Mar√°tha forces in Gujar√°t, and the combined army advancing against the capital camped by the K√°nkariya lake.

Mar√°th√°s Invest Áhmed√°b√°d, 1756.The Mar√°th√°s now regularly invested the city, but Momín Kh√°n, aided by Shambhúr√°m, made a vigorous defence. Up to this time Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n was receiving £150 (Rs. 1500) daily for the pay of his own and his brother’s troops. Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra, considering the number of the troops too small for so large a payment, reduced the amount and retained the men in his own service. After a month’s siege, Momín Kh√°n’s troops began to clamour for pay, but Shambhúr√°m, by collecting the sum of £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh) from the inhabitants of the town managed for the time to appease their demands. When they again became urgent for pay, Shambhúr√°m diverted their thoughts by a general sally from all the gates at night. On this occasion many men were slain on both sides, and many of the inhabitants deserted the town. The copper vessels of such of the townspeople as had fled [341]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759. were melted and coined into money and given to the soldiery. In this state of affairs an order arrived from the imperial court bestowing on Momín Kh√°n a dress of honour and the title of Bah√°dur. Although the imperial power had for years been merely a name Momín Kh√°n asked and obtained permission from the besiegers to leave the city and meet the bearers of the order. The Mar√°th√°s redoubled their efforts. Still though the besiegers were successful in intercepting supplies of grain the garrison fought gallantly in defence of the town.

R√°v of Ídar helps Momín Kh√°n, 1757.At this juncture, in a.d. 1757, R√°ja Shivsingh of Ídar, son of the late Anandsingh, who was friendly to Momín Kh√°n, sent Saj√°nsingh Haz√°ri with a force to assist the besieged. On their way to Áhmed√°b√°d, Harbhamr√°m with a body of Mar√°th√°s attacked this detachment, while Momín Kh√°n sent to their aid Muhammad L√°l Rohilla and others, and a doubtful battle was fought. Shortly afterwards Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar made an attempt on the fort of K√°likot. The fort was successfully defended by Jam√°d√°r Núr Muhammad, and the Mar√°th√°s were repulsed. The Mar√°th√°s endeavoured in vain to persuade Shambhúr√°m to desert Momín Kh√°n, and though the garrison were often endangered by the faithlessness of the Kolis and other causes, they remained staunch. Momín Kh√°n, though frequently in difficulties owing to want of funds to pay his soldiery, continued to defend the town. The Mar√°th√°s next tried to seduce some of Momín Kh√°n’s officers, but in this they also failed, and Successful Sally under Shambhur√°m.in a sally Shambhúr√°m attacked the camp of Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar, and burning his tents all but captured the chief himself.

Negotiations for Peace.When the siege was at this stage, Hassan Kúli Kh√°n Bah√°dur, viceroy of Oudh, relinquishing worldly affairs and dividing his property among his nephews, set out to perform a pilgrimage to Makkah. Before he started Shuja-ûd-daulah, the Naw√°b of Lucknow, requested him on his way to visit B√°l√°jir√°v, and endeavour to come to some settlement of Áhmed√°b√°d affairs. Accordingly, adopting the name of Sh√°h Núr, and assuming the dress of an ascetic, Hassan Kúli made his way to Poona, and appearing before the Peshwa offered to make peace at Áhmed√°b√°d. Sh√°h Núr with much difficulty persuaded the Peshwa to allow Momín Kh√°n to retain Cambay and Gogha without any Mar√°tha share, and to grant him a l√°kh of rupees for the payment of his troops, on condition that he should surrender Áhmed√°b√°d. He obtained letters from the Peshwa addressed to Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra to this effect, and set out with them for Áhmed√°b√°d. When he arrived Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra was unwilling to accede to the terms, as the Áhmed√°b√°d garrison were reduced to great straits. Sh√°h Núr persuaded him at last to agree, provided Momín Kh√°n would surrender without delay. Accordingly Sh√°h Núr entered the city and endeavoured to persuade Momín Kh√°n. Momín Kh√°n demanded in addition a few Petl√°d villages, and to this the Mar√°th√°s refused their consent. Sh√°h Núr left in disgust. Before many days Momín Kh√°n was forced to make overtures for peace. After discussions with D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, it was agreed that Momín Kh√°n should surrender the city, receive £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh) to pay his soldiery, and be allowed to retain Cambay as heretofore, that is to say that the Peshwa should, as [342]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759. formerly, enjoy half the revenues. In addition to this Momín Kh√°n had to promise to pay the Mar√°th√°s a yearly tribute of £1000 (Rs. 10,000) and to give up all claims on the town of Gogha and hand over Shambhúr√°m to the Mar√°th√°s. It was also arranged that the £3500 (Rs. 35,000) worth of ashrafis which he had taken through Jam√°d√°r S√°lim should be deducted from the £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh). Momín Kh√°n surrendered the town on February 27th, 1758.

Mar√°tha Arrangements in Áhmed√°b√°d.Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar and D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r entered the city and undertook its management on behalf of the Mar√°th√°s. Of the other chiefs who were engaged in prosecuting the siege, Sad√°shiv D√°modar returned to the Dakhan and Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n receiving some presents from Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar departed for P√°tan after having had a meeting with D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r at a village a few miles from the capital. Shambhur√°m, the N√°gar Br√°hman, who had so zealously supported Momín Kh√°n, when he saw that further assistance was useless, tried to escape, but was taken prisoner and sent in chains to Baroda. Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar, on taking charge of the city, had interviews with the principal officials, among whom was the author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, and, receiving them graciously, confirmed most of them in their offices. Then, after choosing N√°ro Pandit, brother of P√°ndurang Pandit, to be his deputy in Áhmed√°b√°d, he started on an expedition to collect tribute in Jh√°l√°v√°ḍa and Sorath. New Coins.On receiving the government of the city the Mar√°tha generals ordered new coin bearing the mark of an elephant goad to be struck in the Áhmed√°b√°d mint. Say√°jir√°v G√°ikw√°r remained in Áhmed√°b√°d on behalf of his father D√°m√°ji, and shortly afterwards went towards Kapadvanj to collect tribute. Thence at his father’s request he proceeded to Sorath to arrange for the payment of the G√°ikw√°r’s share of the revenues of that district. On his return to Cambay Momín Kh√°n was much harassed by his troops for arrears of pay. The timely arrival of his steward Varajl√°l with the Peshwa’s contribution of £10,000 (Rs. 1 l√°kh) enabled him to satisfy their demands.

Momín Kh√°n at Cambay.Momín Kh√°n now began to oppress and extort money from his own followers, and is said to have instigated the murder of his steward Varajl√°l. Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar went from Porbandar to Jun√°gaḍh, where he was joined by Say√°jir√°v G√°ikw√°r. At Jun√°gaḍh Sher Kh√°n B√°bi presented Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra and Siy√°jir√°v with horses and they spoke of the necessity of admitting a Mar√°tha deputy into Jun√°gaḍh. Nothing was settled as the Mar√°th√°s were forced to return to Áhmed√°b√°d. In accordance with orders from the Peshwa, Shambhur√°m and his sons, who were still in confinement, were sent to Poona. D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r was also summoned to Poona, but he did not go. In this year R√°o Lakhpat of Kachh presented Kachh horses and Gujar√°t bullocks to the emperor, and in return received the title of Mírza R√°ja.

Expedition from Kachh against Sindh, 1758.About this time the R√°o of Kachh, who planned an expedition against Sindh, solicited aid both from D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r and Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar to enable him to conquer Thatta, and, as he agreed to pay expenses, Sad√°shiv sent Ranchord√°s, and D√°m√°ji sent Shevakr√°m to help him. In this year also Nekn√°m Kh√°n, governor of Broach, received the title of Bah√°dur and other honours. In a.d. 1758, Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar advanced to Kaira and after settling accounts [343]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759. with D√°m√°ji’s agent proceeded against Cambay. Momín Kh√°n, who was about to visit the Peshwa at Poona, remained to defend the town, but was forced to pay arrears of tribute amounting to £2000 (Rs. 20,000). In this year Sher Kh√°n B√°bi died at Jun√°gaḍh, and the nobles of his court seated his son Muhammad Mah√°bat Kh√°n in his place.

The Mar√°th√°s levy Tribute.Shortly after at the invitation of the Peshwa, D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r went to Poona, and sent his son Say√°jir√°v into Sorath. After his success at Cambay Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra levied tribute from the chiefs of Umeta, and then returned. On his way back, on account of the opposition caused by Sard√°r Muhammad Kh√°n son of Sher Kh√°n B√°bi, the chief of B√°l√°sinor, Sad√°shiv R√°mchandar besieged B√°l√°sinor and forced the chief to pay £3000 (Rs. 30,000). Next marching against Lun√°v√°ḍa, he compelled the chief Dípsingh to pay £5000 (Rs. 50,000). Sad√°shiv then went to Visalnagar and so to P√°lanpur, where Muhammad Kh√°n Bah√°dur Jh√°lori resisted him; but after a month’s siege he agreed to pay a tribute of £3500 (Rs. 35,000). Passing south from P√°lanpur, Sad√°shiv went to Únja-Un√°va, and from that to Katosan where he levied £1000 (Rs. 10,000) from the chief Shuja, and then proceeded to Limbḍi.

Surat Affairs, 1758.During a.d. 1758 important changes took place in Surat. In the early part of the year Sayad Muîn-ud-dín, otherwise called Sayad Achchan, visited the Peshwa at Poona, and received from him the appointment of governor of Surat. Sayad Achchan then set out for his charge, and as he was aided by a body of Mar√°tha troops under the command of Muzaffar Kh√°n G√°rdi and had also secured the support of Nekn√°m Kh√°n, the governor of Broach, he succeeded after some resistance in expelling Áli Naw√°z Kh√°n, son of the late Safdar Muhammad Kh√°n, and establishing himself in the government. During the recent troubles, the English factory had been plundered and two of their clerks murdered by Ahmed Kh√°n Habshi, commandant of the fort. The English take command of Surat, 1759.The English therefore determined to drive out the Habshi and themselves assume the government of the castle. With this object men-of-war were despatched from Bombay to the help of Mr. Spencer, the chief of the English factory, and the castle was taken in March a.d. 1759, and Mr. Spencer appointed governor. The Peshwa appears to have consented to this conquest. The Mar√°tha troops aided and made a demonstration without the city, and a Mar√°tha man-of-war which had been stationed at Bassein, came to assist the English. A Mr. Glass appears to have been appointed kiled√°r under Governor Spencer.

Momín Kh√°n Visits Poona, 1759.Shortly afterwards Momín Kh√°n, by the advice of Sayad Husain, an agent of the Peshwa, contracted friendship with the English through Mr. Erskine, the chief of the English factory at Cambay. Momín Kh√°n then asked Mr. Erskine to obtain permission for him to go to Poona by Bombay. Leave being granted, Momín Kh√°n set out for Surat, and was there received by Mr. Spencer. From Surat he sailed for Bombay, where the governor, Mr. Bourchier, treating him with much courtesy, informed the Peshwa of his arrival. The Peshwa sending permission for his further advance to Poona, Momín Kh√°n took leave of Mr. Bourchier and proceeded to Poona. [344]


Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759.
Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra Peshwa’s Viceroy, 1760. Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra Peshwa’s Viceroy, 1760.From Limbḍi, to which point his tribute tour has been traced, Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra advanced against Dhr√°ngadhra, when the chief who was at Halvad sent an army against him. The Mar√°th√°s, informed of the chief’s design, detaching a force, attacked Halvad at night, and breaching the walls forced open the gates. The chief retired to his palace, which was fortified, and there defended himself, but was at last forced to surrender, and was detained a prisoner until he should pay a sum of £12,000 (Rs. 1,20,000). The neighbouring chiefs, impressed with the fate of Halvad, paid tribute without opposition. The Mar√°th√°s in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, 1759.Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra now went to Jun√°gaḍh, but ere he could commence operations against the fortress, the rainy season drew near, and returning to Áhmed√°b√°d he prepared to depart for Poona. Say√°ji G√°ikw√°r, who was also in Sorath collecting tribute, amongst other places besieged Kundla, and levying from that town a tribute of £7500 (Rs. 75,000) returned to the capital. During this time Khander√°v G√°ikw√°r had been levying tribute from the Kolis, and after visiting the Bhíl district went to Bij√°pur, Ídar, Kadi, Dholka, and Naḍi√°d. The chief of Halvad on paying his £12,000 (Rs. 1,20,000) was allowed to depart, and Dípsingh of Lun√°v√°ḍa, who was also a prisoner, was sent to Lun√°v√°ḍa and there released after paying his tribute. On receiving the news of the capture of the Surat fort by the English the emperor issued an order, in the name of the governor of Bombay, confirming the command of the fort to the English instead of to the Habshis of Janjira, appointing the Honourable East India Company admirals of the imperial fleet, and at the same time discontinuing the yearly payment of £2000 (Rs. 20,000) formerly made to the Habshi on this account. When in the course of the following year, a.d. 1760, this imperial order reached Surat, Mr. Spencer and other chief men of the city went outside of the walls to meet and escort the bearers of the despatch. Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra was appointed viceroy of Áhmed√°b√°d on behalf of the Peshwa. Bhagvantr√°v now conquered B√°l√°sinor from Sard√°r Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, and then marching to Sorath, collected the Peshwa’s share of the tribute of that province, according to the scale of the previous year. Say√°ji G√°ikw√°r, when Bhagvantr√°v had returned, set out to Sorath to levy the G√°ikw√°r’s share of the tribute. He was accompanied by Harbhamr√°m whom D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r had specially sent from his own court to act as K√°md√°r to Say√°ji. When Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra reported to the Peshwa the conquest of B√°l√°sinor by Bhagvantr√°v he was highly pleased, and gave Bhagvantr√°v a dress of honour and allowed him to keep the elephant which he had captured at Lun√°v√°ḍa; and passed a patent bestowing B√°l√°sinor upon him. Momín Kh√°n, after making firm promises to the Peshwa never to depart from the terms of the treaty he had made with the Mar√°th√°s, left Poona and came to Bombay, where he was courteously entertained by the Governor, and despatched by boat to Surat. From Surat he passed to Cambay by land through Broach. Say√°ji G√°ikw√°r had returned to Áhmed√°b√°d from Sorath in bad health, and his uncle Khander√°v G√°ikw√°r, who had been vainly endeavouring to subdue the Kolis of Lúh√°ra, came to Áhmed√°b√°d and took Say√°ji G√°ikw√°r to Naḍi√°d. In 1761 Sad√°shiv R√°mchandra was displaced as viceroy of Gujar√°t by [345]
Chapter III.
Mughal Viceroys.
Álamgir II. Emperor, 1754–1759.
Ápa Ganesh Viceroy, 1761. Ápa Ganesh Viceroy, 1761.Ápa Ganesh. This officer acted in a friendly manner to Momín Kh√°n, and marching to Cambay, he fixed the Mar√°tha share of the revenues of that place for that year at £8400 (Rs. 84,000), and then went to Áhmed√°b√°d by way of D√°kor. Narbher√°m collected this year the G√°ikw√°r’s share of the tribute of Sorath and Say√°ji G√°ikw√°r went to Baroda. On his return to Áhmed√°b√°d at the end of the year, Say√°ji sacked and burned the Koli village of Lúh√°ra in Bahyal about eighteen miles east of Áhmed√°b√°d. Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n now issued from P√°tan and levied small contributions from the holdings in V√°gad, as far as Anj√°r in Kachh. From V√°gad he proceeded to Sorath, and in concert with Muhammad Mah√°bat Kh√°n of Jun√°gaḍh and Muhammad Muz√°ffar Kh√°n B√°bi, between whom he made peace, he levied tribute in Sorath as far as Loliy√°na, and returned to P√°tan.

P√°nipat, 1761.While their power and plunderings were thus prospering in Gujar√°t the crushing ruin of P√°nipat (a.d. 1761) fell on the Mar√°th√°s. Taking advantage of the confusion that followed, the Dehli court despatched instructions to the chief Musalm√°n nobles of Gujar√°t, directing Momín Kh√°n, Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n, and the governor of Broach to join in driving the Mar√°th√°s out of the province. In consequence of this despatch Sard√°r Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi, defeating the Mar√°tha garrison, regained B√°l√°sinor, while the governor of Broach, with the aid of Momín Kh√°n, succeeded in winning back Jambúsar. Ápa Ganesh, the Peshwa’s viceroy, remonstrated with Momín Kh√°n for this breach of faith. In reply his envoy was shown the despatch received from Dehli, and was made the bearer of a message, that before it was too late, it would be wisdom for the Mar√°th√°s to abandon Gujar√°t. Things were in this state when D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, wisely forgetting his quarrels with the Peshwa, marched to the aid of Sad√°shiv with a large army. Advancing against Cambay he attacked and defeated Momín Kh√°n, plundering one of his villages. But the Mar√°th√°s were too weak to follow up this success, or exact severer punishment from the Musalm√°n confederates. Ápa Ganesh invited Sard√°r Muhammad Kh√°n B√°bi to Kaira, and on condition of the payment of tribute, agreed to allow him to keep possession of B√°l√°sinor. Subsequently D√°m√°ji’s energy enabled him to enlarge the power and possessions of the G√°ikw√°r’s house, besides acquisitions from other chiefs, recovering the districts of Visalnagar, Kher√°lu, Vadnagar, Bij√°pur, and P√°tan from Jaw√°n Mard Kh√°n. After the death of the great D√°m√°ji, the importance of the G√°ikw√°r’s power sensibly diminished. Had it not been for their alliance with the British, the feeble hands of Say√°jir√°v I. (a.d. 1771–1778) would probably have been the last to hold the emblem of G√°ikw√°r rule. If in the zenith of G√°ikw√°r power Momín Kh√°n could reconquer, and for so long successfully defend Áhmed√°b√°d, what might not have been possible in its decline? [347]

1 The emperor Akbar took Muzaffar Sh√°h with him to Agra, and settled on him the districts of S√°rangpur and Ujjain in M√°lwa with a revenue of Rs. 20,00,000 (50 l√°khs of tank√°s) (Elliot, V. 353). When Mun’im Kh√°n Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n was going to Bengal, the emperor made Muzaffar over to him. Mun’im Kh√°n gave his daughter Sh√°hz√°dah Kh√°nam in marriage to Muzaffar, but shortly afterwards having reason to suspect him imprisoned him, whence Muzaffar finding an opportunity fled to Gujar√°t in a.d. 1581 (H. 989) according to Farishtah (II. 460), 1583 according to the Mirăt-i-Sikandari. ↑

2 Both the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari (Elliot, V. 342) and Farishtah (I. 491) name four other nobles Mír Abu Tur√°b, Sayad Áhmed Bhukh√°ri, Malik Ashraf, and Wajíh-ul-Mulk. The Sayad Áhmed of these two writers is a misprint for the Sayad H√°mid of the text. ↑

3 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 415; Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot, V. 343. ↑

4 These details of the Surat expedition are taken from the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot, V. 343–346 and Abúl Fazl’s Akbar-n√°mah in Elliot, VI. 42. ↑

5 The emperor Jeh√°ngír in his Diary (Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri, Persian Text, Sir Sayad Ahmed’s Edition, page 196) says that Biharji or Viharji was the hereditary title of the chiefs of B√°gl√°n. The personal name of the Bagl√°n Bih√°rji of his time was Part√°p. ↑

6 According to the Áin-i-Akbari (Blochmann, I. 325) the province of Gujar√°t over which the Kokalt√°sh was placed did not pass further south than the river Mahi. ↑

7 Tuzuki Jeh√°ngíri or Jeh√°ngír’s Memoirs, Pers. Text, Sayad Áhmed Kh√°n’s Edition page 20. For Akbar’s march compare Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot, V. 365 and Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, I. 325 and note. The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Pers. Text, 131) records these further details: When starting from his last camp Akbar began to mount his horse on the day of the battle that took place near Áhmed√°b√°d. The royal steed unable to bear the weight of the hero laden with the spirit of victory sat down. R√°ja Bhagw√°nd√°s Kachw√°hah ran up to the rather embarrassed emperor and offered him his congratulations saying: This, your Majesty, is the surest sign of victory. There are also two further signs: the wind blows from our back and the kites and vultures accompany our host. ↑

8 Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot, V. 405. ↑

9 M√°ngrúl (north latitude 21° 8′; east longitude 70° 10′), a seaport on the south coast of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, about twenty miles west of Somn√°th. This town, which is supposed to be the Monoglossum emporium of Ptolemy (a.d. 150) (see Bird, 115), is spelt M√°nglúr by the Muhammadan historians. Barbosa (a.d. 1511–1514), under the name of Surati-mangaler, calls it a ‘very good port where many ships from Malab√°r touch for horses, wheat, rice, cotton goods, and vegetables.’ In a.d. 1531 the city was taken by the Portuguese general Sylveira with a vast booty and a great number of prisoners (Churchill’s Travels, III. 529). It is incidentally mentioned in the Áin-i-Akbari (a.d. 1590). In a.d. 1638 Mandelslo describes it as famous for its linen cloth, and in a.d. 1700 it is mentioned by Hamilton (New Account, I. 136) as a place of trade. ↑

10 This has been rendered by Bird, 353, ‘the mountain of Dín√°r,’ as if Koh Dín√°r. ↑

11 H. 992 (1584 a.d.) according to the Tabak√°t-i-Akbari (Elliot, V. 428). ↑

12 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 422. Compare Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, I. 386. ↑

13 Mirăt-i-Sikandari, 426: Farishtah, I. 503; Elliot, V. 434. In honour of this victory the Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n built, on the site of the battle, a palace and garden enclosing all with a high wall. This which he named Jítpur the City of Victory was one of the chief ornaments of Áhmed√°b√°d. In November 1613 the English merchant Wittington writes (Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 127): A kos from Sarkhej is a pleasant house with a large garden all round on the banks of the river which Chon-Chin-Naw (Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n) built in honour of a great victory over the last king of Gujar√°t. No person inhabits the house. Two years later (1615) another English merchant Dodsworth (Kerr, IX. 203) describes the field of Victory as strongly walled all round with brick about 1½ miles in circuit all planted with fruit trees and delightfully watered having a costly house called by a name signifying Victory in which Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n for some time resided. In 1618, the emperor Jeh√°ngír (Memoirs Persian Text, 210–213) on his way to Sarkhej visited the Kh√°n-i-Kh√°n√°n’s B√°ghi Fateh or Garden of Victory which he had built at a cost of two l√°khs of rupees ornamenting the garden with buildings and surrounding it with a wall. The natives he notices call it Fateh-W√°di. In 1626 the English traveller Herbert (Travels, 66) writes: Two miles nearer Áhmed√°b√°d than Sirkhej are the curious gardens and palace of Kh√°n Kh√°n√°n where he defeated the last of the Cambay kings and in memory built a stately house and spacious gardens the view whereof worthily attracts the traveller. Mandelslo writing in 1638 is still louder in praise of Tschietb√°g the Garden of Victory. It is the largest and most beautiful garden in all India because of its splendid buildings and abundance of fine fruits. Its site is one of the pleasantest in the world on the border of a great tank having on the water side many pavilions and a high wall on the side of Áhmed√°b√°d. The lodge and the caravanserai are worthy of the prince who built them. The garden has many fruit trees oranges, citrons, pomegranates, dates, almonds, mulberries, tamarinds, mangoes, and cocoanuts so closely planted that all walking in the garden is under most pleasing shade (Mandelslo’s Travels, French Ed. 111–112). When (a.d. 1750) the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi was written several of the buildings and the remains of the summer house were still to be seen (Bird’s History of Gujar√°t, 375). A few traces of the buildings known as Fateh B√°di or Victory Garden remains 1879). (Áhmed√°b√°d Gazetteer, 292.) ↑

14 Two l√°khs of mahmúdis. The mahmúdi varied in value from about one-third to one-half of a rupee. See Introduction page 222 note 2. ↑

15 Morvi (north latitude 29° 48′; east longitude 70° 50′), a town in K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, about twenty-one miles south of Kachh. ↑

16 Jagat (north latitude 22° 15′; east longitude 69° 1′), the site of the temple of Dw√°rka, at the western extremity of the peninsula of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. ↑

17 Ver√°val (north latitude 20° 55′; east longitude 70° 21′), on the south-west coast of K√°thi√°v√°ḍa. On the south-east point of Ver√°val bay stood the city of Dev or Mungi P√°tan and within its walls the temple of Soman√°tha. ↑

18 Jeh√°ngír’s Memoirs, Persian Text, 23; Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, I. 470. Bah√°dur died about a.d. 1614: Jeh√°ngír’s Memoirs, 134. ↑

19 Now belonging to His Highness the G√°ikw√°r about twenty-seven miles north-west of Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

20 Belp√°r, belonging to the Th√°kor of Umeta in the Rewa K√°ntha. ↑

21 This M√°ndwa is probably the M√°ndwa under His Highness the G√°ikw√°r in his district of Atarsumba, but it may be M√°ndwa on the Narbada in the Rewa K√°ntha. Atarsumba is about ten miles west of Kapadvanj in the British district of Kaira. ↑

22 Jeh√°ngír’s Memoirs, Persian Text, 75. ↑

23 Now belonging to the R√°ja of Dharampur, east of the British district of Surat. ↑

24 In this year (a.d. 1611) the English East India Company sent vessels to trade with Surat. The Portuguese made an armed resistance, but were defeated. The Mughal commander, who was not sorry to see the Portuguese beaten, gave the English a warm reception, and in a.d. 1612–13 a factory was opened in Surat by the English, and in a.d. 1614 a fleet was kept in the T√°pti under Captain Downton to protect the factory. In a.d. 1615, Sir Thomas Roe came as ambassador to the emperor Jeh√°ngír, and obtained permission to establish factories, not only at Surat but also at Broach, Cambay and Gogha. The factory at Gogha seems to have been established in a.d. 1613. The emperor Jeh√°ngír notes in his memoirs (Persian Text, 105) that Mukarrab Kh√°n, viceroy from a.d. 1616–1618, regardless of cost had bought from the English at Gogha a turkey, a lemur and other curiosities. On his return from Jeh√°ngír’s camp at Áhmed√°b√°d in January 1618 Roe obtained valuable concessions from the viceroy. The governor of Surat was to lend ships to the English, the resident English might carry arms, build a house, practise their religion, and settle their disputes. Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 253. The Dutch closely followed the English at Surat and were established there in a.d. 1618. ↑

25 At first Jeh√°ngír, who reached Áhmed√°b√°d in the hot weather (March a.d. 1618), contented himself with abusing its sandy streets, calling the city the ‘abode of dust’ gard√°b√°d. After an attack of fever his dislike grew stronger, and he was uncertain whether the ‘home of the simoom’ samumist√°n, the ‘place of sickness’ bím√°rist√°n, the ‘thorn brake’ zakumd√°r, or ‘hell’ jah√°nnam√°b√°d, was its most fitting name. Even the last title did not satisfy his dislike. In derision he adds the verse, ‘Oh essence of all goodnesses by what name shall I call thee.’ Elliot’s History of India, VI. 358; Jeh√°ngír’s Memoirs Persian Text, 231. Of the old buildings of Áhmed√°b√°d, the emperor (Memoirs, Persian Text, 208–210) speaks of the K√°nkariya tank and its island garden and of the royal palaces in the Bhadar as having nearly gone to ruin within the last fifty years. He notes that his Bakhshi had repaired the K√°nkariya tank and that the viceroy Mukarrab Kh√°n had partly restored the Bhadar palaces against his arrival. The emperor was disappointed with the capital. After the accounts he had heard it seemed rather poor with its narrow streets, its shops with ignoble fronts, and its dust, though to greet the emperor as he came on elephant-back scattering gold the city and its population had put on their holiday dress. The emperor speaks (Memoirs, Persian Text page 211) of having met some of the great men of Gujar√°t. Chief among these was Sayad Muhammad Bukh√°ri the representative of Sh√°hi Álam and the sons of Sh√°h Wajíh-ud-dín of Áhmed√°b√°d. They came as far as Cambay to meet the emperor. After his arrival in the capital Jeh√°ngír with great kindness informally visited the house and garden of Sikandar Gujar√°ti the author of the Mirăt-i-Sikandari, to pick some of the author’s famous figs off the trees. Jeh√°ngír speaks of the historian as a man of a refined literary style well versed in all matters of Gujar√°t history, who six or seven years since had entered his (the imperial) service (Memoirs, 207–211). On the occasion of celebrating Sh√°h Jeh√°n’s twenty-seventh birthday at Áhmed√°b√°d Jeh√°ngír records having granted the territory from M√°ndu to Cambay as the estate of his son Sh√°h Jeh√°n (Prince Khurram). Memoirs, Persian Text, 210–211. Before leaving Gujar√°t the emperor ordered the expulsion of the Sevadas or Jain priests, because of a prophecy unfavourable to him made by M√°n Sing Sewda (Memoirs, Persian Text, 217). ↑

26 This was probably the gold ashrafi or seraph of which Hawkins (1609–1611) says, ‘Serraffins Ekberi, which be ten rupees a-piece.’ Thomas Chron. Pat. Kings of Dehli, 425. ↑

27 The peaked masonry tomb over Aurangzíb’s after-birth with its mosque, enclosure, and intact endowment is one of the curiosities of Dohad. In a letter to his eldest son Muhammad Muâzzam then (a.d. 1704) viceroy of Gujar√°t the aged Aurangzíb writes: My son of exalted rank, the town of Dohad, one of the dependencies of Gujar√°t, is the birth-place of this sinner. Please to consider a regard for the inhabitants of that town incumbent on you, and continue in office its decrepid old Faujd√°r. In regard to that old man listen not to the whisperings of those suffering from the disease of self-interest: “Verily they have a sickness in their hearts and Allah addeth to their ailments.” (Letters of the Emperor Aurangzíb: Persian Text, Cawnpur Edition, Letter 31.) ↑

28 Elliot, VII. 24. ↑

29 The words used in the text is tuyúl. In meaning it does not differ from j√°gir. ↑

30 This is one of the first mentions in history of peninsular Gujar√°t as K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, or as anything other than Sorath or Saur√°shṭra. The district referred to was probably united to the eastern possessions of the Kh√°char K√°this and Panch√°l. ↑

31 The author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi says that in his time, a.d. 1746–1762, these Nav√°nagar koris were current even in Áhmed√°b√°d, two koris and two-thirds being equal to one imperial rupee. They were also called j√°mis. The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Persian Text, 225) calls them mahmúdis. The legend on the reverse was the name of the Gujar√°t Sult√°n Muzaffar and on the obverse in Gujar√°ti the name of the J√°m. Usually two mahmúdis and sometimes three went to the imperial rupee. The author says that in Áhmed√°b√°d up to his day (a.d. 1756) the account for ghi clarified butter was made in mahmúdis. When the order for melting the mahmúdis was passed a mint was established at Jun√°gaḍh but was afterwards closed to suit the merchants from Diu and other parts who transmitted their specie to Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

32 The traveller Mandelslo, who was in Áhmed√°b√°d in 1638, says: No prince in Europe has so fine a court as the governor of Gujar√°t. Of none are the public appearances so magnificent. He never goes out without a great number of gentlemen and guards on foot and horse. Before him march many elephants with housings of brocade and velvet, standards, drums, trumpets, and cymbals. In his palace he is served like a king and suffers no one to appear before him unless he has asked an audience. (Travels, French Edition, 151.) Of the general system of government be says: The viceroy is absolute. It is true he summons leading lords of the country to deliberate on judgments and important matters. But they are called to ascertain their views not to adopt them. On the one hand the king often changes his governors that they may not grow overpowerful. On the other hand the governors knowing they may be recalled at any time take immense sums from the rich merchants especially from the merchants of Áhmed√°b√°d against whom false charges are brought with the view of forcing them to pay. As the governor is both civil and criminal judge if the merchants did not temper his greed they would be ruined beyond remedy. (Ditto, 150.) The frequent changes of viceroys in Gujar√°t is explained by Terry, 1615–17 (Voyage to East Indies, 364): To prevent them from becoming popular the king usually removes his viceroys after one year sending them to a new government remote from the old one. Terry adds a curious note: When the king sends any one to a place of government they never cut their hair till they return into his presence as if they desired not to appear beautiful except in the king’s sight. As soon as he sees them the king bids them cut their hair (Ditto, 365). It does not seem to have been cheating to keep up fewer horse than the number named. Terry (Voyage to East Indies, 391) says: He who hath the pay of five or six thousand must always have one thousand or more in readiness according to the king’s need of them, and so in proportion all the rest. ↑

33 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi Persian Text, II. 46–47. Pinj√°r√°s are cotton teasers, Mansúris are Pinj√°r√°s who worship Mansúr a tenth century (3rd century Hijrah) saint. ↑

34 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi Persian Text, 237. ↑

35 Jh√°bua, now under the Bhop√°war Agency. ↑

36 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi Persian Text, 249. ↑

37 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Persian Text, 274, 279. ↑

38 R√°ygad (north latitude 18° 14′; east longitude 73° 30′), the name given in a.d. 1662 to Rairi, a hill fortress in the Mah√°d sub-division of the Kol√°ba collectorate. Shiv√°ji took the place and made it his capital in a.d. 1662. ↑

39 Janjira (north latitude 17° 59′ to 18° 32′) that is Jazírah the Island, on the western coast, about forty-four miles south of Bombay. ↑

40 Another post of Isl√°m√°b√°d was at Pun√°dra in the parganah of Ázam√°b√°d on the W√°trak about twenty-one miles east-south-east of Áhmed√°b√°d. Ázam√°b√°d was built by Ázam Kh√°n during his viceroyalty (a.d. 1635–1642) and at his request by permission of the emperor Sh√°h Jeh√°n was erected into a parganah. For the pay of the garrison twelve villages were attached from the neighbouring parganahs of Bahyal and Kapadvanj. ↑

41 The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Persian Text, 311) adds that Bahlol’s following of Kasb√°tis was so poorly equipped that he had to mount many of them, for whom he could not find horses, on bullocks. The sense of security in the mind of the Ídar chief bred by contempt at the sight of this motley crowd was the chief cause of Bahlol’s success. ↑

42 The zak√°t or purification is the tax required by law to be given annually to the poor. It is levied on camels, oxen, buffaloes, sheep, goats, horses, asses, mules, and gold or silver whether in money or ornaments or vessels. The tax is not levied on any one who owns less than a minimum of five camels, thirty oxen, forty-five sheep, five horses, two hundred dirhems or twenty din√°rs. The proportion to income is generally one-fortieth; the amount may be paid either in kind or in money. Compare Stanley Lane Poole’s Arabian Society in the Middle Ages, 14. ↑

43 This S√°mprah according to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Persian Text, II. 127, was a small police post or th√°na in Parganah Bahyal, twenty miles north-east of Áhmed√°b√°d. It is now in the G√°ekw√°r’s territory. Bahyal was under P√°tan, so in the text the place is described as under P√°tan. ↑

44 The surkh or little black-dotted red seed of the Abrus precatorius is called ghúngchi in Hindi and cock’s-eye, chashmi-i-khurús, in Persian. As a weight the seed is known as a rati 96 going to the tola. It is used in weighing precious stones. Blochmann’s Áin-i-Akbari, I. 16 note 1 and Mirăt-i-Áhmedi Persian Text, 366. ↑

45 Sinor in Baroda territory on the right bank of the Narbada about thirty miles south of Baroda. ↑

46 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Persian Text, 372. ↑

47 Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Persian Text, 427–434. ↑

48 Arhar-M√°tar is according to the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Persian Text, II. 126) the present Kaira sub-division of M√°tar. The Mirăt-i-Áhmedi places it twenty miles south-west of Áhmed√°b√°d. It is four miles south-west of Kaira. ↑

49 In the beginning of Ajítsingh’s administration the Sacrifice Íd of the Musalm√°ns very nearly ended in a riot. An overzealous police officer belonging to the K√°lúpúr section of Áhmed√°b√°d, hoping to please the Hindu viceroy, by force deprived some of the Sunni Bohor√°s of that quarter of a cow which they had purchased for the sacrifice. The Bohor√°s in a mass appealed to the K√°zi who not succeeding in his representation to the viceroy was obliged to allay the popular excitement by publicly sacrificing a cow after the Íd prayers. Mirăt-i-Áhmedi Royal Asiatic Society MS., I. 567–568. ↑

50 This is the first known mention of Gohilv√°ḍa, the Gohils country, as a separate district. ↑

51 During the governorship of Haidar Kúli at Surat the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Royal Asiatic Society MS., I. 567–568) notices the death of Mulla Abdul Ghafúr the founder of the wealthy family of the Mull√°s of Surat. Haidar Kúli confiscated Abdul Ghafúr’s property representing to the emperor that the Mulla died issueless. But the Mulla’s son Abdúl Hye proceeding to Dehli not only obtained from the emperor an order of restitution of property but the title of chief of merchants, Umda-tut-Tujj√°r, and an elephant. ↑

52 The sum is 6,75,000 mahmúdis. Like the changízi (see above page 222 note 2) the mahmúdi seems to have varied in value from one-third to one-half of a rupee. ↑

53 See note 1 page 312. The author of the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Persian Text Royal Asiatic Society’s Library Edition, I. 658) says Trimbakr√°v was slain. This seems an oversight as in another passage (Ditto, 738–739, see below page 312) he states that Trimbakr√°v was killed in 1731. The latter statement is in agreement with Grant Duff (History of the Mar√°th√°s, I. 364). ↑

54 The amount was 1,25,000 mahmúdis. ↑

55 Kasb√°tis are the descendants of the Musalm√°n garrisons of some towns of north Gujar√°t. The Kasb√°tis of Víramg√°m were originally T√°nk R√°jputs. ↑

56 See note on page 306. ↑

57 P√°tdi (north latitude 23° 10′; east longitude 71° 44′), at the south-east angle of the Ran of Cutch, fifty-two miles west of Áhmed√°b√°d. ↑

58 The M√°hi-mar√°tib was a banner having the likeness of a fish at its top. ↑

59 Of the death at the age of nine years of this son of Saint Sh√°h-i-Álam the Mirăt-i-Áhmedi (Printed Persian Text, II. 26) gives the following details: Malik Seif-ud-dín, the daughter’s son of Sult√°n Áhmed I., had a son who he believed was born to him by the prayer of Saint Sh√°h-i-Álam. This boy who was about nine years old died. Malik Seif-ud-dín ran to Sh√°h-i-Álam, who used then to live at As√°wal, two or three miles east of Áhmed√°b√°d, and in a transport of grief and rage said to the Saint: ‘Is this the way you deceive people? Surely you obtained me the gift of that boy to live and not to die? This I suppose is how you will keep your promise of mediating for our sinful souls before All√°h also?’ The Saint could give no reply and retired to his inner apartments. The stricken father went to the Saint’s son Sh√°h Bhíkan, who, going in to his father, entreated him to restore the Malik’s boy to life. The Saint asked his son ‘Are you prepared to die for the boy?’ Sh√°h Bhíkan said ‘I am ready.’ The Saint, going into an inner room, spread his skirts before All√°h crying ‘R√°janji,’ a pet name by which the Saint used to address All√°h, meaning Dear King or Lord, ‘R√°janji, here is a goat for a goat; take thou this one and return the other.’ Lamentations in the Saint’s harem showed that half of the prayer was granted and the Malik on returning to his house found the other half fulfilled. ↑

[Contents]

APPENDIX I.

The Death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur, a.d. 1526–1536.1


Appendix I.
The Death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur, a.d. 1526–1536. Colonel Briggs (Muhammadan Power in India, IV. 132) gives the following summary of the events which led to the fatal meeting of Sult√°n Bah√°dur and the Portuguese viceroy Nono da Cunha in the beginning of 1536–37:

When in 1529 Nono daCunha came as viceroy to India he held instructions to make himself master of the island of Diu. In the following year a great expedition, consisting of 400 vessels and 15,600 men, met in Bombay and sailed to the K√°thi√°v√°ḍa coast. After vigorous assaults it was repulsed off Diu on the 17th February 1531. From that day the Portuguese made ceaseless efforts to obtain a footing on the island of Diu. In 1531 besides harrying the sea trade of Gujar√°t the Portuguese sacked the towns of T√°r√°pur, Bals√°r, and Surat, and, to give colour to their pretensions, received under their protection Ch√°nd Kh√°n an illegitimate brother of Bah√°dur. In 1532, under James de Silveira, the Portuguese burned the south K√°thi√°v√°ḍa ports of Pattan-Somn√°th, Mangrul, Tal√°ja, and Muzaffar√°b√°d, killing many of the people and carrying off 4000 as slaves. Shortly after the Portuguese took and destroyed Bassein in Th√°na obtaining 400 cannon and much ammunition. They also burned Daman, Th√°na, and Bombay. “All this” says the Portuguese historian “they did to straiten Diu and to oblige the king of Gujar√°t to consent to their raising a fort on the island of Diu.” When Bah√°dur was engaged with the Mughals (a.d. 1532–1534) the Portuguese Governor General deputed an embassy to wait on Hum√°yún to endeavour to obtain from him the cession of Diu, hoping by this action to work indirectly on the fears of Bah√°dur. At last in 1534 Bah√°dur consented to a peace by which he agreed to cede the town of Bassein to Portugal; not to construct ships of war in his ports; and not to combine with Turkish fleets against Portugal.

Permission was also given to the Portuguese to build in Diu. In consideration of these terms the Portuguese agreed to furnish Bah√°dur with 500 Europeans of whom fifty were men of note. According to the Portuguese historian it was solely because of this Portuguese help that Bah√°dur succeeded in driving the Mughals out of Gujar√°t. Bah√°dur’s cession of land in Diu to the Portuguese was for the purpose of building a mercantile factory. From the moment Bah√°dur discovered they had raised formidable fortifications, especially when by the withdrawal of the Mughals he no longer had any motive for keeping on terms with them, he resolved to wrest the fort out of the hands of the Portuguese. On the plea of separating the natives from the Europeans, Bah√°dur instructed his governor of Diu to build a wall with a rampart capable of being mounted with guns. But as this created much dispute and ill-will the rampart was given up. Bah√°dur next attempted to seize Emanuel de Souza the captain of Diu fort. With this object he invited DeSouza to his camp. DeSouza was warned but determined to accept Bah√°dur’s invitation. He went attended by only one servant, an act of courage which [348]
Appendix I.
The Death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur, a.d. 1526–1536. Bah√°dur so greatly admired that he treated him with honour and allowed him to return in safety. Bah√°dur next schemed to secure DeSouza in the fort by surprise. With this end he began to pay the Portuguese officers visits at all hours. But DeSouza was always on his guard and Bah√°dur’s surprise visits failed to give him an opportunity. In 1536 DeSouza wrote to the viceroy complaining of the bad feeling of the Gujar√°t Moors towards the Portuguese in Diu and of the efforts of the king to drive them out of the fort. In consequence of DeSouza’s letter Nono daCunha the viceroy arrived at Diu early in 1536–7. Bah√°dur went to visit the viceroy on board the viceroy’s ship. On his return he was attacked and leaping into the water was killed by a blow on the head and sank.

Of the unplanned and confused circumstances in which the brave Bah√°dur met his death four Musalm√°n and four Portuguese versions remain. The author of the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 280–281) states that the Portuguese, who offered their help to Bah√°dur in the days of his defeat by the emperor Hum√°yún, obtained from him the grant of land at Diu, and on this land built a fort. After the re-establishment of his power the Sult√°n, who had no longer any need of their help, kept constantly planning some means of ousting the Portuguese from Diu. With this object Bah√°dur came to Diu and opened negotiations with the Portuguese viceroy, hoping in the end to get the viceroy into his power. The viceroy knowing that Bah√°dur regretted the concessions he had made to them was too wary to place himself in Bah√°dur’s hands. To inspire confidence Bah√°dur, with five or six of his nobles all unarmed, paid the viceroy a visit on board his ship. Suspecting foul play from the behaviour of the Portuguese the king rose to retire, but the Portuguese pressed upon him on all sides. He had nearly reached his boat when one of the Portuguese struck him a blow with a sword, killed him, and threw his body overboard.

The same author gives a second version which he says is more generally received and is probably more accurate. According to this account the Portuguese had come to know that Bah√°dur had invited the Sult√°ns of the Dakhan to co-operate with him in driving the Portuguese from the Gujar√°t, Konkan, and Dakhan ports. That the Portuguese viceroy had come with 150 ships and had anchored at Diu off the chain bastion. That Sult√°n Bah√°dur not suspecting that the Portuguese were aware of his insincerity went in a barge to see the fleet, and when he got in the midst of their ships, the Portuguese surrounded his barge and killed him with lances.

According to Farishtah (II. 442, 443, Pers. Text) on the invasion of Gujar√°t by the emperor Hum√°yún, Sult√°n Bah√°dur had asked help of the Portuguese. When his power was re-established, Bah√°dur, hearing of the arrival of between five and six thousand Portuguese at Diu, feared they would take possession of that port. He therefore hastened to Diu from Jun√°gaḍh. The Portuguese who were aware that Hum√°yún had withdrawn and that Bah√°dur had re-established his power, preferred to attempt to gain Diu by stratagem rather than by force. Bah√°dur asked the viceroy to visit him. The viceroy feigned sickness and Bah√°dur with the object of proving his goodwill offered to visit the viceroy on board his ship. On leaving the viceroy’s ship to enter his own barge the Portuguese suddenly moved their vessel and Bah√°dur fell overboard. While in the water a Portuguese struck the king with a lance and killed him. [349]


Appendix I.
The Death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur, a.d. 1526–1536. Abul Fazl’s account a.d. 1590 (Akbarn√°mah in Elliot, VI. 18) seems more natural and in better keeping with Bah√°dur’s impetuous vigour and bravery than either the Gujar√°t or Farishtah’s narratives. The Portuguese chief was apprehensive that as the Sult√°n was no longer in want of assistance he meditated treachery. So he sent to inform the Sult√°n that he had come as requested, but that he was ill and unable to go on shore, so that the interview must be deferred till he got better. The Sult√°n, quitting the royal road of safety, embarked on the 12th February 1536 (3rd Ramazan H. 943) with a small escort to visit the viceroy on board the viceroy’s ship. As soon as Bah√°dur reached the vessel he found the viceroy’s sickness was a pretence and regretted that he had come. He at once sought to return. But the Portuguese were unwilling that such a prey should escape them and hoped that by keeping him prisoner they might get more ports. The viceroy came forward and asked the Sult√°n to stay a little and examine some curiosities he had to present. The Sult√°n replied that the curiosities might be sent after him and turned quickly towards his own boat. A European k√°zi or priest placed himself in the Sult√°n’s way and bade him stop. The Sult√°n, in exasperation, drew his sword and cleft the priest in twain. He then leaped into his own boat. The Portuguese vessels drew round the Sult√°n’s boat and a fight began. The Sult√°n and Rúmi Kh√°n threw themselves into the water. A friend among the Portuguese stretched a hand to Rúmi Kh√°n and saved him: the Sult√°n was drowned in the waves.

Of the four Portuguese versions of Bah√°dur’s death the first appears in Correa’s (a.d. 1512–1550) Lendas Da Asia, a.d. 1497 to 1550; the second in DeBarros’ (died a.d. 1570) Decadas, a.d. 1497 to 1539; the third in Do Couto’s (died a.d. 1600 ?) continuation of DeBarros, a.d. 1529 to 1600; and the fourth in Faria-e-Souza’s (died a.d. 1650) Portuguese Asia to a.d. 1640. A fifth reference to Bah√°dur’s death will be found in Castaneda’s Historia which extends to a.d. 1538.

As Correa was in India from a.d. 1512 till his death in Goa in a.d. 1550, and as his narrative which was never published till a.d. 1856–64 has the highest reputation for accuracy of detail his version carries special weight. According to Correa (Lendas Da Asia, Vol. III. Chap. XCV.) during the monsoon of 1536, Nono DaCunha the viceroy received by land a letter from Manoel deSouza the captain of Diu fort, telling him of the discontent of the Gujar√°t Moors with king Bah√°dur for allowing the Portuguese to build a fort at Diu. In consequence of this information early in the fair season Nono daCunha sailed from Goa in his own galleon accompanied by about ten small vessels fustas and katurs under the command of Antonio deSylveira. Nono reached Diu about the end of December. King Bah√°dur was glad that the viceroy should come to Diu almost alone since it seemed to show he was not aware of Bah√°dur’s designs against the Portuguese. When Bah√°dur arrived at Diu he sent a message to the viceroy inviting him to come ashore to meet him as he had important business to transact. The king’s messenger found the viceroy ill in bed, and brought back a message that the viceroy would come ashore to meet the king in the evening. Immediately after the king’s messenger left, Manoel deSouza, the captain of Diu fort, came on board to see the viceroy. The viceroy told Manoel to go and thank the king and to return his visit. The king expressed his grief at the viceroy’s illness and proposed to start at once to see him. He went to his barge and rowed straight to the viceroy’s [350]
Appendix I.
The Death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur, a.d. 1526–1536. galleon. The king had with him, besides the interpreter St. Jago, seven men and two pages one carrying a sword and the other a bow. The captain of the fort and some other officers in their own barges followed the king. Bah√°dur, who was the first to arrive, came so speedily that the viceroy had hardly time to make preparations to receive him. He put on heavy clothes to show he was suffering from ague and ordered all the officers to be well armed. When Bah√°dur came on board he saw the men busy with their weapons but showed no signs that he suspected foul play. He went straight to the viceroy’s cabin. The viceroy tried to get up but Bah√°dur prevented him, asked how he was, and returned at once to the deck. As Bah√°dur stood on the deck the captain of the fort boarded the galleon, and, as he passed to the cabin to see the viceroy, Bah√°dur laughingly upbraided him with being behind time. Then without taking leave of the viceroy Bah√°dur went to his barge. When the viceroy learned that the king had left he told the captain to follow the king and to take him to the fort and keep him there till the viceroy saw him. The captain rowed after the king who was already well ahead. He called to the king asking him to wait. The king waited. When the captain came close to the king’s barge he asked the king to come into his vessel. But the interpreter without referring to the king replied that the captain should come into the king’s barge. DeSouza ordered his boat alongside. His barge struck the king’s barge and DeSouza who was standing on the poop tripped and fell into the water. The rowers of the royal barge picked him out and placed him near the king who laughed at his wet clothes. Other Portuguese barges whose officers thought the Moors were fighting with the captain began to gather. The first to arrive was Antonio Cardoza. When Cardoza came up the interpreter told the king to make for land with all speed as the Portuguese seemed to be coming to seize and kill him. The king gave the order to make for the shore. He also told the page to shoot the hollow arrow whose whistling noise was a danger signal. When the Moors in the king’s barge heard the whistle they attacked Manoel deSouza, who fell dead into the sea. Then Diogo de Mesquita, D’Almeida, and Antonio Correa forced their way on to the king’s barge. When the king saw them he unsheathed his sword and the page shot an arrow and killed Antonio Cardoza, who fell overboard and was drowned. D’Almeida was killed by a sword-cut from a Moor called Tiger and Tiger was killed by Correa. At that moment Diogo de Mesquita gave the king a slight sword-cut and the king jumped into the sea. After the king, the interpreter and Rúmi Kh√°n, two Moors, and all the rowers leapt into the water. The Portuguese barges surrounded them and the men struck at the three swimmers with lances and oars. The king twice cried aloud ‘I am Sult√°n Bah√°dur,’ hoping that some one would help him. A man who did not know that he was the king struck Bah√°dur on the head with a club. The blow was fatal and Bah√°dur sank. The second version is given by Barros (a.d. 1560) in his Decadas da Asia, Vol. V. page 357 of the 1707 edition. The third version by Do Couto (a.d. 1600) in his continuation of Barros’ Decadas, and the fourth by Faria-e-Souza (a.d. 1650) in his Portuguese Asia are in the main taken from De Barros. The following details are from Steevens’ (a.d. 1697) translation of Faria given in Briggs’ Muhammadan Power in India, IV. 135–138.

Bah√°dur king of Cambay, who had recovered his kingdom solely by the assistance of the Portuguese, now studied their ruin, and repenting of the leave he had granted to build a fort at Diu endeavoured to [351]
Appendix I.
The Death of Sult√°n Bah√°dur, a.d. 1526–1536. take it and to kill the commander and the garrison. Nono da Cunha the Portuguese viceroy understood his designs and prepared to prevent them. Emanuel deSouza who commanded at Diu was warned by a Moor that the king would send for him by a certain Moor and kill him. DeSouza determined to go, and, when sent for, appeared with only one servant. Admiring DeSouza’s courage the king treated him honourably and allowed him to return in safety. The king’s mother tried to dissuade her son from plotting against DeSouza but to no effect. To remove suspicion Bah√°dur began to pay the Portuguese officers visits at unseasonable hours, but was ever received by DeSouza on his guard. Meanwhile, on the 9th January 1536, Nono daCunha the Portuguese viceroy set out from Goa for Diu with 300 sail. When he put in at Cheul he found Niz√°m-ul-Mulk who pretended he had come to divert his women at sea but really with designs on that place. When Nono reached Diu the king was hunting in the mountains and Nono apprised him of his arrival. The king sent for him by a Portuguese apostate of the name of John de St. Jago called Firangi Kh√°n, but Nono daCunha pleaded illness. The king pretending great friendship came to Diu accompanied by Emanuel deSouza, who had brought the last message from DaCunha. At Diu the king went on board the viceroy’s ship and for a time they discoursed. The king was troubled at a page whispering something to DaCunha, but as DaCunha took no notice his suspicions were allayed. The message was from DeSouza, stating that the captains whom he had summoned were awaiting orders to secure or kill the king. DaCunha thought it strange that DeSouza had not killed the king while he was in his power in the fort; and DeSouza thought it strange that DaCunha did not now seize the king when he was in his power in the ship. DaCunha directed all the officers to escort the king to the palace and then accompany DeSouza to the fort, where DaCunha intended to seize the king when he came to visit him. The king on his part had resolved to seize DaCunha at a dinner to which he had invited him and send him in a cage to the Great Turk. De Souza who was going to invite the king to the fort after DaCunha had entered it, came up with the king’s barge and delivered his invitation through Rúmi Kh√°n. Rúmi Kh√°n warned the king not to accept it. The king disregarding this warning invited DeSouza into his barge. While stepping into the king’s barge DeSouza fell overboard, but was picked up by officers who carried him to the king. At this time three Portuguese barges came up and some of the officers seeing DeSouza hastily enter the king’s barge drew close to the king’s barge. The king remembering Rúmi Kh√°n’s warning ordered Emanuel deSouza to be killed. James de Mesquita understanding the order flew at and wounded the king. An affray followed and four Portuguese and seven of the king’s men were killed. The king tried to get away in a boat but a cannon shot killed three of his rowers and he was stopped. He next attempted to escape by swimming, but being in danger of drowning discovered himself by crying for help. A Portuguese held out an oar to him; but others struck him fatal blows, so that he sank.

The conclusion to be drawn from these four Musalm√°n and four Portuguese versions is that on either side the leader hoped by some future treachery to seize the person of the other; and that mutual suspicion turned into a fatal affray a meeting which both parties intended should pass peacefully and lull the other into a false and favourable security. [352]
