But that great monarch has left an example of his watchful care in the rebuilding of the Âlamgír or Aurangzíb Gate, which guards the approach to the stone-crossing of the great northern ravine and bears an inscription of a.d. 1668, the eleventh year of Âlamgír’s reign. In spite of this additional safeguard thirty years later (a.d. 1696) M√°ndu was taken and the standard of Ud√°ji Pav√°r was planted on the battlement.159 The Mar√°th√°s soon withdrew and M√°lwa again passed under an imperial governor. In a.d. 1708 the Shía-loving emperor Bah√°dur Sh√°h I. (a.d. 1707–1712) visited M√°ndu, and there received from Ahmed√°b√°d a copy of the Kurâ√°n written by Im√°m Âli Taki, son of Im√°m Músa Raza (a.d. 810–829), seventh in descent from Âli, the famous son-in-law of the Prophet, the first of Musalm√°n mystics. In a.d. 1717 Ásaph J√°h Niz√°m-ul-Mulk was appointed governor of M√°lwa and continued to manage the province by deputy till a.d. 1721. In a.d. 1722 R√°ja Girdhar Bah√°dur, a N√°gar Br√°hman, was made governor and remained in charge till in a.d. 1724 he was attacked and defeated by Chimn√°ji Pandit and Ud√°ji Pav√°r.160 R√°ja Girdhar was succeeded by his relation Dia Bah√°dur, whose successful government ended in a.d. 1732, when through the secret help of the local chiefs Malh√°rr√°o Holkar led an army up the Bhairav pass, a few miles east of M√°ndu, and at Tirellah, between Amjera and Dh√°r, defeated and slew Dia Bah√°dur. As neither the next governor Muhammad Kh√°n Bangash nor his successor R√°ja Jai Singh of Jaipúr were able to oust the Mar√°th√°s, their success was admitted in a.d. 1734 by the appointment of Peshwa B√°jir√°o (a.d. 1720–1740) to be governor of M√°lwa. On his appointment (a.d. 1734) the Peshwa chose Anand R√°o Pav√°r as his deputy. Anand R√°o shortly after settled at Dh√°r, and since a.d. 1734 M√°ndu has continued part of the territory of the Pav√°rs of Dhar.161 In a.d. 1805 M√°ndu sheltered the heroic Mína B√°i during the birth-time of her son R√°mchundra R√°o Pav√°r, whose state was saved from the clutches of [383]
Appendix II.
The Hill Fort of M√°ndu.
History
Notices, a.d. 1820–1895. Holkar and Sindhia by the establishment of British overlordship in a.d. 1817.162

Notices, a.d. 1820–1895.In a.d. 1820 Sir John Malcolm163 describes the hill-top as a place of religious resort occupied by some mendicants. The holy places on the hill are the shrine of Hoshang Ghori, whose guardian spirit still scares barrenness and other disease fiends164 and the Rewa or Narbada Pool, whose holy water, according to common belief, prevents the dreaded return of the spirit of the Hindu whose ashes are strewn on its surface, or, in the refined phrase of the Br√°hman, enables the dead to lose self in the ocean of being.165 In a.d. 1820 the J√°m√° Mosque, Hoshang’s tomb, and the palaces of B√°z Bah√°dur were still fine remains, though surrounded with jungle and fast crumbling to pieces.166 In a.d. 1827 Colonel Briggs says167: Perhaps no part of India so abounds with tigers as the neighbourhood of the once famous city of M√°ndu. The capital now deserted by man is overgrown by forest and from being the seat of luxury, elegance, and wealth, it has become the abode of wild beasts and is resorted to by the few Europeans in that quarter for the pleasure of destroying them. Instances have been known of tigers being so bold as to carry off troopers riding in the ranks of their regiments. Twelve years later (a.d. 1839) Mr. Fergusson168 found the hill a vast uninhabited jungle, the rank vegetation tearing the buildings of the city to pieces and obscuring them so that they could hardly be seen.169 Between a.d. 1842 and 1852 tigers are described as prowling among the regal rooms, the half-savage marauding Bhíl as eating his meal and feeding his cattle in the cloisters of its sanctuaries and the insidious pípal as levelling to the earth the magnificent remains.170 So favourite a tiger retreat was the Jah√°z Palace that it was dangerous to venture into it unarmed. Close to the very huts of the poor central village, near the J√°m√° Mosque, cattle were frequently seized by tigers. In the south tigers came nightly to drink at the S√°gar lake. Huge bonfires had to be burnt to prevent them attacking the houses.171 In a.d. 1883 Captain Eastwick wrote: At M√°ndu the traveller will require some armed men, as tigers are very numerous and dangerous. He will do well not to have any dogs with him, as the panthers will take them even from under his bed.172 If this was true of M√°ndu in a.d. 1883—and is not as seems likely the repetition of an old-world tale—the last ten years have wrought notable changes. Through the interest His Highness Sir Anand R√°o Pav√°r, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., the present Mah√°r√°ja of Dh√°r takes in the old capital of his state, travelling in M√°ndu is now as safe and easier than in many, perhaps than in most, outlying districts. A phæton can drive across the northern ravine-moat through the three gateways and along the hill-top, at least as far south as the Sea Lake. Large stretches of the level are cleared and tilled, and herds of cattle graze free from the dread of wild beasts. The leading buildings have been saved from their ruinous tree-growth, the underwood has been cleared, the marauding Bhíl has settled to tillage, the tiger, even the panther, is nearly [384]
Appendix II.
The Hill Fort of M√°ndu.
History
Notices, a.d. 1820–1895. as rare as the wild elephant, and finally its old wholesomeness has returned to the air of the hill-top.

This sketch notices only the main events and the main buildings. Even about the main buildings much is still doubtful. Many inscriptions, some in the puzzling interlaced Tughra character, have still to be read. They may bring to light traces of the M√°ndu kings and of the Mughal emperors, whose connection with M√°ndu, so far as the buildings are concerned, is still a blank. The ruins are so many and so widespread that weeks are wanted to ensure their complete examination. It may be hoped that at no distant date Major Delasseau, the Political Agent of Dh√°r, whose opportunities are not more special than his knowledge, may be able to prepare a complete description of the hill and of its many ruins and writings.

1 The following Persian verses are carved on the Âlamgír gateway:

In the time of Álamgír Aurangzíb (a.d. 1658–1707), the ruler of the World,

This gate resembling the skies in altitude was built anew.

In the year a.h. 1079 (a.d. 1668) the work of renewal was begun and completed

By the endeavour of the exalted Kh√°n Muhammad Beg Kh√°n.

From the accession of this Emperor of the World Aurangzíb.

This was the eleventh year by way of writing and history.

 ↑

2 Mr. Fergusson (Indian Architecture, page 543) says: “The pillars appear to have been taken from a Jain building.” But the refinement on the square capital of each pillar of the Hindu Singh-múkh or horned face into a group of leaves of the same outline shows that the pillars were specially carved for use in a Muslim building. The porch on the north side of the tomb enclosure is described (Ditto, page 543) as composed of pillars avowedly re-erected from a Jain building. This note of Mr. Fergusson’s must have gone astray, as the north porch of Hoshang’s tomb enclosure is in the plain massive pointed arch and square-shafted style of the tomb and of the great mosque. Mr. Fergusson’s note apparently belongs to the second and smaller J√°m√° Masjid, about a hundred yards east of the Sea or Sag√°r lake, the pillars of whose colonnade and porch are still enlivened by rows of the lucky face of the Hindu old horny. ↑

3 Hoshang’s great mosque has the following much damaged Persian inscription:

The mosque of exalted construction, the temple of heavenly altitude,

Whose every thick pillar is a copy of the (pillars of the) Sacred Temple (the Temple of Makkah).

On account of the greatness of its dignity, like the pigeons of the Temple of Makkah,

Sacred angels of high degree are always engaged in hovering around it,

The result of the events born of the merciless revolution of the skies.

When the sun of his life came as far as the balcony (i. e. was ready to set).

Áazam Hum√°yún (that is Malik Mughi’s) said …

The administration of the country, the construction of buildings, and the driving back of enemies

Are things which I leave you (the son of Áazam Hum√°yún) as parting advice with great earnestness.

The personification of the kindness of Providence, the Sult√°n Al√°-ud-dín (Mehmúd I. a.d. 1436–1469), who is

The outcome of the refulgence of the Faith, and the satisfier of the wants of the people,

In the year a.h. 858. (a.d. 1454),

In the words of the above parting advice, finished the construction of this building.

 ↑

4 This J√°m√° Mosque has the following Persian inscription dated H. 835 (a.d. 1431):

With good omens, at a happy time, and in a lucky and well-started year,

On the 4th of the month of All√°h (Ramaz√°n) on the great day of Friday,

In the year 835 and six months from the Hijrah (a.d. 1431)

Counted according to the revolution of the moon in the Arabian manner,

This Islamic mosque was founded in this world,

The top of whose dome rubs its head against the green canopy of Heaven.

The construction of this high mosque was due to Mughís-ud-dín-wad-dunya (Malik Mughís), the father of Mehmúd I. of M√°lwa (a.d. 1436–1469), the redresser of temporal and spiritual wrongs.

Ulugh (brave), Áazam (great), Hum√°yún (august), the Kh√°n of the seven climes and the nine countries.

By the hands of his enterprise this so great mosque was founded,

That some call it the House of Peace, others style it the Ka√°bah.

This good building was completed on the last of the month of Shaww√°l (a.h. 835, a.d. 1431).

May the merit of this good act be inserted in the scroll of the Kh√°n’s actions!

In this centre may the praises of the sermon read (in the name) of Mehmúd Sh√°h

Be everlasting, so long as mountains stand on the earth and stars in the firmament.

 ↑

5 The following Persian inscription carved on the entrance arch shows that though it may have been repaired by B√°z Bah√°dur, the building of the palace was fifty years earlier (H. 914, a.d. 1508):

“In the time of the Sult√°n of Nations, the most just and great, and the most knowing and munificent Kh√°k√°n N√°sir Sh√°h Khilji (a.d. 1500–1512). Written by Yúsuf, the year (H. 914) (a.d. 1508).” ↑

6 Translations of its two much-admired Persian inscriptions are given below pages 370–371. ↑

7 On the T√°r√°púr gateway a Persian inscription of the reign of the emperor Akbar (a.d. 1556–1605) states that the royal road that passed through this gateway was repaired by T√°hir Muhammad Hasan Im√°d-ud-dín. ↑

8 The Persian references and extracts in this section are contributed by Kh√°n S√°heb Fazl-ul-l√°h Lutfull√°h Farídi of Surat. ↑

9 Sir John Malcolm in Eastwick’s Handbook of the Panj√°b, 119. This reference has not been traced. Farishtah (Elliot, VI. 563) says M√°ndu was built by Anand Dev of the Bais tribe, who was a contemporary of Khusrao Parwíz the Sassanian (a.d. 591–621). ↑

10 The date is uncertain. Compare Elphinstone’s History, 323; Briggs’ Farishtah, I. 210–211; Tabak√°t-i-N√°siri in Elliot, II. 328. The conquest of M√°ndu in a.d. 1227 is not M√°ndu in M√°lwa as Elphinstone and Briggs supposed, but Mandúr in the Siw√°lik Hills. See Elliot, Vol. II. page 325 Note 1. The Persian text of Farishtah (I. 115), though by mistake calling it M√°ndu (not M√°ndu), notes that it was the Mandu in the Siw√°lik hills. The poetical date-script also terms it Bil√°di-Siw√°lik or the Siw√°lik countries. The date of the conquest of the Siw√°lik M√°ndu by Altamsh is given by Farishtah (Ditto) as a.h. 624 (a.d. 1226). The conquest of M√°lwa by Altamsh, the taking by him of Bhilsah and Ujjain, and the destruction of the temple of Maha K√°li and of the statue or image of Bikram√°jit are given as occurring in a.h. 631 (a.d. 1233). The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 13) notices an expedition made in a.d. 1395 by Zafar Kh√°n (Muzaffar I. of Gujar√°t) against a Hindu chief of M√°ndu, who, it was reported, was oppressing the Musalm√°ns. A siege of more than twelve months failed to capture the fort. ↑

11 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 170. ↑

12 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 168. According to the W√°kiăt-i-Musht√°ki (Elliot, IV. 553) Dil√°war Kh√°n, or as the writer calls him Amín Sh√°h, through the good offices of a merchant whom he had refrained from plundering obtained the grant of M√°ndu, which was entirely desolate. The king sent a robe and a horse, and Amín gave up walking and took to riding. He made his friends ride, enlisted horsemen, and promoted the cultivation of the country (Elliot, IV. 552). Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 460–61) states that when Sult√°n Muhammad, the son of Fírúz Tughlak, made Khw√°jah Sarwar his chief minister with the title of Khw√°jah Jeh√°n, and gave Zafar Kh√°n the viceroyalty of Gujar√°t and Khizr Kh√°n that of Mult√°n, he sent Dil√°war Kh√°n to be governor of M√°lwa. In another passage Farishtah (II. 461) states that one of Dil√°war’s grandfathers, Sult√°n Shah√°b-ud-dín, came from Ghor and took service in the court of the Dehli Sult√°ns. His son rose to be an Amír, and his grandson Dil√°war Kh√°n, in the time of Sult√°n Fírúz, became a leading nobleman, and in the reign of Muhammad, son of Fírúz, obtained M√°lwa in fief. When the power of the Tughlaks went to ruin Dil√°war assumed the royal emblems of the umbrella and the red-tent. ↑

13 Dil√°war Kh√°n Ghori, whose original name was Husein, was one of the grandsons of Sult√°n Shah√°b-ud-dín Muhammad bin S√°m. He was one of the nobles of Muhammad, the son of Fírúz Tughlak, who after the death of that monarch, settled in and asserted his power over M√°lwa. (Pers. Text Faristah, II. 460). The emperor Jeh√°ngír (who calls him Âmíd Sh√°h Ghori) attributes to him the construction of the fort of Dh√°r. He says (Memoirs Pers. Text, 201–202): Dh√°r is one of the oldest cities of India. R√°ja Bhoj, one of the famous ancient Hindu kings, lived in this city. From his time up to this a thousand years have passed. Dh√°r was also the capital of the Muhammadan rulers of M√°lwa. When Sult√°n Muhammad Tughlak (a.d. 1325) was on his way to the conquest of the Dakhan he built a cut-stone fort on a raised site. Its outline is very elegant and beautiful, but the space inside is empty of buildings. Âmíd Sh√°h Ghori, known as Dil√°war Kh√°n, who in the days of Sult√°n Muhammad the son of Sult√°n Fírúz, king of Dehli, gained the independent rule of M√°lwa, built outside this fort an assembly mosque, which has in front of it fixed in the ground a four-cornered iron column about four feet round. When Sult√°n Bah√°dur of Gujar√°t took M√°lwa (a.d. 1530–31) he wished to carry this column to Gujar√°t. In digging it up the pillar fell and broke in two, one piece measuring twenty-two feet the other thirteen feet. As it was lying here uncared-for, I (Jeh√°ngír) ordered the big piece to be carried to Ágra to be put up in the courtyard of the shrine of him whose abode is the heavenly throne (Akbar), to be utilised as a lamp post. The mosque has two gates. In front of the arch of one gate they have fixed a stone tablet engraved with a prose passage to the effect that Âhmíd Sh√°h Ghori in the year H. 808 (a.d. 1405) laid the foundation of this mosque. On the other arch they have written a poetic inscription of which the following verses are a part:

The liege lord of the world.

The star of the sphere of glory.

The stay of the people.

The sun of the zenith of perfection.

The bulwark of the law of the Prophet, Ámíd Sh√°h D√°úd.

The possessor of amiable qualities, the pride of Ghor.

Dil√°war Kh√°n, the helper and defender of the Prophet’s faith.

The chosen instrument of the exalted Lord, who in the city of Dh√°r constructed the assembly mosque

In a happy and auspicious moment on a day of lucky omen.

Of the date 808 years have passed (a.d. 1405)

When this fabric of Hope was completed.

 ↑

14 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 169. ↑

15 When fellow-nobles in the court of the Tughlak Sult√°n, Zafar Kh√°n (Sult√°n Muzaffar of Gujar√°t) and Dil√°war Kh√°n bound themselves under an oath to be brothers in arms. Farishtah, Pers. Text II. 462. ↑

16 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 173; Elphinstone’s History, 678. ↑

17 Though their temples were turned into mosques the Jains continued to prosper under the Ghoris. At Deogarh in Lalitpura in Jh√°nsi in the North-West Provinces an inscription of Samvat 1481, that is of a.d. 1424, records the dedication of two Jaina images by a Jain priest named Holi during the reign of Sh√°h Alambhaka of Mandapapura, that is of Sh√°h Alp Kh√°n of M√°ndu that is Sult√°n Hoshang Ghori. Archæological Survey of India, New Series, II. 120. ↑

18 Farishtah, Pers. Text II. 464–65. ↑

19 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 176, 178, 180, 181, 183. ↑

20 Farishtah, Pers. Text II. 466–67. ↑

21 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 180. In connection with the T√°r√°púr Gate Farishtah says (Pers. Text, II. 468): The fort of M√°ndu is built on the top of a mountain, and the line of its fortification is about twenty-eight miles in length. In place of a moat it is surrounded by a deep chasm, so that it is impossible to use missiles against it. Within the fort water and provisions are abundant and it includes land enough to grow grain for the garrison. The extent of its walls makes it impossible for an army to invest it. Most of the villages near it are too small to furnish supplies to a besieging force. The south or T√°r√°púr gate is exceedingly difficult of access. A horseman can hardly approach it. From whichever side the fort may be attempted, most difficult heights have to be scaled. The long distances and intervening hills prevent the watchers of the besieging force communicating with each other. The gate on the side of Delhi is of easier access than the other gates. ↑

22 It follows that Farishtah (Briggs, IV. 196) is mistaken in stating that Hoshang’s son Muhammad gave M√°ndu the name of Sh√°di√°b√°d, the Abode of Joy. ↑

23 Farishtah, Pers. Text II. 472–475. It seems to follow that from the first the monument to Hoshang in Hoshang√°b√°d was an empty tomb. Compare Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 180–190. ↑

24 The following more detailed, but also more confused, story is told in the W√°kiăt-i-Musht√°ki (Elliot, IV. 552–54): A man named Mehmúd, son of Mughís Khilji, came to Hoshang and entered his service. He was a treacherous man, who secretly aspired to the throne. He became minister, and gave his daughter in marriage to the king. [Farishtah, Pers. Text, II. 474, says: “Malik Mughís gave his daughter (Mehmúd’s sister) in marriage, not to Hoshang, but to Hoshang’s son Muhammad Shah.”] His father Malik Mughís, coming to know of his son’s ambitious designs, informed the king of them. Hereupon Mehmúd feigned illness, and to deceive the king’s physicians shut himself in a dark room and drank the blood of a newly killed goat. When the physicians came Mehmúd rose hastily, threw up the blood into a basin, and tossing back his head rolled on the floor as if in pain. The physicians called for a light. When they saw that what Mehmúd had spat up was blood they were satisfied of his sickness, and told the king that Mehmúd had not long to live. The king refrained from killing a dying man. This strange story seems to be an embellishment of a passage in Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 477). When Kh√°n Jeh√°n, that is Malik Mughís the father of Mehmúd, was ordered by Sult√°n Muhammad to take the field against the R√°jput rebels of N√°doti (H√°roti?) many of the old nobles of M√°lwa went with him. In their absence the party hostile to the Khiljis represented to Sult√°n Muhammad that Mehmúd Khilji was plotting his death. On hearing that the Sult√°n was enraged against him Mehmúd secluded himself from the Court on pretence of illness. At the same time he worked secretly and bribed Sult√°n Muhammad’s cup-bearer to poison his master. On the death of Sult√°n Muhammad the party of nobles opposed to Mehmúd, concealing the fact of Muhammad’s death, sent word that Muhammad had ordered him immediately to the palace, as he wanted to send him on an embassy to Gujar√°t. Mehmúd, who knew that the Sult√°n was dead, returned word to the nobles that he had vowed a life-long seclusion as the sweeper of the shrine of his patron Sult√°n Hoshang, but that if the nobles came to him and convinced him that the good of his country depended on his going to Gujar√°t he was ready to go and see Sult√°n Muhammad. The nobles were caught in their own trap. They went to Mehmúd and were secured and imprisoned by him. ↑

25 Farishtah, Pers. Text, II. 480. ↑

26 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 196. These titles mean: The Chief of Nobles, the Great, the August. ↑

27 It is related that one of the pious men in the camp of Sult√°n Ahmed of Gujar√°t had a warning dream, in which the Prophet (on whom be peace) appeared to him and said: “The calamity of (spirit of) pestilence is coming down from the skies. Tell Sult√°n Ahmed to leave this country.” This warning was told to Sult√°n Ahmed, but he disregarded it, and within three days pestilence raged in his camp. Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 484. ↑

28 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 205, gives 230 minarets and 360 arches. This must have been an addition in the Text used by Briggs. These details do not apply to the building. The Persian text of Farishtah, II. 485, mentions 208 columns or pillars (duyast o hasht ustuw√°nah). No reference is made either to minarets or to arches. ↑

29 Farishtah, Pers. Text II. 487. ↑

30 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 207. Malcolm’s Central India, I. 32. In a.d. 1817 Sir John Malcolm (Central India, I. 32 Note) fitted up one of Mehmúd’s palaces as a hot-weather residence. ↑

31 Of the siege of Kumbhalmer a curious incident is recorded by Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 485). He says that a temple outside the town destroyed by Mehmúd had a marble idol in the form of a goat. The Sult√°n ordered the idol to be ground into lime and sold to the R√°jputs as betel-leaf lime, so that the Hindus might eat their god. The idol was perhaps a ram, not a goat. The temple would then have been a Sun-temple and the ram, the carrier or v√°hana of the Sun, would have occupied in the porch a position similar to that held by the bull in a Mah√°deva temple. ↑

32 Ruins of M√°ndu, 13. ↑

33 In the end of a.h. 846 (a.d. 1442) Mehmúd built a seven-storeyed tower and a college opposite the J√°m√° Mosque of Hoshang Sh√°h. Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 210; Persian Text, II. 488. ↑

34 Compare Briggs’ Farishtah, IV 323. ↑

35 Gladwin’s Áin-i-Akbari, II. 41. ↑

36 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 210; Farishtah, Persian Text II. 488. ↑

37 Memoirs of the emperor Jeh√°ngír (Pers. Text) Sir Sayad Áhmed’s Edition, page 188, eleventh year of Jeh√°ngír, a.d. 1617. ↑

38 Herbert’s Kh√°n Jehan is doubtless Mehmúd’s father the minister Malik Mughís, Kh√°n Jeh√°n Aâzam Hum√°yún. It cannot be Kh√°n Jeh√°n Pir Muhammad, Akbar’s general, who after only a few months’ residence was slain in M√°ndu in a.d. 1561; nor can it be Jeh√°ngír’s great Afgh√°n general, Kh√°n Jeh√°n Lodi (a.d. 1600–1630), as he was not in M√°ndu until a.d. 1628, that is more than a year after Herbert left India. Compare Herbert’s Travels, 107–118; Elliot, VI. 249–323, VII. 7, 8, and 21; and Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 503–506. ↑

39 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 214. ↑

40 Ruins of M√°ndu, 13. Farishtah has three mentions of colleges. One (Pers. Text, II. 475) as the place where the body of Hoshang was carried, probably that prayers might be said over it. In another passage in the reign of Mehmúd I. (Pers. Text, II. 480) he states that Mehmúd built colleges in his territories which became the envy of Shír√°z and Samarkand. In a third passage he mentions a college (page 488) near the Victory Tower. ↑

41 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 217. A different but almost incredible account of the capture of the royal belt is given in the Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Pers. Text, 159: When Sult√°n Kutb-ud-dín, son of Sult√°n Muhammad, defeated Sult√°n Mehmúd Khilji at the battle of Kapadvanj, there was such a slaughter as could not be exceeded. By chance, in the heat of the fray, which resembled the Day of Judgment, the wardrobe-keeper of Sult√°n Kutb-ud-dín, in whose charge was the jewelled belt, was by the restiveness of his horse carried into the ranks of the enemy. The animal there became so violent that the wardrobe-keeper fell off and was captured by the enemy, and the jewelled belt was taken from him and given to Sult√°n Mehmúd of M√°lwa. The author adds: This jewelled waistband was in the M√°lwa treasury at the time the fortress of M√°ndu was taken by the strength of the arm of Sult√°n Muzaffar (a.d. 1531). Sult√°n Mehmúd sent this belt together with a fitting sword and horse to Sult√°n Muzaffar by the hands of his son. ↑

42 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 209. ↑

43 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 234–235: Pers. Text, II. 503. ↑

44 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 236. ↑

45 Ruins of M√°ndu, 6. ↑

46 Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 504–505. ↑

47 Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 505. ↑

48 Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 507. ↑

49 W√°kiăt-i-Musht√°ki in Elliot, IV. 554–556. Probably these are stock tales. The Gujar√°t historians give Muzaffar and Muhammad the Gold-giver (a.d. 1441–1451) credit for the horse scrupulosity. See Mirăt-i-Sikandari Pers. Text, 178. ↑

50 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 236–239; W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 349–350; W√°kiăt-i-Musht√°ki in Elliot, IV. 554–55; Malcolm’s Central India, I. 35–36. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Pers. Text, 160) has the following notice of Ghi√°s-ud-dín: The Sult√°ns of M√°ndu had reached such a pitch of luxury and ease that it is impossible to imagine aught exceeding it. Among them Sult√°n Ghi√°s-ud-dín was so famous for his luxurious habits, that at present (a.d. 1611) if any one exceeds in luxury and pleasure, they say he is a second Ghi√°s-ud-dín. The orders of the Sult√°n were that no event of a painful nature or one in which there was any touch of sadness should be related to him. They say that during his entire reign news of a sad nature was only twice conveyed to him: once when his son-in-law died and once when his daughter was brought before him clothed in white. On this occasion the Sult√°n is related to have simply said: “Perhaps her husband is dead.” This he said because the custom of the people of India is that when the husband of a woman dies she gives up wearing coloured clothes. The second occasion was when the army of Sult√°n Bahlol Lodi plundered several of the districts of Chanderi. Though it was necessary to report this to the Sult√°n, his ministers were unable to communicate it to him. They therefore asked a band of actors (bh√°nds) to assume the dress of Afgh√°ns, and mentioning the districts to represent them as being pillaged and laid waste. Sult√°n Ghi√°s-ud-dín exclaimed in surprise: “But is the governor of Chanderi dead that he does not avenge upon the Afgh√°ns the ruin of his country!” ↑

51 Compare Catalogue of Indian Coins, The Mahomedan States, pages LIV. LV. and 118–121. ↑

52 Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 507. ↑

53 Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 508) detailing how N√°sir-ud-dín came to power, says: There was a difference between N√°sir-ud-dín and his brother Al√°-ud-dín. The mother of these princes, Khurshíd R√°ni, who was the daughter of the Hindu chief of B√°gl√°na, had taken Al√°-ud-dín the younger brother’s side. After killing his father N√°sir-ud-dín ordered his mother to be dragged out of the harím and Al√°-ud-dín and his children to be slaughtered like lambs. ↑

54 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 238–239. Farishtah holds that N√°sir-ud-dín’s murder of his father is not proved. He adds (Pers. Text, II. 515) that N√°sir-ud-dín was at Dh√°r where he had gone to quell the rebellion of the nobles when the news of Ghi√°s-ud-dín’s death reached him. He argues that as a parricide cannot flourish more than a year after his father’s murder, and as N√°sir-ud-dín ruled for years after that event, he could not have killed his father. ↑

55 Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 516. ↑

56 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 243. The emperor Jeh√°ngír (Memoirs Pers. Text, 181) says that N√°sir-ud-dín had a disease which made him feel so hot that he used to sit for hours in water. ↑

57 W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 350. Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 517–18) says that N√°sir-ud-dín died of a burning-fever he had contracted by hard drinking and other evil habits, that he showed keen penitence before his death, and bequeathed his kingdom to his third son Mehmúd. The emperor Jeh√°ngír (Memoirs Pers. Text, 181) confirms the account of the W√°kiăt as to the manner of N√°sir-ud-dín’s death. ↑

58 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 243. ↑

59 The emperor Jeh√°ngír thus describes (Memoirs Pers. Text, 181) his visit to N√°sir-ud-dín’s grave. It is related that when during his reign Sher Kh√°n Afgh√°n Súr (a.d. 1540–1555) visited N√°sir-ud-dín’s grave he ordered his attendants to flagellate the parricide’s tomb: When I visited the sepulchre I kicked his grave and ordered those with me to do the same. Not satisfied with this I ordered his bones to be dug out and burned and the ashes to be thrown into the Narbada. ↑

60 W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 350. The emperor Jeh√°ngír (Memoirs Pers. Text, 202) refers to the well-known bridge and water-palace about three miles north of Ujjain as the work of N√°sir-ud-dín. He says: On Sunday I reached Sa√°dulpur near Ujjain. In this village is a river house with a bridge on which are alcoves both built by N√°sir-ud-dín Khilji (a.d. 1500–1512). Though the bridge is not specially praiseworthy the water-courses and cisterns connected with it have a certain merit. ↑

61 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 246. ↑

62 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 247–249. Malcolm’s (Central India, I. 38) writes the R√°jput’s name Maderay. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Persian Text, 149–155), gives the form Med√°ni Rai, the Lord of the Battlefield, a title which the author says (page 149) Mehmúd conferred on the R√°jput in acknowledgment of his prowess. ↑

63 The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Pers. Text, 154) gives the following details of Mehmúd’s flight: Sult√°n Mehmúd, on pretence of hunting left M√°ndu and remained hunting for several days. The Hindus, whom Med√°ni R√°i had placed on guard over him, slept after the fatigue of the chase. Only some of the more trusted guards remained. Among them was a R√°jput named Kṛishṇa, a M√°lwa zamínd√°r who was attached to the Sult√°n. Mehmúd said to Kṛishṇa: “Can you find me two horses and show me the way to Gujar√°t that I may get aid from Sult√°n Muzaffar to punish these rascals? If you can, do so at once, and, All√°h willing, you shall be handsomely rewarded.” Kṛishṇa brought two horses from the Sult√°n’s stables. Mehmúd rode on one and seated his dearest of wives, R√°ni Kannya Kuar, on the other. Kṛishṇa marched in front. In half the night and one day they reached the Gujar√°t frontier. ↑

64 T√°rikh-i-Sher Sh√°hi in Elliot, IV. 386. The Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Pers. Text, 160) gives the following details of the banquet: Sult√°n Mehmúd showed great hospitality and humility. After the banquet as he led the Sult√°n over the palaces, they came to a mansion in the centre of which was a four-cornered building like the Kaâbah, carved and gilded, and round it were many apartments. When Sult√°n Muzaffar placed his foot within the threshold of that building the thousand beauties of Sult√°n Mehmúd’s harím, magnificently apparelled and jewelled, all at once opened the doors of their chambers and burst into view like húris and fairies. When Muzaffar’s eyes fell on their charms he bowed his head and said: “To see other than one’s own harím is sinful.” Sult√°n Mehmúd replied: “These are mine, and therefore yours, seeing that I am the slave purchased by your Majesty’s kindness.” Muzaffar said: “They are more suitable for you. May you have joy in them. Let them retire.” At a signal from Sult√°n Mehmúd the ladies vanished. ↑

65 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 250–262. ↑

66 Farishtah Pers. Text. II. 527. According to the Mirăt-i-Sikandari (Pers. Text, 161) Mehmúd marched against G√°graun first, and slew Hemkaran, a partisan of Med√°ni R√°i, in a hand-to-hand fight. On this the R√°na and Med√°ni R√°i joined their forces against Mehmúd. ↑

67 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 262–263. ↑

68 Persian Edition, 239. ↑

69 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 267–68. Sult√°n Bah√°dur apparently surprised the party in charge of the T√°r√°púr or Southern Gate. ↑

70 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 269; Mirăt-i-Áhmedi, Persian Text, I. 76. ↑

71 Briggs’ Farishtah, II. 77. ↑

72 Abul Fazl’s Akbar N√°mah in Elliot, VI. 14; Briggs’ Farishtah, II. 77. ↑

73 Abul Fazl’s Akbar N√°mah in Elliot, V. 192. ↑

74 Abul Fazl’s Akbar N√°mah in Elliot, VI. 15; Briggs’ Farishtah, II. 80–81. ↑

75 Abul Fazl’s Akbar N√°mah in Elliot, VI. 18. According to Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 532) Mallu, the son of Mallu, was a native of M√°lwa and a Khilji slave noble. Mallu received his title of K√°dir Sh√°h from Sult√°n Mehmúd III. of Gujar√°t (a.d. 1536–1544) at the recommendation of his minister Im√°d-ul-Mulk who was a great friend of Mallu. Mirăt-i-Sikandari, Persian Text, 298. ↑

76 Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 532. ↑

77 T√°rikh-i-Sher Sh√°h in Elliot, IV. 391; Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 271–72. ↑

78 Farishtah (Pers. Text, 533–34) refers to the following circumstance as the cause of K√°dir Sh√°h’s suspicion. On his way to Sher Sh√°h’s darb√°r at Ujjain K√°dir saw some Mughal prisoners in chains making a road. One of the prisoners seeing him began to sing:

Mar√° mí bín darín ahw√°l o fikrí khíshtan mí kun!

In this plight thou seest me to-day,

Thine own turn is not far away.

When K√°dir Sh√°h escaped, Sher Sh√°h on hearing of his flight exclaimed:

B√° m√° chi kard dídí

Mallû Ghul√°m-i-gídí.

Thus he treats us with scorn,

Mallu the slave base born.

To this one of Sher Sh√°h’s men replied:

Kaul-i-Rasúl bar hakk

L√° khaira fil abídi.

The words of the Prophet are true,

No good can a slave ever do.

 ↑

79 T√°rikh-i-Sher Sh√°hi in Elliot, IV. 397. ↑

80 T√°rikh-i-Alfi in Elliott, V. 168; Elphinstone’s India, 402–403. ↑

81 T√°rikh-i-Alfi in Elliot, V. 168. ↑

82 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 276. ↑

83 When B√°z Bah√°dur attacked the Gonds their chief was dead, and his widow, R√°ni Durg√°vati, was ruling in his place. The R√°ni led the Gonds against the invaders, and hemming them in one of the passes, inflicted on them such a defeat that B√°z Bah√°dur fled from the field leaving his baggage and camp in her hands. Farishtah Pers. Text, II. 538. ↑

84 According to Farishtah (Pers. Text, II. 538) B√°z Bah√°dur was already an adept in music. ↑

85 Malcolm’s Central India, I. 39; Ruins of M√°ndu, 30. ↑

86 Briggs’ Farishtah, II. 210. ↑

87 Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 321. ↑

88 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 211. ↑

89 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 216. ↑

90 Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot, V. 291. ↑

91 Tabak√°t-i-Akbari in Elliot, V. 330–31. ↑

92 Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 375. ↑

93 The emperor Jeh√°ngír thus describes (Memoirs Pers. Text, 372) a visit to this building: On the third day of Amard√°d (July 1617) with the palace ladies I set out to see Nílkanth, which is one of the pleasantest places in M√°ndu fort. Sh√°h Bud√°gh Kh√°n, who was one of the trusted nobles of my august father, built this very pleasing and joy-giving lodge during the time he held this province in fief (a.d. 1572–1577). I remained at Nílkanth till about an hour after nightfall and then returned to my state quarters. ↑

94 An officer who distinguished himself under Hum√°yún, one of Akbar’s commanders of Three Thousand, long governor of M√°ndu, where he died. Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 372. ↑

95 When opposed to Ârab the word Âjam signifies all countries except Arabia, and in a narrow sense, Persia. The meaning of the word Âjam is dumbness, the Arabs so glorying in the richness of their own tongue as to hold all other countries and nations dumb. ↑

96 The stones on which this inscription is carved have been wrongly arranged by some restorer. Those with the latter portion of the inscription come first and those with the beginning come last. Múnshi Abdur Rahím of Dh√°r. ↑

97 The maternal uncle of Naushírw√°n (a.d. 586–635) the Sassanian, Shirw√°n Sh√°h was ruler of a district on Mount Caucasus. Al Masúdi, Arabic Text Prairies d’Or, II. 4, and Rauzat-us-Safa, Persian Text, I. 259. ↑

98 Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 353. ↑

99 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 279. ↑

100 Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 429. ↑

101 Gladwin’s Áin-i-Akbari, II. 41. ↑

102 Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 31. ↑

103 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 169, 181, 190. ↑

104 Nineteen kos, taking the kos to be two miles. ↑

105 The emperor Jeh√°ngír’s Memoirs, Pers. Text, Sir Sayad Áhmed’s Edition, 178–203. ↑

106 Literally single-men. The Ahadís were a corps of men who stood immediately under the emperor’s orders. Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 20 note 1. ↑

107 This scattering of gold silver or copper coin, called in Arabic and Persian nis√°r, is a common form of offering. The influence of the evil eye or other baneful influence is believed to be transferred from the person over whom the coin is scattered to the coin and through the coin to him who takes it. ↑

108 This feat of Núr Jeh√°n’s drew from one of the Court poets the couplet:

Núr Jeh√°n gar chih ba súrat zanast

Dar safi Mard√°n zani sher afkanast.

Núr Jeh√°n the tiger-slayer’s woman

Ranks with men as the tiger-slaying woman.

Sherafkan, that is tiger-slayer, was the title of Núr Jeh√°n’s first husband Ali-Kuli Istajlu. ↑

109 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 187. ↑

110 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 189. ↑

111 The misk√°l which was used in weighing gold was equal in weight to ninety-six barleycorns. Blochman’s Áin-i-Akbari, 36. ↑

112 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 195. ↑

113 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 195. ↑

114 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 192–194. ↑

115 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 190. ↑

116 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 192. ↑

117 Tuzuk-i-Jeh√°ngíri Pers. Text, 194–5. ↑

118 A Voyage to East India, 181. Terry gives April 1616, but Roe seems correct in saying March 1617. Compare W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 351. ↑

119 Akbarpur lies between Dharampuri and Waisar. Malcolm’s Central India, I. 84 note. ↑

120 Carriages may have the old meaning of things carried, that is baggage. The time taken favours the view that wagons or carts were forced up the hill. For the early seventeenth century use of carriages in its modern sense compare Terry (Voyage, 161). Of our wagons drawn with oxen … and other carriages we made a ring every night; also Dodsworth (1614), who describes a band of R√°jputs near Baroda cutting off two of his carriages (Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 203); and Roe (1616), who journeyed from Ajmír to M√°ndu with twenty camels four carts and two coaches (Kerr, IX. 308). Terry’s carriages seem to be Roe’s coaches, to which Dela Valle (a.d. 1623) Hakluyt’s Edition, (I. 21) refers as much like the Indian chariots described by Strabo (b.c. 50) covered with crimson silk fringed with yellow about the roof and the curtains. Compare Idrísi (a.d. 1100–1150), but probably from Al Istakhiri, a.d. 960: Elliot, I. 87). In all Nahrwala or north Gujar√°t the only mode of carrying either passengers or goods is in chariots drawn by oxen with harness and traces under the control of a driver. When in 1616 Jeh√°ngír left Ajmír for M√°ndu the English carriage presented to him by the English ambassador Sir Thomas Roe was allotted to the Sult√°nah Núr Jeh√°n Begam. It was driven by an English coachman. Jeh√°ngír followed in the coach his own men had made in imitation of the English coach. Corryat (1615, Crudities III., Letters from India, unpaged) calls the English chariot a gallant coach of 150 pounds price. ↑

121 Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 335; W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 377. ↑

122 Roe writing from Ajmír in the previous year (29th August 1616) describes M√°ndu as a castle on a hill, where there is no town and no buildings. Kerr, IX. 267. ↑

123 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 313. ↑

124 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 314. ↑

125 Compare W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 377. ↑

126 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 314. ↑

127 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 321. ↑

128 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 335. ↑

129 Corryat’s Crudities, III. Extracts (unpaged). This Master Herbert was Thomas, brother of Sir Edward Herbert, the first Lord Herbert. It seems probable that this Thomas supplied his cousin Sir Thomas Herbert who was travelling in India and Persia in a.d. 1627 with his account of M√°ndu. See below pages 381–382. ↑

130 Corryat’s Crudities, III. Extracts (unpaged). ↑

143 Roe in Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 343. ↑

144 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 340–343. ↑

145 Roe in Kerr’s Travels, IX. 344. ↑

146 Terry’s Voyage, 377. Terry’s details seem not to agree with Roe’s who states (Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 344 and Pinkerton’s Voyages, VIII. 37): I was invited to the drinking, but desired to be excused because there was no avoiding drinking, and their liquors are so hot that they burn out a man’s very bowels. Perhaps the invitation Roe declined was to a private drinking party after the public weighing was over. ↑

147 Roe in Kerr’s Voyage, IX. 347; Elphinstone’s History, 494. Kerr (IX. 347) gives September 2 but October 2 is right. Compare Pinkerton’s Voyages, VIII. 39. ↑

148 Ruins of M√°ndu, 57. As the emperor must have passed out by the Dehli Gate, and as Roe’s lodge was two miles from B√°z Bah√°dur’s palace, the lodge cannot have been far from the Dehli Gate. It is disappointing that, of his many genial gossipy entries Jeh√°ngír does not devote one to Roe. The only reference to Roe’s visit is the indirect entry (Wa’kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 347) that Jeh√°ngír gave one of his nobles a coach, apparently a copy of the English coach, with which, to Jeh√°ngír’s delight, Roe had presented him. ↑

149 Roe in Kerr’s Voyages, IX. 353. ↑

150 Terry’s Voyage, 180. ↑

151 Terry’s Voyage, 181. ↑

152 W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 383. ↑

153 W√°kiăt-i-Jeh√°ngíri in Elliot, VI. 387. ↑

154 Elphinstone’s History, 496–97. Compare Dela Valle (Hakluyt Edition, I. 177) writing in a.d. 1622, Sult√°n Khurram after his defeat by Jeh√°ngír retired to M√°ndu. ↑

155 Dela Valle’s Travels, Hakluyt Edition, I. 97. ↑

156 Elphinstone’s History, 507. ↑

157 Herbert’s Travels, 84. Corryat’s Master Herbert was as already noticed named like the traveller Thomas. The two Thomases were distant relations, both being fourth in descent from Sir Richard Herbert of Colebroke, who lived about the middle of the fifteenth century. A further connection between the two families is the copy of complimentary verses “To my cousin Sir Thomas Herbert,” signed Ch. Herbert, in the 1634 and 1665 editions of Herbert’s Travels, which are naturally, though somewhat doubtfully, ascribed to Charles Herbert, a brother of our Master Thomas. It is therefore probable that after his return to England Sir Thomas Herbert obtained the M√°ndu details from Master Thomas who was himself a writer, the author of several poems and pamphlets. Corryat’s tale how, during the water-famine at M√°ndu, Master Herbert annexed a spring or cistern, and then bound a servant of the Great King who attempted to share in its use, shows admirable courage and resolution on the part of Master Thomas, then a youth of twenty years. The details of Thomas in his brother Lord Herbert’s autobiography give additional interest to the hero of Corryat’s tale of a Tank. Master Thomas was born in. a.d. 1597. In 1610, when a page to Sir Edward Cecil and a boy of thirteen, in the German War especially in the siege of Juliers fifteen miles north-east of Aix-la-Chapelle, Master Thomas showed such forwardness as no man in that great army surpassed. On his voyage to India in 1617, in a fight with a great Portuguese carrack, Captain Joseph, in command of Herbert’s ship Globe, was killed. Thomas took Joseph’s place, forced the carrack aground, and so riddled her with shot that she never floated again. To his brother’s visit to India Lord Herbert refers as a year spent with the merchants who went from Surat to the Great Mughal. After his return to England Master Thomas distinguished himself at Algiers, capturing a vessel worth £1800. In 1622, when Master Thomas was in command of one of the ships sent to fetch Prince Charles (afterwards King Charles I.) from Spain, during the return voyage certain Low Countrymen and Dunkirkers, that is Dutch and Spanish vessels, offended the Prince’s dignity by fighting in his presence without his leave. The Prince ordered the fighting ships to be separated; whereupon Master Thomas, with some other ships got betwixt the fighters on either side, and shot so long that both Low Countrymen and Dunkirkers were glad to desist. Afterwards at divers times Thomas fought with great courage and success with divers men in single fight, sometimes hurting and disarming his adversary, sometimes driving him away. The end of Master Thomas was sad. Finding his proofs of himself undervalued he retired into a private and melancholy life, and after living in this sullen humour for many years, he died about 1642 and was buried in London in St. Martin’s near Charing Cross. ↑

158 Khafi Kh√°n in Elliot, VII. 218. ↑

159 Malcolm’s Central India, I. 64. ↑

160 Malcolm’s Central India, I. 78. ↑

161 Malcolm’s Central India, I. 100. ↑

162 Malcolm’s Central India, I. 106. ↑

163 Central India, II. 503. ↑

164 Ruins of M√°ndu, 43: March 1852 page 34. ↑

165 Ruins of M√°ndu, 43: March 1852 page 34. ↑

166 Malcolm’s Central India, II. 503. ↑

167 Briggs’ Farishtah, IV. 235 note *. ↑

168 Indian Architecture, 541. ↑

169 Ruins of M√°ndu, 9. ↑

170 Ruins of M√°ndu, 9. ↑

171 Ruins of M√°ndu, 13, 25, 35. Some of these extracts seem to belong to a Bombay Subaltern, who was at M√°ndu about a.d. 1842, and some to Captain Claudius Harris, who visited the hill in April 1852. Compare Ruins of M√°ndu, 34. ↑

172 Murray’s Handbook of the Panj√°b, 118. ↑

MARÁTHA HISTORY
OF
GUJARÁT:

a.d. 1760–1819.

BY
J. A. BAINES Esquire, C.S.I.,
LATE OF H.M.’s BOMBAY CIVIL SERVICE.

[Contributed in 1879.] [385]

[Contents]

HISTORY OF GUJARÁT.

MARÁTHA PERIOD.

a.d. 1760–1819.


The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. It will be evident from what has been related in the Musalm√°n portion of this history that long before 1760, the Mar√°th√°s had a firm foothold in Gujar√°t, and were able to dictate to the local chiefs the policy of the Dakhan Court. Long before 1819 too, Mar√°tha influence was on the wane before the rising fortunes of the British. Between these two dates however is comprised the whole or nearly the whole of the period during which the Mar√°th√°s were virtually paramount in Gujar√°t. From each of these two dates the political history took a new departure, and on this account they serve respectively to denote the starting point and terminus of Mar√°tha supremacy. Most of what took place before 1760 is so interwoven with the interests and intrigues of the Muhammadan delegates of the court of Dehli that it has been fully described in the history of the Musalm√°n Period. It is however necessary, in order to trace the growth of Mar√°tha power, to briefly set forth in a continuous narrative the events in which this race was principally concerned, adding such as transpired independently of Musalm√°n politics. This task is rendered easier by the very nature of Mar√°tha policy, which has left little to be recorded of its action in Gujar√°t beyond the deeds and fortunes of its initiators and their adherents.

The connection of the Mar√°th√°s with Gujar√°t can be divided by the chronicler into the following periods. First, the time of predatory inroads from 1664 to 1743, before the leaders of these expeditions had permanently established themselves within the province. Secondly, what may be termed the mercenary period, when the Mar√°th√°s partly by independent action, but far more by a course of judicious interference in the quarrels of the Muhammadan officials and by loans of troops, had acquired considerable territorial advantages. Towards the end of this period, as has been already seen, their aid was usually sufficient to ensure the success of the side which had managed to secure it, and at last the capital itself was claimed and held by them. Then came the time of domination, from 1760 to 1801, during which period the G√°ikw√°r influence was occasionally greater than that of the Peshwa. From 1802, internal dissensions at the courts of Poona and Baroda weakened the hold the Mar√°th√°s had on the province, and the paramount power had to all intents and purposes passed over to the British long before the downfall of B√°jir√°v Peshwa and the final annexation of his rights and territory in 1819. [386]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. Shortly after, when the G√°ikw√°r made over to the British the work of collecting the tribute from K√°thi√°v√°ḍa, Mar√°tha supremacy came to an end.

Śiv√°ji’s First Inroad, 1664.The first Mar√°tha force that made its appearance in Gujar√°t was led there early in 1664 by Śiv√°ji. This leader was at the time engaged in a warfare with the Mughals, which, however desultory, required him to keep up a much larger force than could be supported out of the revenues of his dominions. He therefore looked to plunder to supply the deficiency, and Surat, then the richest town of Western India, was marked down by him as an easy prey. His mode of attack was cautious. He first sent one Bahirji N√°ik to spy out the country and report the chances of a rich booty, whilst he himself moved a force up to Junnar on pretence of visiting some forts in that direction recently acquired by one of his subordinates. On receiving a favourable report from Bahirji, Śiv√°ji gave out that he was going to perform religious ceremonies at N√°sik, and taking with him 4000 picked horsemen, he marched suddenly down the Gh√°ts and through the D√°ng jungles, and appeared before Surat. There he found an insignificant garrison, so he rested outside the city six days whilst his men plundered at their leisure. On hearing of the tardy approach of a relieving force sent by the governor of Ahmed√°b√°d, Śiv√°ji beat a retreat with all his booty to the stronghold of R√°ygad. By the time the reinforcement reached Surat, the only trace of the invaders was the emptied coffers of the inhabitants. About the same time, or shortly after, the fleet which Śiv√°ji had equipped at Alib√°g about two years before came up to the mouth of the gulf of Cambay and carried off one or two Mughal ships which were conveying to Makka large numbers of pilgrims with their rich oblations.1

Śiv√°ji’s Second Attack, 1670.This insult to the Muhammadan religion was enough to incense the bigoted Aurangzeb, apart from the additional offences of the sack of Surat and the assumption in 1665 of royal insignia by Śiv√°ji. He therefore sent an expedition to the Dakhan strong enough to keep the Mar√°th√°s for some time away from Gujar√°t. One of Śiv√°ji’s officers, however, seems to have attacked a part of the Surat district in 1666, and to have got off safely with his spoils. In 1670, Śiv√°ji again descended upon that city with about 15,000 men. The only serious resistance he experienced was, as before, from the English factors. He plundered the town for three days, and only left on receiving some information about the Mughals’ movements in the Dakhan, which made him fear lest he should be intercepted on his way back to the country about the Gh√°ts.

1671.Śiv√°ji left a claim for twelve l√°khs of rupees to be paid as a guarantee against future expeditions. It is possible, however, that as he does not appear to have taken any immediate steps to recover this sum, the demand was made only in accordance with Mar√°tha policy, [387]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. which looked upon a country once overrun as tributary, and assumed a right to exercise paramount authority over it by virtue of the completed act of a successful invasion. In 1671 the Mar√°tha fleet was ordered to sail up the gulf and plunder Broach, and it is probable that Śiv√°ji intended at the same time to levy tribute from Surat, but the whole expedition was countermanded before the ships sailed.

The conduct of the military authorities in Gujar√°t with regard to this expedition of 1670 was such as to render it highly probable that the Mughal leaders were in complicity with the Mar√°th√°s in order to gain the favour and support of their leader. Shortly before Śiv√°ji’s arrival there had been a large garrison in Surat, apparently kept there by the governor, who suspected that some attempt on the town would soon be made. This garrison was withdrawn before Śiv√°ji’s attack, and almost immediately after his departure 5000 men were sent back again. The commanders of the Mughal army in the Dakhan were Jasvant Singh the R√°htor chief of Jodhpur and prince Muazzam. Jasvant Singh had been viceroy of Gujar√°t from a.d. 1659 to 1662, and in a.d. 1671 shortly after Śiv√°ji’s second expedition was re-appointed to that post for three years. He had, moreover, been accused of taking bribes from Śiv√°ji during the operations in the Dakhan. Prince Muazzam, again, had every reason for wishing to secure to himself so powerful an ally as Śiv√°ji in the struggle for the imperial crown that took place, as a rule, at every succession. Aurangzeb, reasoning from his own experiences as a son, refused to allow a possible heir to his throne to become powerful at court; and accordingly sent him against Śiv√°ji with an army quite inadequate for such operations. It is therefore not unreasonable to suppose that if there had not been some previous understanding between Śiv√°ji and the Mughal leaders, the troops that were known to be within easy reach of Surat would have been found strong and numerous enough either to have repulsed him altogether or at least to have prevented the three days’ sack of the city.

S√°ler Taken, 1672.In a.d. 1672 Śiv√°ji took some of the small forts to the south of Surat, such as P√°rnera and Bagv√°da, now in the P√°rdi sub-division of the Surat district, whilst Moro Trimal got possession of the large fort of S√°ler in B√°gl√°n, which guarded one of the most frequented passes from the Dakhan into Gujar√°t. The Mar√°th√°s were thus able to command the routes along which their expeditions could most conveniently be despatched.

The Narbada Crossed, 1675.No further incursion was made till 1675, in which year a Mar√°tha force first crossed the Narbada. On the resumption of hostilities between Śiv√°ji and the Mughals, Has√°ji Mohite, who had been made Sen√°pati, with the title of Hambirr√°v, marched up the North Konkan, and divided his army into two forces near Surat. One portion plundered towards Burh√°npur, the other commanded by himself plundered the Broach district. Ten years later a successful expedition was made against Broach itself, either preconcerted or [388]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. actually led by a younger son of Aurangzeb, who had taken refuge with the Mar√°th√°s. Broach was plundered, and the booty safely carried off before the local force could get near the invaders. Gujar√°t was now left free from inroad for some fourteen years, probably because the attention of the Mar√°tha leaders was concentrated on their quarrels in the Dakhan.

Raids by D√°bh√°de, 1699.In a.d. 1699 R√°m R√°ja appointed one of his most trusted officers, Khander√°v D√°bh√°de, to collect in B√°gl√°n the chauth2 and sardeshmukhi imposts which had by that time become regularly instituted. This chief, whose name was afterwards so intimately connected with Gujar√°t, not only collected all that was due to his master from the village officers in B√°gl√°n, but also made an incursion into the Surat districts on his own account. 1700–1704.Between 1700 and 1704 Khander√°v attempted two expeditions, but was foiled by the vigilance of the Mughal authorities. 1705.In 1705, however, he made a raid on a large scale and got safely across the Narbada, where he defeated two Muhammadan detachments sent against him, and got back to S√°ler with his booty. 1706–1711.Khander√°v now kept bodies of troops constantly hovering on the outskirts of Gujar√°t and along the road to Burh√°npur. He himself led several expeditions into the Ahmed√°b√°d territory, and is said to have once got as far as Sorath in the peninsula, where however he was repelled by the Musalm√°n governor. In 1711, again he was severely defeated by the Mughals near Anklesvar in the Broach district, and had to withdraw to the borders of Kh√°ndesh.

1713.In 1713 some treasure was being conveyed from Surat to Aurang√°b√°d escorted by a large force under Muhammad Tabrízí. The party was attacked in the jungles east of Surat and the treasure carried off. Just before this, Sarbuland Kh√°n, the deputy viceroy, on his way to take up his office at Ahmed√°b√°d, was attacked and robbed in the wilds of S√°gb√°ra on the north bank of the T√°pti. As Khander√°v had a short while previous to these occurrences taken up his position near N√°ndod3 in the R√°jpipla territory, it is probably to him or to his subordinates that these raids are to be attributed. He managed by a system of outposts to cut off communication between Surat and Burh√°npur, except for those who had paid him a fee for safe conduct. If this charge was evaded or resisted, he appropriated one-fourth of the property that the traveller was conveying up country.

D√°bh√°de, 1716.As the Burh√°npur road was one of those most frequented by both pilgrims and merchants, the Dehli authorities were obliged, in 1716, to organize an expedition against D√°bh√°de. The leader of the force was one Zulfikar Beg, an officer inexperienced in Mar√°tha warfare. D√°bh√°de found little difficulty in decoying him into a mountainous country, and there completely defeated him with the usual Mar√°tha accompaniment of plunder. [389]


The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. D√°bh√°de Sen√°pati.Finding himself once more in the Dakhan, Khander√°v D√°bh√°de took the opportunity of rejoining the court at S√°t√°ra, from which he had long been absent. He was lucky enough to arrive just as the Sen√°pati Man√°ji Mor√°r had failed on an important expedition and was consequently in disgrace. R√°ja Sh√°hu, pleased with Khander√°v’s recent success against the Delhi troops, divested Man√°ji of the title of Sen√°pati, and bestowed it upon the more fortunate leader.

The Peshwa’s Negotiations, 1717.Khander√°v remained away from Gujar√°t for three years, accompanying, meanwhile, B√°l√°ji Vishvan√°th the Peshwa to Dehli, where the latter was engaged in negotiations for the confirmation of the Mar√°tha rights to chauth and other tribute from certain districts in the Dakhan.

It is evident that at this time there was no definite claim to tribute from Gujar√°t on the part of the Mar√°tha government; for in spite of the intrigues of B√°l√°ji and the weakness of the court party at Delhi no concessions were obtained with regard to it, although the Mar√°tha dues from other parts of the country were fully ratified. The grounds on which B√°l√°ji demanded the tribute from Gujar√°t were that Sh√°hu would thereby gain the right to restrain the excesses of Mar√°tha freebooters from the frontier and would guarantee the whole country against irregular pillage. The argument was a curious one, considering that the most troublesome and notorious freebooter of the whole tribe was at the elbow of the envoy, who was so strenuously pleading for the right to suppress him. It is probable that B√°l√°ji foresaw that Khander√°v’s newly acquired rank would take him for a time from B√°gl√°n to the court, so that meanwhile an arrangement could be made to prevent the growth of any powerful chief in the Gujar√°t direction who might interfere with the plans of the central government. The Mar√°tha statesman was as anxious to ensure the subordination of distant feudatories as the Mughals to secure the freedom of the Gh√°t roads to the coast.

In the redistribution of authority carried out about this time by B√°l√°ji Vishvan√°th, the responsibility of collecting the Mar√°tha dues4 from Gujar√°t and B√°gl√°n was assigned to Khander√°v as Sen√°pati or commander-in-chief; but as these dues were not yet settled, at least as regards the country below the Gh√°ts, Khander√°v seems to have remained with the Peshwa in the field.

D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, 1720.At the battle of B√°l√°pur, fought against the Niz√°m-ul-Mulk, one of the officers of Khander√°v, by name D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, so distinguished himself that the Sen√°pati brought his conduct prominently to the notice of R√°ja Sh√°hu. The latter promoted D√°m√°ji to be second in command to Khander√°v with the title of Shamsher Bah√°dur, which had been formerly borne by one of the Atole family in 1692. This is the first mention of the present ruling family of Baroda. Before many months both Khander√°v and D√°m√°ji died. The former was succeeded by his son Trimbakr√°v, on whom his father’s title was conferred. Pil√°ji, nephew of D√°m√°ji, was confirmed in his uncle’s [390]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. honours and retired to Gujar√°t. As soon as he could collect a sufficiently strong force, he attacked the Surat district and defeated the Musalm√°n commander close to the city itself. After extorting from him a handsome sum as ransom, Pil√°ji returned eastwards. He selected Songad,5 a fort about fifty miles east of Surat, as his headquarters, and from thence made continual excursions against the neighbouring towns. He once attacked Surat, but although he defeated the Mughal leader, he seems to have contented himself with contributions levied from the adjacent country, and not to have entered the town. Pil√°ji soon obtained possession of some strongholds in the 1723.R√°jpipla country between N√°ndod and S√°gb√°ra, which he fortified, as Khander√°v D√°bh√°de had formerly done. Here he resided as representative of the Sen√°pati, whose family had removed for a while to the Dakhan. The tribute collected from B√°gl√°n and Gujar√°t was supposed to be transmitted by Pil√°ji to the royal treasury through the Peshwa; but there is no record of these dues having been levied with any regularity or even fixed at any special amount. Whilst Trimbakr√°v was taking an active part in the affairs of his royal patron in the Dakhan, Pil√°ji occupied himself in sedulously cultivating the goodwill of the border tribes surrounding his residence in Gujar√°t.

Mar√°tha Tribute, 1723.The year 1723 is noteworthy as being the date of the first imposition of the regular Mar√°tha demand of one-fourth, chauth, and one-tenth, sardeshmukhi, of the revenue of Gujar√°t. Whilst Pil√°ji was directing his attacks against Surat and the south of the province another of R√°ja Sh√°hu’s officers, who had been sent up towards M√°lwa, entered Gujar√°t by the north-east, and after ravaging the country round Dohad,6 settled a fixed tribute on the district.

Kant√°ji Kadam.This officer, Kant√°ji Kadam B√°nde, was soon after engaged by one of the parties struggling for the viceroyalty of Ahmed√°b√°d to bring his cavalry into the province and take part in the civil war. The leader of the opposite party, Rustam Ali, enlisted the services of Pil√°ji G√°ikw√°r. The Niz√°m-ul-Mulk, whose influence in the Dakhan was very great, managed to detach Pil√°ji from Rustam Ali’s side. This was the easier, as Rustam had already defeated Pil√°ji more than once in attacks by the latter against Surat, of which district Rustam was governor. There are two different accounts7 of what took place when the rival forces came into action, but both show clearly that the Mar√°tha leaders acted on both sides with utter disregard of their agreements and looked only to plundering the Muhammadan camps whilst the soldiers were engaged in battle. After the defeat of Rustam, the two Mar√°tha chiefs joined forces and proceeded to levy chauth, of which the Mughal deputy had granted Pil√°ji a share equal to that of his first ally Kant√°ji.

Mar√°tha Dissensions, 1725.This division led to quarrels and at last to an open rupture between the two Mar√°tha leaders, which was only patched up by the [391]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. grant of the chauth north of the Mahi river to Kant√°ji and of that to the south to Pil√°ji. The chief ground of quarrel seems to have been the relative position of the G√°ikw√°r as agent for the Sen√°pati, who had a right to collect all dues from Gujar√°t, and of Kant√°ji, who claimed superior rank as holding his commission direct from R√°ja Sh√°hu. On hearing of this dispute and the consequent partition of the Mar√°tha tribute, Trimbakr√°v D√°bh√°de himself hastened up to Cambay with an army, but effected nothing, and seems to have retired, leaving Pil√°ji to look after his interests at Ahmed√°b√°d. Both the latter, however, and Kant√°ji soon after withdrew from Gujar√°t, but were within a short period encouraged to return by the success of a raid made by another leader, Ant√°ji Bh√°skar, on the north-east district. They both joined Hamid Kh√°n in his resistance to the new viceroy, but received several checks from the Muhammadan army, and after plundering again returned to their strongholds for the rainy season.

The Peshwa, 1726.Next year they returned for the tribute and plundered as usual. The Peshwa B√°jir√°v then opened for the first time direct negotiations with the viceroy of Gujar√°t. The rapid increase of the authority of the Br√°hman ministers at the R√°ja’s court in the Dakhan had aroused the jealousy of the Mar√°tha nobles, amongst whom Trimbakr√°v D√°bh√°de was one of the most influential. B√°jir√°v, being fully aware of the fact, and having by this time acquired from the R√°ja the power of acting with foreign powers independently of the throne, determined to undermine Trimbakr√°v’s authority in Gujar√°t by aiming at the rights said to have been formally granted to him by Hamid Kh√°n over the country south of the Mahi. He therefore applied to the viceroy for a confirmation of the right to levy chauth and sardeshmukhi over the whole country, on condition that he would protect it from the inroads of Kant√°ji, Pil√°ji, and other irresponsible freebooters. The viceroy had still some resources left at his disposal and was in hopes that his repeated applications to Dehli for assistance would soon meet with a favourable answer. Cession of Tribute, 1728.He declined therefore to accede to B√°jir√°v’s proposals at once, on the grounds that the court at Dehli had repudiated the concessions made to Pil√°ji and Kant√°ji by his predecessor’s deputy. As however the depredations on the frontier caused serious injury both to the revenues and the people, he allowed the Peshwa to send a feudatory, Ud√°ji Pav√°r, chief of Dh√°r, through the Mughal territories to operate against Pil√°ji. The latter, who was fully aware of these negotiations, persuaded Kant√°ji to join him in expelling the agents of the Peshwa party, as it was clear that if Pil√°ji’s forces were scattered the way would be open for Ud√°ji to attack Kant√°ji himself. The two then proceeded to Baroda and after a while drove back Ud√°ji, and occupied Baroda and Dabhoi. Here Pil√°ji remained, and next year Kant√°ji succeeded in taking Ch√°mp√°ner, thus advancing his posts nearer the centre of the province. With such an advantage gained these two chiefs instituted raids still more frequently than before. In these straits, and finding himself utterly neglected by the emperor, the viceroy re-opened negotiations with the Peshwa, who lost no time in sending his [392]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819.
Cession of Tribute, 1728. brother Chimn√°ji Áppa with an army through Gujar√°t. Petl√°d and Dholka were plundered, but Kant√°ji was left undisturbed, so he took this opportunity of marching to Sorath, where he remained for some time extorting tribute. The viceroy agreed formally to cede the sardeshmukhi of the whole revenue, land and customs (with the exception of the port of Surat and the districts attached to it) and the chauth of the same district, with five per cent on the revenue from the city of Ahmed√°b√°d. Special clauses were inserted in the grant of chauth to suit the convenience of both the Peshwa and the viceroy. The latter stipulated that as few collectors as possible should be kept by the Mar√°th√°s in the districts under tribute, and that no extra demands beyond the one-fourth should be made. He also insisted that the percentage should be calculated on the actual collections and not on the kam√°l or highest sum recorded as having been collected.8 The Mar√°th√°s were also to support the imperial authority and to keep up a body of horse. The Peshwa agreed (probably at his own request) to prevent all Mar√°tha subjects from joining disaffected chiefs, or other turbulent characters, thus receiving the right to suppress Kant√°ji and Pil√°ji, as well as the Bhils and Kolis with whom the latter was on such friendly terms.

After this agreement was executed, B√°jir√°v made over part of the sardeshmukhi to the D√°bh√°de, as well as the mokâsa or three-fourths of the svar√°j as settled by B√°l√°ji Vishvan√°th. The consideration as set forth in the preamble of this agreement was the great improvement effected by the Mar√°tha rulers as regards the wealth and tranquillity of the Dakhan provinces. This was inserted either to give the transaction the appearance of having been executed on the part of the emperor (for otherwise the viceroy had no concern in the state of the Dakhan), or simply as an expression of gratitude on the part of this special viceroy towards the Mar√°th√°s who had just brought to terms the Niz√°m-ul-Mulk, his former rival and enemy. It is even probable that it was merely intended, as usual with such preambles, to veil the forced nature of the treaty.

The hostile movements of the Pratinidhi in the Southern Mar√°tha Country induced the Peshwa to return to the Dakhan. Kant√°ji returned from Sorath to Ch√°mp√°ner, plundering part of the viceroy’s camp on his way. Trimbakr√°v D√°bh√°de, jealous of the interference of the Peshwa in the affairs of Gujar√°t, began to intrigue with other chiefs to overturn the power of the Br√°hman ministers.

Coalition against the Peshwa, 1730.As soon as Niz√°m-ul-Mulk became aware of this discontent on the part of Trimbakr√°v, of whose power he was well informed, he proposed to assist him by an attack on the Peshwa from the east, whilst the Mar√°th√°s operated in another direction. Trimbakr√°v was successful in his overtures with Pil√°ji G√°ikw√°r, the B√°nde, the Pav√°rs, and a few other chiefs resident in Kh√°ndesh or the north Dakhan. The troops sent by them to join his standard soon amounted [393]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. to 35,000 men, who were collected in Gujar√°t. He then gave out that he was bent on rescuing the Mar√°tha R√°ja from the thraldom in which he was being kept by the Br√°hmans. The Peshwa, who had discovered the intercourse between Trimbakr√°v and the Niz√°m, proclaimed this treason on the part of the D√°bh√°de as a royal officer, and stated that the malcontents were only planning the partition of the inheritance of Shiv√°ji between the R√°ja of Kolh√°pur and themselves. As soon as he found the Niz√°m’s troops were on the march, he collected his picked men and advanced on the D√°bh√°de in Gujar√°t.

Defeat of the Allies, 1731.The Peshwa’s army was inferior in numbers but consisted of better trained men. He closed at once with the allies near Dabhoi, and easily defeated the undisciplined forces of the Pav√°rs and B√°nde. The D√°bh√°de’s army, however, had more experience of regular warfare and made a stand. But a stray shot killed Trimbakr√°v as he was endeavouring to rally the forces of his allies, and as usual in such engagements, the loss of the leader disheartened the army. Utter confusion ensued, in which many of the nobles fell, others ran away, and the Peshwa, without the necessity of pushing further his advantage, made good his retreat to the Dakhan. The Niz√°m, who was in pursuit, only managed to capture some of the baggage with the rear guard as it was crossing the T√°pti near Surat.9

Safe again in the Dakhan, the Peshwa at once began negotiations with both the Niz√°m and the adherents of Trimbakr√°v D√°bh√°de. He recognized the rights of the former to some possessions in Gujar√°t independent of the viceroy of Ahmed√°b√°d, and agreed to further his designs of severing the Dakhan from the possessions of the emperor. He conciliated the D√°bh√°de family by establishing at Poona an annual distribution of food and presents to Br√°hmans such as had formerly been the practice in the native village of Khander√°v.10 This institution was known as Dakshin√°.

B√°jir√°v acquiesced also in the general tendency amongst Mar√°th√°s of all offices to become hereditary, and conferred the title of Sen√°pati on Yeshvantr√°v the minor son of the deceased Trimbakr√°v. The widow Um√°b√°i became guardian, and Pil√°ji G√°ikw√°r deputy or mut√°lik in Gujar√°t. This latter appointment seems to have been made by the Peshwa and not by the D√°bh√°de, for Pil√°ji received at the same time a new title, namely that of Sen√° Kh√°s Khel or commander of the special band or perhaps the household brigade. He was also bound on behalf of the Sen√°pati to respect the Peshwa’s rights in M√°lwa and Gujar√°t, and to pay half the collections from the territory he administered to the royal treasury through the minister. A provision was also inserted with regard to future acquisitions. This reciprocal agreement was executed at the special command of the Mar√°tha R√°ja Sh√°hu, who had not yet quite abrogated his authority in favour of the Peshwa. Pil√°ji after these negotiations retired to Gujar√°t. [394]


The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. Assassination of Pil√°ji G√°ikw√°r, 1732.His influence amongst the Bhils and other troublesome races dwelling in the wild parts of the eastern frontier made Pil√°ji an object of hatred and fear to the Mughal viceroy, who had him assassinated by one of his adherents whilst the latter was pretending to whisper some important and confidential news in Pil√°ji’s ear. This event took place at D√°kor in the Kaira district. The followers of the G√°ikw√°r slew the assassin and retired south of the Mahi. They were driven by the Mughals out of Baroda, but continued to hold Dabhoi. D√°m√°ji G√°ikw√°r, son of Pil√°ji, was at this time prowling round Surat watching for an opportunity of interfering in the disturbed affairs of that town. One of the candidates for the governorship had offered him one-fourth the revenue of the city for his assistance, but the expedition was deferred on account of the appointment of a rival by the emperor. D√°m√°ji therefore was preparing to act on his own account independently of his ally. The news of his father’s assassination, however, took him northwards. He found that the Des√°i of P√°dra near Baroda had stirred up the Bhils and Kolis to revolt, in order to give the relations of Pil√°ji a chance of striking a blow at the murderers of their deceased leader. 1733.Um√°b√°i D√°bh√°de, too, bent on the same errand, moved down the Gh√°ts with an army. The Mar√°th√°s were bought off, however, by the viceroy and peace was restored for a while.

G√°ikw√°rs Secure Baroda, 1734.In this year also J√°doji, a younger son of Trimbakr√°v, made an expedition to collect tribute through Gujar√°t as far as Sorath. Next year M√°dhavr√°v G√°ikw√°r, brother of Pil√°ji, obtained possession of Baroda during the absence of Sher Kh√°n B√°bi the governor. Since that date this town has been the capital of the G√°ikw√°r family. Sindia and Holkar soon afterwards joined the chief of Ídar against the Musalm√°n deputy, and extorted from the latter a considerable sum as ransom.

The Mar√°tha Deputy Governor, 1736.Um√°b√°i had recognized D√°m√°ji as her agent in succession to Pil√°ji; but as she required D√°m√°ji in the Dakhan the latter had been obliged to leave in his turn a locum tenens in Gujar√°t. There ensued quarrels between this deputy, named Rangoji, and K√°nt√°ji Kadam which brought D√°m√°ji back again, and after obtaining from the Muhammadan viceroy, who had espoused the cause of Kant√°ji, a grant of one-fourth the revenues of the country north of the Mahi he went as usual to Sorath. Kant√°ji Kadam, who as a partisan of the Peshwa was hostile to the Sen√°pati, harassed the country within reach of his frontier. D√°m√°ji, meanwhile, had again proceeded to the Dakhan, where Um√°b√°i was intriguing against the Peshwa and required all the help she could obtain to further the ambitious schemes she was devising in the name of her half-witted son. His deputy Rangoji, by demanding a heavy price for his aid at a time when an aspirant to the viceroyalty of Ahmed√°b√°d was in distress, managed to secure for the Mar√°th√°s half the revenue of Gujar√°t with certain exceptions.

Ahmed√°b√°d Riots, 1738.D√°m√°ji then moved into Gujar√°t again, and on his way to join Rangoji extorted Rs. 7000 from the English at Surat as a [395]
The Mar√°th√°s, a.d. 1760–1819. guarantee against plundering them. The events of this year have been detailed in full in the history of the Musalm√°n Period. After getting possession of a great part of the city of Ahmed√°b√°d the 1739.Mar√°th√°s, by their oppressive rule, excited a rising amongst the Musalm√°n inhabitants. Similar quarrels and subsequent reconciliations took place between 1739 and 1741, the Musalm√°ns distrusting the Mar√°th√°s, yet not daring to attempt to oust them. D√°m√°ji, on his way back from one of his Sorath expeditions, laid 1741.siege to Broach, which was held by a Muhammadan officer direct from the viceroy of the Dakhan.11 As the latter personage was still regarded by the Mar√°tha chiefs as a possible ally against the Peshwa, D√°m√°ji at once obeyed the request of the Niz√°m to raise the siege, but probably obtained a promise of future concessions such as he had acquired at Surat.

1742.Rangoji in the absence of D√°m√°ji took up his residence in Borsad. There he fell into several disputes with the Muhammadan officials, in the course of one of which he was taken prisoner, but escaped the next year (1743). Meanwhile D√°m√°ji had joined with R√°ghoji Bhonslé in attacking the Peshwa. Whilst R√°ghoji was preparing his army in the east, D√°m√°ji made a feint against M√°lwa, which had the desired effect of withdrawing a large portion of the ministerial army. The G√°ikw√°r’s troops retreated without giving battle, but to prevent any future junction between D√°m√°ji and the Bhonslé party in Ber√°r, B√°l√°ji Peshwa confirmed the Pav√°r family in their claims to Dh√°r, which had never been acknowledged as their territory since the defection of the Pav√°rs to the D√°bh√°de party in 1731. It is worth remarking that though the rank of Sen√°pati had apparently been made hereditary in the D√°bh√°de family (for the owner of the title was quite unfit for the command of an army), the Ghorpadé family applied at this time to have it restored to them on the ground that it once had been held by one of their house. The Peshwa, however, managed to secure their alliance by a grant of land, and their claims to the chief command of the army seem to have been waived.

1743–44.For the next two years the Mar√°tha force in Gujar√°t under Rangoji and Dev√°ji T√°kpar was employed by the Musalm√°ns in their quarrels regarding the viceroyalty. The Mar√°tha practice of appointing deputies gives rise to some confusion as to the negotiations that took place about this time between the G√°ikw√°r’s party and the rival candidates for the office of subhed√°r. For instance, Um√°b√°i D√°bh√°de had appointed the G√°ikw√°r family as her agents-in-chief, but the principal members of that house were absent in the Dakhan.
