Al Masúdi speaks of an emerald known as the Makkan emerald being carried from Kamb√°ya by Aden to Makkah where it found a market.93 Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–996) names Kamb√°ya among the cities of Hind.94 In his time there were J√°m√° or assembly mosques in Kamb√°ya, where the precepts of Isl√°m were openly taught. Among the productions of Kamb√°ya he gives mangoes cocoanuts lemons and rice in great plenty and some honey but no date trees.95 He makes Kamb√°ya four miles (one farasang) from the sea and four (that is four days’ journey) from Sub√°ra apparently Surab√°ra that is Surat. The distance to K√°muhul or Anhilw√°ra by some mistake is shown as four farsangs instead of four days’ journey.96 Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) places Kamb√°ya within the large country of Gujar√°t (120 miles)97 (30 farsakh) from Debal (Kar√°chi). He says the men of Kamb√°ya receive tribute from the chiefs of the island of Kís or Kísh (probably Kich-Makr√°n).98 Al Idrísi (a.d. 1100) places Kamb√°ya with other Gujar√°t cities in the second [515]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Port or Coast Towns.
Cambay. climate.99 He says it is a pretty and well known naval station, second among the towns of Gujar√°t.100 It stands at the end of a bay three miles from the sea where vessels can enter and cast anchor. It is well supplied with water and has a fine fortress built by the Government to prevent the inroads of the pirates of Kísh (Makr√°n). From Kamb√°ya to the island of Aubkin (Píram) is two and a half days’ sail and from Aubkin to Debal (or Kar√°chi) two days more. The country is fertile in wheat and rice and its mountains yield the bamboo. Its inhabitants are idolators. In his Tazjiyat-ul-Ams√°r, Abdullah Wass√°f101 in a.d. 1300 (H. 699) writes: “Gujar√°t which is commonly called Kamb√°yat contains 70,000 villages and towns all populous and the people abounding in wealth and luxuries. In the course of the four seasons seventy different species of beautiful flowers bloom. The purity of the air is so great that the picture of an animal drawn with the pen is lifelike. Many plants and herbs grow wild. Even in winter the ground is full of tulips (poppies). The air is healthy, the climate a perpetual spring. The moisture of the dew of itself suffices for the cold season crops. Then comes the summer harvest which is dependent on the rain. The vineyards bring forth blue grapes twice a year.”

The trade in horses from the Persian isles and coast and from Katíf, L√°hsa, Bahrein, and Hurmuz was so great that during the reign of At√°bak Abu Bakr102 (a.d. 1154–1189) 10,000 horses worth 2,20,000 dín√°rs103 (Rs. 1,10,00,000) were imported into Cambay and the ports of Malab√°r. These enormous sums were not paid out of the government treasuries but from the endowments of Hindu temples and from taxes on the courtezans attached to them. The same author mentions the conquest104 of Gujar√°t and the plunder of Kamb√°yat by Malik Muîzz-ud-dín (called by Farishtah Alf and by Barni Ulugh meaning the great Kh√°n.) The T√°ríkh-i-Fírúz Sh√°hi states that Nasrat Kh√°n and not Ulugh Kh√°n took and plundered Cambay and notices that in Cambay Nasrat Kh√°n purchased K√°fúr Haz√°r Dín√°ri (the thousand Dín√°r K√°fur), the future favourite minister and famous general of Al√°-ud-dín. About fifty years later the hot-headed Muhammad bin Tughlak (a.d. 1325–1351) was in Cambay quelling an insurrection and collecting the arrears of Cambay revenue.105 [516]


Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Port or Coast Towns.
Cheul. Cheul.Cheul (Saimúr). Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) is the first Arab geographer to mention Saimúr.106 He says: On the coast as in Saimúr Sub√°ra and T√°na the L√°riyyah language is spoken. In describing Saimúr Al Masúdi states107 that at the time of his visit (H. 304; a.d. 914) the ruler on behalf of the Balh√°ra was Jh√°njha (this is the fifth Sil√°h√°ra a.d. 916). Nearly ten thousand Musalm√°ns were settled in Saimúr including some (called Bay√°sirah) born in the land of Arab parents and others from Sír√°f and Persian Gulf, Basrah, Baghd√°d, and other towns. A certain Músa bin Is-h√°k was appointed Raís or ruler108 by the Balh√°ra or Valabhi, that is the reigning R√°shṭrakúṭa Indra Nityaṃvarsha to adjudicate Muhammadan disputes according to Musalm√°n law and customs. He describes109 at length the ceremony of self-destruction by a Besar110 youth (a Hindu by religion) to gain a better state in his future life, his scalping himself and putting fire on his head, his cutting out a piece of his heart and sending it to a friend as a souvenir.

Al Istakhri (a.d. 951) mentions Saimúr as one of the cities of Hind, makes it the southern end of the Balh√°ra kingdom with Kamb√°ya as the northern,111 and places it at a distance of five days from Sind√°n (the Th√°na Sanj√°n) and fifteen days from Sarandíb or Ceylon.112 Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968) notices Saimúr as one of the cities of Hind known to him and mentions the sea of F√°rs (or the Indian Ocean) as stretching from Saimúr on the east to Tíz or Makr√°n.113 He states114 that the country between Saimúr and T√°mhal (Anhilaw√°ra) belongs to Hind. He makes115 the distance between Sub√°ra (probably Surab√°ra or Sw√°t), Sind√°n, and Saimúr five days each and between Saimúr and Sarandib (Ceylon) fifteen days. Al Bírúni (a.d. 1020) says:116 “Then you enter the land of L√°r√°n in which is Saimúr also called Jaimúr or Chaimúr.” Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) mentions Saimúr as one of the towns of the second climate.117 He describes it as large and well-built, five days from Sind√°n and among its products notes cocoanut trees in abundance, henna (Lawsonia inermis), and on its mountains many aromatic plants.118 His remark that Saimúr formed a part of the vast, fertile, well-peopled and commercial kingdom of the Balh√°ras must be taken from the work of Al-Jauhari (a.d. 950).

Al Kazwíni (a.d. 1236) quoting Misâar bin Muhalhil (a.d. 942) describes Saimúr as one of the cities of Hind near the confines of Sind,119 whose people born of Turkish and Indian parents are very beautiful. It was a flourishing trade centre with a mixed population of Jews, Fireworshippers, [517]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Port or Coast Towns.
Cheul. Christians, and Musalm√°ns.120 The merchandise of the Turks (probably of the Indo-Afgh√°n frontier) was conveyed thither and the best of aloes were exported and called Saimúri after its name. The temple of Saimúr was on an eminence with idols of turquoise and baidjadak or ruby. In the city were many mosques churches synagogues and fire-temples.

Chief Towns.
Dholka.Dholka (Dúlaka). Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) places Dúlaka and another town he calls Han√°wal that is Chunwal or Junawal perhaps Jh√°l√°w√°r between B√°rúh (Broach) and Nahrw√°ra. He describes Dúlaka as on the banks of a river (the S√°barmati) which flows into the sea, which forms an estuary or gulf on the west (east) of which stands the town of B√°rúh. Both these towns, he adds, stand at the foot of a chain of mountains which lie to the north and which are called Undaran apparently Vindhya. The kana (bamboo) grows here as well as a few cocoanut trees.121

Goa.Goa. See Sind√°bur.

Gondal.Gondal (Kondal). Zi√°-ud-dín Barni in his T√°rikh-i-Fíruz Sh√°hi states122 that Sult√°n Muhammad Tughlak spent (a.d. 1349) his third rainy season in Gujar√°t in Kondal (Gondal). Here the Sult√°n assembled his forces before starting on his fatal march to Sindh.

Capitals.
Kachh.Kachh. Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) is the only Arab writer who refers to Kachh. He calls Kachh123 with Somn√°th the head-quarters of the country of the Baw√°rij or Medh pirates. Speaking of the Indus he notices124 that one of its branches which reaches the borders of Kachh is known as Sind S√°gar. In a third passage he refers125 to Kachh as the land of the mukl or balsamodendron and of b√°drúd or bezoar. It was twenty-four miles (6 farsangs) from Debal (Kar√°chi). According to the T√°ríkh-i-Maâsúmi126 when (a.d. 1069) the sovereignty of Sindh passed from the descendants of Mahmúd of Ghazni to the Sumras, Singhar, the grandson of Sumra (a.d. 1069)127 extended his sway from Kachh to Nasarpúr128 near Sindh Haidar√°b√°d and Khafíf the son of Singhar consolidated his power and made Kachh a Sumra dependency.129 Dúda the grandson of Khafíf quelled a threatened Sumra rising by proceeding to Kachh and chastising the Sammas.130 On the fall of the Sumras the Chauras became masters of Kachh from whose hands the country passed to those of the Sammas. Ground down under the iron sway of the Sumras a number of Sammas fled from Sindh and entered Kachh where they were kindly received by the Chauras who gave them land to cultivate. After acquainting themselves with the country and the resources of its rulers the Samma immigrants who seem to have increased in numbers and strengthened themselves by union, obtained possession by stratagem but not without heroism of the chief fortress of Kachh.131 This fort now in ruins [518]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Capitals.
Kachh. was the fort of Gúntrí.132 The T√°rikh-i-T√°hiri states that up to the time the history was written (a.d. 1621)133 the country was in the possession of the Sammas, both the R√°is Bh√°ra and J√°m Sihta of great and little Kachh in his time being of Samma descent.

Kaira.Kaira (Karra). One mention of Karra apparently Kaira or Kheḍ√° occurs in Zi√°-ud-dín Barni’s134 account of Muhammad Tughlak’s (a.d. 1325) pursuit of his rebellious Gujar√°t noble T√°ghi. He speaks of Muhammad’s detention for a month at As√°wal during the rains and his overtaking and dispersing T√°ghi’s forces at Karra. From Karra the rebels fled in disorder to Nahrw√°ra (Anhilw√°ra). Several of T√°ghi’s supporters sought and were refused shelter by the R√°na of M√°ndal that is P√°tri near Viramg√°m.

Chief Towns.
K√°birún.K√°birún. Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) mentions K√°birún and As√°wal as towns of the same ‘section’ both of them populous, commercial, rich, and producing useful articles. He adds that at the time he wrote the Musalm√°ns had made their way into the greater portion of these countries and conquered them. K√°birún like the Akabarou of the Periplus (a.d. 240) is perhaps a town on the K√°veri river in south Gujar√°t.

Kambay.Kambay. See Cambay.

Kanauj.Kanauj. Al Masúdi135 (a.d. 956) is the first Arab traveller who gives an account of Kanauj. He says:136 The kingdom of the Baûúra king of Kanauj extends about a hundred and twenty square parasangs of Sindh, each parasang being equal to eight miles of this country. This king has four armies according to the four quarters of the world. Each of them numbers 700,000 or 900,000. The army of the north wars against the prince of Mult√°n and with his Musalm√°n subjects on the frontier. The army of the south fights against the Balh√°ra king of M√°nkír. The other two armies march to meet enemies in every direction. Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–976) says137 that from the sea of F√°rs to the country of Kanauj is three months journey. Rashíd-ud-dín from Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1039) places138 Kanauj south of the Him√°layas and states139 that the Jamna falls into the Ganga below Kanauj which is situated on the west of the river (Ganga). The chief portion of Hind included in the “second climate” is called the central land or Madhya Desh. He adds that the Persians call it Kanauj. It was the capital of the great, haughty, and proud despots of India. He praises the former magnificence of Kanauj, which he says being now deserted by its ruler has fallen into neglect and ruin, and the city of B√°ri, three days’ journey from Kanauj on the eastern [519]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Chief Towns.
Kanauj. side of the Ganges being now the capital. Kanauj was celebrated for its descendants of the P√°ndavas as M√°hura (Mathra) is on account of B√°s Dev (Kṛishṇa). Al Idrísi, end of the eleventh century, speaks140 of Kanauj in connection with a river port town of the name of Samand√°r “a large town, commercial and rich, where there are large profits to be made and which is dependent” on the rule of the Kanauj king. Samand√°r, he says, stands on a river coming from Kashmír. To the north of Samand√°r at seven days is, he says, the city of Inner Kashmír under the rule of Kanauj. The Ch√°ch N√°mah (an Arabic history of great antiquity written before a.d. 753, translated into Persian in the time of Sult√°n N√°sir-ud-dín Kab√°chah) (a.d. 1216) says141 that when Ch√°ch a.d. 631–670) advanced against Akham Loh√°na of Brahman√°b√°d that the Loh√°na wrote to ask the help of “the king of Hindust√°n,” that is Kanauj, at that time Satb√°n son of R√°sal, but that Akham died before his answer came.

Kol.Kol. Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) has Kol seventy-two miles (18 farsakhs) from Sanj√°n in Kachh.142 And the T√°j-ul-Mâ√°sir143 relates how in a.d. 1194 Kutb-ud-dín advanced to Kol and took the fort.

M√°lkhet.M√°lkhet (M√°nkír). Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) is the first Arab writer to mention M√°nkír that is M√°ny√°kheta now M√°lkhet about sixty miles south-east of Shol√°púr. In relating the extinction of the great Brahma-born dynasty of India Al Masúdi states144 that at the time the city of M√°nkír, the great centre of India, submitted to the kings called the Balh√°ras who in his time were still ruling at M√°nkír.145

Al Masúdi correctly describes the position of M√°lkhet as eighty Sindh or eight-mile farsakhs that is six hundred and forty miles from the sea in a mountainous country. Again he notices that the language spoken in M√°nkír was Kiriya,146 called from Karah or Kanara the district where it was spoken. The current coin was the T√°rtariyeh dirham (each weighing a dirham and a half)147 on which was impressed the date of the ruler’s reign. He describes the country of the Balh√°ras as stretching from the Kamkar (or Konkan) in the south or south-west north to the frontiers of the king of Juzr (Gujar√°t), “a monarch rich in men horses and camels.” Al Istakhri (a.d. 951) describes M√°nkír as the dwelling of the wide-ruling Balh√°ra. Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–976) repeats almost to the letter the information given by Al Istakhri. The destruction of M√°lkhet (M√°nya Kheta) by the western Ch√°lukya king Tailappa in a.d. 972 explains why none of the writers after Ibni Haukal mentions M√°nkír. [520]


Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Chief Towns.
M√°ndal. M√°ndal.M√°ndal. Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) enumerates M√°ndal (in Viramg√°m) with Rúmla,148 Kuli, and B√°rúh as countries of Sindh. During the Khil√°fat of Hish√°m the son of Abdul Malik (a.d. 724–743) Junnaid son of Abdur Rahman-al-Murri was appointed to the frontier of Sindh. According to Al Bil√°duri (a.d. 892) Junnaid sent his officers to M√°ndal,149 Dahnaj perhaps Kamlej, and B√°hrús (Broach).

N√°r√°na.N√°r√°na. In his Indica Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) notices N√°r√°na near Jaipur as the ancient capital of Gujar√°t. He says that its correct name is Baz√°nah but that “it is known to our people (the Arabs) as N√°r√°in.” He places it eighty miles (20 farsakhs) south-west of Kanauj, and adds that when it was destroyed the inhabitants removed to and founded another city.150 Abú Rih√°n makes N√°r√°na the starting point of three itineraries to the south the south-west and the west. Al Bírúni’s details suffice to place this centre in the neighbourhood of the modern Jaipúr and to identify it with N√°r√°yan the capital of Bairat of Matsya which according to Farishtah151 Mahmúd of Ghazni took in a.d. 1022 (H. 412).

R√°nder.R√°nder (R√°hanjir or Rahanjúr). Al Bírúni (a.d. 1031) gives152 R√°hanjúr and B√°hrúj (Broach) as the capitals of Lar Desh or south Gujar√°t. Elliot (Note 3. I. 61) writes the word Damanhúr or Dahanhúr but the reading given by Sachau in his Arabic text of Al Bírúni (page 100 chapter 18) is plainly Rahanjúr (رہنجور‎) and the place intended is without doubt R√°nder on the right bank of the T√°pti opposite Surat. In his list of Indian towns Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) seems to refer153 to it under the forms Jandúr and Sandúr.

Sanj√°n.Sanj√°n (Sind√°n). The two Sanj√°ns, one in Kachh the other in Th√°na, complicate the references to Sind√°n. Sind√°n in Kachh was one of the earliest gains of Isl√°m in India. Al Bil√°duri154 (a.d. 892) speaks of Fazl, the son of M√°h√°n, in the reign of the greatest of the Abb√°si Khalíf√°hs Al-M√°mún (a.d. 813–833), taking Sind√°n and sending Al M√°mún the rare present of “an elephant and the longest and largest s√°j or turban or teak spar ever seen.” Fazl built an assembly mosque that was spared by the Hindus on their recapture of the town. Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) includes this Kachh Sind√°n with Broach and other places in Gujar√°t among the cities of Sindh. In his itinerary starting from Bakkar, he places Sind√°n seventy-two miles155 (18 farsakhs) from Kol. Al Masúdi (a.d. 915–944) states that Indian emeralds from (the Kachh) Sind√°n and the neighbourhood of Kamb√°yat (Cambay) approached those of the first water in the intensity of their green and in brilliance. As they found a market in Makkah they were called Makkan emeralds.156 Al Istakhri (a.d. 951) under cities of Hind places the Konkan Sind√°n five days from Surab√°ya (Surab√°ra or Surat) and as many from Saimúr157 [521]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350. (Chewal). Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968) mentions (the Kachh) Sind√°n among the cities of Hind, which have a large Musalm√°n population and a J√°m√° Masjid158 or assembly mosque. Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031)159 in his itinerary from Debal in Sindh places the Kokan 200 miles (50 farsakhs) from that port and between Broach and Sup√°ra. At the end of the eleventh century probably the Kachh Sind√°n was a large commercial town rich both in exports and imports with an intelligent and warlike, industrious, and rich population. Al Idrísi gives the situation of the Konkan Sind√°n as a mile and a half from the sea and five days from Saimúr (Cheval).160 Apparently Abul Fida161 (a.d. 1324) confused Sind√°n with Sind√°búr or Goa which Ibni Batúta (a.d. 1340) rightly describes as an island.162

Port or Coast Towns.
Sind√°búr or Sind√°púr.Sind√°búr or Sind√°púr. Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) places Sind√°púr he writes it Sind√°búra or Goa in the country of the Bughara (Balh√°ra) in India.163 Al Bírúni (a.d. 1021) places Sind√°púr or Sind√°búr that is Goa as the first of coast towns in Malab√°r the next being F√°knúr.164 Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) describes Sind√°búr as a commercial town with fine buildings and rich bazaars in a great gulf where ships cast anchor, four days along the coast165 from Th√°na.

Somn√°th.Somn√°th. Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) is the first of the Arab writers to notice Somn√°th. He calls Somn√°th and Kachh the capital of the Baw√°rij pirates who commit their depredations in boats called baira.166 He places Somn√°th (14 farsakhs) fifty-six miles from Debal or Kar√°chi 200 miles (50 farsakhs) from Anhilw√°ra and 180 miles (60 yoj√°nas) from Broach. He notes that the river Sarsút falls into the sea an arrow-shot from the town. He speaks of Somn√°th as an important place of Hindu worship and as a centre of pilgrimage from all parts of India. He tells of votaries and pilgrims performing the last stage of their journey crawling on their sides or on their ankles, never touching the sacred ground with the soles of their feet, even progressing on their heads.167 Al Bírúni gives168 the legendary origin of the Somn√°th idol: how the moon loved the daughters of Praj√°pati; how his surpassing love for one of them the fair Rohini kindled the jealousy of her slighted sisters; how their angry sire punished the partiality of the moon by pronouncing a curse which caused the pallor of leprosy to overspread his face; how the penitent moon sued for forgiveness to the saint and how the saint unable to recall his curse showed him the way of salvation by the worship of the Liṅgam; how he set up and called the Moon-Lord a stone which169 for ages had lain on the sea shore less than three miles to the west of the mouth of the Sarasvatí, and to the east of the site of the golden castle of B√°rwi (Ver√°val) the residence of B√°súdeo and near the scene of his death and of the destruction of his people the Y√°davas. The waxing and the waning of the moon caused the flood that hid the Liṅgam and the ebb that showed it and proved that the Moon was its servant who bathed it regularly. Al Bírúni notices170 that in his time the castellated walls and other fortifications round the temple were not more than a hundred [522]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Port or Coast Towns.
Somn√°th. years old. Al Bírúni represents the upper part of the Liṅgam as hung with massive and bejewelled gold chains. These chains together with the upper half of the idol were, he observes, carried away by the Emir171 Mahmúd to Ghazna, where a part of the idol was used to form one of the steps of the Assembly Mosque and the other part was left to lie with Chakra Sw√°m, the Th√°nesar idol, in the maid√°n or hippodrome of Mahmúd’s capital. Somn√°th, says Al Bírúni,172 was the greatest of the Liṅgams worshipped in India where in the countries to the south-west of Sindh the worship of these emblems abounds. A jar of Ganges water and a basket of Kashmir flowers were brought daily to Somn√°th. Its worshippers believed the stone to possess the power of curing all diseases, and the mariners and the wanderers over the deep between Sof√°l√° and China addressed their prayers to it as their patron deity.173 Ibni Asír174 (a.d. 1121) gives a detailed account of the temple of Somn√°th and its ancient grandeur. He says Somn√°th was the greatest of all the idols of Hind. Pilgrims by the hundred thousand met at the temple especially at the times of eclipses and believed that the ebb and flow of the tide was the homage paid by the sea to the god. Everything of the most precious was brought to Somn√°th and the temple was endowed with more than 10,000 villages. Jewels of incalculable value were stored in the temple and to wash the idol water from the sacred stream of the Ganga was brought every day over a distance of two hundred farsangs (1200 miles). A thousand Br√°hmans were on duty every day in the temple, three hundred and fifty singers and dancers performed before the image, and three hundred barbers shaved the pilgrims who intended to pay their devotions at the shrine. Every one of these servants had a settled allowance. The temple of Somn√°th was built upon fifty pillars of teakwood covered with lead. The idol, which did not appear to be sculptured,175 stood three cubits out of the ground and had a girth of three cubits. The idol was by itself in a dark chamber lighted by most exquisitely jewelled chandeliers. Near the idol was a chain of gold to which bells were hung weighing 200 mans. The chain was shaken at certain intervals during the night that the bells might rouse fresh parties of worshipping Br√°hmans. The treasury containing many gold and silver idols, with doors hung with curtains set with valuable jewels, was near the chamber of the idol. The worth of what was found in the temple exceeded two millions of dín√°rs (Rs. 1,00,00,000). According to Ibni Asír Mahmúd reached Somn√°th on a Thursday in the middle of Zilka√°da H. 414 (a.d. December 1023). On the approach of Mahmúd Bhím the ruler of Anhilv√°ḍ fled abandoning his capital and took refuge in a fort to prepare for war. From Anhilv√°ḍ Mahmúd started for Somn√°th taking several forts with images which, Ibni Asír says, were the heralds [523]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Port or Coast Towns.
Somn√°th. or chamberlains of Somn√°th. Resuming his march he crossed a desert with little water. Here he was encountered by an army of 20,000 fighting men under chiefs who had determined not to submit to the invader. These forces were defeated and put to flight by a detachment sent against them by Mahmúd. Mahmúd himself marched to Dabalw√°rah a place said by Ibni Asír to be two days journey from Somn√°th. When he reached Somn√°th Mahmúd beheld a strong fortress whose base was washed by the waves of the sea. The assault began on the next day Friday. During nearly two days of hard fighting the invaders seemed doomed to defeat. On the third the Musalm√°ns drove the Hindus from the town to the temple. A terrible carnage took place at the temple-gate. Those of the defenders that survived took themselves to the sea in boats but were overtaken and some slain and the rest drowned.176

Sup√°ra.Sup√°ra (Sub√°r√°, Suf√°ra, or Surb√°r√°h.)—The references to Sub√°r√° are doubtful as some seem to belong to Surab√°ra the T√°pti mouth and others to Sop√°ra six miles north of Bassein. The first Arab reference to Sub√°ra belongs to Sop√°ra. Al Masúdi’s (a.d. 915)177 reference is that in Saimúr (Cheval), Sub√°ra (Sop√°ra), and T√°na (Th√°na) the people speak the L√°riy√°h language, so called from the sea which washes the coast. On this coast Al Istakhri (a.d. 951)178 refers to Sub√°ra that is apparently to Surab√°ra or Surat a city of Hind, four days from Kamb√°yah (Cambay).179

Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–976) mentions180 Surb√°rah apparently the T√°pti mouth or Surat as one of the cities of Hind four farsakhs, correctly days, from Kamb√°yah and two miles (half farsakh) from the sea. From Surb√°ra to Sind√°n, perhaps the Kachh Sanj√°n, he makes ten days. Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) makes Sub√°ra perhaps the Th√°na Sop√°ra six days’ journey from Debal181 (perhaps Diu). Al Idrísi (a.d. 1100) mentions Sub√°ra apparently Sop√°ra as a town in the second climate, a mile and a half from the sea and five days (an excessive allowance) from Sind√°n. It was a populous busy town, one of the entrepôts of India and a pearl fishery. Near Sub√°ra he places B√°ra, a small island with a growth of cactus and cocoanut trees.182

Sur√°b√°ra.Sur√°b√°ra. See Sup√°ra.

Capitals.
Th√°na.Th√°na (T√°na).—That Th√°na was known to the Arabs in pre-Isl√°m times is shown by one of the first Musalm√°n expeditions to the coast of India being directed against it. As early as the reign of the second Khalifah Umar Ibnal Khatt√°b (a.d. 634–643; H. 13–23) mention is made183 of Usm√°n, Umar’s governor of Um√°n (the Persian Gulf) and Bahrein, [524]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Capitals.
Th√°na. sending a successful expedition against Th√°na. Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) refers to Th√°na on the shore of the L√°rwi sea or Indian Ocean, as one of the coast towns in which the L√°rwi language is spoken.184 Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) gives185 the distance from Mahrat Desh (the Mar√°tha country) to the Konkan “with its capital T√°na on the sea-shore” as 100 miles (25 farsakhs) and locates the L√°r Desh (south Gujar√°t) capitals of B√°hrûj and Rahanjur (Broach and R√°nder) to the east of Th√°na. He places Th√°na with Somn√°th Konkan and Kamb√°ya in Gujar√°t and notices that from Th√°na the L√°r country begins. Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) describes186 Th√°na as a pretty town upon a great gulf where vessels anchor and from where they set sail. He gives the distance from Sind√°bur (or Goa) to Th√°na as four days’ sail. From the neighbourhood of Th√°na he says the kana or bamboo and the tab√°shír or bamboo pith are transported to the east and west.187

V√°la or Valabhi.Bar√°da (Porbandar).—Of the Arab attacks on the great sea-port Vala or Valabhi, twenty miles west of Bh√°vnagar, during the eighth and ninth centuries details are given Above pages 94–96. The manner of writing the name of the city attacked leaves it doubtful whether Balaba that is Valabhi or Bar√°da near Porbandar is meant. But the importance of the town destroyed and the agreement in dates with other accounts leaves little doubt that the reference is to Valabhi.188

In the fourth year of his reign about a.d. 758 the Khalífah Jaâfar-al-Mansúr189 (a.d. 754–775) the second ruler of the house of Abb√°s appointed Hish√°m governor of Sindh. Hish√°m despatched a fleet to the coast of Bar√°dah, which may generally be read Balabha, under the command of Amru bin Jam√°l Taghlabi. Tabari (a.d. 838–932) and Ibni Asír (a.d. 1160–1232)190 state that another expedition was sent to this coast in a.h. 160 (a.d. 776) in which though the Arabs succeeded in taking the town, disease thinned the ranks of the party stationed to garrison the port, a thousand of them died, and the remaining troops while returning to their country were shipwrecked on the coast of Persia. This he adds deterred [525]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Capitals.
V√°la or Valabhi. Al Mahdi191 (a.d. 775–785) the succeeding Khalífah from extending the eastern limits of his empire. Besides against Balaba the Sindhi Arabs sent a fleet against Kandh√°r apparently, though somewhat doubtfully,192 the town of that name to the north of Broach where they destroyed a temple or budd and built a mosque. Al Bírúni193 (a.d. 1030) writing of the Valabhi era describes the city of Balabah بلبہ‎ as nearly thirty jauzhans (yojanas) that is ninety miles to the south of Anhilv√°ra. In another passage194 he describes how the B√°nia R√°nka sued for and obtained the aid of an Arab fleet from the Arab lord of Mansúrah (built a.d. 750) for the destruction of Balaba. A land grant by a Valabhi chief remains as late as a.d. 766. For this reason and as the invaders of that expedition fled panic-struck by sickness Valabhi seems to have continued as a place of consequence if the expedition of a.d. 830 against Bala king of the east refers to the final attack on Valabhi an identification which is supported by a Jain authority which places the final overthrow of Valabhi at 888 Samvat that is a.d. 830.195

Kings.Of the rulers of Gujar√°t between a.d. 850 and a.d. 1250 the only dynasty which impressed the Arabs was the Balh√°ras of M√°lkhet or M√°nyakheta (a.d. 630–972) sixty miles south-east of Shol√°púr. From about a.d. 736 to about a.d. 978, at first through a more or less independent local branch and afterwards (a.d. 914) direct the R√°shṭrakúṭas continued overlords of most of Gujar√°t. The Arabs knew the R√°shṭrakúṭas by their title Vallabha or Beloved in the case of Govind III. (a.d. 803–814), Pṛithivívallabha, Beloved by the Earth, and of his successor the long beloved Amoghavarsha Vallabhaskanda, the Beloved of Śiva. Al Masúdi (a.d. 915–944) said: B√°l√°r√°i is a name which he who follows takes. So entirely did the Arabs believe in the overlordship of the R√°shṭrakúṭas in Gujar√°t that Al Idrísi (a.d. 1100, but probably quoting Al Jauhari a.d. 950) describes Nehrwalla as the capital of the Balar√°s. Until Dr. Bhand√°rkar discovered its origin in Vallabha, the ease with which meanings could be tortured out of the word and in Gujar√°t its apparent connection with the Valabhi kings (a.d. 509–770) made the word Balar√°i a cause of matchless confusion.196

The merchant Sulaim√°n (a.d. 851) ranks the Balh√°ra, the lord of M√°nkír, as the fourth of the great rulers of the world. Every prince in India even in his own land paid him homage. He was the owner of many elephants and of great wealth. He refrained from wine and paid his troops and servants regularly. Their favour to Arabs was famous. Abu Zaid (a.d. 913) says that though the Indian kings acknowledge the supremacy of no one, yet the Balh√°ras or R√°shṭrakúṭas by virtue of the title Balh√°ra are kings of kings. Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) describes the Balh√°ras as the greatest of Indian kings being as the name imports the king of kings. Al Masúdi (a.d. 915) described Balh√°ra as a dynastic name which he who followed took. Though he introduces two other potentates the king of Jurz and the Baûra or Parm√°r king of Kanauj fighting with each other and with the Balh√°ra he makes the Balh√°ra, the lord of the M√°nkír or the great centre, the greatest king [526]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Kings. of India197 to whom the kings of India bow in their prayers and whose emissaries they honour. He notices that the Balh√°ra favours and honours Musalm√°ns and allows them to have mosques and assembly mosques. When Al Masúdi was in Cambay the town was ruled by B√°nia, the deputy of the Balh√°ra. Al Istakhri (a.d. 951) describes the land from Kamb√°yah to Saimúr (Cheul) as the land of the Balh√°ra of M√°nkír. In the Konkan were many Musalm√°ns over whom the Balh√°ra appointed no one but a Musalm√°n to rule. Ibni Haukal (a.d. 970) describes the Balh√°ra as holding sway over a land in which are several Indian kings.198 Al Idrísi (a.d. 1100 but quoting Al Jauhari a.d. 950) agrees with Ibni Khurd√°dbah that Balh√°ra is a title meaning King of Kings. He says the title is hereditary in this country, where when a king ascends the throne he takes the name of his predecessor and transmits it to his heirs.199

Condition.That the Arabs found the R√°shṭrakúṭas kind and liberal rulers there is ample evidence. In their territories property was secure,200 theft or robbery was unknown, commerce was encouraged, foreigners were treated with consideration and respect. The Arabs especially were honoured not only with a marked and delicate regard, but magistrates from among themselves were appointed to adjudicate their disputes according to the Musalm√°n law.

The Gurjjaras.The ruler next in importance to the Balh√°ra was the Jurz that is the Gurjjara king. It is remarkable, though natural, that the Arabs should preserve the true name of the rulers of Anhilv√°ḍa which the three tribe or dynastic names Ch√°pa or Chaura (a.d. 720–956), Solaṅki or C√°ulukya (a.d. 961–1242), and V√°ghela (a.d. 1240–1290) should so long have concealed. Sulaim√°n (a.d. 851) notices that the Jurz king hated Musalm√°ns while the Balh√°ra king loved Musalm√°ns. He may not have known what excellent reasons the Gurjjaras had for hating the Arab raiders from sea and from Sindh. Nor would it strike him that the main reason why the Balh√°ra fostered the Moslem was the hope of Arab help in his struggles with the Gurjjaras.

Jurz.According to the merchant Sulaim√°n201 (a.d. 851) the kingdom next after the Balh√°ra’s was that of Jurz the Gurjjara king whose territories “consisted of a tongue of land.” The king of Jurz maintained a large force: his cavalry was the best in India. He was unfriendly to the Arabs. His territories were very rich and abounded in horses and camels. In his realms exchanges were carried on in silver and gold dust of which metals mines were said to be worked.

The king of Jurz was at war with the Balh√°ras as well as with the neighbouring kingdom of T√°fak or the Panj√°b. The details given under Bhínm√°l page 468 show that Sulaim√°n’s tongue of land, by which he apparently meant either K√°thi√°v√°ḍ or Gujar√°t was an imperfect idea of the extent of Gurjjara rule. At the beginning of the tenth century a.d. 916 Sulaim√°n’s editor Abu Zaid describes Kanauj as a large country [527]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Kings.
Jurz. forming the empire of Jurz,202 a description which the Gurjjara Vatsar√°ja’s success in Bengal about a century before shows not to be impossible. Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) ranks the king of Juzr as fourth in importance among Indian kings. According to him “the T√°tariya dirhams were in use in the Juzr kingdom.” Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) speaks of the Konkan country of the Balh√°ra as on one side exposed to the attacks of the king of Juzr a monarch rich in men horses and camels. He speaks of the Juzr kingdom bordering on T√°f√°n apparently the Panj√°b and T√°f√°n as bounded by Rahma203 apparently Burma and Sum√°tra. Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–976) notices that several kingdoms existed, including the domain of the Śil√°h√°ras of the north Konkan within the land of the Balh√°ra between Kamb√°yah and Saimúr.204 Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) uses not Juzr, but Gujar√°t.205 Beyond that is to the south of Gujar√°t he places Konkan and T√°na. In Al Bírúni’s time N√°r√°yan near Jaipúr, the former capital of Gujar√°t, had been taken and the inhabitants removed to a town on the frontier.206 Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century really from tenth century materials) ranks the king of Juzr as the fourth and the king of S√°f√°n or T√°f√°n as the second in greatness to the Balh√°ra.207 In another passage in a list of titular sovereigns Al Idrísi enters the names of S√°fir (T√°f√°n) Hazr (Jazr-Juzr) and Dumi (Rahmi).208 By the side of Juzr was T√°fak (doubtfully the Panj√°b) a small state producing the whitest and most beautiful women in India; the king having few soldiers; living at peace with his neighbours and like the Balh√°ras highly esteeming the Arabs.209 Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) calls T√°ban the king next in eminence to the Balh√°ra.210 Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) calls T√°fak the ruler of a mountainous country like Kashmír211 with small forces living on friendly terms with neighbouring sovereigns and well disposed to the Moslims.212 Al Idrísi (end of eleventh century but materials of the tenth century) notices S√°f√°n (T√°f√°n) as the principality that ranks next to the Konkan that is to the R√°shṭrakúṭas.

Rahma or Ruhmi.Rahma or Ruhmi, according to the merchant Sulaim√°n (a.d. 851) borders the land of the Balh√°ras, the Juzr, and T√°f√°n. The king who was not much respected was at war with both the Juzr and the Balh√°ra. He had the most numerous army in India and a following of 50,000 elephants when he took the field. Sulaim√°n notices a cotton fabric made in Rahma, so delicate that a dress of it could pass through a signet-ring. The medium of exchange was cowries Cypræa moneta shell money. The country produced gold silver and aloes and the whisk of the s√°mara or y√°k Bos poëphagus the bushy-tailed ox. Ibni Khurd√°dbah213 (a.d. 912) places Rahmi as the sixth kingdom. He apparently identified it with Al Rahmi or north Sum√°tra as he notes that between it and the other kingdoms communication is kept up by ships. He notices that the ruler had five thousand elephants and that cotton cloth and aloes probably the well-known Kum√°ri [528]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Kings.
Rahma or Ruhmi. or Cambodian aloes, were the staple produce. Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) after stating that former accounts of Rahma’s214 elephants, troops and horses were probably exaggerated, adds that the kingdom of Rahma extends both along the sea and the continent and that it is bounded by an inland state called K√°man (probably K√°marup that is Assam). He describes the inhabitants as fair and handsome and notices that both men and women had their ears pierced. This description of the people still more the extension of the country both along the sea and along the continent suggests that Masúdi’s Al Rahmi is a combination of Burma which by dropping the B he has mixed with Al Rahma. Lane identifies Rahmi215 with Sum√°tra on the authority of an Account of India and China by two Muhammadan Travellers of the Ninth Century. This identification is supported by Al Masúdi’s216 mention of R√°mi as one of the islands of the Java group, the kingdom of the Indian Mihr√°j. The absence of reference to Bengal in these accounts agrees with the view that during the ninth century Bengal was under Tibet.

Products.In the middle of the ninth century mines of gold and silver are said to be worked in Gujar√°t.217 Abu Zaid (a.d. 916) represents pearls as in great demand. The T√°rt√°riyah, or according to Al Masúdi the T√°hiriyah dín√°rs of Sindh, fluctuating218 in price from one and a half to three and a fraction of the Baghd√°d dín√°rs, were the current coin in the Gujar√°t ports. Emeralds also were imported from Egypt mounted as seals.219

Ibni Khurd√°dbah220 (a.d. 912) mentions teakwood and the bamboo as products of Sind√°n that is the Konkan Sanjan.221 Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) notes that at the great fair of Mult√°n the people of Sindh and Hind offered Kumar that is Cambodian aloe-wood of the purest quality worth twenty dín√°rs a man.222 Among other articles of trade he mentions an inferior emerald exported from Cambay and Saimúr to Makkah,223 the lance shafts of Broach,224 the shoes of Cambay,225 and the white and handsome maidens of T√°f√°n226 who were in great demand in Arab countries. Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–976) states that the country comprising F√°mhal, Sind√°n, Saimúr, and Kamb√°yah produced mangoes cocoanuts lemons and rice in abundance. That honey could be had in great quantities, but no date palms were to be found.227

Al Bírúni (a.d. 1031) notices that its import of horses from Mekran and the islands of the Persian Gulf was a leading portion of Cambay trade.228 According to Al Idrísi (a.d. 1100) the people of M√°mhal229 (Anhilw√°ra) had many horses and camels.230 One of the peculiarities of [529]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Products. the Nahrw√°la country was that all journeys were made and all merchandise was carried in bullock waggons. Kamb√°yah was rich in wheat and rice and its mountains yielded the Indian kan√° or bamboo. At Sub√°ra231 (Sop√°ra) they fished for pearls and B√°ra a small island close to Sub√°ra produced the cocoanut and the costus. Sind√°n according to Al Idrísi produced the cocoa palm, the ratan, and the bamboo. Saimúr had many cocoa palms, much henna (Lawsonia inermis), and a number of aromatic plants.232 The hills of Th√°na yielded the bamboo and tab√°shír233 or bamboo pith. From Saimúr according to Al Kazwíni (a.d. 1236, but from tenth century materials) came aloes. Rashíd-ud-dín (a.d. 1310) states that in Kamb√°yah, Somn√°th, Kankan, and T√°na the vines yield twice a year and such is the strength of the soil that cotton-plants grow like willow or plane trees and yield produce for ten years. He refers to the betel leaf, to which he and other Arab writers and physicians ascribe strange virtues as the produce of the whole country of Malab√°r. The exports from the Gujar√°t coasts are said to be sugar (the staple product of M√°lwa), b√°drúd that is bezoar, and haldi that is turmeric.234

According to Ibni Haukal (a.d. 170) from Kamb√°ya to Saimúr the villages lay close to one another and much land was under cultivation.235 At the end236 of the eleventh century trade was brisk merchandise from every country finding its way to the ports of Gujar√°t whose local products were in turn exported all over the east.237 The R√°shṭrakúṭa dominion was vast, well-peopled, commercial, and fertile.238 The people lived mostly on a vegetable diet, rice peas beans haricots and lentils being their daily food.239 Al Idrísi speaks of certain Hindus eating animals whose deaths had been caused by falls or by being gored,240 but Al Masúdi states that the higher classes who wore the “baldric like yellow thread” (the Janoi) abstained from flesh. According to Ibni Haukal (a.d. 968–970) the ordinary dress of the kings of Hind was trousers and a tunic.241 He also notices that between Kamb√°yah and Saimúr the Muslims and infidels wear the same cool fine muslin dress and let their beards grow in the same fashion.242 During the tenth century on high days the Balh√°ra wore a crown of gold and a dress of rich stuff. The attendant women were richly clad, wearing rings of gold and silver upon their feet and hands and having their hair in curls.243 At the close of the Hindu period (a.d. 1300) Rashíd-ud-dín describes Gujar√°t as a flourishing country with no less than 80,000 villages and hamlets the people happy the soil rich growing in the four seasons seventy varieties of flowers. Two harvests repaid the husbandman, the earlier crop refreshed by the dew of the cold season the late crop enriched by a certain rainfall.244

Review.In their intercourse with Western India nothing struck the Arabs more than the toleration shown to their religion both by chief and peoples. [530]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Review. This was specially marked in the R√°shṭrakúṭa towns where besides free use of mosques and J√°m√° mosques Musalm√°n magistrates or k√°zis were appointed to settle disputes among Musalm√°ns according to their own laws.245 Toleration was not peculiar to the Balh√°ras. Al Bírúni records246 that in the ninth century (a.d. 581), when the Hindus recovered Sind√°n (Sanj√°n in Kachh) they spared the assembly mosque where long after the Faithful congregated on Fridays praying for their Khalífah without hindrance. In the Balh√°ra country so strongly did the people believe in the power of Isl√°m or which is perhaps more likely so courteous were they that they said that our king enjoys a long life and long reign is solely due to the favour shown by him to the Musalm√°ns. So far as the merchant Sulaim√°n saw in the ninth century the chief religion in Gujar√°t was Buddhism. He notices that the principles of the religion of China were brought from India and that the Chinese ascribe to the Indians the introduction of Buddhas into their country. Of religious beliefs metempsychoses or re-birth and of religious practices widow-burning or satti and self-torture seem to have struck him most.247 As a rule the dead were burned.248 Sulaim√°n represents the people of Gujar√°t as steady abstemious and sober abstaining from wine as well as from vinegar, ‘not’ he adds ‘from religious motives but from their disdain of it.’ Among their sovereigns the desire of conquest was seldom the cause of war.249 Abu Zaid (a.d. 916) describes the Br√°hmans as Hindus devoted to religion and science. Among Br√°hmans were poets who lived at kings’ courts, astronomers, philosophers, diviners, and drawers of omens from the flight of crows.250 He adds: So sure are the people that after death they shall return to life upon the earth, that when a person grows old “he begs some one of his family to throw him into the fire or to drown him.”251 In Abu Zaid’s time (a.d. 916) the Hindus did not seclude their women. Even the wives of the kings used to mix freely with men and attend courts and places of public resort unveiled.252 According to Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) India has forty-two religious sects “part of whom believe in God and his Prophet (on whom be peace) and part who deny his mission.”253 Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) describes the Hindus as divided into seven classes. Of these the first are Th√°karias254 or Th√°kurs men of high caste from whom kings are chosen and to whom men of the other classes render homage, the second are the Bar√°hmas255 who abstain from wine and fermented liquors; the third are the Katariya or Kshatrias who drink not more than three cups of wine; the fourth are the Sudaria or Shudras husbandmen by profession; the fifth are the Baisura or Vaish artificers and domestics; the sixth Sandalias or Chandala menials; and the seventh the ‘Lahúd,’ whose women adorn themselves and whose men are fond of amusements and games of skill. Both among the people and the kings of Gujar√°t256 wine [531]
Appendix V.
Arab References, a.d. 851–1350.
Review. was “unlawful and lawful” that is it was not used though no religious rule forbade its use. According to Al Masúdi (a.d. 943) a general opinion prevailed that India was the earliest home of order and wisdom. The Indians chose as their king the great Br√°hma who ruled them for 366 years. His descendants retain the name of Br√°hman and are honoured as the most illustrious caste. They abstain from the flesh of animals.257 Hindu kings cannot succeed before the age of forty nor do they appear in public except on certain occasions for the conduct of state affairs. Royalty and all the high offices of state258 are limited to the descendants of one family. The Hindus strongly disapprove of the use of wine both in themselves and in others not from any religious objection but on account of its intoxicating and reason-clouding qualities.259 Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1031) quoted by Rashíd-ud-dín (a.d. 1310) states that the people of Gujar√°t are idolators and notices the great penance-pilgrimages to Somn√°th details of which have already been given.260 Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) closely follows Ibni Khurd√°dbah’s (a.d. 912) division of the people of India. The chief exception is that he represents261 the second class, the Br√°hmans, as wearing the skins of tigers and going about staff in hand collecting crowds and from morn till eve proclaiming to their hearers the glory and power of God. He makes out that the Kastari√°s or Kshatriyas are able to drink three ratl (a ratl being one pound troy) of wine and are allowed to marry Br√°hman women. The Sabdaliya or Chandal women, he says, are noted for beauty. Of the forty-two sects he enumerates worshippers of trees and adorers of serpents, which they keep in stables and feed as well as they can, deeming it to be a meritorious work. He says that the inhabitants of Kamb√°ya are Buddhists (idolators)262 and that the Balh√°ra also worships the idol Buddha.263 The Indians, says Al Idrísi264 (end of the eleventh century) are naturally inclined to justice and in their actions never depart from it. Their reputation for good faith, honesty, and fidelity to their engagements brings strangers flocking to their country and aids its prosperity. In illustration of the peaceable disposition of the Hindus, he quotes the ancient practice of duh√°i or conjuring in the name of the king, a rite which is still in vogue in some native states. When a man has a rightful claim he draws a circle on the ground and asks his debtor to step into the circle in the name of the king. The debtor never fails to step in nor does he ever leave the circle without paying his debts. Al Idrísi describes the people of Nahrw√°ra as having so high a respect for oxen that when an ox dies they bury it. “When enfeebled by age or if unable to work they provide their oxen with food without exacting any return.”265 [532]

1 Contributed by Kh√°n S√°heb Fazlull√°h Lutfull√°h Farídi of Surat. ↑

2 This account which is in two parts is named Silsil√°t-ut-Taw√°ríkh, that is the Chain of History. The first part was written in a.d. 851–52 by Sulaim√°n and has the advantage of being the work of a traveller who himself knew the countries he describes. The second part was written by Abu Zeid-al-Hasan of Sir√°f on the Persian Gulf about sixty years after Sulaim√°n’s account. Though Abu Zeid never visited India, he made it his business to read and question travellers who had been in India. Abul Hasan-el-Masúdi (a.d. 915–943) who met him at Basrah is said to have imparted to and derived much information from Abu Zeid. Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 2. ↑

3 Ahmed bin Yahyâ, surnamed Abu Jaâfar and called Bil√°duri or Bil√°zuri from his addiction to the electuary of the Malacca bean (bil√°zur بلازر‎) or anacardium, lived about the middle of the ninth century of the Christian era at the court of Al-Mutawakkil the Abb√°si, as an instructor to one of the royal princes. He died a.h. 279 (a.d. 892–93). His work is styled the Futúh-ul-Buld√°n The Conquest of Countries. He did not visit Sindh, but was in personal communication with men who had travelled far and wide. ↑

4 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 115–116. ↑

5 The reason of Umar’s dislike for India is described by Al Masúdi (Murúj Arabic Text, Cairo Edition, III. 166–171), to have originated from the description of the country by a philosopher to whom Umar had referred on the first spread of Isl√°m in his reign. The philosopher said: India is a distant and remote land peopled by rebellious infidels. Immediately after the battle of Kadesiah (a.d. 636) when sending out Utbah, his first governor to the newly-founded camp-town of Basrah Umar is reported to have said: I am sending thee to the land of Al-Hind (India) as governor. Remember it is a field of the fields of the enemy. The third Khalífah Usm√°n (a.d. 643–655) ordered his governor of Ir√°k to depute a special officer to visit India and wait upon the Khalífah to report his opinion of that country. His report of India was not encouraging. He said: Its water is scarce, its fruits are poor, and its robbers bold. If the troops sent there are few they will be slain; if many they will starve. (Al-Bil√°duri in Elliot, I. 116.) ↑

6 Sir H. Elliot’s History of India, I. 116. ↑

7 Sir H. Elliot (Hist. of India) transliterates this as B√°sia. But neither B√°sea nor his other supposition (Note 4 Ditto) Budha seem to have any sense. The original is probably B√°tiah, a form in which other Arab historians and geographers also allude to Baet, the residence of the notorious Baw√°rij who are referred to a little farther on as seafarers and pirates. Ditto, I. 123. ↑

8 This important expedition extended to Ujjain. Details Above page 109 and also under Bhínm√°l. Raids by sea from Sindh were repeated in a.d. 758, 760, 755, and perhaps a.d. 830. Reinaud’s Fragments, 212. See Above Bhagv√°nl√°l’s Early History page 96 note 3. ↑

9 Details Above pages 94–96. ↑

10 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 129. ↑

11 Sir Henry Elliot (History of India, I. 129) calls it K√°llari though (Ditto note 3) he says the text has M√°li. ↑

12 Sir H. Elliot’s History of India, I. 129. ↑

13 Ibni Khurd√°dbah a Musalm√°n of Magian descent as his name signifies, died H. 300 (a.d. 912). He held high office under the Abb√°si Khalífahs at Baghd√°d (Elliot’s History of India, I. 13). ↑

14 Abul Hasan Al Masudi, a native of Baghd√°d, who visited India about a.d. 915 and wrote his “Meadows of Gold” (Murúj-uz-zahab) about a.d. 950–51 and died a.d. 956 in Egypt. (Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 23–25.) ↑

15 Abu Is-h√°k Al Istakhri, a native (as his cognomen signifies) of Persepolis who flourished about the middle of the tenth century and wrote his Book of Climes (Kit√°bul Ak√°lím) about a.h. 340 (a.d. 951). Elliot’s History of India, I. 26. ↑

16 See Appendix A. Volume I. Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India. ↑

17 Elliot’s History of India, 394, where Sir Henry Elliot calculates a parsang or farsang (Arabic farsakh) to be 3½ miles. Al Bírúni, however, counts four kroh or miles to a farsakh. Sachau’s Al Bírúni Arabic Text, chapter 18 page 97. ↑

18 Sir Henry Elliot (History of India, I. 403) locates Surab√°ya somewhere near Surat. The mouth of the T√°pti is still known in Surat as the B√°ra. ↑

19 Ibni Haukal (Muhammad Abul K√°sim) a native of Baghd√°d, left that city in H. 331 (a.d. 943), returned to it H. 358 (a.d. 968), and finished his work about H. 366 (a.d. 976). Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 31. ↑

20 Elliot, I. 34. ↑

21 Sir Henry Elliot (History of India, I. 363) correctly takes F√°mhal to be a misreading for Anhal that is Anhilw√°ra. Al Bírúni (a.d. 970–1039) uses the name Anhilw√°ra without any Arab peculiarity of transliteration or pronunciation. Sachau’s Arabic Text, 100. Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century) styles Anhilw√°ra “Nahrw√°ra” (Elliot, I. 84) an equally well known name. ↑

22 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 34. ↑

23 M. Gildemeister’s Latin translation of Ibni Haukal’s Ashk√°l-ul-Bil√°d (Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 39). ↑

24 Abu Rih√°n Al Bírúni was a native of Balkh in Central Asia. He accompanied Mahmúd of Ghazni to India in his expeditions and acquired an accurate knowledge of Sanskrit. His acquaintance with this language and Greek and his love of enquiry and research together with his fairness and impartiality, make his Indica a most valuable contribution to our information on India in the end of the tenth and beginning of the eleventh centuries. He finished his work after the death of his patron in a.d. 1030–31. See Sachau’s Preface to the Arabic Text of the Indica, ix. ↑

25 Al Bírúni makes his farsakh of four miles. Sachau’s Arabic Text, 97. ↑

26 Sir Henry Elliot’s translation and transliteration of Rahanjúr (History of India, I. 61) are, be it said with all respect to the memory of that great scholar, inaccurate. He cannot make anything of the word (note 3) while in the Arabic Text of Sachau (page 100) the first letter is a plain ر‎ = r and not د‎ = d. From the context also the ancient town of R√°ndir seems to be meant. It is plainly written (رهنجور‎) Rahanjúr and is very likely the copyist’s mistake for the very similar form رهندور‎ or R√°handúr. ↑

27 Sachau’s Arabic Text of Al Bírúni, 98 and Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 61. ↑

28 Elphinstone’s History of India, Book V. Chapter I. 263 Note 25 (John Murray’s 1849 Edition) on the authority of Captain MacMurdo and Captain Alexander Burnes inclines to the opinion that Debal was somewhere near the site of the modern Kar√°chi. ↑

29 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 65. Sachau’s Text of Al Bírúni, chapter 18 page 102. ↑

30 Al Bil√°duri uses the word Barija for a strong built war vessel. Sir Henry Elliot derives the word from the Arabic and gives an interesting note on the subject in his Appendix I. 539. The word is still used in Hindust√°ni as beda (بيڈا‎) to signify a boat or bark. ↑

31 Sachau’s Arabic Text, 102. ↑

32 According to Richardson (Arabic Dictionary voce مقل‎ myrrh) though rendered gum by all translators. According to the Makhzan the word mukl (Urdu gughal) is Balsamodendron and B√°drud the corruption of B√°ruz (Urdu biroza) is balsam or bezoar. ↑

33 Sachau’s Arabic Text page 99 chapter 18. ↑

34 After giving the distances in days or journeys the Text (page 102 Sachau’s Text of Al Bírúni) does not particularise the distances of the places that follow in journeys or farsakhs. ↑

35 Elliot’s History of India, I. 67. ↑

36 Abu Abdallah Muhammad Al Idrísi, a native of Ceuta in Morocco and descended from the royal family of the Idrísis of that country, settled at the court of Roger II. of Sicily, where and at whose desire he wrote his book The Nuzhat-ul-Musht√°k or The Seeker’s Delight. Elliot’s History of India, I: 74. Almost all Al Idrísi’s special information regarding Sindh and Western India is from Al-Jauhari governor of Khur√°s√°n (a.d. 892–999), whose knowledge of Sindh and the Indus valley is unusually complete and accurate. Compare Reinaud’s Abulfeda, lxiii. ↑

37 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 77. ↑

38 Bombay Gazetteer, II. 69. ↑

39 Elliot’s History of India, I. 76. ↑

40 Elliot’s History of India, I. 79. ↑

41 Elliot’s History of India, I. 79. ↑

42 Elliot’s History of India, I. 84. ↑

43 The details of Kul√°mmali given by Al Kazwíni (a.d. 1263–1275) seem to show it is Quilon on the Malab√°r Coast. When a ruler died his successor was always chosen from China. ↑

44 Elliot (I. 363–364) on the authority of Al Istakhri thinks that all the names Ámhal, F√°mhal, K√°mhal, and M√°mhal are faulty readings of Anhal (Anhil)w√°ra owing to irregularity in the position or absence of diacritical points. ↑

45 This is probably R√°nder, a very natural Arab corruption. Instance Al Bírúni’s Ranjhur. See page 507 note 11 and page 520. ↑

46 Rum√°la is mentioned at pages 14, 87, 92 and 93 volume I. of Elliot. It is first mentioned (page 14) by Ibni Khurd√°dbah (a.d. 912) as one of the countries of Sindh. It is next mentioned by Al Idrísi (end of the eleventh century according to Elliot, I. 74) as one of the places of the eighth section describing the coast of India, but is mentioned along with Nahrw√°ra, Kandh√°r, and Kalbata (?). At page 92 (Ditto) the same writer (Idrísi) says that Kalbata and Rum√°la are on the borders of the desert which separates Mult√°n from Sijist√°n. Again at page 93 (Ditto) Idrísi gives the distance between Kalbata and Rum√°la as a distance of three days. ↑

47 Elliot’s History of India, I. 84. ↑

48 Sir H. Elliot’s History of India, I. 85. ↑

49 Elliot, I. 90–93. ↑

50 Elliot’s History of India, I. 89. ↑

51 Zakariah Ibni Muhammad Al Kazwíni, a native of Kazwín (Kasbin) in Persia, wrote his Ás√°r-ul-Bil√°d or “Signs or Monuments of Countries” about a.h. 661 (a.d. 1263) compiling it chiefly from the writings of Al Istakhri (a.d. 951) and Ibni Haukal (a.d. 976). He also frequently quotes Misâr bin Muhalhil, a traveller who (a.d. 942) visited India and China. Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 94. ↑

52 Barbier De Meynard’s Text of Al Masúdi’s Les Prairies D’Or, I. 382. ↑

53 Sir Henry Elliot misreads Tamraz for Al Bírúni’s Arabic form of Narmaza. He says: It comes from the city of Tamraz and the eastern hills; it has a south-easterly course till it falls into the sea near B√°hruch about 60 yojanas to the east of Somn√°th. The literal translation of the text of Al Bírúni (see Sachau’s Al Bírúni’s India, 130) is that given above: It is hard to believe that the accurate Al Bírúni while in one place (see Sachau’s Text, 99) giving the name of the Narbada faultlessly, should in another place fall into the error of tracing it from Tirmiz a city of Central Asia. A comparison of Elliot’s version with the text sets the difficulty at rest. Compare Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 49 and note 3 ditto and Sachau’s Arabic Text of Al Bírúni, 180 chapter 25. ↑

54 Compare Sachau’s Al Bírúni with Sir Henry Elliot, I. 49, who is silent as to the distance. ↑

101 Tazjiyat-ul-Amsar in Elliot, III. 32. ↑

102 Saâdi’s patron mentioned by him in his Garden of Roses. ↑

103 The word dín√°r is from the Latin denarius (a silver coin worth 10 oz. of brass) through the Greek δηναριον. It is a Kur√°anic word, the ancient Arabic equivalent being متقال‎ mithk√°l. The dín√°r sequin or ducat varied in value in different times. In Abu Haúfah’s (the greatest of the four Sunni Jurisconsults’) time (a.d. 749) its value ranged from 10 to 12 dirhams. Then from 20 to 25 dirhams or drachmas. As a weight it represented a drachma and a half. Though generally fluctuating, its value may be assessed at 9s. or 10 francs to half a sovereign. For an elaborate article on the Dín√°r see Yule’s Cathay, II. 439; Burton’s Alf Leilah, I. 32. The word Dirham is used in Arabic in the sense of “silver” (vulg. siller) the Greek δραχμη and the drachuma of Plautus. This silver piece was 9¾d. and as a weight 66½ grains. Sir Henry Elliot does not speak more at length of the dín√°r and the dirham than to say (History of India, I. 461) that they were introduced in Sindh in the reign of Abdul Malik (a.d. 685) and Elliot, VII. 31) that the dín√°r was a Rúm and the dirham a Persian coin. The value of the dín√°r in modern Indian currency may be said to be Rs. 5 and that of the dirham nearly annas 4. ↑

104 Wass√°f gives the date of this event as a.d. 1298, but the T√°rikh-i-Al√°i of Amír Khusrao places it at a.d. 1300. See Elliot’s History of India, III. 43 and 74. ↑

109 Al Masúdi’s Murúj Arabic Text Cairo Edition, II. 56–57. ↑

110 One born in India of an Arab father and an Indian mother probably from the Gujar√°ti word Ádh-besra meaning mixed blood. This seems the origin of the Bais R√°jput. The performer in the case in the text was a Hindu. Al Masúdi (Murúj Arabic Text II. 57 Cairo Edition) says that the singular of Bay√°sirah is Besar. ↑

135 In his Arabic Text of the Murúj (Prairies D’Or, Cairo Edition) Al Masúdi writes the name of the Kanauj king as Farwarah. (If the F stands for P and the w for m, as is quite possible in Arab writing, then this can be Parm√°rah the Arab plural for Parm√°r.) At volume I. page 240 the word Farwarah is twice used. Once: “And the king of Kanauj, of the kings of Sindh (India) is Farwarah.” Again at the same page (240): “And Farwarah he who is king of Kanauj is opposed to Balhara.” Then at page 241: Farwarah is again used in the beginning of the account quoted by Elliot in I. 23. ↑

136 Elliot’s History of India, I. 23. In the Cairo Edition of the Arabic Text of Al Masúdi’s Murúj (Prairies D’Or) vol. I. page 241 is the original of this account. ↑

143 T√°j-ul-Mâ√°sir in Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, II. 222. ‘After staying some time at Dehli he (Kutb-ud-dín) marched in a.d. 1194 (H. 590) towards Kol and Banâras passing the Jumna which from its exceeding purity resembled a mirror.’ It would seem to place Kol near Banâras. ↑

144 Al Masúdi’s Prairies D’Or (Arabic Text), I. 168. ↑

145 Al Masúdi in Elliot (History of India), I. 19, 20, 21 and Prairies D’Or, I. 178. ↑

146 Al Masúdi Arabic Text Prairies D’Or, (I. 381); Al Masúdi in Elliot (History of India), I. 24. ↑

147 That is an Arab dirhem and a half. Al Istakhri in Elliot (History of India), I. 27. These T√°rtariyya dirhems are mentioned by almost all Arab writers. Al Idrísi says they were current in Mansúrah in Sindh and in the Malay archipelago. See Elliot, I. 3 note 4. According to Sulaim√°n (a.d. 851) the T√°rtariya dirham weighed “a dirham and a half of the coinage of the king.” Elliot, I. 3. Al Masúdi (Prairies D’Or, I. 382) calls these “T√°tiriyyah” dirhams, giving them the same weight as that given by Sulaim√°n to the T√°rtariyah dirhams. Ibni Haukal calls it the Titari dirhem and makes its weight equal to “a dirham and a third” (Elliot, I. 85). ↑

148 Kumlah is rauma salt land. There is a Rúm near K√°rur about sixty miles south-east of Mult√°n. Al Idrísi (a.d. 1135) has a Rum√°lah three days from Kalbata the salt range. Elliot, I. 92. ↑

149 Probably Okh√°mandal. See Appendix vol. I. page 390 Elliot’s History of India. ↑

167 Elliot’s History of India, I. 67. ↑

168 Sachau’s Text of Al Bírúni, 252. ↑

169 Sachau’s Arabic Text, 253. ↑

170 Sachau’s Arabic Text, 253 chapter 58. ↑

171 It appears that at the time of his expedition to Somn√°th Mahmúd had not adopted the title of Sult√°n. ↑

172 Sachau’s Arabic Text, 253 chapter 58. ↑

173 Sachau’s Text, 253 chapter 58. ↑

174 The T√°ríkh-i-K√°mil. Ibni Asír (a.d. 1160–1232) is a voluminous and reliable historian. Ibni Khallik√°n, the author of the famous biographical dictionary, knew and respected Asír always alluding to him as “our Sheikh.” See Elliot, II. 245. ↑

175 From the term ‘sculptured’ it would seem the idol was of stone. It is curious how Ibni Asír states a little further that a part of the idol was “burned by Mehmúd.” See Elliot, II. 471. The T√°rikh-i-Alfi says (Elliot, II. 471) that the idol was cut of solid stone. It however represents it as hollow and containing jewels, in repeating the somewhat hackneyed words of Mahmúd when breaking the idol regardless of the handsome offer of the Br√°hmans, and finding it full of jewels. ↑

176 The Rauzat-us-Safa (Lithgd. Edition, IV. 48) speaks of Mahmúd’s project of making Somn√°th his capital and not Anhilw√°ra as stated by Farishtah (I. 57, Original Persian Text). The Rauz√°t-us-Safa says that when Mahmúd had conquered Somn√°th he wished to fix his residence there for some years as the country was very large and had a great many advantages including mines of pure gold and rubies brought from Sarandíb or Ceylon which he represents as a dependency of Gujar√°t. At last he yielded to his minister’s advice and agreed to return to Khur√°s√°n. ↑

177 Prairies D’Or (DeMeynard’s Arabic Text, I. 381); also Al Masúdi in Elliot (History of India. I. 24). ↑

178 Al Istakhri in Elliot (History of India), I. 27. ↑

179 Al Istakhri in Elliot (History of India), I. 30. ↑

180 Ibni Haukal in Elliot (History of India), I. 34, 39. ↑

181 Thus in Sachau’s Arabic Text page 102, but Elliot (I. 66) spells the word Suf√°ra in his translation. It might have assumed that form in coming from the Arabic through Rashíd-ud-dín’s Persian version from which Sir Henry Elliot derives his account. ↑

182 Al Idrísi in Elliot (History of India), I. 77 and 85. ↑

183 Al Bil√°zuri in Elliot, I. 116. ↑

184 Barbier DeMeynard’s Text of Masúdi’s Prairies D’Or, I. 330 and 381. ↑

185 Sachau’s Arabic Text of Al Bírúni, chapters 18, 99, 102 and Elliot’s History of India, I. 60–61, 66–67. ↑

186 Al Idrísi in Elliot, 1–89. ↑

187 Al Idrísi says the real tab√°shír is extracted from the root of the reed called sharki. Sarki is Gujar√°ti for reed. It is generally applied to the reeds growing on river banks used by the poor for thatching their cottages. Tab√°shír is a drug obtained from the pith of the bamboo and prescribed by Indian physicians as a cooling drink good for fever. ↑

188 The name Bar√°dah برادة‎ in Arabic orthography bears a close resemblance to برابہ‎ Barâbah, بارلبہ‎ B√°rlabah, برلبہ‎ Barlabah, all three being the forms or nearly the forms in which the word ولبہ‎ Walabah or وَلَبي‎ Walabi would be written by an Arab, supposing the diacritical points to be, as they often are, omitted. Besides as Bar√°dah the word has been read and miswritten نارند‎ N√°rand or B√°rand and بارد‎ B√°rad or Barid. In the shikastah or broken hand N√°rand or B√°rand بارند‎ would closely resemble بارلبہ‎ B√°rlabah or B√°radah باردة‎. Al Bil√°zuri in Elliot’s History of India I. 127, writes the word N√°rand or B√°rand. Sir Henry Elliot (History, I. 444) reads the word Barada and would identify the place with the Barda hills inland from Porbandar in south-west K√°thi√°v√°ḍ. The objection to this is that the word used by the Arab writers was the name of a town as well as of a coast tract, while the name of Barda is applied solely to a range of hills. On the other hand Balaba the coast and town meets all requirements. ↑

189 Reigned a.d. 754–775. ↑

190 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, II. 246 and Frag. Arabes 3, 120, 212; Weil’s Geschichte der Chalifen, II. 115. ↑

191 Sir Henry Elliot’s History of India, I. 444. ↑

192 Sir Henry Elliot (History of India, I. 445) identifies Kandh√°r with Kandad√°r in north-west K√°thi√°v√°ḍ. ↑
